HEADLINE: New York Poll Sees Grim View Of Life in City

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
A majority of New Yorkers say the quality of life in the city has declined over the last four years, and they generally have a bleak view of the state of the local economy, race relations, crime and the public schools, according to the latest New York Times/ WCBS-TV News Poll.
But in the midst of an election campaign in which Rudolph W. Giuliani has made the quality of life a major issue, the poll also found that most New Yorkers do not think either he or Mayor David N. Dinkins is likely to change things significantly. 
 In the survey of 1,223 adults, conducted between Sept. 29 and Oct. 3, 62 percent said life in the city had got worse over the last four years, while only 9 percent of those surveyed said it had improved. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Sixty-five percent of the respondents said they viewed the state of the local economy as bad or very bad; 59 percent said they found the city less safe than they did four years ago; 67 percent described race relations as poor, and 70 percent said they were not satisfied with the quality of the public schools. Black New Yorkers were somewhat more optimistic than white or Hispanic respondents on virtually every measure, the poll found.
Those findings would seem to work against Mr. Dinkins, the Democratic incumbent, and in favor of Mr. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate, who has tried to present himself as an agent for change, framing the contest as between himself as a bold innovator and the Mayor as a fatigued defender of the status quo. But the poll indicates strongly that whatever dissatisfactions that New Yorkers have about the state of the city, they have low expectations of either candidate's ability to turn things around.
"The city has gone down," said Nan Babiak, 27, who works in television production and lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. "I've noticed a lot more crime on the street. If it could get any dirtier, it looks like it has."
Ms. Babiak said she did not think Mr. Dinkins or Mr. Giuliani was likely to improve significantly the state of the city. She said no mayor by himself could reduce crime or expand the economy; at best, she said, a mayor can be a kind of municipal cheerleader. "It's a bigger job than anyone can handle," she said. "It's more of a moral support kind of thing."
 
Race Relations
 When registered voters were asked in the survey how they thought race relations might change if Mr. Dinkins were re-elected, 55 percent said they thought they would remain the same. Eighteen percent said race relations would get worse and 22 percent said they would get better in a second Dinkins administration.
Forty-four percent of those surveyed said race relations would remain the same if Mr. Giuliani became mayor, while 18 percent said they would improve and 25 percent said they would get worse.
Similarly, 45 percent of the voters said the economy would remain the same if Mr. Dinkins were re-elected, and 41 percent said the election of Mr. Giuliani would not change the state of the local economy. A slightly higher number of people said the economy would improve if Mr. Giuliani became mayor, with 28 percent saying it would improve under the Republican-Liberal, and 21 percent saying it would get better under Mr. Dinkins.
 
Distinct Edge on Crime
 Mr. Giuliani did have a distinct edge when it came to voters' perceptions on crime. Sixty-eight percent of the voters surveyed said Mr. Giuliani was tough enough to deal with crime in New York, while only 40 percent thought the Mayor was tough enough.
Black voters, who support Mr. Dinkins overwhelmingly, tended to be more upbeat about conditions in the city and the Mayor's ability to improve things. For example, 24 percent of black voters surveyed said New York was safer now than it was four years, while 5 percent of white voters said it was safer. And though 18 percent of black voters said life in the city had improved over the last four years, only 5 percent of white voters said life had got better.
It may not be surprising after nearly five years of a deep recession that the poll found New Yorkers' overall outlook to be grim. But the survey also showed some striking ambivalence on significant civic questions.
While the respondents were very dissatisfied with the general quality of the public schools -- 70 percent said they were not satisfied and 16 percent said they were -- New Yorkers were less unhappy about their own local schools. Forty-seven percent said they were dissatisfied with the public schools in their neighborhood, with 35 percent saying they were satisfied with the local schools.
Forty-nine percent of those who said they had a child in a public school said they were satisfied with their local schools, while 46 percent in this category were dissatisfied.
 
A Familiar Pattern
 Pollsters say the pattern is a familiar one in surveys, in which people's dissatisfactions diminish as they are questioned about matters increasingly close to home. The most common version of the phenomenon involves respondents who say they have broad discontent with Congress but are relatively content with their own Congressional representative.
New Yorkers also showed a marked ambivalence about the homeless in The Times/WCBS-TV News Poll. Sixty-three percent of the voters surveyed said the city should get tougher with homeless people who make a nuisance of themselves; 55 percent said the city should get tougher in a similar survey four years ago.
But when asked about a proposal by Mr. Giuliani to restrict most homeless people to a maximum of 90 days in the city's shelters, only 25 percent of the respondents said it was a good idea. Sixty percent said it would create more problems.
The poll also showed some intriguing patterns on other public issues. Asked, for example, whom they blamed for the asbestos problems that delayed the opening of school last month, 67 percent of those surveyed blamed the Board of Education alone, while only 6 percent blamed Mr. Dinkins and 7 percent blamed former Mayor Edward I. Koch.
 
Support for Chancellor
 The new Schools Chancellor, Ramon C. Cortines, won strong support after his first month in the job: 39 percent said they approved of his performance, and 13 percent disapproved.
But there appeared to be deep concerns about the Board of Education. A majority of those questioned, 52 percent, said the mayor should be able to appoint more members to the central board, a change that Mr. Dinkins has been advocating. Yet a larger majority, 68 percent, favored the elimination of the central board and the creation of five separate borough boards, something that Mr. Giuliani, among others, has proposed.
A possible explanation for these seemingly contradictory findings is that New Yorkers are sufficiently frustrated over the Board of Education that they are inclined to favor any change in its structure.
 
Ready to Leave
 In its most provocative finding, the survey determined that 45 percent of respondents said things had got so bad in New York that they would move out tomorrow if they could. Some pollsters played down the significance of the finding, noting that similar surveys in Chicago and London also showed many residents said they wanted to leave immediately.
"I wish I had the money to get out of the city," said Joanne Walter, 34, who lives in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, and has three children. "There are people going through the garbage. There was a hooker on my corner the other morning. They broke into my car several times. My mother was mugged. It's rough."
But Alan Deberry, 44, who lives in Williamsbridge in the Bronx, said he had no desire to leave. "I'm not giving up on the city because I was born here, raised here and went to school here," he said. "It seems like the city is getting a little better. The Mayor is trying his best to make the city a little safer."

HEADLINE: New York Hospitals Foresee Loss Of Billions Under Clinton's Plan

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN

 BODY:
Already facing chronic money problems, New York City's hospitals said yesterday that they would lose about $4 billion in Government revenue, or about 4 percent of the hospitals' total budgets, in the first five years of President Clinton's proposed national health plan.
In perhaps the first detailed look at how the Clinton proposal could affect local health care providers, the Greater New York Hospital Association said that cuts in Medicare and Medicaid would far outweigh increases in aid for people who now lack health insurance.
 
Cuomo Meets With Moynihan
 The hospital association's report is a first step in what promises to be intense jockeying among interest groups in the health care industry that hope to reshape the Administration's plan to guarantee health care to all Americans. In New York City, for example, although hospitals stand to lose revenue, some clinics, doctors and other health care providers may receive more money. 
 White House officials say they are taking steps to lessen the burden on urban hospitals as they translate their draft plan into legislative proposals.
For his part, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo met yesterday with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and one of the lawmakers who will help determine the ultimate face of the health care plan. State officials said the Governor, who has expressed specific concerns about how the health care overhaul would affect New York's finances, told Mr. Moynihan about changes he would like to see in the plan, including increases in matching funds from the Federal Government to help the state pay its share of Medicaid.
The hospital report is the work of an association that includes the 64 nonprofit and municipal hospitals that provide the overwhelming share of hospital care in New York City.
"If the plan were financed as currently proposed, the hospitals in New York City would experience net revenue reductions of such magnitude that many would not be able to sustain their current level of operations," the report says. "Hospitals most at risk would be those that serve high concentrations of patients whose health insurance coverage is publicly financed through the Medicare and Medicaid programs."
The hospital group said it strongly supported the goals of the health plan, which ultimately should help relieve hospitals of one of their most pressing problems: caring for people who lack either company-sponsored health insurance or Government protection for health care costs.
But the detailed figures in the report suggest that, at least in New York and possibly in other large cities, sharp cuts in reimbursements for Medicare coverage for the elderly and Medicaid coverage for the poor are likely to exceed the increased money from a variety of sources for providing health care to those who are now uninsured. The national health care overhaul could prove particularly difficult for the city's web of hospitals and clinics, the nation's largest public health system.
The problem for New York City involves several factors: New York is more generous in its health care support for low-income people than other cities and it has a larger proportion of people on Medicaid. At the same time, it has a smaller proportion who are uninsured, so it would gain less than other cities from the Clinton plan's support for such people.
"New York's municipal hospitals already face chronic deficits," said Karen Parker, vice president for health economics at the association. "This could develop into a very, very dangerous situation."
 
Changes to Be Made
 At the White House, Richard Kronick, a senior health policy adviser, said the hospital study, which he pointed out was based on preliminary figures, failed to take into account changes to be made in the initial Medicare proposals that should soften the impact on New York City hospitals. Moreover, he said, the study assumes that of the approximately $800 million a year in Medicaid spending cuts, about $300 million of the cuts would be made by state and city governments. Those governments might choose to preserve that aid, even as the Federal share drops.
He also said that some of the money that hospitals expect to lose would flow to doctors and clinics outside the hospital system. "It is important to remember that we are still talking about net increases to the New York health care industry, even if there will be some redistribution to nonhospital providers."
Mr. Kronick said that hospitals should also be able to save money through greater efficiencies in the Clinton plan, like standardized insurance forms. "There's no intention that needed hospital services will be forced to close," he said.
 
Compensating Aspects
 Some local hospital officials expressed reservations about the study. Dr. Benjamin Chu, a senior vice president at the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, said the report highlighted the "grave revenue implications" for local hospitals of the initial Clinton proposal, but said that he expected certain other aspects of the plan to help compensate for the losses. He mentioned the Administration's promise, which has yet to be spelled out in detail, to provide extra money to cities and states that must provide health care to large numbers of undocumented immigrants.
The study acknowledged that the full impact of the health care proposal is hard to determine, because many of the details have yet to be worked out.
According to the study, which was done in conjunction with a health care consulting company, Network Inc., city hospitals could lose as much as $12 billion from 1996 through 2000 because of Medicare and Medicaid reductions. That sum represents more than 12 percent of the total revenues of New York's hospitals.
In return, city hospitals could expect to receive $8 billion in new revenues as a result of the expansion of health care coverage to those who are now uninsured. The shortfall would be almost $4 billion, or roughly 4 percent of the hospitals' expected total spending of about $100 billion over the five years.
The report projects that over five years, the city's hospitals could gain $7.98 billion to provide coverage for the uninsured. But they would lose $4 billion given to hospitals that serve a high proportion of low-income, Medicaid patients. Changes to reduce the rise in Medicare would cut an additional $7.34 billion, and $588 million would be lost in Federal money for hospitals that train new doctors.

HEADLINE: Pessimism in Haiti: Violence Could Swamp Diplomacy

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Just three weeks before Haiti's exiled President is to be restored to power, many Haitians are expressing doubts about whether a peaceful return to democracy is possible in the climate of growing violence here.
One reason for the fear is a lack of faith in the foreign force that is envisioned as the glue to hold together this country's negotiated political settlement. The 1,300-member contingent of troops and policemen coming in will carry nothing more powerful than handguns and will not be authorized to stop violence. A warship carrying about 250 American soldiers left a naval base in Puerto Rico today and another ship with 300 more troops was preparing to depart, the Pentagon said. 
 The rising pessimism also has been fanned by reports of deep ambivalence toward the mission among United States defense officials in the wake of a rising death toll among American soldiers in Somalia.
 
No Somalia, Diplomats Say
 But diplomats in Haiti say the country in no way resembles Somalia.
The 7,000-man Haitian Army, for all of its unruliness, remains a ragtag, poorly equipped force that has shown no inclination for direct confrontation with anything more challenging than the unarmed civilians who are routinely found dead here.
Critics of the current diplomatic strategy say they fear that the army, emboldened by assurances against foreign intervention, will make the country ungovernable. Some of those critics, including dissenting diplomats, say such a campaign is already under way.
Two of the most prominent supporters of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the popularly elected Catholic priest who was ousted two years ago in a military coup, have narrowly escaped assassination by plainclothes gunmen. On Thursday, the capital and much of the countryside were shut down in a strike enforced at gunpoint. And today, more than 500 boisterous opponents of Father Aristide's return marched past army headquarters and shouted to waving senior officers that they must not step down, as called for in the diplomatic settlement.
 
Nature of Haitian Situation
 "The fatal flaw is a lack of understanding of the Haitian mentality or of the Haitian situation," said a businessman with close ties to diplomats. The man, who has grown increasingly doubtful of the chances that diplomacy will succeed, added, "What this settlement is asking for is that people who have been accustomed to a certain way of living for over 30 years give up their control of the country voluntarily."
Even as doubts like these emerge, diplomats involved in Haiti's political crisis insist that everything is working well, and point to their own achievements.
In the three months of diplomacy since an accord was signed in New York calling for the restoration of President Aristide, a constitutional Government has been seated and a crushing economic embargo has been lifted. Foreign economic aid has begun to flow into the country.
The army commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, renewed a pledge to resign by Oct. 15 in a meeting on Thursday with Robert Malval, the Prime Minister chosen by Father Aristide, said diplomats who took part in talks.
But Haitian analysts and diplomats with long experience in the country say there are danger signals. For one, these observers say, the organizers of the recent anti-Aristide demonstrations are closely tied to the army high command, in particular with General Cedras's most trusted aide, Gen. Philippe Biamby, the chief of staff.
 
Protest Leader Linked to Army
 A leader of the demonstrations, Emmanuel Constant, spent much of the first six months after the coup against Father Aristide working out of General Biamby's office, say businessmen who know both men.
Furthermore, diplomats say many of the demonstrators are known to be off-duty policemen and attaches, the plainclothes police auxiliaries who have committed most of the recent violence, often operating under the open protection of uniformed police.
Diplomats who are leading political discussions here say that much of Haiti's planned settlement was inspired by the experience of deeply torn nations in Central America, where extremists of the right and left were gradually brought toward a democratic middle. But in Haiti, even these architects admit that there has been little real movement toward reconciliation from either side. Father Aristide, a leftist, has failed to name a broad-based Government, and the army has skillfully used violence and procedural roadblocks to prevent a buildup of momentum in support of the settlement plan.
Moreover, critics of the approach say, the Haitian military lives comfortably on the spoils of graft and smuggling and is not as sensitive to issues of military aid and professional respect as its Central American counterparts.
Haitian analysts say there is little that can be done under the settlement to force the military to relinquish power as planned.
"There has been an obsession in the United States in bending over backwards to accommodate Haitian concerns over intervention," said a former Haitian official with close ties to American diplomats. "If putting an embargo back in place is all they can come up with, the army is prepared to live with it. They made money on the embargo last time."

COUNTRY: HAITI (99%); UNITED STATES (93%); SOMALIA (93%); PUERTO RICO (79%);

HEADLINE: Hanoi Journal;
Promise of Prosperity Threatens a City's Charm

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam

 BODY:
Nguyen Lan stands between this 1,000-year-old capital and the wrecking ball that has destroyed so much of the architectural heritage of Southeast Asia. And he would just as soon be standing somewhere else.
"I know that our Government leaders support preservation of the old city," said Mr. Lan, the chief Government architect of Hanoi. "They know its beauty." 
 "But there are many ideas about what should happen to Hanoi," he said as he nervously fingered the architectural designs for a 20-story building that could change the look of the capital forever. "Some people say that it is not necessary to preserve the old city of Hanoi because it is a symbol of poverty. Some people question whether we would let them starve so that a few of us can admire the beautiful old buildings."
This tranquil capital of tree-shaded streets and ocher, colonial-era villas set among tiny lakes is under threat from an economic revolution that has the potential of transforming Vietnam from a Communist backwater to one of the economic tigers of Southeast Asia.
The increasingly lonely vigil to save old Hanoi is being led by a handful of Vietnamese officials and foreign friends of the city who want to prevent its gracious if crumbling beauty from being sacrificed in Vietnam's headlong rush to free markets and economic development.
The preservation debate has begun in earnest with the announcement that a Singapore-based development company is planning to erect the city's first tall building, a 20-story tower of luxury apartments, the heart of a $41-million residential and office complex directly across from the Hoan Kiem Lake. Many of Hanoi's three million people consider the lake to be the center of their city.
Also bound for "redevelopment" in Hanoi is the site of the colonial-era prison that became known to a generation of Americans as the Hanoi Hilton, because it was there that American prisoners of war were held during the Vietnam War. Those plans are not so far advanced, but there are reports that the prison will be torn down and replaced with a $33-million, five-star hotel.
 
Where Rivers Join
 Hanoi was founded in the 11th century by the Vietnamese King Ly Thai To, who wanted to inaugurate his dynasty by creating a beautiful new capital along the confluence of the Red River and the To Lich River. It has been preserved not because of the work of enlightened urban planners, but because of generations of civil war and economic stagnation in Vietnam.
During the Vietnam War, Hanoi, unlike much of the rest of North Vietnam, was mostly spared the devastation of American bombers. Neighborhoods are little changed in appearance from the era of the great Vietnamese kings or the French colonialists who deposed them.
Vietnam's era of economic stagnation appears to be over, however. With the collapse of its former patron, the Soviet Union, Vietnam has abandoned Marxist economic theory and has embraced the free market. Foreign real estate developers have rushed into Vietnam.
From the beginning, there was less to preserve in Ho Chi Minh City, formerly the southern capital of Saigon, which during the Vietnam War developed a skyline of tall, modern, mostly characterless buildings.
In Hanoi, however, there is little of modern architecture and no very tall buildings -- the city's tallest structure is a six-story office complex that until recently was the only building in the city with an elevator.
Foreign developers say that with land prices exploding in the capital, they are without a cost-effective means of preserving much of the old architecture of Hanoi.
"It's called progress," said Peter Purcell, the Australian developer who is behind Hanoi Plaza, the complex that will include the 20-story building.
"If Hanoi is going to achieve anything like the importance it seeks as a government and financial center, you will have to have modern buildings," he said. "And the economics of modern buildings hold that if the land is of a certain value, the buildings have to be a certain size. To make omelets in this city, you will have to break some eggs."
For Hanoi Plaza, the cost of progress will include the demolition of a city landmark, a cavernous, cream-colored two-story department store built by the French in the late 1920's.
 
A Practical Matter
 "We've been right through the department store and it was quite clear to us that it was impractical to save any of it," said Mr. Purcell.
While his project has already received the approval of the Government's foreign investment department, other agencies have not yet signed off including Mr. Lan's office.
"On a case-by-case basis," he said, the city will probably have to approve the construction of a number of high-rise buildings or risk the loss of the foreign investment needed to create a prosperous city.
"All of the foreign investors want to put their money into projects right in the center of the city, and they only want to build tall buildings," he said. "If we reject them, then maybe the investors will go to Beijing or Seoul or Bangkok. That is not what we want."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Hanoi, colonial-era buildings are threatened by an economic revolution that is transforming Vietnam from a Communist backwater to an economic tiger. One such building is the prison, known to a generation of Americans as the Hanoi Hilton, where American prisoners were held in the Vietnam War. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Salinas Asks Trade Pact Effort

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 8

 BODY:
President Carlos Salinas de Gortari appealed to a group of visiting American Congressmen today to approve the North American Free Trade Agreement without modification or delay, suggesting that Mexico might not support the pact if it is not put into effect by Jan. 1.
In a meeting with the Congressional delegation at the presidential residence, Los Pinos, Mr. Salinas reaffirmed a written statement he made to The Washington Post on Thursday that neither renegotiating nor rescheduling the agreement "are real options at this stage." 
 But Mr. Salinas and other Mexican officials stopped well short of saying directly that they would reject the agreement if it were not voted on in the United States until early next year. The possibility of such a delay has been raised in recent weeks by Clinton Administration officials and leaders on Capitol Hill.
The hard tone of Mr. Salinas's remarks smacked of political maneuvering because it contrasts notably with other statements he has made.
He has previously insisted that some form of trade agreement between Mexico, the United States and Canada is "inevitable." A short-term delay in the agreement's passage in Washington, he has also predicted, will probably not have pernicious consequences either for the Mexican economy or for his party's chances in the presidential elections scheduled for August 1994.
Mexican political analysts and foreign diplomats said they considered it extremely unlikely, if not unthinkable, that Mr. Salinas would walk away from the accord if a United States Congressional vote were postponed until early next year. The accord has already been ratified in Canada, and its approval in Mexico is a foregone conclusion.

HEADLINE: New York's Lucrative Offer Persuades Unicef to Stay

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Unicef, the United Nations relief organization that had considered moving to New Rochelle, said yesterday it would remain in its current headquarters across from the United Nations and expand into 14 floors of a nearby Manhattan office tower.
The agency, which had been negotiating with the two cities for three years and had even considered moving to Germany, said it would accept a lucrative package of financial incentives offered by the Dinkins administration. 
 In effect, the city agreed to hand over ownership of Unicef headquarters to the agency at the end of a 30-year lease. The agreement all but assures that Unicef will remain in Manhattan for at least three decades and is a major symbolic victory for the city, which has battled to keep major corporations from leaving Manhattan.
 
Praise for New Rochelle
 But in announcing its decision at a news conference attended by Mr. Dinkins, Unicef officials praised the efforts of New Rochelle, which has prepared a plan for major redevelopment of its downtown business district and had worked hard to lure the agency as an anchor tenant.
"Little New Rochelle has to be a remarkable community to have stimulated New York City to offer this massive response," said James P. Grant, the agency's executive director. He added that Unicef had always considered the East Side of Manhattan to be the best location for its headquarters because of its proximity to the United Nations.
The agency has 900 employees at its headquarters in 3 United Nations Plaza, an office tower built for it by New York City in 1987. It was considering moving because more space was needed.
 
Identity Crisis Avoided
 In announcing that it would occupy 14 floors at 633 Third Avenue, just off 41st Street Unicef said it planned to expand its Manhattan staff by 600 people over the next 20 years.
Mayor Dinkins said New York City had more at risk than 1,500 jobs when the agency threatened to leave.
"Unicef is important to New York's identity as an international city," said the Mayor, who had lobbied hard to persuade the agency not to leave.
In the end, Unicef officials said the financial inducements offered by City Hall persuaded it to stay.
Unicef's headquarters is part of a complex that was financed and built by the United Nations Development Corporation, an agency created by the city and state. The agency raised money in the 1980's through the sale of tax-free municipal bonds
Until now, Unicef, like the other United Nations tenants, has simply been a tenant But under terms of the deal announced yesterday, it will receive a new 30-year lease at reduced rent, with the rent being used, in essence, as mortgage payments
Carl Weisbrod, one of Mayor Dinkins's chief economic advisers, said yesterday that Unicef will pay $1.7 million less annually when the term of its new lease begins. The new lease, has provision To persuade Unicef to expand into 633 Third Avenue, he said, the United Nations Development Agency will again raise money through the sale of public bonds and buy 14 floors of the building, which are being sold as condominium space. Although the deal has not been completed, officials said the agency will pay about $26 million for the space, or about $100 per square foot.
Unicef is then to lease the space for 30 years under the same terms asat its headquarters. By 2026, it is to own both properties.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The unemployment rate remained at 6.7 percent in September, with the labor market improving only modestly by adding 156,000 payroll jobs. Although the results matched expectations, some secondary numbers reflected more weakness than had been expected. The report sent the dollar down against European currencies and ignited a powerful rally in the bond market. [Page 39.]
Suspicion that some traders made big profits in Treasury bond futures using an unauthorized leak of the September employment data has prompted an investigation by the Chicago Board of Trade and the Labor Department. [51.] 
 The mood was oddly buoyant when 100,000 farmers gathered in Iowa for the annual Farm Progress Show, even though many Midwestern fields are still under water from the summer's flooding and many crops were planted late. [39.]
 
Companies
QVC Network is negotiating with BellSouth and at least two other companies in search of financing to raise its $9.5 billion bid for Paramount Communications and avoid having to turn for help to John C. Malone, one of its partners in the offer. [39.]
Martin Marietta is said to be negotiating to buy the space division of General Dynamics. A formal agreement could be announced as early as next week, aerospace executives say. [41.]
Delta Air Lines is under Justice Department investigation over concern its agreements with travel agents in Salt Lake City might harm a smaller competitor, Morris Air. [41.]
Western Waste shares plunged 38 percent after the company announced the collapse of a merger with Browning-Ferris. [41.]
Volkswagen is struggling to correct problems at SEAT, its Spanish subsidiary, which had a $769 million fiscal 1993 loss. [41.]
Amdahl expects a third-quarter operating loss, its third in a row, as the mainframe business continues to deteriorate. [41.]
Dell Computer is recalling about 17,000 discontinued notebook computers because of a possible fire hazard. [47.]
 
International
A dinner for the First Deputy Prime Minister of Vietnam in Manhattan attracted dozens of senior executives from American industry, eager to do business with a former enemy that, sooner or later, will be freed from an 18-year-old economic embargo. [39.]
The U.S. is planning to raise $2.1 billion to offset lost revenue caused by the North American Free Trade Agreement primarily by raising customs and other fees for foreign tourists. [10.]
 
Markets
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond plunged to 5.92 percent as the bond market interpreted the September employment report as hard evidence of a weak American economy. [48.]
Stocks were mixed despite a strong performance by the bond market. The Dow industrials gained 1.11 point, to 3,584.74. [40.]
The dollar fell against European currencies after the employment report indicated interest rates would not be raised. [50.]
Lumber prices rose on an agreement with environmental groups that opened less land for logging than expected. [50.]
 
Your Money
Stocks in small companies look promising for investors with a long view and the stomach for sharp downturns. Lately, these issues have produced handsome rewards. [37.]
Small investors can partake in computerized trading through computer data services including Compuserve and Prodigy. [37.]
Term life insurance may become too costly for some people as they grow older, and its usefulness should be reconsidered. [37.]
Most American investors interested in the public offering of Banque Nationale de Paris must turn to mutual funds. [38.]

HEADLINE: Traveler Fees May Rise To Pay for Trade Accord

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 8

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is planning to raise $500 million a year to help pay for the North American Free Trade Agreement, primarily by raising fees on travelers entering the United States, Congressional officials say.
Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, said at a news conference here this morning that Administration officials were in the final stages of drafting the plan with members of Congress, and would announce the plan in a few days. 
 By gradually eliminating tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada, the free-trade agreement would reduce Federal revenue by at least $2.4 billion over the next five years. A provision of the 1990 budget agreement effectively requires that this revenue loss be offset with higher taxes or cuts in mandatory spending programs like Medicare, creating a thorny problem for an Administration that barely persuaded Congress this summer to raise taxes and lower spending to reduce the budget deficit.
Five Congressional participants in drafting the plan said this week that the most likely plan would be a sharp increase in customs, immigration and agricultural inspection fees now charged on airline and ship passengers arriving from countries outside North America.
 
Airline Ticket Price
 The $5 customs fee, $5 immigration fee and $1.45 agricultural fee are included in the price of round-trip international airline tickets, and are now used to pay for the Government's costs in handling incoming passengers.
One of the five participants said on Monday that the fees would be doubled and the customs fee would apply for the first time to travelers flying to the United States from Canada and Mexico, while the agricultural fee would apply for the first time to travelers flying here from Canada. Other participants said today, however, that the increases would be large but would not amount to a doubling of the fees.
The Administration has also been looking at the imposition of border crossing fees on trains, trucks and individuals, participants said.
Administration officials notified the Mexican Government on Thursday that the White House was considering an increase in the airline fees. There has been no response from Mexico City yet, said a Mexican official who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Mexican Government was not notified of any plans to impose border crossing fees, the official added.
In an interview after his news conference, Mr. Kantor said that no final decision had been made but that higher customs fees were under consideration. "There are a number of alternatives," he said. "That's only one of them; we've looked at 15 or 20."
The Congressional participants also said that no decision had been made, but that the alternatives were less politically palatable and unlikely to happen. "If you have to reach into an entitlement, you've got Medicare, disability, Social Security," which are all popular programs, one participant said.
The nation's airline industry is beginning to lobby against the plan, and is considering whether to oppose the entire agreement if the Administration goes through with it. "The industry has been suffering from a tremendous burden of taxes and user fees," said Edward A. Merlis, the senior vice president for external affairs of the Air Transport Association, an industry trade group in Washington that has taken no position on the pact so far.
Mr. Merlis said the Administration could raise $645 million a year just from airline tickets if it doubles the fees and eliminates the exemptions. Mr. Kantor said the free-trade agreement would cost the Federal Government about $500 million a year.
The Administration plan must generate money not only for the lost tariffs but also for the $225 million that the White House has pledged for the creation of a border cleanup fund with Mexico. The Administration has also been trying to decide whether to include money in the trade pact legislation for extra customs officials along the Mexican border and to help American workers who lose their jobs because of Mexican competition.
 
Punitive Tariffs Law
 Mr. Kantor also indicated today that the Administration might include a trade law known as Super 301 into legislation putting the free-trade agreement into law. The law requires the Trade Representative to impose punitive tariffs or other trade sanctions quickly on any country that persistently restricts American exports.
An aide to Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat who heads the Finance Committee's Subcommittee on International Trade, said the Senator was trying to persuade the Administration to add such a provision, and had been warmly received. But another Congressional aide said the Administration would risk antagonizing Republicans if it adds Super 301, while most Democratic advocates of Super 301 are opposed to the free-trade pact and unlikely to be swayed by its inclusion.
In effect from 1988 to 1990, Super 301 was an amendment to Section 301 of the 1974 Trade Act. The law was intended by Congressional Democrats to be a weapon against what they perceived as Japanese trade barriers.
Seiichiro Noboru, the economics minister at the Japanese Embassy, said the free-trade agreement was a trade-expanding measure that should not be linked to Super 301, which he criticized as a law that could be exploited by American protectionists.
Congressional rules for the approval of free-trade agreements call for the legislation to include "necessary or appropriate" language to put the agreements' provisions into law. In the past, this has been interpreted to allow changes in trade laws not mentioned in the agreement. But the legislation cannot include unrelated measures like money for bridges and highways in the districts of influential members of Congress.

HEADLINE: Nicaragua's Feuding Parties Strike Deal to End a Standoff

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Nicaragua's feuding political parties have struck a deal aimed at resolving the country's political crisis.
The leftist Sandinistas and the conservative National Opposition Union said late Thursday that they had agreed to remove President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's economic Cabinet members and paved the way for the departure of Gen. Humberto Ortega Saavedra, the head of the armed forces. His departure would be part of a military reorganization bill under review by Mrs. Chamorro's staff. 
 Nicaragua was plunged into a crisis in August when contra rebels kidnapped 39 legislators, soldiers and Government officials, triggering a retaliatory seizure of conservatives, including Vice President Virgilio Godoy, by pro-Sandinista commandos.
No one was injured in the weeklong standoff, but the kidnappings revealed the extent of the country's polarization three years after the end of a civil war, which pitted American-backed contras against the Sandinistas.

HEADLINE: Stocks End Day Mixed As Dow Moves Up 1.11

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday despite a strong performance by the bond market, where prices gained and yields fell on employment figures that traders interpreted as showing the economy was still underperforming.
Analysts said the chief reason for the stock market's lackluster performance was investor concern over forthcoming third-quarter corporate earnings reports. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, which was down more than 25 points at midday, closed with a gain of 1.11 points, to 3,584.74; it gained 3.63 for the week. New York Stock Exchange volume was heavy at 243.6 million shares traded, compared with 255.2 million on Thursday. The number of issues that gained in price exceeded decliners by 1,109 to 850.
"Although bonds firmed they are not apt to lend support to stocks in coming weeks, as traders sense interest rates may be bottoming," said Harry W. Laubscher, senior vice president and market analyst at Tucker Anthony. "Softness in utilitiy shares may be reflecting this concern."
Mr. Laubscher added that with most stocks currently at high prices, "traders are casting about for groups still seen as being undervalued, and pollution control and precious metals could be beneficiaries of this casting about."
 
The Most Active Issues

Among active issues yesterday,Western Waste Industries fell 6 3/4, to 11, after saying its proposed merger with Browning-Ferris Industries was canceled because the two companies were unable to agree on definitive terms. Shares of Browning-Ferris rose 5/8, to 24.
Liberty Media fell 3 1/4, to 25 1/4, in active trading. The television programming company is being bought by Tele-Communications for $3.8 billion in stock, less than the market had expected. Also, three shareholder class action suits were filed in Delaware Chancery Court yesterday to block the proposed merger. Shares of Tele-Communications were up 1 5/8, to 27 1/2.
Detroit Diesel attracted strong demand in its initial public offering. The truck engine manufacturer's stock closed at 25 7/8 in its first day of trading, up 29 percent from the offering price of $20 a share.
Salem Sportswear was up 1 3/4, to 9 1/4, after the company said it was in merger talks with an undisclosed party.
Elan closed up 3, at 34 1/8, after the developer of drug delivery systems said its Beodas technology would be used for oral delivery of the anti-coagulant Heparin.
C. R. Bard fell 1 3/4, to 23, as Mabon Securities lowered its recommendation to neutral from buy. The company said it was in talks with the Justice Department on a possible settlement of a previously disclosed Boston Federal grand jury investigation into possible labeling and testing irregularities in its angioplasty products unit. Terms of any settlement could result in a substantial fine or penalty, the company said.
Spartan Motors, a manufacturer of custom-built vehicles, fell 3 5/8, to 13 3/8, after announcing it expects third-quarter earnings to be lower than analysts' estimates of 20 cents a share. Also, Prudential Securities cut its estimate on the company.
In Tokyo, stocks closed higher. The 225-share Nikkei average rose 113.01 points, or 0.56 percent, to 20,378.64.

HEADLINE: Sluggish Jobs Data Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The labor market improved only modestly in September as payroll jobs expanded by 156,000 and the unemployment rate remained at 6.7 percent, its two-year low, the Labor Department reported today.
Although the basic figures closely matched consensus expectations, some of the secondary numbers reflected more weakness than had been expected. Among the weaker of these was an 18-minute cut in the length of the private-sector workweek, a seventh straight decline in the number of jobs in factories and a sharp increase in the length of jobless spells. 
 The report, which was the first comprehensive gauge of the economy's overall performance for the month, sent the dollar down against the German mark and other European currencies, and ignited a powerful rally in the bond market, driving interest rates down across the entire spectrum.
Yields on the 30-year bond retreated below 6 percent. [Page 48.]
 
No Rise in Wages
 The bond market was also encouraged, economists said, by the report of no change in average hourly earnings in September after a sizable August rise.
The overall report was "a bit disappointing," said James W. Coons, chief economist at the Huntington National Bank in Columbus, Ohio. He pointed particularly to the jump, to 9.1 weeks from 8.4 weeks, in the median duration of unemployment.
As a result, Mr. Coons trimmed by one-quarter of a point his estimate for economic growth in the just-concluded third quarter, to a rate of 3.25 percent. That is still a gain from the 1.9 percent pace in the second quarter, but few analysts expect to see much further acceleration in 1994.
Robert G. Dederick, executive vice president of the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said he was neither encouraged nor discouraged by today's report, which included optimistic elements like job growth in heavy machinery and other industries that had been faring poorly. He also cited some statistical quirks that made interpretation difficult.
Noting that the payroll expansion of 156,000 was quite close to the average so far this year, Mr. Dederick concluded that the economy continued to "slog" ahead.
 
Improvement in East
 Geographically, today's data showed that the unemployment rate eased in the Northeast and South, to 7 percent and 6 percent, respectively, while it rose in the Midwest and West, to 5.9 percent and 8.1 percent.
Among the 11 individual states for which figures were reported today, a 1.7-point leap in Ohio's unemployment rate, to 7.3 percent, was far the largest change among any of the states covered. Analysts point out that the state results are far more erratic than the national ones because of smaller survey samples and that for most states a move must be at least a full percentage point to be considered statistically significant.
The rate for Illinois climbed to 8.5 percent from 7.6 percent, while New York and New Jersey moved in opposite directions from one another -- New York down eight-tenths of a point, to 7.1 percent, and New Jersey up six-tenths of a point, to 7.7 percent. The unemployment rate in New York City was 8.7 percent in September, down from 9.5 percent in each of the previous two months.
The jobless rate for California moved up four-tenths of a point, to 9.4, the report also showed. Excluding California, the biggest state, the national jobless rate was 6.3 percent.
 
No School Effect
 A Labor Department official said the delay in the start of the school year in New York City had no discernible effect on the employment figures since teachers remained on payrolls and students with temporary jobs seemed to stop working before Labor Day.
An unusually long period between the August and September survey weeks swelled the payroll total by about 25,000, one official estimated, but this was roughly offset by a lower seasonally adjusted count for jobs in the construction and amusement industries.
Also muddying the report was a rise of 54,000 in local government jobs, so big in view of tight school and other budgets as to be suspect, according to various analysts, who added that such figures at this time of the year might be skewed by lagging effects of summer job programs.
Retail trade, the report also showed, added 41,000 jobs last month and health services added 36,000 despite flat employment in hospitals. Moreover, the electronic equipment industry did not lose jobs for the first time in six months; the loss in aircraft manufacturing was the smallest in two years and the finance, insurance and real estate group added 10,000 jobs, mostly in financial institutions.
 
Some Sectors Lose More
 The loss of 18,000 jobs in factories was unusual in that it was concentrated in the nondurable sectors, like food processing, printing and publishing and the manufacturing of apparel, rubber and plastics. The majority of the lost factory jobs involved middle managers, who accounted for 11,000 of the total with the remaining 7,000 coming from production workers.
Business services were unusually weak, mainly reflecting the fact that temporary-help agencies failed to add jobs after having been a major job generator for the last two years.
Another unusual result, one also contributing to the bond rally, was that the revision in the August payroll figure was downward. The change was tiny, 2,000 jobs, but analysts have become accustomed to substantial upward revisions.
The survey of households, meanwhile, registered a drop of 253,000 in jobs last month after an exceptionally big gain of 409,000 in August. But the labor force also fell, by 395,000, allowing the unemployment rate to remain at 6.7 percent, one point below its June 1992 peak.
Still, the quarterly tally of discouraged workers -- those who have given up looking for jobs because they think they cannot find one -- eased a bit in the July-September period, to 1,122,000 from 1,202,000 in the spring.
Whites were slightly more discouraged; blacks substantially less so.
Among the long-term jobless, the ranks of those out of work 15 to 26 weeks swelled by 75,000 last month while those jobless for more than six months grew just 6,000 to remain slightly below the July level.
After a talk to a group of institutional investors in New York today, Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, said he was encouraged by the job growth in the report but he lamented the long periods of joblessness.
Reflecting the decline in the workweek from extremely high levels, the index of aggregate weekly hours slipped a full point, to 123.8, today's report also showed. On the other hand, the percentage of industries adding workers surged to 54.5 from 43.4, recovering most of an August plunge. The gain among manufacturers was even more striking -- to 49.6 from 34.5.

HEADLINE: Rally Sends 30-Year Yield Below 6%

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Bond market investors interpreted the September employment report as strong evidence of a weak American economy, and they sent the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond plunging to 5.92 percent yesterday.
More than any other security, the 30-year bond reflects the opinions of millions of bondholders concerning inflation, and yesterday by buying the bonds in big quantities -- driving up the price and driving down the yield -- they voted that inflation was unlikely to rise in the foreseeable future. 
 The 30-year bond jumped more than a point, to 10420/32 , while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction to the price, fell to 5.92 percent from 6.01 percent. Yields on other Treasury issues also fell, with the 10-year note dropping to 5.25 percent from 5.32 percent.
 
Even Lower Yields Are Seen
 "The Treasury bond yield is definitely on a new leg down," said Jay Goldinger, a bond trader for Capital Insight, a bond brokerage house in Los Angeles. "The employment report reaffirmed the feeling that the economy is not growing at a pace that will create inflation."
Mr. Goldinger, like other analysts, said that if the reports on the Producer Price Index and the Consumer Price Index to be released on Thursday and Friday failed to show new inflationary pressures, then long-term yields could fall further, with the 30-year bond breaking below its old low of 5.86 percent, set on Sept. 8.
In the month since then, bonds have been trading in a narrow range as investors tried to decide whether the economy, and with it the inflation rate, might be strengthening or weakening. The September unemployment report, released early yesterday, seemed to provide a strong answer, and bond prices rose quickly as investors moved in from the sidelines.
 
Signs of Weakness
 "The employment report skewed the odds toward weakness rather than strength, and a weak economy means less inflation," said Matthew Alexy, government trading strategist for CS First Boston.
Bond traders had anticipated that the Labor Department would report an unemployment rate of 6.7 percent in September, unchanged from August, and that job growth would come in at about the 156,000 that was reported. What the market did not anticipate, Mr. Alexy and others said, was that 71,000 of the new jobs would be in government and only 85,000 in the private sector. For the third quarter, the nation averaged 90,000 new jobs a month in the private sector compared with 165,000 a month in the second quarter.
No analyst concluded that the employment report signaled a recession, only an economy that has failed to shake off its sluggish growth 30 months after the last recession ended, defying numerous forecasts earlier this year that the economy would by now be growing more strongly than it is.
"With this kind of labor market activity, it is hard for the economy to overheat as it did last year at this time," Mr. Alexy said. "And that was one of the worries that people had."
A drop in the average weekly workweek reinforced the notion of a weak labor market, along with the report that manufacturers shed jobs again in September, as they have almost every month this year.
 
Watching the Fed
 Investors had also been concerned about reports that the Federal Reserve might push up interest rates before the end of the year, to stave off inflation. The job report seemed to dissipate that concern, although rates on short-term Treasury securities barely moved, suggesting that investors did not expect the Fed to ease rates, either.
"There were people around today who had wanted to buy," Mr. Goldinger said, "but they wanted to make sure that the news was O.K., and as soon as they saw that the news was O.K., they committed money to the market."
The yield on the two-year note dropped to 3.78 percent from 3.81 percent. And the discount rate on the one-year bill slipped to 3.17 percent, from 3.19 percent. But the discount rate on the six-month bill was unchanged at 3.06 percent, while the three-month bill rose to 2.97 percent from 2.96 percent.

HEADLINE: Clinton Sounds A Rallying Cry: Security for All

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that the Democratic Party should seize the theme of personal security, which he is already using to promote his health care package, as a way of persuading Americans to rally behind his proposals on everything from the economy to crime to trade.
In an address to the fall meeting of the Democratic National Committee, Mr. Clinton made only a passing reference to the American military deployment in Somalia, saying it was most important that the public focus on matters at home. 
 So in a speech that was at times reflective and at times rambling, the President emphasized his domestic priorities, lumping them under the label of security for Americans.
"If we were the party of Social Security, why can't we be the party of health security and personal security and freedom from fear?" he declared to a buoyant audience over breakfast at the Sheraton Washington Hotel.
Through the security theme, Presidential advisers say, Mr. Clinton can reassure middle-class people who fear the loss of their jobs and health coverage in a time of economic flux.
 
'This Is a Breakthrough'
 "We've been reaching for a consistency that makes things reinforce one another rather than compete with one another," Stanley Greenberg, the President's poll taker, said of the emerging strategy. "In some sense, this is a breakthrough in how to give people hope in a world that is changing and that people are fearful of."
The President spoke two days after Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, suggested in a speech that the Administration was not doing enough to calm the fears of the middle class in a world changed by the end of the cold war, a vast expansion of technical knowledge and increasingly severe limits on Government programs because of the ever-rising national debt.
Today the President, jumping from his economic package to the new family leave law to military conversion, sought to make a case that issues so disparate could be linked by the theme of security.
 
Needed Sense of Security
 "When you change a country now," he said, "you can't just pass a law and change it. You can't just write a bill and change it. You have to change the behavior of the whole country. People have to change their lives. So, we can't do that unless people feel a higher level of security. I think that's self-evident."
The mood of party leaders during this two-day meeting, which ends on Saturday, was decidedly more upbeat than it was in Albuquerque, N.M., in late June, when they spent much of their time offering post-mortems on Mr. Clinton's failed effort to get a job stimulus package through Congress.
Recent polls show Mr. Clinton's popularity on the rebound, and today both the President and David Wilhelm, the party chairman, spoke not of missteps but of their achievements and the agenda that lies ahead.
"Thanks to you, and with your help," Mr. Clinton said as he opened his 45-minute talk, "we have begun to fulfill the promise of the long campaign of 1992 and the commitment of our party to change America for the better."
 
Nothing But Praise
 Mr. Wilhelm, who earlier this year was on the defensive over the President's performance and Democratic efforts, had nothing but praise for the party today. He said the successes had paid off in fund-raising, with 100,000 new donors on the party rolls.
"For the first time in modern history," Mr. Wilhelm said, "we are matching the Republican National Committee dollar for dollar."
All the self-congratulation could not completely blot out the signs of dissension, which was evident in part by what was not said. Although he did allude to the North American Free Trade Agreement, which is supposed to be a top priority of the Administration but is opposed by many Democrats, Mr. Clinton never mentioned it by name.
Inevitably, however, the issue arose at an afternoon question-and-answer session with Roy Neel, the deputy White House chief of staff, and it created an awkward moment.
In the first question to Mr. Neel, Frank Garrison, who heads the Michigan A.F.L.-C.I.O. and is a member of the party's governing board, said: "On the Nafta issue, I think the Administration is wrong. I hope we'll do the Administration a favor and defeat it."
 
Ticklish Question
 His question was greeted with applause from only a few in the audience. From others, there was dead silence.
Mr. Neel responded by saying, "Obviously we know there are disagreements on this issue." He added that party members could "agree to disagree -- and it can be a constructive disagreement."
No disagreement was apparent when Mr. Clinton asked the party faithful to support bills on crime, health care and education.
"Unless we can be secure in our work and families, unless we can be secure on our streets, unless we can be secure in our health care," he said, "I'm not sure the American people will ever be able to recover the personal optimism and courage to open up to the rest of the world, to continue to reach out and break down the barriers of trade."
Mr. Clinton drew perhaps the most prolonged applause when he said the family leave bill showed that his Administration was helping people in their daily lives. He recalled how he was approached during a White House tour recently by a man whose young daughter, confined to a wheelchair, was dying.
"Her father grabbed my by the arm, and I turned around," Mr. Clinton said. "And he said, 'You know, my daughter's probably not going to make it, and because of that, these last weeks I've spent with her are the most important times of my whole life. And because of that family leave bill, I didn't have to lose my job to spend that time.' "

HEADLINE: Florio and Whitman Hit Trail After Debate

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 8

 BODY:
One day after their first debate, Gov. Jim Florio and his Republican opponent, Christine Todd Whitman, resumed life on the campaign trail. She visited a high school and a financial firm. He got a visit from the top Democrat in the United States, President Clinton.
The President officially came to New Jersey to lobby in support of his health care package. But in one short speech before an enthusiastic crowd at the Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, Mr. Clinton managed, through the issue of violence in America, to link his health care proposals to one of the most popular planks in Mr. Florio's campaign: gun control. 
 Mr. Clinton said America's ability to develop a health care system that will protect every resident depended directly on the country's ability to confront its tendency towards violence. To do that, he said, the nation needs to pass a crime bill that will pay for more police and require a waiting period for buying weapons. He said the country also needed to follow New Jersey's lead in enacting a ban on semiautomatic weapons.
"We have a decision to make and it's time to make it," Mr. Clinton said. "We can't keep saying we deplore these things and it's terrible and keep extolling our American values on how much more law-abiding we are than other people and put up with this."
 
Clinton Proud of Florio
 Mr. Clinton praised Mr. Florio for his part in enacting the ban, and for making what he said were tough economic decisions -- an indirect reference to the $2.8 billion tax increase that came within months of Mr. Florio's taking office.
"We need more people in our country who are willing to call them like they see them, who will try to identify the problems and try to get up every day and try to do something about them," Mr. Clinton said. "I am proud to be associated with Jim Florio."
The visit came just one day after a gubernatorial debate in which Mr. Florio held his own but did not score a knockout punch. It was another payment on the political debt Mr. Clinton owes the Governor.
When Mr. Clinton was just one of many contenders for the Democratic nomination, Mr. Florio was one of the earliest nationally-known politicians to support him. More importantly, Mr. Florio used his influence to raise campaign funds for Mr. Clinton. New Jersey contributors added $4 million to the Clinton campaign -- second only to those in Arkansas, the President's home state.
 
White House Helps Trenton
 After winning the Democratic Party nomination, Mr. Clinton made New Jersey his first campaign stop. In February, he intervened with the Department of Health and Human Services to help New Jersey get $412 million in Medicaid reimbursements that had been held up in a yearlong dispute with the Bush Administation. Without the reimbursement, Mr. Florio faced the prospect of cutting jobs and services to balance his budget for the 1994 fiscal year.
Mr. Clinton followed up that favor by appearing in February at the annual New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce dinner in Washington. And a steady string of Clinton Administration officials, including Attorney General Janet Reno, have visited the state during the last few months.
Mr. Clinton's visit occurred with barely three weeks left before the gubernatorial election. The Presidential trip dominated news coverage in the state today and put Mr. Florio at the center of that attention as he stood alongside Mr. Clinton.
Mrs. Whitman's public schedule today had three events: a morning visit to the Beneficial Corporation office in Peapack, an afternoon visit to Hamilton High School East in Hamilton Township and a Republican dance in Lakewood this evening.
 
G.O.P. Assails Clinton Visit
 The Republicans tried to steal some attention from Mr. Florio by holding a news conference on the steps of the State House in Trenton just hours before the President's arrival in New Jersey. State leaders including Representative H. James Saxton, Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian and Virginia N. Littell, chairwoman of the State Republican Committee, showed up to proclaim Mrs. Whitman the winner of Thursday night's debate.
Mrs. Whitman's campaign called the President's visit blatantly political and demanded that Mr. Florio's campaign be assessed the estimated $45,000 cost of the trip.
"The guy came in here to take the edge off of Florio's defeat last night in the debate and that makes it a political visit," said Carl Golden, the chief spokesman for the Whitman campaign. "This is no accident of scheduling that he came here on Oct. 8 and Florio ought to pay for it."
Mr. Florio met the President at Newark International Airport and accompanied him to the medical center, where they toured a trauma unit and met with several patients who were the victims of violence.
 
Pride in Weapons Ban
 Before introducing the President, Mr. Florio reminded the audience of New Jersey's ban on semiautomatic weapons. The ban, which Mr. Florio also helped save from a repeal by the Republican-led Legislature, is one of the centerpieces of Mr. Florio's administration and has been a constant theme in his campaign.
"We fought hard to pass the toughest assault weapons ban in the country," he said. "That should be a source of pride to the people of New Jersey."
But since this was billed as an official visit, Mr. Florio tried to avoid appearing too political in his remarks. That was left to the warm-up speaker, Sheriff Armando Fontoura of Essex County.

HEADLINE: Board of Trade Investigating Rally Before Data's Release

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Did some traders make big profits from an unauthorized leak of September employment data?
The Chicago Board of Trade said today that it was investigating that possibility, after futures prices for Treasury bonds rallied sharply in extremely heavy trading two minutes before the report was released this morning. 
 "Our own time-and-sales data do show there was a run-up of the market in advance of the numbers," said a spokesman for the Chicago Board. "We are looking into it."
 
 
A Washington Inquiry
 The Labor Department, which takes precautions to keep its data secret before the 8:30 A.M., Eastern time, release, also said it was looking into reports of a possible leak. But a spokesman for the department said it was possible that the unusual activity could be a result of trading based on rumors.
Trading on leaked economic data could lead to dismissal, if not criminal prosecution, of a Government employee or a trader.
The market rallied strongly after the report's release, meaning whoever bought early made a big gain.
The Board of Trade said the price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose from 1196/32 at 8:28 to 11913/32 at 8:29 and then jumped to 11928/32 at 8:29:54, just six-hundredths of a second before the report was released. The price slipped just after the report, to 1195/32 at 30 seconds after the release, but quickly rebounded after that and held its gains.
The brokers who manage trading in the pit declared a "fast market" about one minute before the report was released. That designation, which warns traders that the order trading is so rapid that the posted prices might not be keeping up, is relatively common when significant statistics are released but is unusual beforehand.
"We get fast markets all the time, but this one struck us as unusual," said David Prosperi, a Board of Trade spokesman.
Board officials said that they would unravel who made the trades and interview traders in the pit. At this point, they said, there is no indication of improper trading.
At the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, floor traders also noticed a price rise that some called unusual in currency futures before the report was released.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Amdahl Expects to Report Another Losing Quarter

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The Amdahl Corporation said today that it expected to report a third-quarter operating loss that would be considerably larger than the loss it reported in the second quarter.
Amdahl, a maker of mainframe computers, lost $23.7 million in the second quarter. With the third-quarter loss, Amdahl will have lost money for three consecutive quarters, and analysts said it was unlikely to show near-term improvement. 
 Amdahl shares fell 87.5 cents today, closing at $5 on the American Stock Exchange.
 
Depends on Mainframes
 Amdahl's core mainframe business is particularly vulnerable to economic downturns, and unlike I.B.M., its main competitor, it lacks other lines to fall back on.
Amdahl, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., cited a continuation of depressed conditions in the market for its mainframe systems combined with intense competitive pressure on pricing as the principal reasons for its continuing losses.
Amdahl also said it expected to incur additional restructuring charges as it made operational changes necessary to address current business conditions.
"Amdahl is a narrow-line vendor, and therefore more susceptible to hiccups in the marketplace, especially when those hiccups occur in the high end," said Bob Djurdjevic, president of Annex Research, a mainframe industry consulting firm.
Amdahl, like I.B.M., is suffering from perhaps premature reports of the death of the mainframe computer, which is being supplanted by decentralized work station systems, and from the continuing recession in Europe, which has prompted many large companies to postpone big capital expenditures, Mr. Djurdjevic said. He added that Amdahl had made positive steps toward diversifying but that these would take time to show results.
Amdahl announced last month that it would resell computers manufactured by Sun Microsystems Inc. and abandon its own internal effort to develop machines using Sun's Sparc processor.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Lumber Prices Up Sharply After Clinton Agreement

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Lumber prices rose sharply yesterday in reaction to an agreement between the Clinton Administration and environmental groups that opened up less land for logging than the timber industry had hoped.
November lumber jumped $9.20, to $307.50 a thousand board feet, at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. 
 The agreement, which must still be approved by a Federal court, would lift court injunctions blocking sales of 83 million board feet of timber on federally controlled lands.
Logging groups said that Mr. Clinton promised them earlier this year at a forest conference that 2 billion board of feet of timber could be sold in the first year of a program to free 12 billion board feet of timber over a decade.
The Administration said timber on more Federal lands would become available soon. However, the agreement reached Thursday may leave avenues through the courts that environmental groups might use to impede future timber sales.
On other commodity markets, cattle prices sank as meatpackers scaled back their bids for the animals in light of falling wholesale beef prices. Cattle not sold will go back up for auction next week, further depressing prices, Chuck Levitt, an analyst at the Alaron Trading Corporation, said.
October live cattle fell 1.125 cents, to 70.925 cents a pound, and October feeder cattle dropped 0.975 cent, to 84.15 cents a pound.
Elsewhere, energy prices also ended a relatively slow day slightly higher. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, November crude oil, which traded with a loss for most of the day, ended 6 cents higher to close at $18.55 a barrel. November heating oil gained 0.14 cent, to 55.99 cents a gallon, and November gasoline rose 0.45 cent, to 51.65 cents.
"We saw some good short-covering at the end of the day," one trader said. "That was about the only action."
After two days of sharp advances, silver prices stabilized in light trading. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, December silver slipped 2.3 cents, to $4.36 an ounce. Signs of an improving economy that would increase industrial demand for silver -- along with strong interest in silver options from Middle East investors -- had lifted the market earlier in the week.

HEADLINE: Vietnam Does Some Networking

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
A few feet from trays of crab cakes and fried shrimp and white wine, dozens of senior executives from the anchors of American industry were obediently lined up in a Plaza Hotel ballroom. They were from companies like Pfizer, Mobil and Avon, and they were waiting to shake the hand of -- and, they hoped, to have a few words with -- the First Deputy Prime Minister of Vietnam.
It was not a royal dinner, but sometimes it seemed on Thursday night as if the American executives were treating the Vietnamese official, Phan Van Khai, like a prince. They flattered him. They toasted him. They gave him several standing ovations. They left little doubt that they were eager -- maybe too eager in the minds of demonstrators nearby -- to do business with a former enemy. 
 Mr. Khai, the No. 2 official in the Vietnamese Government, was in Manhattan for the opening of the United Nations General Assembly. Organized by the Vietnam-American Chamber of Commerce, the dinner in the Grand Ballroom at the Plaza marked the first time in decades that a high-ranking Vietnamese official had addressed representatives of American companies.
The dinner seemed to bring to the surface many of the conflicting emotions Americans hold toward Vietnam. Even as the executives ate beef tenderloin and grilled salmon with their Vietnamese guests, several Vietnamese-American and veterans groups were protesting outside the hotel.
Nearly 200 people from American corporations and firms paid $350 each to hear Mr. Khai, 59, a lifelong Communist who studied socialism in Moscow and was the former chairman of the State Planning Commission.
The executives' enthusiasm seemed prodded by the sense that sooner or later Congress will repeal the 18-year-old American economic embargo against Vietnam. In another step toward chipping away at those restrictions, President Clinton last month allowed American companies to bid on projects in Vietnam financed by international aid groups like the World Bank.
"This is a statement that American executives believe that it is time to end the embargo," Irwin Jay Robinson, president of the Vietnam-American Chamber of Commerce, said of the dinner as he surveyed the ranks of dark suits in the Grand Ballroom. "It's a statement that they believe that there are very substantial business opportunities in Vietnam."
 
'Business From Day 1'
 Peter M. Ham, a vice president at Merrill Lynch & Company, said the broad range of companies that had sent people to the dinner appeared to reflect the intense interest in Vietnam as one of the last unexplored markets.
"Read the list of the companies that are sponsoring this event: law firms, infrastructure firms, power companies, telecommunications companies," he said. "They are really curious. I can guarantee you that each one of the companies represented here has someone on their payroll in Saigon today. So when the embargo is lifted, they are effectively doing business from Day 1."
Despite the cheerful expressions of camaraderie, there was also an underlying tone of frustration and wariness to the evening.
Some executives said they were angry that European countries and Japan were aggressively pursuing business in Vietnam, while they were forced to woo officials like Mr. Khai from the sidelines. But they said they realized that they had to go out of their way to avoid offending veterans' groups, who accuse Vietnam of withholding information on Americans missing since the Vietnam War.
The issue is so sensitive that some corporations decided not to send people to the dinner, Mr. Robinson said, adding that some veterans' groups had called for boycotts of the companies that did. Only a few companies -- including Avon Products Inc. and the Occidental Petroleum Corporation -- bought full tables at the event. And some executives would not speak for attribution.
Across the street from the Plaza, about 50 Vietnamese-Americans and veterans conducted a demonstration before the event, waving signs that read, "Freedom For Vietnam" and "No Trade With Vietnam." During the cocktail hour, a middle-age veteran wearing a ribboned military-style cap slipped through security and began shouting at the executives.
"All of you have betrayed the American public!" the man said before he was removed from the room. "I hope you're proud of yourselves! You have disgraced this country!"
 
Toward a Freer Market
 In his speech, Mr. Khai sounded like a committed capitalist, noting proudly that in the last year, more than 500 American executives had visited Vietnam to study its markets and 20 companies had obtained licenses to open offices there. He stressed that the country was moving forward on reforming its economy -- a process called "Doi Moi" -- and reducing state ownership.
"We do not want to see American companies being left out or lagging behind in competing for business opportunities in Vietnam," he said, speaking through an interpreter. "Vietnam attaches great importance to building a better relationship with the United States."
The speech and Mr. Khai's responses to written questions appeared to strike a chord with many executives, who said they felt more confident about pursuing opportunities in Vietnam once the embargo is lifted.
"We've now reached the point that we did with China in the early 1970's and we did with the Russians and Eastern Europeans," said George Suter, an area president with Pfizer Inc., the pharmaceuticals company. "We need to bury the hatchet and go ahead. These animosities can't go on forever. That's totally unrealistic."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Phan Van Khai, First Deputy Prime Minister of Vietnam, greeting Frank Masi, a California businessman, and Irwin Jay Robinson, center, president of the Vietnam-American Chamber of Commerce, in Manhattan. (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times)
