HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Discovering Lower East Side

 BODY:
A colorful map and fold-out brochure that serves as a guide to more than 25 cultural and historic attractions on the Lower East Side of Manhattan has been published by the Lower East Side Consortium, an economic development group.
Titled "Discover Five Treasures on the Lower East Side," it gives detailed information about Little Italy, Chinatown, the area around Orchard and Delancey Streets, the East Village and the East Village area east of Avenue B called Loisaida by its largely Hispanic population from the Spanish pronunciation of Lower East Side. Each neighborhood is represented with sections labeled "Discover the History," "Discover the Cultures" and "Discover the Sights." 
 The brochure is available free by mail only from the Lower East Side Consortium, 110 William Street, Third Floor, New York, N.Y. 10038. Enclose a long business envelope with 29 cents' postage.
Two groups that run guided walks of the Lower East Side are Big Onion Walking Tours and the Eldridge Street Project.
Big Onion Walking Tours, Columbia University Post Office, Post Office Box 250201, New York, N.Y. 10025, telephone (212) 439-1090, conducts walks throughout the year. Tours last from two to two and a half hours, and cost $9. "Irish New York" will be the subject of a tour on Oct. 23 and the "Jewish East Side" on Nov. 7.
The Eldridge Street Project, 12 Eldrige Street, New York, N.Y. 10002, (212) 219-0888, was founded in 1986 to restore the Eldridge Street synagogue and make it a heritage center on the Lower East Side. It runs tours throughout the year under such titles as "The Synagogues of the Lower East Side" and "Pickles, Rugelach, Bialys and Knishes," both of which cost $10 a person.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 4; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2104 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property:/Upper Broadway;
The Glitter of the Other Broadway

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
FOR years they've flocked to Zabar's for their lox, to H & H for their bagels, to Fairway for their fruits and vegetables. They are a motley lot, with well-coiffed women in minks jostling ponytailed men in cutoffs for counter space; some have their bags of goodies loaded into limousines, others tie them to bicycle racks, still others hail cabs -- and many, many more just walk home.
These are the Broadway shoppers, people from all careers, all classes, all races, who hate to waste money but are willing to spend whatever it takes for quality. They have been around for decades. And now a new wave of retailers, including some national chains, are recognizing them as one of the most potentially lucrative customer groups around. 
 "It seems like every retail tenant we represent has a standard requirement with us, to get them on Broadway," said Benjamin Fox, an executive vice president of New Spectrum Realty Services. "Dollar for dollar, it is the best retail street in the city."
In the last two or three years there has been an explosion of retail leasing activity on Broadway north of Columbus Circle. Barnes & Noble, Cosmetics Plus, the Gap, Talbots and a host of other Manhattan mainstays have either opened or are about to open new stores in the area, many of them much larger than their stores elsewhere in the city.
Filene's Basement, a newcomer to New York, chose Broadway and 79th Street for its flagship store. Even Broadway in the West 90's, long considered a bit too seedy for many retailers' tastes, is enjoying a renaissance, with a new Vitamin Corner between 94th and 95th, a Lechter's Housewares near 94th Street and a Gap Kids near 96th.
"Retailers are like sheep; they want to follow wherever the others go," said Faith H. Consolo, a managing director at Garrick-Aug, the store-leasing specialists. "And in the last six to eight months everyone has been going to Broadway."
If current projects continue as planned, Broadway will become even more of a shopper's -- and thus, a seller's -- haven. The Kmart Corporation has expressed interest in the Coliseum, that much-discussed building expected to bring hundreds of new residents for its 38 floors of apartments, but also a 10-screen movie theater, a Gap, another Barnes & Noble superstore, a sports center, even an Armani A.X.
"This area is dynamite," said Edward A. Friedman, president of Newmark Retail Services. "It's a small area with an unbelievably dense population, and anyone who is thinking of coming into New York now is looking at Broadway."
OF course, much of this revolves around economics. Broadway above Columbus Circle has always been an established shopping corridor, catering more to residents than to tourists or office workers, and its retailers did not suffer nearly as much in this recession as did their midtown counterparts, who need to draw customers from office buildings with persistently high vacancy levels.
Still, in keeping with the general recession, Broadway rents have gone down. Decent storefront space on upper Broadway that went for annual rents of $100 a square foot or more a couple of years ago is now $65 to $80, although a good corner spot can still command $100 or better.
That's one reason that the 9 West Group, which operates several upscale women's shoe stores in tonier parts of Manhattan, is about to open on Broadway near 83d Street.
"No, we're not projecting the same volume that we get on Lexington or Madison, but then, we're not paying a Madison Avenue rent," said Joel Fisher, senior vice president of real estate and store planning for the 9 West Group. "And we've visited this street a lot in the last few years, and we like the traffic that we've seen."
The rent drop has encouraged some retailers to take larger spaces than they normally would. Cosmetics Plus is moving into 4,500 square feet -- nearly double its usual store size -- that the Marine Midland Bank had occupied near 75th Street. The chain will use the extra space to put in a beauty service and create what Ms. Consolo, who brokered the deal, calls a "spa-like" atmosphere.
"We made a great sublet deal with the bank, so this was a chance to build a really high-impact store," Ms. Consolo said.
People willing to take basement or upstairs space, particularly on the east -- for that, read non-Zabar's -- side of the street, can do even better. Jennifer Leathers, part of the Jennifer Convertibles chain, took a total of 5,700 feet at 2300 Broadway, near 83d Street, 4,500 square feet of which was basement. It is using both levels to sell, yet because basement space is so much cheaper -- and because the east side of Broadway has traditionally generated less pedestrian traffic and thus commands lower rents -- its average rent for the entire space is less than $40 a square foot.
Similarly, Preferred Seating, which has for many years operated a successful furniture store across from ABC Carpet on Broadway near 18th Street, opened a couple of years ago in about 4,000 square feet of second-floor space near 85th Street, for a rent in the low $20's. It is using a big awning on its entrance and a huge neon sign in its windows to herald its presence.
"We'd been looking at upper Broadway for several years, but until this space opened up we couldn't find anything that fit our rent parameters," said Robert Villency, chairman of Maurice Villency, which owns Preferred Seating. "Preferred Seating operates on razor-thin margins and we simply couldn't pay the rent that a Maurice Villency store pays."
But not all the retail newcomers have been bargain hunters. Brokers say that Cooper's Coffee Bar paid well above market rates for its new cafe on Broadway and 75th Street. Whole Foods, which runs a successful health foods store in SoHo, recently opened a 2,300-square-foot store on 89th Street and Broadway. No one is talking numbers, but the word among brokers is that Charles Rosenbloom, the store's owner, also agreed to above-market prices on his 15-year lease.
"Yes, he's paying a hefty rent, but look at what he got," said New Spectrum's Mr. Fox, who negotiated for Whole Foods. "He got a corner store, terrific frontage, and most important, he's convenient to the loyal West Side customer."
Indeed, any number of the long-time retailers in the area speak of customer loyalty as one of the boons of being on upper Broadway. Varizioni, a high-priced women's clothing shop on the west side of Broadway near 82d Street, has one year left on its 10-year lease. It stocks a huge assortment of hats and long-sleeved items, and that has garnered it a lot of repeat business from the neighborhood's large contingent of Orthodox Jewish women.
Although Varizioni's owners would love to see the whole neighborhood go a bit more upscale -- "We wish Barneys would be coming in across the street instead of Filene's," said Manoucher Hedvat, one of the owners -- they fully intend to renew their lease.
Similarly, Harry's Shoes, a family shoe store on the southwest corner of 83d Street and Broadway, has been there for about 18 years. "Sure, Barnes & Noble has drawn traffic, and Filene's will draw more, but even before them we have never wanted to move elsewhere," said Joseph Goldberg, one of the owners, who says that 70 percent of his customers are from the neighborhood.
That neighborhood orientation has been the saving grace of the Broadway retailers. Retailers on Columbus Avenue, once thought to be the West Side's equivalent to Madison Avenue, have not done as uniformly well. "Columbus is a weekend strolling street, and one that suffered mightily from the demise of the yuppies," said Ms. Consolo. "Broadway is an everyday street that caters to residents of all incomes."
UPPER BROADWAY is, in fact, really four different shopping neighborhoods: the 60's, the 70's, the 80's and the 90's. The southern tip, which encompasses Lincoln Center and many of the newer high-rises, is probably the toniest part, and the one most visited by tourists. It is less homey, more expensive, more attractive to chains and restaurants than to the proverbial butcher, baker and candlestick maker.
North of 72d Street the neighborhood becomes almost purely residential, and neighborhood service stores peacefully coexist with clothing stores, electronics stores and the like. The neighborhood's gentrification has marched slowly but steadily north from Columbus Circle, and the farther north one goes, the larger the proportion of poorer residents. A store like Armani A.X., which is opening in the Lincoln Square complex, would probably not have a chance were it to open 25 blocks north.
Gentrification slows dramatically at 96th Street. Between there and Columbia University, about a mile north, Broadway remains a hodgepodge of bargain stores, older supermarkets and groceries and other long-time retail residents.
Each of the 10-block neighborhoods is so densely populated that it is a mini-city unto itself. Each has its own supermarkets, its own clothing stores, its own bookstores. Few West Side residents venture out of their own neighborhoods to shop, except tor high-powered traffic pullers like Zabar's or Barnes & Noble. Mr. Villency, for one, did not even consider putting a Maurice Villency store, which sells very high-end furniture, in the Preferred Seating locale.
"Maurice Villency needs to draw people from a radius of 20 miles to get 90 percent of its business," Mr. Villency said. Indeed, Mr. Villency says that the Maurice Villency store on 35th Street and Madison Avenue more than covers the company's customer base in the borough. "One Maurice Villency store in Manhattan is enough," he said.
But for retailers with popularly priced items, Broadway's segmentation has a definite upside. The street can support numerous stores from the same chain, with none of the stores cannibalizing each other. The Gap already has four stores between 59th and 96th and is looking to put another in Lincoln Square. It is seeking more sites for Gap Kids stores as well, and its Banana Republic store on 87th Street has done so well that it is moving into the much larger space that the East New York Bank occupied a block south, on the northeast corner of 86th Street.
In fact, from 72d Street through 82d Street, the east and west sides of Broadway are worlds apart. On the west side, Fairway, Zabar's and lately, Barnes & Noble, act as magnets, drawing people north for half a mile. The east side, by comparison, is a ghost town.
"From 70th to 80th, pedestrian traffic on the west side of Broadway is 20 times that on the east," New Spectrum's Mr. Fox estimated. That may, of course, change when Filene's Basement opens on Broadway's east side, but for now, the dichotomy between the west side haves and the east side have-nots is clear.
It has been for years. James Bildner can tell you that. In 1987 he opened a J. Bildner's & Sons, a Massachussetts-based chain of high-priced perishable foods, on the northeast corner of 74th Street and Broadway, right across from Fairway. He paid a high rent -- some brokers guess it was in excess of $150 a foot -- but he was certain that a neighborhood that could support a Zabar's could easily support him.
He was wrong. The store closed barely nine months later.
"WE just didn't understand the difference between the west side and east side of the street," Mr. Bildner recalls. "Our intent was to be parasitic on the traffic heading for Zabar's or Fairway, but the fact is they never walked by us." That experience, combined with problems finding employees who could give the type of service that Bildner's offers to justify its prices, has pretty well soured Mr. Bildner on trying New York again any time soon.
But while a poor site can mean a death knell, even the best site in town doesn't guarantee success. The Muffin Lady, a diet food chain that has done terrifically on Long Island, opened a 1,000-foot store right next to Zabar's a couple of years ago. The store lasted barely a year; its products were costly, and West Siders balked at paying for them.
Koo Koo Roo, on the northwest corner of 76th Street, was similarly short-lived. The idea -- skinless broiled chicken -- fit in with the West Side's health consciousness, but neither the product itself nor the restaurant's fast-food ambiance wooed repeat business.
"The preponderance of people shopping the West Side are successful but not rich," said Newmark's Mr. Friedman. "They are price-conscious and value-conscious. And that means this will always be an area where strong retailers will survive and prosper. Marginal retailers will simply fail."

HEADLINE: After Weicker, New Candidates, New Strategies

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
AS a politician, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has conducted his affairs rather like one of the opera stars he so admires: larger than life, full of grand passions, and capable at any moment of springing an improbable plot twist on his audience.
The election campaign that has now begun, following Mr. Weicker's decision to leave the stage after one term, promises to be on a more human scale, for better and worse. 
 The half-dozen or so candidates and would-be candidates whose names are now in play for the 1994 governor's race will face no sitting incumbent with Mr. Weicker out, a fact that by itself would tend to level the field. And party officials say that perhaps partly in reaction to the sometimes grand guignol effects of the Weicker years, the script for all the candidates will likely stay close to the basic messages as well -- issues like jobs, the economy and health care. The result may still be exciting but it will not be Aida. "This time there aren't going to be any dominant personalities," said John G. Rowland, who was the Republican Party's candidate in 1990 and who is widely expected to run again in 1994. "This time the issues are so significant -- the job market, the economy, the future, the income tax, education, crime -- that the campaign is going to go beyond particular personality, it's going to get into pure gut policies."
Other politicians say that Mr. Weicker's large shadow will still hang over the race, if only by the indelible image that he carries in many voters' minds and the inevitable comparisons that will be made.
And who knows what the best answer is, anyway? When stacked up against a politician of Mr. Weicker's stature -- first third-party governor in a century, father of the state income tax, veteran of the Watergate Committee -- does a more life-size candidate end up looking small by comparison, or refreshingly down to earth? Is it better to run with a hint of the self-assured Weicker swagger, or to step forward more humbly as a candidate who would transcend problems rather than charge them like a bull?
 
The Grand Moment or Day to Day?
 "This is an administration that favored the grand moment -- desegregation, casino gambling, the income tax -- sometimes, I would argue, at the expense of the day-to-dayness of things," said the State Comptroller, William E. Curry Jr., a Democrat who said last week that he was close to a decision to run. Under Mr. Weicker, Mr. Curry said, there were moments of high moral purpose and conscience, "but the basic systems of government have continued to run down and need attention."
Among those in the race or considering a bid, three worked directly with or in some instances against Mr. Weicker in Hartford: Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark, running on the ticket of A Connecticut Party, and State Senators John B. Larson of East Hartford and Richard J. Balducci of Newington, both Democrats.
Four others, plus Mr. Rowland, are on the early lists as well: Mr. Curry, the Comptroller; United States Representative Nancy L. Johnson, a Republican from New Britain; Joel Schiavone, a New Haven businessman and a Republican who ran for Comptroller in 1990, and the Secretary of the State Pauline R. Kezer of Plainville, also a Republican.
 
Reinventing Compelling Figures
 Party leaders and candidates stress that with the election still 13 months away, all prognostications about the final shape of the campaign are mere guesses, but that some early lead lines are emerging about how the players will attempt to connect with voters, make themselves known and in some cases reinvent themselves as compelling figures who deserve votes. In general, they say, two related questions are expected to be paramount.
No. 1: Who gets credit or blame for the state of the economy on Election Day? and No. 2: Has the allure of third-party politics worn off?
On the first point, battle lines have already been drawn. Senator Larson, who entered the race this spring in anticipation of a campaign against Mr. Weicker, had already formulated a blistering critique of the state's Department of Economic Development, which Mr. Larson says has blundered clue-less and plan-less, with a "scattershot approach," that has distributed hundreds of millions of dollars in grants and loans to companies without getting any measure of whether jobs were actually being created.
 
No More 'Money Store'
 "We can't continue to be the Connecticut Money Store," Mr. Larson said. "We can't continue to act as though we're Phil Rizzuto."
Facing off on that front, based on her early comments, will be Mrs. Groark, who entered the campaign on Tuesday and pledged to continue Mr. Weicker's policies -- and his economic development programs in particular.
"Our decisions are keeping the businesses here, and most importantly, keeping paychecks in the hands of the citizens of the state of Connecticut," she said. "Connecticut can only continue to move forward," she added, under "a governor committed to continuing the course that we have set in this administration, not dismantling our reforms and retreating to the problems of the past."
 
Holding a Coalition
 The second question centers even more directly on Mrs. Groark. Can she hold together the coalition of disaffected Democrats and liberal Republicans who elected Mr. Weicker? And if she does not win, which of the other two major parties does her candidacy help or hurt?
Mrs. Groark, like Mr. Weicker, is a former Republican, but unlike Mr. Weicker she has no track record of attracting Democratic votes except at Mr. Weicker's side in the 1990 election. And neither Democrat nor Republican party leaders have been kind so far in assessing her chances of following up where Mr. Weicker left off. A Connecticut Party, which she represents, has only about 1,800 members statewide, or less than one-tenth of 1 percent of the statewide voter registration total of 1.95 million. And she is not widely known outside the Hartford area.
"Eunice's run is just some kind of blind loyalty to Lowell," said Mr. Rowland. "The ultimate loyalty of the captain going down with the ship."
The chairman of the Democratic Party, Edward L. Marcus, was similarly dismissive. "I consider Eunice to be a nice person and a credible candidate, but I wouldn't categorize her as a formidable candidate," he said.
 
Power Potential of Office
 But those early assessments also do not reckon with the potential power of her office and exposure that Mr. Weicker could bestow by simply stepping a little more out of the spotlight and allowing Mrs. Groark to the front and center over the next year.
To one degree or another, all the candidates face problems of either not being widely known, or like Mr. Rowland, having been out of government and out of the spotlight entirely for three long years since the last election. And making voters' acquaintance, or reacquaintance, is expensive, especially in places like Fairfield County, where many people are only considered reachable -- for television advertising, at least -- through time purchased on New York stations with their huge audiences and high rates.
In his 1990 race against Mr. Weicker and Bruce A. Morrison (the Democratic candidate), Mr. Rowland (then a Congressman from the district around Waterbury) spent nearly one-third of his entire campaign fund buying New York advertising. And he did well there, beating Mr. Weicker across most of the county. But he still lost by three percentage points in the statewide count.
"The less you are known, the more you have to spend to become known," said the state Republican Party chairman, John A. Mastropietro. "But name recognition is also an overplayed commodity," he added. "Early on, certainly, it is important, but it is not something that you cannot overcome."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Making Gold-Coast Affordable Housing a Reality

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
DECADE after decade, Fairfield County's wealthier towns have talked about affordable housing, but as a subject for action it has been as intractable as the weather. Barely noting state guidelines suggesting that a minimum of 10 percent of housing be in the "affordable" category -- which means $100,000 for a family of four in Fairfield County earning $40,000 a year -- most communities remain at about 2 percent. Only the larger cities of Bridgeport and Stamford exceed the minimum.
Nevertheless, 126 units of new or renovated affordable housing have been produced around the county by the Fairfield 2000 Homes Corporation, a group of volunteer movers and shakers founded in 1987. 
 The 18-member privately financed nonprofit organization is a spinoff of the Regional Plan Association; its chairman is Bruce Warwick, a Stamford developer. The group is currently shepherding dozens more units from drawing board to reality.
"Fairfield 2000 is successful because it takes a middle-of-the-road approach," said Rick Redniss of Parsons, Bromfield, Redniss & Mead, a Stamford land-use planning firm that has written zoning laws allowing the corporation to bring its projects to fruition. "They target the municipal employees and low-income town residents who are traditionally left out, the very people that the communities say they want to help."
While the units are open to anyone, priority is given to townspeople.
Waterside Green, in an industrial neighborhood in south Stamford, was the corporation's first venture. It opened 16 months ago and the last of 75 units was bought and occupied last month. The complex was designed by Zane Yost, a Bridgeport architect with strong convictions that low-cost housing should be stylish, well-built and contain communal open space.
Jose Quinones, a shipping supervisor for Perkin-Elmer in Wilton, his wife, Caroline, and their two young daughters moved in a year ago.
"We paid $109,000, with $3,175 down," Mrs. Quinones said. Their monthly mortgage, taxes and insurance cost $950, exactly what they paid for a two-bedroom apartment in Stamford that was "so small we had to keep our stuff in boxes," she added. Now they have three bedrooms, two and a half bathrooms, a living room, dining room, fully equipped kitchen, fenced patio and central air-conditioning.
One-bedroom units start at $63,500 and common charges range from $60 to $90 a month.
Mr. Yost also designed a 30-unit complex that is expected to get municipal approval in Darien by the end of the year. Resistance to such housing had generated prolonged litigation until the town asked for a proposal from Fairfield 2000 last year.
The group's latest venture in Stamford is the proposed conversion of 300 Broad Street, an office building it has under contract, into 69 apartments expected to sell for $25,000 to $35,000. The city is considering using its allocation of $1.8 million from the Federal Housing and Urban Development Department to finance up to $15,000 of renovations for each unit, said Timothy Beeble, director of the Stamford Community Development Agency.
Designed as an apartment house in 1971, the nine-story building was switched to offices in an attempt to cash in on the market. When the recession hit and most of its tenants left, the Pacific Mutual Life Insurance Company became the owner by foreclosure. "The asking price is $1.5 million," said James Fagan, broker with CB Commercial. "In 1986, it sold for $8 million."
While there is no rush to turn empty office buildings into apartments, Mr. Redniss said there were some buildings on Summer Street that would be adaptable.
"This does reduce the office vacancy rate and addresses a type of housing for which some companies moved elsewhere," he said.
Summer Street, which runs north from downtown Stamford, contains a mix of old and new buildings.
FAIRFIELD 2000's foray into Westport involved taking over Wassell Lane, a one-block development of 16 similar cottages built in the 50's by the Federal Government. Just south of the Merritt Parkway off Main Street, they once housed Army personnel who worked at nearby sites.
With the Army long gone, the Government put the cottages up for sale in 1990. Working with Fairfield 2000, Westport acquired them with a state grant of $672,000.
"Because the houses had been there and created no negative situation, nobody objected to recycling them for low-income people," said Catherine Barnard, Westport's planning director. "We rezoned for quarter-acre lots and got the necessary setback variances."
The one-story, three-bedroom, one-bathroom houses were refurbished and new septic systems were installed under grandfathered zoning. Three homes were set aside for use by homeless women with children for periods of a year.
The rest of the units, some with garages, were advertised and sold for $88,750 to $99,750 in the last few months. They were assigned by lottery to applicants with jobs who qualified as first-time buyers. Income limits set for Fairfield County by the state Housing Department range from a minimum of $27,900 for a single person to a maximum of $62,200 for a family of six. Units may be resold only to similarly qualified buyers, and appreciation is limited to 5 percent a year beginning at the third year.
AMONG the new owners is Joseph DeMattio, a young mechanic who grew up in Westport.
"I always hoped to buy a house, but prices got so inflated it was impossible," he said.
Like the Quinoneses, he will pay the same amount for mortgage, taxes and insurance each month, around $700, as he did for rent in Norwalk, but he has a three-bedroom house and will be reunited with friends who also bought homes in Wassell Lane.
George Davon, a Danbury developer, contacted Fairfield 2000 for help in getting qualified buyers under Federal Housing Administration and Connecticut Housing Finance Authority programs for Liberty Terrace, his 35-unit complex in Danbury's downtown renewal area. He financed the $3 million project independently and since breaking ground last December he has sold 24 of the 25 completed units.
The two-bedroom, one- and two-story homes, some with terraces, are fully equipped and carpeted. They are priced at $78,900 and $98,900.
"As long as the market stays as tight as it is," Mr. Davon said, "developers will work in affordable housing. And those who do so need to team up with a nonprofit partner. Otherwise, many doors to financing and the market place are closed to them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jose and Caroline Quinones and two daughters live in a unit they bought at Waterside Green, a development in Stamford. (Carl David LaBianca for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: 55 Water Street;
New Start for a Troubled Building

 BODY:
Finally, the end of a painful odyssey for a troubled building: Last week the ownership of the 52-story, 3.6 million-square-foot 55 Water Street was formally transferred from Olympia & York to the New Water Street Corporation, the majority of which is owned by the Retirement Systems of Alabama. And now the more pleasant journey begins: taking the once-debt-laden building from run-down property to modern corporate center.
It won't be a quick trip or a cheap one. It will cost well over $20 million to remove asbestos. The new owners plan to install a back-up electrical system to end, once and for all, the electricity outages that have plagued the building. And they've just hired the architects Kohn Pedersen Fox to come up with an extensive cosmetic remodeling plan as well. 
 The building, which is now free of debt, has time on its side. It is 65 percent occupied, with few leases rolling over before 1997. The new owners do not plan a major marketing push until most of the renovations are complete. "We want to show prospective tenants results, not just give them promises," said David G. Bronner, the Retirement Systems of Alabama's chief executive officer.
Dr. Bronner seems undaunted by what many would see as a huge gamble on a recession-ravaged section of New York. "We have great faith in the prospects of downtown Manhattan," he said.

LENGTH: 1189 words

HEADLINE: Clinton Emboldens Advocates of More Pacific Trade

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
EVEN as it struggles to gain Congressional approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement, the Clinton Administration is casting its eyes across the Pacific.
It envisions a gradual dismantling of trade barriers between the United States and Pacific nations and perhaps someday a free trade area similar to that of Nafta. A Pacific free trade area could bring even more rewards to the American economy than some people expect from Nafta, but might be an even harder sell domestically. 
 For the moment, Administration officials say, the vehicle for integrating the United States with the fast-growing economies across the Pacific is the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, or APEC. While the 4-year-old organization is little known outside a rarefied group of policy makers and business executives, it could gain a wider following when President Clinton hosts a summit conference next month in Seattle attended by the heads of 14 of the 15 APEC countries.
In their dreamier moments, supporters of APEC inside and outside the Administration foresee a gigantic free trade zone that encompasses East Asia, Australia and parts of the Western Hemisphere, an entity with more than enough economic muscle to help set world trade policy.
Indeed, interest in the region is the same as Willie Sutton's for picking banks to rob: It's where the money is. "This is the dynamic area of the world economy," said C. Fred Bergsten, an economist who heads the Institute for International Economics in Washington and a consultant for APEC. "Europe's dead in the water. Latin America's improving, but still has a lot of problems."
If the idea of a Pacific Rim trading bloc gains momentum, some countries left out might decide to push harder to complete trade talks under way among 116 countries. Those talks are aimed at lowering tariffs and expanding the free trade rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to cover services and agriculture for the first time.
Fifteen countries comprise APEC: Australia, Brunei, Canada, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States. Together they contain 40 percent of the world's population and have a combined gross domestic product of $13 trillion. Last year, the United States did $344 billion in merchandise trade with countries across the Pacific, far above its $265 billion in trade with Canada and Mexico and its $228 billion with Western Europe, according to the Commerce Department.
"Even today there are about 2.5 million jobs in the U.S. that are dependent on Asian trade, and that does not include Canada," said Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative. "As you look at APEC nations you see tremendous potential for growth in that trade."
Yet the euphoria that surrounds discussions of APEC is punctured by some hard-edged questions. Can APEC evolve into anything more than a group of countries that does little more than talk about trade liberalization? Will the protectionist forces giving the Administration fits over Nafta allow free trade with Asian countries which are much tougher competitors than Mexico? Can the United States work alongside countries with which it is often at odds over issues like human rights and weapons proliferation.
Some proponents worry that pushing the group to do too much too fast could shatter its consensus. "It's a baby, it's a child," said William Bodde Jr., executive director of APEC's secretariat, in Singapore. "If you load it down with too much baggage, it will never grow up."
APEC adherents hope the group will gain from the meeting hosted by President Clinton in Seattle on Nov. 19-20. "What we'd like to see coming out of Seattle is a reinforcement from the leaders that APEC makes sense," said Donald Russell, Australia's Ambassador to the United States.
At the meeting, the first ever held just with a large group of Pacific Rim nations, the leaders are expected to ratify an agreement to work toward a code that will govern private investments in member countries.
In addition, the leaders are expected to endorse a statement of principles on other issues, including harmonization of standards for products and service. For example, certification by one APEC member that a product is safe would be accepted by all members.
The leaders will also discuss accepting Mexico, Chile and Papua New Guinea as members.
But if APEC could someday be an economic Godzilla, it currently seemslike an uncertain college sophomore: It doesn't know what it wants to be. While all the countries want to liberalize trade, there are differences on how fast -- and even whether -- APEC should be transformed into a formal body that negotiates tariff reductions or settles disputes.
Some countries, including the United States, Canada, South Korea, Australia and New Zealand, are pressing APEC to move faster toward becoming a formalized body with some teeth. But they acknowledge that making APEC into something resembling GATT or the European Community could take 10 to 20 years.
At the other extreme, some members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or ASEAN, particularly Malaysia, worry that larger economies, especially those of the United States and Japan, will use the organization to dominate the region. Indeed, the Prime Minister of Malaysia, Mahathir Mohamad, is boycotting the Seattle meeting.
To find a coherent strategy, the organization set up a group of economists, former Cabinet officials and academics headed by Mr. Bergsten. Mr. Bergsten said he wanted to move APEC toward concrete accomplishments, including a dispute-resolution mechanism.
His group will present a report in Seattle that will call for the establishment of an investment code that will assure private investors that their capital will be protected and that earnings can be repatriated.
Given the nebulous nature of APEC, some economists said the Clinton Administration should not place too much emphasis on the group, at the expense of bilateral talks with nations like Japan and China. "I just don't think a great nation like the United States should be relying on what is really a group that is not ready to take on the needed task of doing more than talking about trade liberalization," said Paula Stern, an economist in Washington.
Hovering over the talk of a Pacific trade zone is concern over the fate of Nafta. Many Pacific Rim leaders worry that a defeat of Nafta would empower protectionist forces in the United States, who would resist free trade across the Pacific.
Whether or not APEC becomes something more concrete, some say they think it is already having some impact. They say fear of a regional trade bloc might make some countries, most notably France, show more flexibility in the current GATT negotiations. Said Lawrence Krause, a professor of economics at the University of California at San Diego's Graduate School of International Relations and Pacific Studies: "If you're the French, and believe that the U.S. and Japan have other alternatives to the GATT, you've got to think twice."

HEADLINE: Interface: People and Technology;
All Quiet in Economy Class

BYLINE: By HANS FANTEL

 BODY:
NO, I didn't sleep. I can never sleep on airplanes. But after more than eight hours overnight from Kennedy International Airport I arrived in Vienna surprisingly rested and fresh.
The Noise Buster, a new portable device to combat stress and fatigue caused by noise, did the trick. Basically a small electronic box wired to a pair of Sony MDR-84 stereo headphones, the system can create what seems like a personal island of quiet in noisy settings like planes, trains, buses or factories. 
 Ear plugs or bulky ear protectors, which can cut down the higher frequencies, are ineffective against low droning sounds like airplane engine noises, which penetrate mechanical barriers. It is precisely such throbbing vibrations that can cause tension and fatigue.
The Noise Buster deals with sound of this kind by artificially creating "anti-noise," which, for the person wearing the earphones, cancels the unwanted noise in the environment.
Until now, devices of this kind came with four-figure prices and were used mainly by the military. At $149, the Noise Buster, made by Noise Cancellation Technologies Inc. of Stamford, Conn., is the first model priced for the average consumer. A similar kind of anti-noise headset is under development by the Koss Corporation of Milwaukee, the largest maker of earphones in the United States.
The device uses a technology known as active noise cancellation, in which unwanted sound waves are snuffed out by the sound waves of the same frequency but in opposite phase. It as if a two-foot ocean wave were to meet a two-foot trough; the result would be flat water. So, too, when a sound wave meets its mirror opposite, a sonic calm is created.
As a journalist who writes about audio equipment, I was lent a Noise Buster for a working vacation with my wife, Shea, to my native Austria. When I slipped on the earphones during the flight, it suddenly seemed that the plane, a two-engine Airbus 320, had stopped flying and was quietly hovering in midair. A person tends to associate engine noise with motion, so when the noise stops we think the plane is standing still. Very relaxing.
Despite the feeling of sonic privacy, I wasn't really isolated. My wife, sitting next to me, could easily talk with me because the Noise Buster does not block frequencies above 1,500 hertz that make human speech intelligible. But because the lower frequencies were missing, it sounded as if she were talking on the telephone.
Other ambient noise -- a rushing sound reminiscent of ocean surf -- also persisted. But the more disturbing growl of the aircraft was virtually eliminated.
When the movie, "Groundhog Day," started in mid-Atlantic, I plugged the Noise Buster into the electronic earphone outlet on the armrest. Although it was a rather tame movie, I was surprised that the crucial scenes seemed to pack quite an emotional punch. Later I figured out why. The muffled roar of background noise that normally flattens the dialogue of in-flight movies had been filtered out by the Noise Buster. The actors' vocal nuances came through crisp and clear.
Although it can make plane travel more restful, the Noise Buster can't eliminate jet lag. After all, it can't change time zones or reset the diurnal clock we all carry in our biological systems. So I still woke up at odd hours after arriving in Austria, and I got hungry at the wrong times.
 HANS FANTEL

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sonically calm at 35,000 feet. (Hans Fantel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: JAMAICA;
Merchants Say a Change in Bus Routes Hurts

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
Merchants in downtown Jamaica are once again fighting to preserve what they regard as the key to their economic well-being, the very thing they say insures the return of their customers each day: bus routes.
The Transit Authority last month began rerouting six bus lines that ran along Jamaica Avenue, the neighborhood's main commercial strip. The goal was to improve service to and from the Archer Avenue station, a stop on the E, F and J subway lines. 
 Many shop owners say the changes have already started to divert customers from the area. Last month, a group of merchants, along with the Jamaica Chamber of Commerce, sued to block the rerouting, but a judge dismissed the case.
"This is taking our livelihood away," said Fairfax Hackley, the manager of Gibbs Men Wear at 163-26 Jamaica Avenue, who says his rush-hour business is down 25 percent. "It's like taking a parking lot away from a shopping mall. It's like taking Penn Station away from 34th Street."
The standoff comes nearly four years after the authority agreed to expand bus service along Jamaica Avenue after an earlier lawsuit filed by local merchants.
"It's happening again," lamented Steven Alschuler, a spokesman for the Chamber of Commerce.
The latest rerouting was instituted after the city's Department of Traffic changed Archer Avenue from a one-way westbound street to two-way. The Q4, Q5, Q42, Q83, Q84 and Q85 bus lines were rerouted from Jamaica Avenue to Archer Avenue.
Before the changes, the buses traveled along Archer to the Archer Avenue subway station and then returned along Jamaica -- a route that transit officials say increased congestion and forced riders to use alternate means of transportation, including illegal vans.
The authority says the changes have already reduced travel time. "There's certainly been a vast improvement," said Jared S. Lebow, a spokesman. The authority also says that keeping the bus lines on Jamaica, given that it, like Archer, has been divided into east- and west-bound strips, would be disastrous for commuters.
And it says that the overall benefits for the neighborhood outweigh the relatively narrow concerns of the Jamaica Avenue group.
But officials at the Jamaica Chamber of Commerce say they plan to continue fighting. They recently conducted an informal survey and say that about 88 percent of the 80 merchants reported losses. Wertheimer's department store reported losing 20 percent of its rush-hour business; the store recently laid off 30 people to make up for its losses.
"We are hoping something will be done about this," said Jamie Brayan, the manager of Wertheimer's, who said the store moved there four years ago to cater to commuters.
"This is choking us," he added. "We don't know how long we will be able to maintain business this way." RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

HEADLINE: CLINTON;
Sex Industry Defends Itself

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Behind the yellow blinking lights of Manhattan Video, an adult store on 39th Street off Fifth Avenue, leaders of a new association met on Thursday to discuss strategy. The group, yet to be named, has a clear goal: to defend the sex industry against neighborhood protests and moves by the city toward increased regulation.
A loose coalition of some 50 sex businesses, the association was formed in reaction to the Manhattan Borough President's Task Force on the Regulation of Sex-Related Businesses, which was established last spring to address complaints about the spread of sex businesses in residential areas. 
 Richard N. Kunis, owner of Manhattan Video, said the first task was to survey the sex industry, including adult book dealers, novelty stores, strip clubs and topless bars. The association hopes to persuade the task force that the industry is economically valuable and does not promote crime.
At public hearings Wednesday, a dozen people in adult video and theater testified about objections to the task force. Most called the 30-member panel invalid because sex businesses were not represented.
But Douglas Turetsky, deputy director of policy and budget for Borough President Ruth W. Messinger, said the panel included "a diversity of opinions," adding that until now there has been no way to identify sex industry representatives.
Several witnesses said that sex businesses increase prostitution and drug dealing in neighborhoods. Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project, said that in 1990, after the removal of many sex-related shops from 42d Street, crime dropped 60 percent. Susan Herman, founder of the Chelsea Action Coalition, called for new zoning to keep sex businesses out of residential areas.
Mr. Kunis, who has been in the adult video business for eight years, defended his colleagues: "We are law-abiding, taxpaying citizens with children." M.H.

HEADLINE: CO-OP CITY;
Countering a Surge in Vacancies

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
Faced with the highest vacancy rate in its history, Co-op City has cut its staff and set out to lure buyers, providing low-interest loans, shortening the review process and offering for the first time wall-to-wall carpeting over the parquet floors.
While Co-op City officials said the vacancy rate peaked in July, the number of empty apartments has nearly doubled in the last year, to 1,200. As with other Mitchell-Lama apartments, owners sell their apartments back to the complex, for equity. The vacancies have led to concerns over cash shortages at the sprawling, 15,372-unit complex in the northeast Bronx, a 300-acre community with shopping malls, schools, community centers and its own power plant. 
 The situation has a strange resonance in the city's history. When Co-op City opened 23 years ago, offering subsidized housing to middle-income families, it drew many Jewish families from the Grand Concourse and other parts of the South Bronx. Those areas had in turn been settled by families from the Lower East Side. In each case, the vacuum was filled by new, often poorer groups.
"The same thing happened to the Grand Concourse," said James W. Parker, vice president of a co-op owners' association at the complex. "At one time there was a waiting list to get into Co-op City, but now people are moving out faster than they're being replaced."
Co-op officials and residents say the vacancies reflect the poor economy and the departure of original residents who have retired and moved to other states.
Concern over the diminishing base of maintenance fees has forced the cooperative's management group, the Riverbay Corporation, to reduce services. Nearly 100 gardeners, plumbers, janitors and other workers -- about 10 percent of the work force -- have been laid off in recent months.
Some residents worry that more reductions could compromise the stability of Co-op City, which operates on an annual budget of $128 million.
The Riverbay Corporation has reduced the initial payment that prospective buyers must put down, from $2,800 per room to $1,750 per room, and that has yielded results. Since July, there have been 638 applicants, up from about 700 in all of 1992. R.H.

HEADLINE: HARLEM;
Getting Respect From City Hall

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
Michael Anglin stood amid weeds, broken glass and discarded needles in Morningside Park on a hill overlooking the paddleball courts at 122d Street, where he and his friends play after work. Eight blocks down, across the critical divide between the Upper West Side and Harlem, are a well-kept baseball diamond, new playground equipment and a waterfall, all of which the city has installed over the last few years.
"There are two parks," Mr. Anglin said. "It's like this is two towns." 
 Against what appear to be economic and political odds, he and his group are trying to remove that divide.
Four years ago, the Parks Department started to renovate Morningside Park, which stretches from 110th to 123d Streets. It started in the southern section, much of which had been closed since 1968, when Columbia University abandoned plans to build a gymnasium on the public property in the face of student protests.
Last summer, construction was completed on the part of the park from 110th to 114th Streets, with Columbia contributing $250,000 of the $5 million spent. Officials said they did not have money to do substantial work on the northern end.
The City Parks Foundation, a nonprofit group, donated some new equipment for a playground at 123d Street last year, said Bob Redmond, a member of the department's Manhattan staff, and the Parks Department is planning to renovate a stairway at 116th Street that he says is the section of the park in the worst condition.
Mr. Anglin and his Morningside Paddleball Players' Association have other concerns. "We began to feel that the only way you get respect is when you organize and you are angry," he said. "You have to compel them to think about you the way they would think about other parks in the city."
The association and its parent, Harlem Initiatives Together, an organization of groups and churches that is committed to increasing local political power, met with city officials last year. The northern section of Morningside Park is heavily used, they said, and needs major renovations as well as regular maintenance, constant police patrols and lights so residents who work days can use the park at night.
Patrick J. Pomposello, the Parks Department Commissioner for Manhattan, called the meeting curt. He said the department has tried to respond to the group's concerns, but that there is only one maintenance worker assigned to the entire 31-acre park.
The lights around the paddleball court are scheduled to go up this week, he said.
The group also asked to form a committee with the Parks Department to help plan capital improvements. Pastors from three churches that are near the park and use it for church functions said they would help solicit money to pay for projects.
"They want results and I don't blame them," Mr. Pomposello said. "But they're talking about real capital dollars. It's going to take I don't know how many millions to finish renovating that park, and we don't have any money in our budget."
Mr. Anglin said his group, which had done its own maintenance at the paddleball courts, would continue to press the city.
"Believe it or not, this is much better than it was," Mr. Anglin said as he trampled fallen branches and garbage along the pathways. "But you would never see anything like this in Central Park. Well, this is our Central Park." EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

HEADLINE: CONEY ISLAND;
Small Merchants Sprucing Up Along Mermaid Avenue

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

 BODY:
Because of a recent influx of city, state and private funds, the dilapidated mom-and-pop businesses along Mermaid Avenue are sprucing up and expanding in hopes of attracting families drawn to the area by an urban renewal program.
More than 2,000 people have moved in since 1981, filling the 700 homes built under urban renewal, but they tend to shop at the larger, more modern stores in Bensonhurst, Mill Basin and Bay Ridge. 
 And the population growth seems far from over. Construction began last month on 148 single-family homes on the side streets around Mermaid Avenue, a bustling shopping hub in the 1960's but the victim of a long decline. A Westchester-based developer, North American Properties, has already signed 65 contracts on the two-story homes, which go for $111,500.
"Our goal is to keep people in the community and provide the services they need," said Judith Orlando, executive director of Estella Development, a grass-roots organization whose charge is to provide affordable housing and initiate commercial revitalization in Coney Island.
Estella has received $240,000 in grant money for revitalization from the state Urban Development Corporation and the Manhattan-based Local Initiative Support Corporation. The money is used to match funds the merchants put up to refurbish their stores. Twenty of the 38 merchants along the mile-and-a-half commercial strip are restoring their buildings and repairing awnings and signs.
"Once they see awnings going up, we will have more merchants participating," Ms. Orlando predicted.
The revitalization coincides with the start of a $4.2 million project at the corner of West 17th Street and Mermaid Avenue. It includes two single-story buildings with four storefronts that will house a dental office, an ice cream store and a new office for Estella Development, and, in a nearby lot, a one-story storefront that will house a funeral parlor and a day care center.
"Coney Island is not dead, not by any means," said James Prince, owner of Major Meat Market at 1514 Mermaid Avenue, who received $4,000 to help upgrade his store. "There are still a lot of us here who have faith because we have the potential -- a wonderful beach and prime real estate. It just takes time. It took a long time for this community to go down. It will take a long time for it to go back up." LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Ms. Kelley, Mr. Southworth 3d

 BODY:
Mary Kathryn Kelley, the daughter of Rosemary and Kevin Kelley of West Point, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Hamilton Southworth 3d, the son of Eleanor and Hamilton Southworth Jr. of New York. The Rev. Richard Funk, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony in the Old Cadet Chapel at the United States Military Academy.
Ms. Kelley is keeping her name. She graduated from Mills College, and she and her husband, both 27, are to graduate from the University of Virginia School of Law in December. They plan to practice law next spring in San Diego, where she is to become an associate at Brobeck, Phleger & Harrison and he an associate at Klinedinst, Fliehman, McKillop & Jones. 
 Her father, an Army colonel, oversees field recruiters for the department of admissions at the Academy and teaches economics there. Her mother teaches job-search skills in Newburgh, N.Y., for the New York State Division of Adult Education.
Mr. Southworth graduated from Yale University. His mother is the coordinator of alumnae affairs at the Chapin School in New York. His father is a computer systems consultant, in Weehawken, N.J,, with Paine Webber, the securities brokerage.

HEADLINE: HOME CLINIC;
Last Chances to Caulk Before Winter's Onslaught

BYLINE: By JOHN WARDE

 BODY:
ALL houses eventually need fresh caulking. The purpose of the compound, often called caulking or caulk, is to seal gaps and cracks that develop between materials. Unless the openings are sealed drafts can develop. Even worse, moisture can penetrate walls.
Any season except winter is a good time to renew caulking. In the winter temperatures are generally too cold to apply caulking. It flows poorly and will not harden when the thermometer dips below 50. 
 Tour the exterior of the house to examine the caulking around door and window frames, where siding joins at corners and meets the roof and foundation, around wall and roof vents, skylights and chimneys, around outdoor faucets and where plumbing and electric lines enter the house. Cracked or loose caulking has to be replaced. Any missing from those areas has to be added.
Read caulking labels carefully. The most important qualities are life expectancy, whether the material can be painted and whether cleanup is with soap and water or a solvent like paint thinner. A high-quality acrylic latex caulk is a good choice. Besides having a life expectancy of at least 20 years, it adheres to most surfaces, is easy to apply without being sticky and accepts paint.
A drawback is that the caulking sometimes shrinks severely. It is not recommended for cracks wider than about half an inch without special procedures.
Siliconized caulking, which contains a small amount of silicone, shrinks less and sometimes flows more smoothly. But cleaning up silicone caulking requires a solvent. Pure silicone caulking cannot be painted.
High-performance caulks containing polysulfide, polyurethane, ethylene copolymer and other compounds compete well. Pure latex has a short life expectancy, but is inexpensive and accepts paint well. It is a good choice for surfaces that will be painted every three to five years. It is also economical to use when preparing a house for sale.
Butyl caulk is recommended for masonry and metal, because it is very sticky. But it has a short life expectancy, requires a solvent for cleanup and does not accept paint. Virtually all high-quality or high-performance caulks adhere as well as butyl and perform better.
Caulk comes in cylindrical cartridges and is applied with a caulking gun that forces the material out of the tube. Guns that cradle the cartridge in a curved metal pan are the most popular and often the least expensive. But guns that contain the cartridge between two parallel metal strips, one above the cartridge and one below it, are also available.
Handy features on some guns are a built-in spout cutter, which eliminates having to slice off the ends of cartridge nozzles with a utility knife; a puncture tool, which ends having to use a long nail to open the seal in the cartridge, and a wrist strap, which frees hands.
To load a conventional gun, squeeze the trigger or press the ratchet-release tab on the handle, pull back on the plunger, and fit the cartridge into the gun, rear end first. Next, squeeze the trigger a few times until the plunger contacts the rear of the cartridge, but do not apply too much pressure.
Finally, slice off the end of the cartridge at a 45-degree angle and break the seal inside by inserting a long nail, ice pick or similar tool into the opening. With a gun having a spout-cutter and puncture tool, open the cartridge before inserting it.
Most caulk, especially latex varieties, work best to seal joints that are less than a half-inch deep or wide. Fill deeper cracks with wadded fiberglass or plastic backer rod. Wider cracks can usually be bridged by applying two strips of caulk side by side.
To apply caulk make sure that the surface is clean and dry. Pry out old caulk, brush away particles and wipe the area with mineral spirits. Place the nozzle of the cartridge against one end of the seam to be filled so that the gun forms a 45-degree angle with the seam. Squeeze the trigger to make the caulk flow while pushing or pulling the gun along the seam. Pushing the gun forces caulk into narrow seams better than pulling, but either technique is correct.
Move the gun evenly. Caulking will adhere better if the gun is moved slowly. Learn to keep the gun moving between trigger strokes and adjust the speed to how the compound emerges from the nozzle.
To stop caulking at the end of a seam, push the nozzle into the corner to sever the strip and then twist the nozzle sharply while lifting the gun away. Pull the plunger away from the rear of the cartridge immediately to prevent caulk from oozing from the nozzle. Wipe off the tip before starting a new seam.
Caulking need not be smoothed after application, except for appearance. Smoothing caulking as it dries sometimes causes cracking. If you decide to smooth caulk use the back of a spoon dipped in a solvent. With latex caulk use a finger dipped in water. Allow caulk to dry according to the instructions before painting.

GRAPHIC: Diagrams: Apply caulking to openings where moisture might penetrate. To load gun, pull back plunger and insert cartridge rear end first. Gun with parallel-strip design delivers straight thrust. Guide nozzle at an angle along seam. (Edward Lipinski)

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: HARM'S WAY;
U. S. Pays Dearly For an Education In Somalia

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
HOW did an operation that began with American soldiers feeding starving Somalis wind up with an American soldier's corpse being dragged through the streets of Mogadishu by Somalis starving only for revenge?
The answer is a tangled web of good intentions gone awry, political miscalculations and military blunders. Together they add up to a chilling object lesson for American engagement abroad in the post-cold war world. 
 But the Somalia story is not over. President Clinton made that clear in his address to the nation last week when, in response to mounting American casualties in the Somali capital and growing domestic opposition to the American involvement there, he announced a doubling of United States ground forces to protect American troops and a March 31 deadline for their withdrawal.
There is a lot riding on how that deadline is met. If a measure of normalcy can yet be restored and Somalia becomes an example of a reasonably successful humanitarian relief operation, there may be hope for Bosnia or Haiti or other failed states desperately in need of outside help as they limp and moan toward the 21st century.
But if Somalia becomes the Beirut or Vietnam of the 1990's, it could have a far-reaching impact. Taken on its own, this little country on the Horn of Africa is irrelevant to vital American interests. Life in America will not be affected whether Somalia wallows in anarchy or emerges from the ashes. But there are other Somalias. Each on its own also represents no threat to vital American interests. But what happens if they are all ignored -- Somalia, Bosnia, Georgia, Nagorno-Karabakh and Haiti -- and who knows how many others to come? One answer is that the United States could wake up 10 years from now and discover that the world has diplomatic cancer -- a mass of failed states metastasizing in a cycle of violence and underdevelopment and slowly sapping the strength of the international system.
 
Needed: Order From Chaos
 That is what makes learning the lessons of Somalia so urgent. Perhaps the most important is that there is rarely such a thing as simple humanitarian intervention, where the United States goes into a country solely to feed the hungry and pass out chewing gum. Humanitarian crises, save for natural disasters, almost always have political roots and can be addressed in a lasting way only if the political problems are addressed. Somalia was short of food not because of bad rains, but because of bad reigns -- a succession of venal warlords whose infighting after the 1991 overthrow of the dictator Mohammed Siad Barre disrupted food distribution.
In the long run, it will be impossible for the Somalia operation to succeed without a working government. Virtually all humanitarian interventions require nation-building. The Reagan Administration learned this rule the hard way in Lebanon, the Bush Administration ignored it when it sent American troops to Somalia last December and the Clinton Administration, which inherited the operation, has been only slowly catching on. In such cases, humanitarian intervention has to be accompanied by a division of diplomats with blueprints for political reconstruction.
If it is true that humanitarian intervention and nation-building go hand-in-hand, the question becomes: does the United States have the will, the wallet and the wiles to make it work?
 
Just Another Faction
 The question of wiles arises because when the United States enters a country with no stable political center, it immediately becomes a faction; politics won't stop because people are hungry. American troops in Somalia saw themselves as the Red Cross, but local political leaders effectively viewed them as the Clinton clan, or, as the Lebanese used to call the Marine peacekeepers in Beirut in 1982, "the international militia."
The Clinton clan had three choices in Somalia: to ally itself with another clan and help it take power, to try to take over the country itself, or to try to broker a power-sharing deal. Unfortunately, the Americans stumbled among all three options, sometimes aligning themselves against the warlord Mohammed Farah Aidid, sometimes brokering deals and sometimes leaving Somalis the impression that the United States would try to run the country.
Thinking like a clan leader does not come naturally to the American statesman. To play this role requires a degree of guile and willingness to absorb pain that Americans were initially unprepared for in Somalia. The key is learning how to bend, how to wink and nod, how to pressure people indirectly and how to play factions off against one another. In his dealings with General Aidid, Adm. Jonathan Howe, the man overseeing the American operation in Mogadishu, has been noticeably lacking in these instincts. There is something almost farcical about the notion of the United Nations issuing an arrest warrant for General Aidid in Mogadishu: habeas corpus in Dante's Inferno, Miranda rights in no man's land.
President Clinton has finally decided that the American clan will play a brokering role in Somalia. He has dispatched the envoy Robert Oakley back to the country this weekend with authorization to wheel and deal.
"We have no interest in denying anybody access to playing a role in Somalia's political future," Mr. Clinton said on Friday, signaling his willingness to include General Aidid in a power-sharing accord provided he returns an American captive and plays ball politically.
There is an old rabbinical saying: "Where there is truth there is no peace and where there is peace there is no truth." It conveys the notion that gray compromises are what make life possible, and that is particularly true when nation-building in a place like Mogadishu.
As for the ability of American forces to absorb pain, the death of one soldier on a mercy mission to Somalia is one too many. But a soldier's job is to fight. Some Americans seem to have forgotten in recent years that you join the Army not just to get a G.I. loan. There is something slightly hysterical about members of Congress rushing to call the troops home the minute a few are killed.
On the other hand, the Bush and Clinton Administrations helped to produce that frenzy by not leveling with the American people from the start that humanitarian intervention and nation-building are high-risk endeavors. Americans were told that their soldiers were being sent to work in a soup kitchen and they were understandably shocked to find them in house-to-house combat.
Had all the risks, pain and costs of humanitarian intervention been laid out by President Bush to the American people from the start, President Clinton might now have more time to see it through to reasonable success. As it happens, he has been forced by Congress to impose a six-month time limit to give the process "a fighting chance." But since the Americans have already bought a departure ticket, Somalia's warlords are likely to lie low and wait the Americans out. Meanwhile, would-be Somali reformers will hardly be emboldened by the likelihood that when the Americans leave, accounts will be settled in time-honored Somali ways. This six-month interregnum seems more like a decent interval to cover a retreat than a serious initiative; you don't do nation-building with a stopwatch.
In fairness to Mr. Clinton, he is only doing what the country wants. But this is a moment of truth for him too. From the start, Mr. Clinton has understood that America does not have the economic resources to remain engaged abroad as it was during the cold war. But Mr. Clinton wanted to maintain an active, pro-democracy agenda abroad, up to the traditional American leadership role. He hoped that through the United Nations the United States could lead and that many others would pay.
But there is no free lunch in diplomacy. As the United Nations naturally took on a nation-building role, the Clinton Administration paid little heed even as it voted for each resolution. Things were quiet; Somalia seemed the sort of low-maintenance, high-political-reward operation that the Clinton team had in mind. But that equation was exploded by last Sunday's street fighting in Mogadishu, exposing the 33-country United Nations peacekeeping unit in Somalia as a Tower of Babel, and driving home to Americans the real, weighty role they would have to play if Somalia is to succeed.
"I don't think we will give up trying to use the U.N. to leverage our involvement to do things that are worth doing, but not worth doing alone," said an Administration official. "But I think we will be far more skeptical about the ability of the United Nations to operate without vigorous involvement of the United States. Ultimately the U.N. is us. You can't hand off to an entity that is a bunch of bureaucrats who have never done this before."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The States' Stakes In Clinton's Health Plan

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ANY social program as vast and complex as President Clinton's health-care plan has to have disparate effects on a country as vast and complex as the United States. For all of its specificity, the plan has left the states trying to figure whether they would be winners or losers.
Take Texas, the state with the highest percentage of workers (25.3 percent) who have no health insurance. By requiring all employers to pay for health insurance, the plan would hit Texas businesses especially hard. But this mandate should mean better health care for 3.8 million uninsured Texans. 
 The pain that the state feels would be offset, at least in part, by its disproportionate share of the more than $80 billion in yearly subsidies that Mr. Clinton has promised to small, low-wage employers and Americans with low incomes. Florida, Mississippi, Alabama, Louisiana and Arkansas are in the same situation, with a high rate of uninsured workers but low wages that would make many eligible for subsidies.
Compare those states with Connecticut, which has the lowest percentage (8.8 percent) of uninsured workers. As a result, the employer mandate would do minimal damage to Connecticut business. But as a high-wage state, Connecticut is expected to receive little in the way of subsidies. New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Michigan have the same pattern.
Some economists predict that the plan would funnel tens of billions of dollars from the high-wage North to the low-wage South by the year 2000. Members of Congress from the Northeast and Midwest have even asked for a meeting with Hillary Rodham Clinton about the matter.
"We're concerned about the redistributional effects," said Paula Duggan, a senior policy analyst at the Northeast-Midwest Institute, which does research for members of Congress from those two regions. "We're concerned that these subsidies will benefit the South at the expense of the Northeast and Midwest."
But Administration officials deny that the health plan would redistribute wealth from North to South, insisting that it will merely take money from cigarette taxes and health care savings to pay for the subsidies.
Midwestern states should not cry too much, the officials say, because Mr. Clinton has thrown several scraps their way. Heavy industry concentrated in these states, especially auto, steel and rubber companies, have grumbled nonstop about medical costs gobbling up 12, 15, even 20 percent of their payrolls. Those industries should benefit most from the proposed 7.9 percent limit on the amount of an employer's payroll going to health insurance. The industrial Midwest should also benefit from the President's proposal to have Washington assume most of the corporate burden of insuring early retirees.
As for the Northeast, Administration officials say New York and New Jersey would also receive a bundle of subsidies because those states have high medical costs and many low-wage workers and families on welfare.
California has different concerns. It has the highest rate (30.6 percent) of participation in health maintenance organizations. This means that when Mr. Clinton's plan pushes doctors and hospitals to begin a frenetic minuet to find partners and form networks, California would not undergo the same degree of upheaval as some other states. Nor would Californians, who are generally familiar with managed care, feel that they were plunging blindly into a social experiment. Minnesota, Oregon, Massachusetts are in the same position, with high participation in H.M.O.'s.
But since those states are already chopping away at health-care inflation, the Clinton plan may not offer them as much help in restraining costs.
On the other end of the spectrum are Montana and North Dakota, where just 1 percent of the population belongs to H.M.O.'s. Hardly anyone expects it to be easy for those states to form networks that join doctors from small communities dozens of miles apart.
"Managed care is going to be a whole new way of life in a state like North Dakota," said Stephen Raetzman, a health-care expert at Towers Perrin, a consulting firm. "It's a very different process from regular fee-for-service medicine."
The good news for rural states is that the President's plan promises billions of dollars for care in underserved areas.
In contrast, the Middle Atlantic states are overserved, many health-care experts say, meaning they have an excess of hospitals. As the Clinton plan strives to squeeze down costs, New York hospitals might be hit hard, although the savings would help employers and patients.
John Gannon, chief health-care consultant at KPMG Peat Marwick, noted that Medicare beneficiaries on the East Coast spend three days in the hospital a year on average -- about double the level on the West Coast. "The amount of care on the East Coast far exceeds the West Coast," said Mr. Gannon. "I think we'll see a significant downsizing of the in-patient health-care system in New York and New Jersey."
The President's plan would have unusual effects on the New York area for another reason: the huge number of New Jersey and Connecticut residents work in Manhattan and receive medical care there. A big question is whether New Jersey and Connecticut residents who sign up with health plans in their home states would be able to continue visiting New York doctors and hospitals. No problem, Administration officials say, asserting that Manhattan doctors and hospitals will be free to participate in New Jersey and Connecticut health-care networks; doctors reply that that is easier said than done.
"Developing health plans in the New York metropolitan marketplace isn't going to be easy because it involves three states and because of the population density," said Mr. Gannon. "It's going to be a slow, very complex process."
