HEADLINE: Slump in Business Lending Has Prime Rate Stuck at 6%

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
While the Clinton Administration counts on low interest rates to revive the economy, the banking industry is coming to a different conclusion: The demand for loans to expand business activity is so weak that lowering the prime rate is not worth their while.
"Simply stated, my customers don't borrow more because we lower rates; they borrow if they see an opportunity to use the borrowed money, and they don't see that opportunity," said Frank Lourenso, an executive vice president at Chemical Bank. His view was echoed in a half-dozen interviews with other bank executives and industry officials. 
 As the most publicized of bank lending rates, the prime serves as the peg for setting rates on tens of billions of dollars in home equity loans and, above all, on loans to small companies, which account for 20 percent of all business borrowing. The fact that the prime has been stuck at 6 percent for 15 months -- while other interest rates have fallen sharply -- has meant that many small companies have not even had an opportunity to borrow at declining rates, in the event that some might have wanted to do so.
 
Strategy Is Questioned
 The reluctance of banks to lower the prime now -- despite their recent campaigns to encourage borrowing by small companies -- is one more sign of the difficulties in using lower rates to generate strong economic activity.
Interest rates have fallen, of course, for mortgages and for corporations large enough to borrow outside the banking system, at rates below the prime rate. But Federal Reserve data show that the lower rates have generated very little net increase in lending this year in these sectors and in most other sectors of the economy.
Interest rates on mortgages, for example, are at their lowest levels since the 1960's. Even so, home sales and home construction have not risen enough to help lift the economy as strongly as in previous recoveries -- although Alan S. Blinder, a member of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, insists that low rates will convert the present slow economic growth to accelerated growth by next year.
For the moment, however, the prime rate's stickiness limits the impact of the Administration's lower-rate strategy. And the banks show no sign of dropping the prime, despite the existence of an unusually wide spread between what banks pay in interest for deposits and for other funds that the banks borrow and then lend out at the prime. That spread has widened from less than 1.5 percentage points in 1989 to about 2 percentage points in July 1992, when the prime was last lowered, to more than 3 percentage points since late last year.
"The banks have room to lower the prime now, if that were in their best interest," said John LaWare, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, who specializes in banking issues for the board. "Their earnings are exuberant and their capital positions are strong, but they are not going to lower the prime if they do not believe that will increase their loan volume, and they do not believe it will."
 
Reason for Reluctance
 One problem is that because businesses are reluctant to borrow, the banks see a lower prime as costing them money, not increasing their income by attracting more business. Chemical Bank, a big lender to small business, has more than $10 billion in loans outstanding at interest rates that vary with the prime, usually costing the borrower up to one percentage point over prime. That spread has fallen in recent months as Chemical, like other banks, tries to lend more.
But the prime rate has not budged. If it were to come down to, say, 5.75 percent, interest income from outstanding loans would drop automatically by a quarter of a percentage point.
Such income losses occur whenever the prime drops, and it has fallen from 11.5 percent in June 1989 to 6 percent, where it has been since July 2, 1992. In the past, however, these losses have been offset by a jump in bank income from new borrowers attracted partly by the lower prime rate, but mostly by the opportunity to use the borrowed money for expansion and higher profits. Now this offset is missing.
Surveys by the National Federation of Independent Business show that borrowing by its 600,000 members, mostly small companies, is at a 20-year low. "The reason is that their mood is sour; I cannot think of a better word," said William Dennis, the federation's director of research.
And Kenneth Guenther, the executive director of the Independent Bankers Association, representing the country's thousands of smaller banks, added, "When I go to bankers' meetings, the major problem on the table is that good loan demand is not there."
The prime rate's stickiness came to public attention in mid-September when several small banks lowered their prime to 5.75 percent, and no one else followed suit. "We went down early because we felt that the prime will go down eventually, and we have made the decision to be the price leader in Virginia," said Peggy Cummings, the director of investor relations at Central Fidelity Bank in Richmond, one of those banks.
Being the price leader has brought Central Fidelity dozens of inquiries since mid-September from potential new borrowers, but so far no measurable increase in new loans pegged to the prime. Such loans now total $750 million at Central Fidelity, or 18 percent of the bank's loan portfolio.
What has improved -- by accident -- is mortgage lending. "People have been calling our branches and saying, 'I hear your mortgage rates are down'," Ms. Cummings said. "Our employees explain that our mortgage rates have not dropped, our prime has. But the calls opened up conversations, and we were able to do new business on mortgages."
Beyond lack of demand, bankers say cutting the prime below 6 percent would be impractical for them. As Richard J. Boyle, the vice chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank, and others explain it, a bank's present costs make a 6 percent prime a base for profitable loans. But a lower prime would mean that a bank could earn similar income with less risk and cost by investing in Treasury notes that pay interest of 4.5 percent to 5 percent annually.
Or banks that already devote huge sums to consumer lending, might devote even more, at a time when consumers have been borrowing more, particularly through their credit cards and through other short-term credit. Most rates charged to consumers are still above 10 percent.
The Federal Reserve, of course, could change the equation by acting to lower interest rates again. That would in turn give banks even more room than they already have to reduce the prime rate, by reducing what they pay in interest on deposits and on other funds the banks then lend at the prime rate. But Fed officials have suggested that they will not act soon, if at all, given the Fed's concern about a reappearance of inflation, which it would fight by raising rates.
"The Fed's view," said David Jones, the chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a Wall Street firm, "is that it is not prudent to twist bankers' arms to lower the prime rate, because the Fed may turn right around in the not too distant future and raise rates, which would force banks to turn around real quickly and raise them, too."

HEADLINE: Essay;
Son Of Synfuels

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Who is the most powerful business executive in the United States today?
She is Dr. Mary Good, President Clinton's Under Secretary of Commerce for Technology, who has quietly been designated czar of the U.S. automobile industry.
The heads of her divisions -- G.M., Ford and Chrysler -- are delighted with the Government's friendly takeover. These newly middle managers no longer bear responsibility for R.& D., can relax about antitrust, and can forget about the old competition among one another and from abroad. Fatigued by the stress of capitalist risk? Dr. Good will see you now. 
 Corporate statism arrived in America last week in the back seat of a dream car. The White House announced "a historic new partnership aimed at strengthening U.S. competitiveness by developing technologies for a new generation of vehicles." Triple the fuel efficiency; ultra-capacitors from despised "Star Wars" projects; stealth-technology windows; "virtual design and prototyping from the Army Tank Command."
And here's the beauty part: it's all free! "This project will not increase the Government's total spending on research," promises the White House. But somehow, as "Government money will be spent on riskier, longer-term projects," the Washington-Detroit axle will "produce competitively priced, high-performance, low-pollution, safe vehicles."
Do you believe that? The presumed guardians of free enterprise do. I called the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, whose president, Richard Lesher, called it "a step forward. It makes sense for the Government to work with industry to advance the public good." At the National Association of Manufacturers, President Jerry Jasinowski said: "This agreement to improve manufacturing techniques seems generally reasonable."
What a marriage: the Washington-knows-best set of liberal Democrats going down the primrose path of industrial policy with a posterior-protecting bunch of corporate managers and business lobbyists who think they can get government money and management without government control.
Mr. Clinton is making no secret of his policy of half-free enterprise. Following the R.& D. takeover of the auto industry, he announced the taxpayer bailout of the leaky shipbuilding industry, piling billions in new liability on today's economywide $6 trillion in loan guarantees.
Then the 800-pound gorilla groom gave its blushing corporate bride a wedding present: an export-subsidy policy to join -- rather than continue to fight -- the nations that use tax money to prop up inefficient industry.
Why is the power-to-the-center crowd in Washington able to get away with this radical restructuring of the American economy?
Because fat-cat managers and their nail-nibbling lobbyists love it. Who wants to risk failure, hostile takeover and accountability by the bottom line -- when an eager government is ready to relieve you of the rigors of competition? Only entrepreneurs object, and those non-team players are too busy creating new industries and jobs to join the hired managers at the public trough.
Can you imagine a self-starter with a far-out invention going up against the Big Three Plus the Bigger One? The Det-Wash deal to monopolize R.& D. eliminates innovative outsiders and makes a mockery of antitrust.
Do you remember Synfuels, the cockamamie Carter-era solution to high oil prices? Our super-efficient Government created a giant corporation to produce oil out of rocks, with big business's blessing. After a decade of taxpayer losses in the billions, Synfuels was quietly folded up because the free market brought down prices with no government help.
Proponents of today's "partnership" cloak their takeover in the rhetoric of savings on research, promotion of exports, job creation, all those good things competent executives do better than bureaucrats. Ironically, we're aping Japan just when the terrible weakness of the protective Japanese system is becoming manifest.
Who will save the free enterprise system from Dr. Do-good?
Commerce Secretary Ron Brown is paralyzed by fear of indictment; the department's top level is wandering about unconfirmed; and its bureaucracy is disconnected from policy. Fortunately, this is the outfit charged with leading us into Clintonism's brave new world. That is how God protects drunks and the free market.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Who Says College Can Only Last Four Years?;
Consider the Negatives

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Sept. 29 Education page article on completing college in three years makes some interesting points about receiving a bachelor's degree in three years versus the traditional four. Despite the perceived economic benefit in the expedited degree, the negatives should be considered. 
 The idea is noteworthy if the intent of a college is primarily to certify a student for a position in the work force. The concept makes far less sense if one main objective of a university is to help a student grow as a person, spend thoughtful time formulating values and develop a broad outlook on life.
Involvement in campus activities, including social activities, is critical in maturation and likely to be lost in the three-year scenario. Jettisoning these important pursuits may be of questionable value to some students.
Economic realities are squeezing everyone -- from parents and students to faculty members and administrators. But for most students, particularly those coming to college directly from high school, attending a university is more than the number of hours they spend in the classroom.
I fully support exploration of the proposition of a three-year degree program, but let us not lose sight of the negatives that are associated with this concept.
 
MYLES BRAND
President, University of Oregon
Eugene, Ore., Sept. 30, 1993

HEADLINE: Treasury Auction Confined To Bill Market This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financing this week is confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills. On Thursday, the Government will auction a one-year bill.
According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 2.97 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was 3.06 percent. The rate for the one-year bill was 3.17 percent.

SECTION: Section A; Page 17; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Foreign Policy Morass

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS BOSTON

 BODY:
The world has caught up with Bill Clinton. If you ever believed that as President he could keep his attention on domestic affairs, that illusion is gone. Russia, Somalia, Haiti, Bosnia: The list of foreign crises is growing, and they will not go away.
For two reasons foreign policy is a difficult area for this President. One lies in himself, the other in the nature of international problems today. 
 "Somehow," The Economist wrote two weeks ago, "the fire is not in Mr. Clinton's belly when he speaks on foreign policy." Anyone who heard him on health care and on Somalia will understand. On health he was sure on his facts, confident, enthusiastic. On Somalia he seemed tentative, fuzzy, unconvincing.
Of course Somalia is a complicated problem. But so is the issue of national health care; there Mr. Clinton may not have the perfect solution, but he is so informed and committed that he communicates his conviction.
In our democracy, foreign policy must have public support to be successful. And the nature of the problems in the world makes it much harder to get that support now than in recent decades.
For 40 years after World War II most Americans saw Communism as a menacing danger to our security and freedom, and they supported programs to oppose it. The Truman Doctrine, the Marshall Plan, the North Atlantic Treaty, Korea, Berlin, even far-fetched Grenada: Presidents could rally public support in the Manichaean framework of the cold war.
Now there is no great enemy. Instead there are brutal internal conflicts and humanitarian crises. To rally Americans for intervention in those matters is difficult. Indeed fewer and fewer Americans have any interest in foreign affairs.
President Bush, goaded by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, managed to rouse support for war on Iraq. He exaggerated: Saddam Hussein was "worse than Hitler." But the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait was undisguised aggression, and the threat to Western oil supplies did present a risk to national security.
To intervene effectively in any conflict abroad a President must persuade the public that the United States has a national security interest there. President Clinton did so in the Russian crisis and did it well. From the first, clearly and consistently, he called for support of President Yeltsin as the best hope of building democracy and preventing a renewed threat to our interests from Moscow.
Somalia is the opposite case. It presents no threat to American security. I favored the dispatch of American forces last year to prevent mass starvation, not foreseeing the larger political difficulties that have arisen. But Mr. Clinton's policy to deal with them, sending more troops while swearing to pull them all out by March, is muddled and unconvincing. What good are we doing? What is our interest? Americans do not know and hence do not support the policy.
But President Clinton's worst failure in foreign policy has been in Bosnia. The humanitarian interest is obvious when hundreds of thousands of people have been raped, murdered and driven from their homes because of their religion. But there is also a powerful security interest.
The greatest challenge that has emerged in the post-cold-war world is ethnic conflict. Freed from the constraints of the superpower rivalry, ethnic groups in the Balkans and the former Soviet republics have turned on each other with terrifying savagery. What is happening threatens to destroy the European stability that is so essential to America.
Bosnia was the place to draw the line. It was the victim, like Kuwait, of open aggression. Serbian ethnic cleansing was more Hitlerian than anything Saddam Hussein did. Bob Dole was right when he told President Clinton last summer that in terms of our national security interest we should get out of Somalia and get into Bosnia.
Mr. Clinton could have stopped the aggression against Bosnia if he had acted forcefully soon after taking office, making clear to Slobodan Milosevic that we would bomb Serbian forces if they continued their sieges and massacres. Instead he deferred to appeasers in Britain and France.
A President who wants to focus on domestic affairs must put foreign policy in a framework that Americans understand and that makes them feel secure. President Clinton still has that job ahead of him.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1252 words

HEADLINE: Showdown: The Populist Vs. the Fed

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
The champions of two very different American schools of thought will do battle this week when Henry B. Gonzalez, a torchbearer of Texas populism, enters the ring against Alan Greenspan, guardian of central bank independence.
After months of planning, Mr. Gonzalez, the 77-year-old chairman of the House Banking Committee, has begun his most vigorous offensive ever to inject more democracy and accountability into the Federal Reserve, which has been insulated from political pressures for six decades.
 
Rare Hearing
 He has planned a series of hearings to make the central bankers feel maximum heat: Not only has he called Mr. Greenspan, the Fed chairman, to testify on Wednesday, but he has called all 12 members of the Fed's main policy-making committee to a rare mass hearing on Oct. 19. 
 The bill he is pushing aims to remove what he sees as two blots on American democracy: the way that private bankers and business executives, rather than the President, appoint several main Fed policy makers, and the way the central bank makes its decisions in secrecy. Mr. Gonzalez talks of the central bank as an elite, secretive club that is often unresponsive to the public's demand for faster growth.
"I am very determined about reforming the Fed," Mr. Gonzalez said in an interview. "This is no subterfuge. If the Fed became more accountable to the public on its own, it would be cause for celebration. But chairman Greenspan has stoutly resisted even the least suggestion of change."
Although Mr. Gonzalez has flooded the news media with press releases over the last year lambasting the Fed for doing too little to spur growth, he asserts that his new campaign is not intended to assert political (read Democratic) control over the central bank's conservative policy makers. All he says he wants is to remove some undemocratic warts from the Fed's structure.
But Mr. Greenspan isn't eager to buy what Mr. Gonzalez is selling. Fed officials say a central bank works best when it is most independent, and many view Mr. Gonzalez's plotting as a transparent effort to bring the Fed to heel.
 
View on Inflation
 Fed officials declined to respond to Mr. Gonzalez's offensive until Mr. Greenspan testifies on Wednesday. But several central bank officials are known to think that having the President appoint -- and the Senate confirm -- the presidents of the 12 Federal Reserve regional banks would make it harder for the Fed to clamp down on inflation.
Federal Reserve officials say they think that having the President name the regional bank presidents would make them more responsive to political winds, meaning they would probably tilt toward faster growth, rather than lower inflation. If one's goal is to minimize inflation, Fed officials reason, then a sure way to achieve that goal is to have private bankers -- who are among the world's fiercest inflation hawks -- appoint the regional bank presidents.
On a rotating basis, 5 of the 12 regional bank presidents sit on the Fed's chief policy-making committee, the Federal Open Market Committee. The other seats are held by the seven members of the Federal Reserve Board, all of whom have 14-year terms and are appointed by the President.
Now that Mr. Gonzalez has finished his work on a savings and loan bailout, he is picking up the populist torch passed him by Wright Patman, the late Texas Democrat and Fed tormentor who used to head the House Banking Committee. (When Mr. Greenspan testifies Wednesday, Mr. Gonzalez will have a decided home court advantage -- the hearing room is named after Mr. Patman.)
"Like chairman Patman, I'm not worried about taking on an icon," Mr. Gonzalez said. "The Federal Reserve has evolved into an entity in and unto itself and now believes it has no relationship to the rest of the Government." In this battle Mr. Gonzalez at times seemed to be being playing David to the Fed's Goliath. But Mr. Gonzalez should not be dismissed as a lightweight, his supporters say. They point to the way he doggedly alerted the nation about one of the biggest foreign policy blunders of the Bush Administration -- its approval of loans to Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
"For Henry, reforming the Fed is a crusade he believes in very deeply," said Barney Frank, a Massachusetts Democrat on the House Banking Committee. "He has often been underrated in the past."
Nonetheless, Mr. Gonzalez faces an uphill battle. The Fed is already working behind the scenes to organize battalions of bankers to howl about efforts to politicize the central bank.
The Fed is crying wolf, Mr. Gonzalez's allies say. "If you want to fix a door jamb at the Federal Reserve, they say you're part of a building demolition crew," said Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota.
Another problem Mr. Gonzalez faces is that while his bill has 20 co-sponsors, most of them liberal Democrats, some moderate Democrats oppose it.
"I work by the theory that if it ain't broke, don't fix it," said Charles E. Schumer, an influential Brooklyn Democrat on the House Banking Committee who opposes the Gonzalez bill. "Over all, the Fed has done a good job. Monetary policy should be structured so it is not subject to the short-term vicissitudes of politics."
But probably the biggest hurdle Mr. Gonzalez faces is President Clinton's opposition. In a letter he sent to Mr. Gonzalez on Sept. 20, the President said he was "disinclined" to support the Gonzalez proposal, saying the Fed "is functioning well and does not need an overhaul just now." He added that the proposed reforms "run the risk of undermining market confidence in the Fed."
Frank Newman, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, said in an interview that Mr. Gonzalez's critique of the Fed was not to be taken lightly. But he said, "It's difficult for us to see that there really is a problem."
"The Fed is independent and that's one of the underlying concepts," he said. "If at some point in time, this policy isn't working well, that's something that could be addressed."
Several respected lawmakers have joined Mr. Gonzalez's cause. Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, a Maryland Democrat who is vice chairman of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, has proposed stripping the regional bank presidents of their votes so that only the Fed's seven board members would vote on monetary policy.
To improve coordination between the White House and the Fed, Lee H. Hamilton, an Indiana Democrat, has proposed allowing Presidents to appoint new Federal Reserve chairmen a year after the Presidents take office. President Clinton cannot appoint a new Fed chairman until Mr. Greenspan's four-year term expires in March 1996.
As with the Gonzalez proposal, Fed officials believe these proposals would eat into the central bank's independence.
 
Proposal on Interest Rates
 Mr. Hamilton has also proposed requiring the Fed to make an immediate announcement when it decides to change its policies on interest rates. At present, the Fed waits until six weeks after its meetings before doing so.
Mr. Gonzalez and his supporters say their fight is not about whether interest rates should be a smidgeon higher or lower, but about the structure of government. "If you take the principles that people are talking about nowadays -- reforming government and opening up government -- the Fed violates it more than any other branch of government," said Mr. Frank, a co-sponsor of the Gonzalez bill. "There are private citizens making national policy, and they do it in secrecy."

Companies

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Deal Fits Phone Company's Big Plan

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Bell Atlantic's planned $1 billion entry into the Mexican wireless telephone market complements the company's technology strategy and could be the forerunner of a North American and perhaps even a pan-American wireless telephone network led by the regional Bell holding company, analysts said yesterday.
Bell Atlantic said that the Mexican venture was part of an increasingly ambitious wireless and advanced-technology program that includes the personal communications services recently authorized in the United States. But the company said also that it was actively pursuing methods for using cable television networks for two-way communications and standard telephone lines for carrying video programming. 
 "Just because we're in Mexico does not mean we're going to let up on anything else," said Lawrence T. Babbio, chairman and chief executive of Bell Atlantic Enterprises International, the unit responsible for the company's wireless telecommunications in the United States and abroad.
 
New Zealand Deal Recalled
 Mr. Babbio sees Bell Atlantic's Mexico deal as similar in some ways to its $1.2 billion investment in 1990 in New Zealand Telecom, which was being privatized at the time and had a large wireless business. But unlike that transaction, in which the New Zealand Government required a rapid reduction in Bell Atlantic's ownership stake, the American company plans to eventually increase its holdings in the Mexican company, Iusacell, after it issues its first publicly traded shares.
And compared with New Zealand, Mr. Babbio expects much faster economic growth in Mexico, even if Congress does not approve the North American Free Trade Agreement.
John E. Money, an analyst at the Argus Research Corporation, said Bell Atlantic was in an ideal position to negotiate with cellular carriers in Canada and Latin America carriers to build a pan-American network.
Mr. Babbio said he liked the "sound of the idea," but quickly added, "I have nothing to announce or discuss."
In the short run, investors seemed yesterday to focus on the deal's expected impact on next year's earnings, which would wipe out much of 1994's previously projected earnings rise. Bell Atlantic's stock dropped $2 on the New York Stock Exchange, to $59.375, on relatively modest volume.
Mr. Babbio said that a write-off of good will, a bookkeeping measure related to the Iusacell investment, would dilute earnings by 15 cents to 20 cents a share.
Daniel Reingold, a telecommunications analyst at Merrill Lynch, had been projecting 1994 earnings at $3.67 a share, compared with estimated 1993 earnings of $3.43 a share. But yesterday he reduced his 1994 estimate to $3.50 a share to reflect the Mexico deal's dilution.
 
Other Bell Stocks Fall
 It was a bad day for two other regional Bells' stock price yesterday. Southwestern Bell, which holds a 10 percent stake in Mexico's largest telecommunications company, Telefonos de Mexico, saw its shares drop $1 on the Big Board to $40.50, also on relatively modest volume. Investors may see Southwestern Bell's stake being hurt by the Bell Atlantic entry.
BellSouth saw its shares drop $1.875, to $58, on modest volume on the Big Board. BellSouth's shares probably dropped in price because of speculation that it might enter the bidding for Paramount Communications on the side of QVC Network Inc., just as the Nynex Corporation entered the battle on the side of Viacom Inc. But BellSouth also has major stakes in smaller Mexican cellular carriers that could be hurt by Iusacell, Bell Atlantic's Mexican partner.
Some analysts tended to view the Bell Atlantic acquisition in terms that are familiar in American cellular deals. Mr. Reingold of Merrill Lynch said the deal reflected an acquisition price of $40 to $45 for each potential cellular subscriber in Mexico, compared with $85 in Germany and more than $175 in the United States.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lawrence T. Babbio, chairman and chief executive of the Bell Atlantic unit responsible for wireless telecommunications in the United States and abroad. (Bell Atlantic)

HEADLINE: In Two Counties, a Struggle to Influence Turnout

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Oct. 6

 BODY:
In the largely Democratic counties of Essex and Hudson, a familiar election year tug-of-war is going on: Democrats want a big voter turnout and Republicans are looking for ways to keep the turnout low.
In the past strong Democratic organizations were able to field armies of workers, their enthusiasm buoyed by thousands of dollars in "street money" to get voters to the polls. Republicans countered with tactics such as posting poll watchers, many of them armed off-duty police officers, outside voting places, a tactic they have promised a Federal judge not to repeat. 
 Mayor Sharpe James and Councilman Donald Tucker of Newark said that neither Gov. Jim Florio nor his Republican rival, Christine Todd Whitman, are reaching out to urban constituencies. A rare exception was the candidates' appearances at the recent annual meeting of the New Jersey Black Issues Convention, of which Mr. Tucker is president.
Organizational tasks for both parties are complicated by the fact that once-vaunted political machines are in disarray. In Essex, the County Executive, Thomas J. D'Alessio, who was also the county Democratic chairman when the year began, is under Federal indictment on charges of misusing political contributions.
And in Hudson, a Republican now sits in the Mayor's office in Jersey City, a longtime Democratic stronghold.
 
Whitman Endorsement
 Although Jersey City's Mayor, Bret Schundler, has endorsed Mrs. Whitman, he still finds fault with her campaign, particularly her explanations of her tax reduction plan.
"If Mrs. Whitman loses it will be because she ran a very poor campaign," Mr. Schundler said. "Florio is a target as big as the side of a barn.
Historically, these counties have provided plenty of votes in the Democratic column in statewide races. And Democrats say the Republicans have not given up trying to keep these votes away from Mr. Florio by discouraging participation by minority voters, most of whom are Democrats. State Republican leaders went to court this month to ask that their poll challengers be allowed to check whether voters are registered and voting machines function properly. Black elected officials, led by Representative Donald M. Payne, Democrat of Newark, are calling it another scare tactic.
Republican leaders in Essex also decided not to field any opposition to the two black State Senators and two black Assemblymen who represent Newark and surrounding towns. The Republicans apparently reasoned that such opposition would not only be futile, but might encourage more black Democrats to go to the polls, which could hurt Republican fortunes in other races where they might have a chance.
Mayor James said the Republican Party "wants black voters to go to sleep," and added, "They don't respect Afro-Americans enough to offer them a candidacy on their ticket."
 
'I Think It's Wrong'
 Even State Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, a Republican, agreed that his party should have candidates challenging the incumbents. "The county party leaders think it will help them win local freeholder races if they hold down the black vote, but I think it's wrong," he said. "We should have opponents in those races."
The turnout question also was a factor in derailing legislation that would have allowed voters to decide whether they wanted sports betting in Atlantic City casinos, according to the bill's chief sponsor.
State Senator C. Louis Bassano, Republican of Union, said the first thing he was told when his bill passed the Senate and went to the Assembly was that it would not be passed because it would generate a lot of voter interest and pull out large numbers of Democrats. "I said that was absurd, and asked them if they thought only Democrats gambled," Mr. Bassano said.
Assemblyman C. Richard Kamin, Republican of Mount Olive Township, and a member of the Assembly Appropriations Committee that refused to release the bill, said he had questioned the wisdom of putting the sports betting question on the ballot.
"I said it would bring in a lot of special interest money and increase voter turnout," he said. "And I asked whether we wanted to get into a numbers game given the difference in party registrations."
Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, Republican of Independence, denied that concerns over arousing Democratic voters had anything to do with the bill's fate. "I opposed the bill on the merits and would have put it up for a vote if the Appropriations Committee had released it," he said.
 
Positive Responses to Florio
 Random interviews with registered voters on their way to work or shopping in Newark and Jersey City showed that Mr. Florio's ban on assault weapons is standing him in good stead, as are his proposals to tighten requirements for receiving welfare. The interviews also showed that Mrs. Whitman still must convince voters she has the ability and experience to be governor and that her proposal to reduce state income taxes for low and middle-income taxpayers by 30 percent is credible.
Gail Phillips, who was walking through the PATH Station in Journal Square on her way to a job interview, knows about losing a job. She worked as a buyer and assistant manager at a Macy's outlet until the retail giant filed for Chapter 11 protection and closed several stores. But Ms. Phillips said she still supports the Governor. "I like Mrs. Whitman and her support for women's lib, but I think the Governor has done a good job and has the experience." As for Mr. Florio's sponsorship of a $2.8 billion tax increase in 1990? "We'll always have taxes," she said.
Nisa McCord of Bayonne, a legal secretary who was posting some letters at a mail box in the PATH concourse, said she is worried about the state's high unemployment rate and taxes and said she will "probably" vote for Mrs. Whitman." "You have to look at where we are and base your decision on that," she said.
Hector Mercado, an artist and the owner of Rascals, a clothing store three blocks from City Hall in Jersey City, said Mr. Florio is doing a good job. "I support his ban on guns all the way, that's number one," he said. "She has no experience."
 
'We Need a Woman'
 But across the street, Millie Rivera, who was slicing loaves of bread at a Subway sandwich shop, one of two jobs she holds to support her family and raise her 10-year-old daughter, saw the need for a change. "We need more jobs and we have to do more to stop the sale of drugs on the street, and to give young people something to do besides hang out on the street corners." For these reasons she said, "I don't think I'll vote for Florio. We need a woman who will understand these things."
Richard Cardiello, owner of the Ironbound Gym and the new owner of the Ultimate Bagel Delicatessen, which he will rename Richie's Restaurant and Deli, said he would stay home on election day. "I don't think I'm going to vote, because every time I do I get the wrong guy," he said. "I think Florio's a jerk because of his anti-gun stand, and I think she's probably against guns too."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Millie Rivera, working at one of her two jobs in Jersey City, favors Christine Todd Whitman. "We need a woman who will understand these things," she said about the problems of families and unemployment. HEADLINE: Americans Rush to Funds That Invest Abroad

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
It was partly the sight of construction on a four-lane highway in the lush paradise of Bali several years ago that aroused Arie Kurtzig's interest in investing his money overseas.
"They're basically doing the same things we did 20, 30, 40 years ago -- building apartments, roads, sewers, oil refineries and telephone systems," Mr. Kurtzig said, comparing the economy of the Indonesian island, after a fashion, to that of the United States. "That's what's going to be behind their massive economic growth over the next 20 years." 
 Shortly after his visit, Mr. Kurtzig, a 49-year-old Silicon Valley resident who sold his computer touch-screen company five years ago, joining what has now become a gold rush of Americans who invest some of their money overseas by buying shares in mutual funds with assets that are solely or largely foreign.
Discouraged by low-yielding investments at home and attracted by high returns in quick-growing overseas economies like China, Chile and other countries, Americans are growing increasingly bold about investing abroad -- especially in the countries that were once called third-world or underdeveloped areas but are now often referred to by funds as "emerging markets."
And investment advisers say that while this money will clearly help the recipient economies and the bank balances of the investors, there is a downside for the United States stock market: The growing trend is reducing the money available for investment in the United States at a time when a record number of American companies are taking advantage of a bullish market to go public.
In August, foreign-oriented mutual funds collected $5.4 billion from investors. That was nearly half of all mutual-fund investments, and a monthly figure that rose from $3.1 billion in July, the previous record, according to the Investment Company Institute, which tracks mutual fund investments. In 1992, such funds took in $6.9 billion, then an annual record. So far this year, $17.4 billion has poured in.
Mutual funds in general remain hugely popular among American investors -- one in four American households invests in mutual funds, and nearly half of all fund owners earn less than $50,000 a year.
But the foreign-oriented ones are growing at a much faster rate than domestic ones. Total mutual fund assets grew by 18 percent in the first six months of the year, while total foreign-oriented mutual fund assets grew by 35 percent.
Despite the explosive growth, assets in foreign-oriented funds represent just one-tenth of all assets held in mutual funds by American investors. And despite its current attractiveness, investing abroad can still hold big risks, from the potential for political instability in some countries to the shortage of regulations to protect investors and the relative lack of investment information.
While momentum in international investment has been gathering for some time, the spring and summer saw intense growth in this area. Joining people like Mr. Kurtzig in the international arena were comparative newcomers like Paul Feldman, 36, a lending officer for a bank in Manhattan, who started putting money in foreign-oriented mutual funds about three or four months ago.
"I feel that growth rates of emerging markets and their economies will far exceed the U.S. market or even the European market," Mr. Feldman said. "If you're willing to sit back and ride out the ups and downs, there's more of an upside for the emerging market economies than there is for the existing, well-established economies."
There are many kinds of mutual funds, a hugely popular kind of investment made of pools of stocks, bonds or other securities that are managed by a professional investment company. These funds may specialize in, say, energy stocks, municipal bonds, or investment in a country like Mexico or a region like Latin America.
Some mutual fund companies have benefited more than others from the leap in foreign investment. At T. Rowe Price, which is based in Baltimore, 74 percent of the money that investors put into Price mutual funds in the first eight months of the year was earmarked for international investments, Steve Norwitz, a spokesman for Price, said. Even more surprising, Mr. Norwitz said, in August about 94 percent of the new money investors gave to T. Rowe Price was destined for international funds.
 
Market Forces Working
 At Fidelity Investments, the mutual fund giant in Boston, Neal Litvak, the executive vice president of marketing, said the flow of international investment had been driven by market forces: Foreign companies and governments offer high yields to investors to compete for cash against, say, United States Treasury bonds or American corporate debt that might carry lower risks for the investor.
Also, increasing privatization and growth in previously stagnant economies in various parts of the third world are making overseas investing more palatable to American investors who are normally averse to risk. Low labor costs, industrial policies designed to foster growth and strong work ethics add to the package, making investors less nervous about the risks associated with nascent stock markets, experiments with capitalism and the occasional military coup.
Since many investors believe the stock market in the United States is overpriced and perhaps cruising for a fall, the big attraction of international plays, of course, is the potential for a high yield or, at least, more and better bargains overseas. As Mr. Norwitz said, the flow of money into Price's international funds "reflects concerns about potentially high valuations in the U.S. equity market."
Greg Johnson, the vice president of marketing for the Franklin-Templeton group of funds in San Mateo, Calif., said Americans were increasingly comfortable with buying abroad.
"There's not a fear of investing in international stocks like there might have been five years ago -- now it's a realistic alternative for the American investor," he said.
 
Track Records Don't Count
 While many of these funds appear to be generating fairy-tale returns, many international funds that are performing so well this year were flat or weak gainers last year, given the fact that the United States stock market has outperformed most foreign markets for the last several years.
Further, all investors need to memorize this sentence from advertisements for mutual funds: "Past performance is no guarantee of future results."
Both the Fidelity and T. Rowe Price Japan funds are up about 38 percent since Jan. 1 of this year, but about half that gain is attributable to a stronger yen, and at least some of the rest to efforts by the Japanese Government to strengthen the stock market, rather than underlying robustness in the Japanese economy. Anyone who had $1,000 in either Japan fund as of Jan. 1 and wanted to sell now would get $1,380. But the next several months are unlikely to see such gains.
It is also true that there is a vast difference between the risk of investing in, say, Canada and Brazil. Fund advisers can talk very casually about "event risk," which means an earthquake or revolution or other unpleasant incident could wipe out all gains. This serves to prove the investing adage that high rewards are almost always accompanied by high risks.
"Sometimes people jump in blindfolded; they close their eyes to the risks and the increased volatility that tends to accompany an international investment, and they get burned," Mr. Litvak said. "We need to make sure that to the extent that people are taking a first step, they take it in a diversified fund, as opposed to a country fund or a regional fund, which is going to be susceptible to event risk, particularly in the emerging market."
And how are the investors doing? Dr. Earle Rosenberg, 64, an oral surgeon from Wellesley, Mass., who has been investing in foreign-oriented mutual funds for a couple of years, says his Fidelity Latin America fund "is going gangbusters" -- it is up about 20 percent since he invested in the spring. His Fidelity Canada fund is up 14.4 percent from Jan. 1, and the Fidelity International fund is up at least 15 percent since he invested in the spring.
Dr. Rosenberg said he regretted not investing in Asia, and added that he kept 20 percent of his assets in international funds and the rest in domestic assets.
From his initial interest in Bali, Mr. Kurtzig now has about 15 percent of his assets overseas, though he said he plans to go no higher than 25 percent. He has the T. Rowe Price Japan fund, which was a 38 percent gainer, he said, as well as a New Asia fund with a 33.5 percent gain, and a Europe fund with a 16.3 percent gain this year.
Robert Trudeau, 52, of Corona, Calif., the president of a company that makes controls for heating, air-conditioning and refrigeration equipment, said he had "the best investing year of my life this year without much play in the U.S. market."
He started international investing gingerly late last year, and now has 50 percent of his portfolio overseas. The other 50 percent is in cash, and nothing is in the United States equity market because, he says, "we had a long string of good news, and it's just going to take a precipitating factor to bring it back to reality." He added, "That will come along one of these mornings, as it inevitably does."
 
Cash Leaving America
 As Mr. Trudeau's pattern suggests, the flow of international money can easily pull cash away from the American economy. Michael Metz, the chief portfolio strategist for Oppenheimer & Company, said: "What this means for the U.S. is that instead of all these savings going into domestic securities, a lot of it's leaking out into foreign securities. This eliminates perhaps the only source of strength in the domestic stock market, which is mutual fund demand."
Meanwhile, money from individual American investors is helping capital-hungry companies and governments overseas. What used to be government-to-government foreign aid, Mr. Metz said, is now something more like capitalist-to-capitalist aid.
"In the long term, that's really what a smart government should depend upon -- not being attractive to another political entity, but being attractive to capital around the world," Mr. Metz said. "Maybe they can't get a handout from the American Government, but they can put out a lure to American capital."

HEADLINE: U.S. Official in Plea to Pension Funds

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
At a time when institutional investors have pressured American corporations to lay off thousands of workers, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich is seeking to persuade these powerful investors to soften their stance.
Mr. Reich, who brought his campaign to a New York gathering last week of managers of the nation's biggest pension funds, believes that investors should begin to look beyond numbers and add nonfinancial criteria to decide which stocks to buy. 
 In doing so, Mr. Reich adds his voice to a growing chorus urging that nonfinancial measures -- such as how a company treats its workers -- might be as useful in predicting corporate performance as traditional balance sheet analysis.
His message was delivered to the Council of Institutional Investors, a trade group representing large corporate and public pension funds, the agents seen as most responsible for the large number of layoffs at such companies as I.B.M., Eastman Kodak and Sears, Roebuck & Company.
 
A Bottom-Line Mentality
 In demanding better returns, these big instititutional shareholders -- which own more than half the stocks in the nation -- have put pressure on companies to cut lagging operations and restructure their operations. The goal has been to increase profits and stock prices, but the cost has been the loss of thousands of jobs and a stubbornly high unemployment rate.
"I am questioning whether we have gone too far in corporate downsizing," Mr. Reich told council members. "Cutting payrolls may not be the most effective way of improving corporate performance. There are a lot of nonfinancial criteria that don't show up on a balance sheet and are hard to get your hands on."
The remarks by Mr. Reich focused on workplace issues, but his thoughts reflect a growing discussion among big institutional investors that overreliance on balance-sheet ratios -- for instance, return on capital, assets and invested capital -- ignores a human dimension that can affect long-term corporate performance. Moreover, this approach may result in large-scale layoffs that can hurt the economy and reduce demand for the products of American companies.
"Of course, at the end of the day institutional investors are fiduciaries and have to care about return to shareholders," said James E. Heard, president of Institutional Shareholder Services, a pension consulting firm. "But they are becoming more interested in how companies get to be good companies and winners. Part of understanding that process is to look at the issue of human capital."
To help institutional investors, the Department of Labor, which regulates corporate pension funds, will be issuing a set of questions that institutional investors can use to judge one workplace against another.
Behind the approach is the sense that rigorous methodology is needed on such "soft" issues, lest underperforming companies use a good track record with employees to justify or mask poor corporate performance.
Dale Hanson, chief executive of the California Public Employees Retirement System, which manages $70 billion in assets, said that the debate was a "response to the unprecedented amount of white-collar unemployment."
Mr. Hanson said that he was "willing to look at nonfinancial indicators" and supported efforts to "put a value on the human side of the corporation." But, he warned, "it won't be an easy process."
To explain the human-dimension approach, Mr. Reich said he is not suggesting companies be allowed "to pursue slothful ways." Rather, he urges that other methods be devised in place of simply lopping off lagging divisions.
In large part, Mr. Reich acknowledged that his quest for an alternative management model was motivated by the drag that long-term employment put on the economy. Corporate layoffs in September reached 2,000 a day; the percentage of workers still unemployed after six months is at a post-World War II high, and the amount spent by state and Federal governments on unemployment compensation reached $35 billion last year.
Many institutional shareholders accepted Mr. Reich's views as an addition to fundamental financial analysis, but not as a substitute.
"This won't supplement traditional financial analysis," said Peter Gilbert, chief investment officer of the Pennsylvania State Employees Retirement System. "But it could be another helpful tool." His $13 billion fund already takes nonfinancial matters into consideration.
Ash Williams Jr., executive director of the Florida State Board of Administration, offered another reason why institutional investors ought to heed the Labor Secretary: companies with good workplace practices tend to have good stock performance. "This isn't just social engineering, it's good business," he said.

HEADLINE: Plant to Close, Leaving Workers Seeking Jobs

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OSSINING, N.Y., Oct. 7

 BODY:
From guitar strings to jumbo jets to smart buildings, Hudson International Conductors helped wire the 20th century. For almost 90 years, the factory on the banks of the Hudson River here has churned out wire for successive waves of technology.
Now Hudson is keeping up with a new trend: the decline of manufacturing in the Northeast. 
 Later this month, the company will close its factories here and in Walden, N.Y., and consolidate its manufacturing operations at its plant in Inman, S.C. The move will leave most of its employees looking for work in a region that is bleeding manufacturing jobs.
"I guess we are all caught up in the same thing," said Richard Carey, a 49-year-old Peekskill resident who worked for the company for 30 years. "The economy, or whatever it is. G.M., I.B.M., they're all doing the same thing. There are no jobs around in the immediate area."
 
All-Time Low in August
 Spinning copper cables into wire was the only job Mr. Carey ever had, and the only one he ever expected to have. When he signed on at Hudson International Conductors, then known as the Hudson Wire Company, Mr. Carey was fresh out of high school. Hudson Wire was the kind of place where families worked together. Mr. Carey joined his late brother Jimmy on line at the factory. Eleven years ago, he brought his stepson, Donald, into the ranks of what was the largest employer in the Village of Ossining. Now they are both unemployed.
Manufacturing throughout the region is in free fall, said Frank M. Surdey, regional economist for the State Department of Labor in Binghamton. Global competition, the end of the cold war, labor-saving technology and the migration of jobs to cheaper areas are the four primary reasons for the decline, he said.
In Westchester County, manufacturing hit an all-time low in August, with 46,200 jobs reported, a drop of 5.9 percent from the same time last year, Mr. Surdey said. In comparison, there were 74,000 manufacturing jobs in Westchester in 1981.
At Hudson Wire, only 35 executives and engineers, out of 225 employees, will continue to work in Ossining, where the company plans to keep its headquarters and research and development centers, said the company's president Robert Akin 3d.
At the start of this year, Hudson Wire had 118 manufacturing employees. Of those, 18 will relocate to South Carolina. In Walden, about half the company's 19 workers will be laid off, and only a warehouse will remain.
 
'Another Person Gone'
 Piece by piece, the machines were trucked south over the summer. As the equipment went, the jobs followed. Teams of workers have been let go from Hudson Wire almost weekly since the end of June.
"This is like Chinese water torture," Mr. Akin said. "Every day, there's another person gone, another machine gone."
For those who will remain with the company, the choice to move to South Carolina was not easy.
Fred Didomizio of Croton-on-Hudson has worked for Hudson Wire for 35 years. At 58, he was too close to retirement to walk away from the company. He accepted the transfer, but still toys with the idea of early retirement. His move has temporarily divided his family. His wife, Karan, decided not to go.
"I can't see moving away," she said. "I don't think I could take it. My children are here. My grandchildren are here. I have a job here."
Mr. Akin, the 57-year-old president of Hudson International, is not proud of dismantling the factory that his grandfather, Robert, founded in 1902 and brought to Ossining in 1904.
The company's departure from the Northeast is, in part, a tale of 1980's expansion squeezed by 1990's limits.
 
More Factories Than Needed
 In 1988, Hudson Wire Company bought out its largest competitor, International Wire Products Company of Inman, S.C. With the purchase, the company got a new name -- Hudson International Conductors -- and a big new factory in the South. The next year, Phelps Dodge Corporation, the copper mining giant, based in Phoenix, bought the family-owned Hudson International for $60 million.
"Within seven days of the sale, the Berlin wall came down," Mr. Akin said. "That really marked what I have come to call 'the outbreak of peace.' "
Diverse as Hudson's business is, nothing rivaled the defense industry in using top-quality and top-dollar wire, Mr. Akin said. The cuts in military spending left Hudson with more factories than it needed. The consolidation is expected to save the company $5 million annually, Mr. Akin said.
Hudson's cuts, in turn, have left its employees wondering where to look next.
Jim Gilbert, a mechanical engineer and shop steward of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, plans to be the last worker out of the factory when it closes. He knows what he will do when it is all over.
"There's no crying over spilled milk," Mr. Gilbert said. "When it's over, I intend to sit down and write a nice long letter to Governor Cuomo and tell him exactly what I think."

HEADLINE: Despite Merger, Hospitals Get a Grim Prognosis

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Even as arbitragers were betting up the stocks of hospital companies last week after two giant chains, the Columbia Healthcare Corporation and HCA-Hospital Corporation of America, agreed to merge, industry executives and health economists were predicting a grim long-range outlook for both investor-owned and nonprofit hospitals.
"There will be a significant amount of hospital failures over the next 10 years," said Richard L. Scott, Columbia Healthcare's chairman. "Society is saying it wants to limit the amount of G.N.P. that we are going to spend on health care." 
 Growing pressure by Government and private insurers for lower prices is expected to squeeze hospital profits, or as the tax-exempt not-for-profit institutions call them, surpluses.
 
One-Stop Shopping
 Industry executives said the likely winners would be health-care systems that offered one-stop shopping: walk-in surgical centers, salaried or contract physicians, home health and nursing home care as well as hospital rooms.
Large buyers of health care, like insurance companies, have been building networks on an a la carte basis and say they would prefer to keep it that way. "We like to pick and choose," said a Houston-based executive of the Metlife managed care unit of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
The hospital chains, which operate 738 of the country's 5,300 general hospitals for short-term illnesses, are widely regarded as equal to the nonprofits in quality of care. But for all their bold talk about trimming costs, spending on overhead last year of 313 hospitals owned by the largest chains averaged 24 percent of pretax operating revenues. That was only about two percentage points less than at the average nonprofit hospital, said HCIA Inc., a health care research firm in Baltimore.
Some experts question the value of being a big national chain in local and regional markets. "It's a big country," said Dr. Michael A. Stocker, president of Cigna Healthcare, the largest for-profit health maintenance organization. "We make our alliances locally."
 
Making the Best of Hard Times
 Mr. Scott of Columbia Healthcare, not surprisingly, expects to make the best of the hard times. "Times are bad in retailing, too, but some people do well," he said. Columbia's stock close yesterday at $27.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, down 37.5 cents. Shares of HCA were unchanged on the Big Board at $27.75.
He said the merged company, which would have 190 hospitals in 26 states, England and Switzerland if Federal antitrust regulators and shareholders of the two companies approve the deal, would be able to get better discounts on the $1.7 billion it would spend annually for hospital supplies. It also could afford to buy better information systems and to pay top dollar for consultants to help arrange managed care deals.
Neither HCA nor Galen Healthcare, the large chain that merged with Columbia a few weeks ago, has been gaining market share. And analysts said two medium-sized hospital companies, American Medical Holdings and National Medical Enterprises, are also having trouble. National Medical Enterprises recently made a $125 million settlement in a lawsuit filed by insurance companies charging fraud and faces a number of similar suits.
The other large chain, Healthtrust Inc., has most of its hospitals in smaller cities where there is less competitive pressure.
 
Incentives for Doctors
 At a time when H.M.O.'s and other managed care contracts put a premium on keeping patients out of hospitals, said Jeff Goldsmith, a veteran Chicago-based hospital consultant, "the hospital chains' profitability continues to be harnessed to incentives that encourage physicians to do more and hospitalize patients more."
Although both Columbia and HCA have sought to give incentives to physicians to help cut costs by reducing services that may not be needed, Gail Warden, president of the Henry Ford Health System, a large hospital and H.M.O. based in Detroit, agreed with Mr. Goldsmith.
"In a managed care world, owning hospitals is not something I would recommend to investors," Mr. Warden said. Stephen M. Shortell, a professor of health services management at Northwestern University, observed that the for-profit chains had been generally slow to form the one-stop health care shopping networks that most hospitals would need to prosper.
Columbia Healthcare may be the exception. It said 30 percent of its business was already in outpatient care.
 
Offering All the Services
 Mr. Scott said he could offer "all the services in Houston" and would soon have all the pieces in place in El Paso, where Columbia is opening a rehabilitation hospital to complement its two hospitals, five outpatient centers and a nursing home. Columbia can also offer almost all services in Corpus Christi, Tex., Dade County, Fla, and Fort Meyers, Fla., he said.
While Wall Street analysts are leery of most hospital stocks, Columbia Healthcare has had generally good reviews. Kenneth S. Abramowitz at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company said the "positive side" of the Columbia-HCA merger was "Rick Scott's energy as a deal maker and his strategy that has worked in a handful of smaller markets."
As for the "negatives," Mr. Abramowitz said, "Mr. Scott has to rejuvenate two mature companies and successfully interject his strategy in 50 major markets."
 
Not a Growth Industry
 Larry Feinberg, president of Oracle Investors, a fund manager specializing in health care stocks, agreed that "hospitals are not going to be a huge growth industry for a while." He is betting that Columbia/HCA will thrive while the rest of the industry is shrinking.
But experts have deflated some of the early optimistic appraisals of the $5.7 billion merger. James D. Donovan Jr., a regional executive in Dallas for Kaiser Permanente, the country's largest H.M.O., was reserved about the prospects of dealing with the six HCA hospitals in the Dallas-Fort Worth market, although Kaiser has had a long and satisfactory relationship with Medical City Dallas Hospital, which Columbia acquired when it recently merged with Galen Healthcare.
George Pillari, chairman of HCIA Inc., the hospital research group, dismissed the projected immediate savings in the merger as relatively small for a company that would have $10 billion in combined revenues. The two companies said the merger would yield $130 million in savings over two years from joint purchasing, lower credit ratings and reduced overhead,
Carl Sherman, an analyst at Dillon, Read & Company, said: "They will have to build each market by buying not-for-profits," he said. "Then, can they actually deliver cost savings? No one has ever done that in this industry."

HEADLINE: Pact's New Hurdle: Hispanic Officials

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 9

 BODY:
As President Clinton tries to sell the North American Free Trade Agreement as a marriage between the United States and its Latin American neighbors, Hispanic lawmakers have become an unexpected obstacle.
The 17 Hispanic members of the House of Representatives have proven resistant to the Administration's argument that they should be natural allies, convinced that the trade accord with Mexico and Canada would create a huge common market helping Hispanic people on both sides of the border. 
 Instead, the Hispanic lawmakers are listening to constituents who are swayed less by feelings of Latin solidarity than by the same kinds of economic and regional concerns that affect everybody else: allegiances to unions, fears for jobs and proximity to the Mexican border.
Many are caught between conflicting loyalties to the White House, which is pushing strenuously for passage of the agreement; organized labor, which is opposed to the pact, and Democratic leaders, who have mixed thoughts and emotions about the accord's effects.
The recent experience of one representative, Luis V. Gutierrez, illustrates those conflicts. When Mr. Gutierrez organized a weekend town meeting in his predominantly Hispanic district here to announce his opposition to the trade agreement, the White House went on a blitz.
The United States Trade Representative, Mickey Kantor, and Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros called Mr. Gutierrez on Friday to ask him to reconsider. And a meeting was set up for the Congressman to discuss details of the agreement with President Clinton at the White House.
Local Hispanic business owners, some of them enlisted by the Mexican Government, flooded Mr. Gutierrez's offices with calls.
But members of some local unions, taking the opposite point of view, jammed into the town meeting. Mexican-American union members held small plastic Mexican flags to emphasize that their opposition to the pact was simply a matter of jobs and not a reflection of hard feelings toward their homeland.
That is a lot of firepower directed at a freshman Congressman, especially one whose outspoken style has frequently isolated him from the mainstream of the House Democratic caucus. But the spirited effort to sway Mr. Gutierrez is indicative of the pains the Administration, the Mexican Government and other interest groups are taking to lobby the Congress's Hispanic members.
"We're in trouble if we split the Hispanic caucus evenly," said Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico, a Democratic chief deputy whip and the senior Mexican-American member of Congress to support the accord. "It's the symbolism on a Latin issue."
At the last minute, Mr. Gutierrezbacked off from announcing his intention to oppose the trade pact; he is still leaning strongly against it because he thinks it could cost Chicago jobs. Otherwise, the Administration's effort to win over the Congressional Hispanic Caucus is not going well. More than half of its 15 members are against or leaning against the accord. On Friday, Representative Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, announced his opposition to the agreement at a sweater factory in Perth Amboy before a group of Cuban-American, Puerto Rican and Dominican-American workers.
 
Snapping Up Lobbyists
 The reaction of the Hispanic caucus flies in the face of a concerted effort by Mexico City to win support for the agreement. The Mexican Government has hired virtually every Hispanic lobbyist in Washington to work for the accord, and they echo the Clinton Administration's pitch that the accord is a way to expand trade and ties with not only Mexico but all of Latin America.
Surveys indicate that Mexican-Americans living near the border hope the agreement will help stem the tide of illegal immigration, a problem that stirs anti-Hispanic feelings. But other Hispanics, particularly those who work in manufacturing industries and are unionized, are among the most ardent opponents of the trade accord. And in the Miami's Cuban-American community, opinions are running strongly against the treaty because of the Mexican Government's long-standing diplomatic ties to Fidel Castro.
"It shows tremendous maturity," Representative Menendez said of the diversity of opinion. "It shows we care about our Latin American brothers and sisters, but we also care about ourselves and about the country that adopted us."
Mr. Menendez had weighed his decision for months, and when he explained his thinking to 35 workers at the Genesis Knitting plant in Perth Amboy, he emphasized his economic concerns. "I want a Nafta that raises the standard of living in the United States and Mexico," he said, switching between Spanish and English. "But this Nafta doesn't do that. It keeps Mexican wages low by making sure Mexico does not need to enforce labor laws or collective bargaining."
 
Internecine Conflicts
 In a separate discussion with plant managers and union representatives, Mr. Menendez, who is of Cuban descent, gave a secondary reason for his opposition: "The Mexican Government is permitting Cuba to come into Mexico to set up front companies so Cuba can violate the commercial embargo and purchase goods from the United States in violation of U.S. law."
Hispanic politicians are worried that the trade debate could worsen divisions between Mexicans and other Hispanic people. As a freshman Puerto Rican representative in a district that is more than half Mexican-American, Mr. Gutierrez has to tread carefully or perhaps face a strong Mexican-American opponent in a primary next year, local Democrats note.
Mr. Gutierrez awoke at dawn to rework the statement he would read at the gathering. His concern: that he would disappoint his labor base by announcing that he had not yet made a decision. So in his speech, the Congressman made an impassioned plea for Hispanic unity and appealed to Mexican nationalism by calling on the United States to treat Mexico as an "equal partner."
"As currently written, this Nafta is bad trade policy," he said. But noting that President Clinton "has asked me to give him a chance," Mr. Gutierrez said he would work to find a compromise in which the accord would include strong enforcement procedures to increase wages for Mexican workers.
The audience of 220, many of them union members, appeared patient, and most people said they were certain Mr. Gutierrez would stand by them.
Still, Roberto de la Cruz, a local Mexican-American union leader, rose at one point and said: "We want you to know that even though we voted for you, we are keeping tabs. We want you to understand."
Mr. Gutierrez smiled and nodded. He understood.

He spoke with constituents at the meeting. (Todd Buchanan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Israel Selling China Military Technology, C.I.A. Chief Asserts

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Israel has sold advanced military technology to China for more than a decade and is moving to expand its cooperation with Beijing, says R. James Woolsey, the Director of Central Intelligence.
The C.I.A. assessment was provided in written responses to questions by the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee. The committee made the assessment public last week as part of a report on recent hearings it conducted on "proliferation threats of the 1990's," a committee aide said tonight. 
 There have been many news reports about the sale of Israeli military technology to China, which did not establish diplomatic relations with Israel until 1992, and the Rand Corporation has made similar assessments. The C.I.A.'s response to the committee was reported tonight by NBC News and confirmed by the aide.
 
Jets, Missiles, Tanks
 The C.I.A. says China has been acquiring advanced military technology from Israel for more than a decade on programs for jet fighters, air-to-air missiles and tanks. The agency said the sale of Israeli military technology to China "may be several billion dollars."
Despite the previous reports, the bluntness of the C.I.A. assessment surprised Congressional specialists and appears to reflect a growing concern among American intelligence experts that China is seeking to use Israel indirectly to obtain military technology that United States and other Western nations have refused to sell to Beijing.
The intelligence agency reports that despite worries in the West about China's military buildup and its export of missile systems and other weapons to Pakistan, Iran and other nations, Israel has continued to share military technology with the Chinese.
"Building on a long history of close defense industrial relations -- including work on China's next generation fighter, air-to-air missiles, and tank programs -- and the establishment of diplomatic relations in January 1992, China and Israel appear to be moving toward formalizing and broadening their military technical cooperation," Mr. Woolsey said.
Explaining its assessment, the agency noted that Beijing and Tel Aviv recently signed an agreement to cooperate in sharing technology in a number of areas, including electronics and space. Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel was visiting Beijing today to discuss the broadening of Israeli-Chinese ties.
In addition, an increasing number of Israeli military firms also have opened offices in China to sell their products.
"Beijing probably hopes to tap Israeli expertise for cooperative development of military technologies, such as advanced tank power plants and airborne radar systems, that the Chinese would have difficulty producing on their own," the agency said.
 
Likely Pressure From Congress
 The agency's assessment is likely to provoke calls by members of Congress for greater scrutiny of the sale of American military technology to Israel. While there is strong support in the Congress for providing Israel with the money and technology to keep its armed forces strong, there has long been worry that Israel might resell some of the technology to other nations.
Ruth Yaron, spokeswoman at the Israeli Embassy, said tonight that she had not seen Mr. Woolsey's statement and could not immediately comment on it.
The four-paragraph C.I.A. statement to the committee did not say the Israelis had been re-exporting American technology, but that has been a concern for United States officials. The assessment also comes a week after China angered the United States by conducting an underground nuclear test.
 
Verification of End-Use
 An August report by the General Accounting Office, for example, asserted that the United States had not adequately supervised the sale of American technology to Israel for its program to develop the Arrow anti-missile interceptor. As a result, the G.A.O. asserted, there was a risk that some of the technology might be diverted to other nations.
"No checks were performed to verify the end-use and destination of U.S.- provided items and technologies," said the report by the G.A.O., which is the investigative arm of Congress.
At the same time, some American concerns about the sharing of technology to Israel have not turned out to be well founded. In the Bush Administration, the United States accused Israel of sharing American-made Patriot missile technology with China in violation of United States-Israeli agreements banning such diversion.
Israel denied the allegation. After an American team visited Israel to look into the charge, the State Department said its investigators had found "no evidence that Israel had transferred a Patriot missile or Patriot missile technology" to China.
Israel is not the only nation that is selling military technology to China. In recent years, Russia has sold advanced fighters, missiles and military technology to China.
