HEADLINE: Mubarak Promising Democracy, and Law and Order

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Oct. 11

 BODY:
President Hosni Mubarak said today that his Government had Islamic militants on the run and that it was moving toward democracy. The President's opponents have charged that the Government had stymied political reform.
"Most of them are criminals," Mr. Mubarak said of the Islamic militants. "They are being directed from outside the country. Most of them have committed about 15 crimes and given 5, 10 or 15 years in jail, but escaped. Now we are collecting them. That is why everything has gone down." 
 For 20 months, the Mubarak administration has been locked in a bloody battle with Islamic militants that has left an estimated 200 dead. The nation's tourism industry, which once brought in $2.2 billion a year, has been crippled by attacks against foreign tourists.
 
See Shift in Popular Wind
 But in a two-hour interview at the Presidential Palace, Mr. Mubarak said the public had turned sharply against those trying to transform Egypt into an Islamic state through violence.
The 65-year-old former Air Force commander, who took power after the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat in 1981, said the militants had selected him for assassination, but he made light of the threat.
"So they attack the President," he said, chuckling. "Another President will just collect them and put them in jail, all of them. They will meet a very tough time. I am the man who is giving them freedom. I am very flexible."
The Government has arrested hundreds, perhaps thousands of suspected militants, and has sentenced 27 to death; 15 were hanged in June and July.
Mr. Mubarak said he knew that the United States, which he will visit later this month, will begin to cut its aid to Egypt from the current $2.3 billion a year, but he cautioned that any reduction should be gradual.
"Keeping Egypt stable is in the interest of the United States," he said. "If you don't realize this, and if you sharply reduce aid, you will be committing a mistake."
Some United States officials have expressed displeasure with the harsh tactics against militants and the failure to institute direct elections.
"The public opinion should be ed-u-ca-ted," Mr. Mubarak said, tapping out each syllable with his finger on the table. "This country was under pressure for years and years, so when you open the gate for freedom, you will find many terrible things taking place.
"If you have a dam and keep the water until it begins to overflow, and then you open the gates, it will drown many people. We have to give a gradual dose so people can swallow it and understand it. The Egyptians are not Americans."
The President denied that an opposition political leader and two journalists detained for three days and released on Saturday had been held, as they asserted, for "humiliating the President."
"They are supporting terrorism," he said of the leader of the Socialist Labor Party, the only legal party with links to Islamic fundamentalists, and the reporters. He attacked the reporters for inciting violence in articles in the opposition weekly Ash Shaab.
He dismissed the call by Ash Shaab for a public disclosure of any arms deals made by the President, and vigorously denied such involvement. "If you give me 10 million or 50 million pounds," he said, referring to the Egyptian currency, "what am I going to do with it? Cars? I have lots of cars, all presents. A house? I am living in a good house. Food? I am eating, and less than any man in the street, less than anybody."
 
Rabin, Arafat, Fahd, Hussein
 Among other points made by Mr. Mubarak were these:
*He praised Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, who signed the Gaza-Jericho accord with Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization. "You can give and take with him," Mr. Mubarak said of Mr. Rabin. "You can discuss with him." But Mr. Mubarak said he probably would not visit Israel in the near future; his aides say a visit to Israel could give ammunition to the militants in their propaganda war.
*He said he would meet within days with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia to discuss financial support for Palestinian autonomy in the occupied territories. His aides also said he would seek a reconciliation between King Fahd and King Hussein of Jordan. Kuwait and Saudi Arabia suspended $500 million in annual aid to Jordan because of King Hussein's support for Iraq during the gulf war.
*He said he expected concessions soon from the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, in an effort to avoid a tightening of sanctions that were imposed when Libya failed to turn over two suspects in the bombing of the Pan Am jumbo jet over Scotland. But the President refused to spell out what the Libyan steps might be.
The President also said he would not seek re-election when his term ends in six years. He said that he had wavered about running again in the referendum on Oct. 4, but that he had finally decided to accept one last term for two reasons: a fear that "chaos" could envelop the 58 million Egyptians if he stepped down, and a desire to push Egypt toward a market economy.
The referendum, in which the President took 96.3 percent of the vote, allowed a yes or no vote for the President. There were no other candidates.
"Until we have stability and economic reforms, this is the best way to run the country," he said.
But Mr. Mubarak said he and his family were tired of life at the helm of the most populous Arab country.
"I am limited," he said. "One of my sons is staying in London, and we are trying to persuade him to come home. 'But Father,' he tells me, 'I have no freedom here.' "

2 OFFICERS KILLED
 ASSYUT, Egypt, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Muslim militants killed a policeman today, ending a 10-day lull in violence in southern Egypt. In Cairo, a policeman and a fugitive died in a shootout.
In Assyut, a stronghold of Islamic militants, two armed men killed an officer who had taken part in raids on militants, security officials said. The Interior Ministry said a high-school student was arrested for the shooting.
In Cairo, an officer and a fugitive were both killed in a gun battle when officers raided a suspected hideout for militants, the police said.

HEADLINE: U.S. and U.N. Tell Haiti Military Must Cooperate

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Acting on a request by the United States, the Security Council warned Haitian military leaders today that Haiti could face renewed economic sanctions for failing to allow a ship carrying United States and Canadian troops to dock.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher also said that the landing of the 200 troops, part of an international contingent to oversee the return of the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, would be delayed until the Haitian military could guarantee the troops' safety. 
 "We believe the current situation does not justify docking the ship at this time," Mr. Christopher said.
 
Request for a Ruling
 Shortly after Mr. Christopher's statement, the Security Council asked Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to determine if the blocking of the ship and harassment of diplomats violated the agreement on Father Aristide's return.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali is expected to report in a few days, Administration officials said. If he finds that Haitian military leaders have breached the accord, the Security Council may reimpose the sanctions, including an oil embargo.
Administration officials said the United Nations special envoy to Haiti, Dante Caputo, and the United States charge d'affaires in Port-au-Prince, Vicki Huddleston, are to meet with Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras to insist that the peace accord he signed be honored. Representatives of the Central Intelligence Agency are to meet with Michel Francois, the chief of police in Port-au-Prince, to convey the same message.
 
Quarrel Over a Berth
 Part of the agreement calls for the dispatch about 1,600 foreign personnel, roughly divided between military and police forces, which includes about 600 Americans. Administration officials said they had already received clearance from Haitian military leaders for the ship, the Harlan County, to dock in Port-au-Prince, and that the appearance of another ship at the assigned berth may have violated the peace accords.
"The berthing arrangements were not in place when the ship arrived," said a senior State Department official, adding that the Administration considered that a "breach of the commitment made by the military and political authorities to allow trainers into the country."
Officials said they were not surprised by today's events, seeing the dispute as a test of international resolve.
 
Nervousness in Congress
 Congress is becoming increasingly jittery over the prospect of United States soldiers being dispatched to a volatile country, and Pentagon officials remain wary of the mission in Haiti.
The Pentagon and the State Department have split over sending the troops, and last week the Defense Department delayed the sailing of the Harlan County until it received clarification of the mission.
Eight days after an airborne assault in Mogadishu, Somalia, against the forces of Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid left at least 15 United States soldiers dead, lawmakers say the Administration is again placing troops in danger without having briefed Congress.
"We're very wary about United States troops going into places of danger," Representative Lee Hamilton, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said today. "I don't think the Haitian effort has been widely explained on the Hill; at least in my case it has not been."
 
The Troops' Mission
 The Administration has agreed to provide 600 military engineers and logistics personnel to aid in reconstruction in Haiti and to train the military after Father Aristide returns to power. Under the peace accord, the President is to be in Port-au-Prince by the end of the month, more than two years after he was deposed.
The Harlan County is ferrying 175 American and 25 Canadian military engineers to Haiti. The total force of 1,600 is to monitor the Haitian military and the police and providing training; it is not to perform combat or police functions.
Officials say, for example, that the lead elements of the international police force, which includes 50 Royal Canadian Mounted Police already in Haiti, will not seek to secure the port area so the Harlan County can land its troops. Instead, the ship will remain offshore until the Haitian military provides an open berth and guarantees that the soldiers will not be harassed.
Officials said that after landing its troops, the Harlan County would remain offshore, ready to take part in a rescue if necessary.
State Department officials have stressed for some time that while gunmen have often intimidated Haitians, they have not threatened diplomats or human rights monitors in Haiti. Thus today's threats against Vicki Huddleston, the charge d'affaires, represents an ominous development, they said.

HEADLINE: In a Quiet Session, Dow Rises 8.67 Points

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
The stock market was generally listless yesterday in a quiet Columbus Day session.
Few significant trends were apparent, analysts said, with banks and some bond markets closed and other markets ending trading early. 
 Much of the trading was related to the employment statistics released on Friday, which many analysts viewed as evidence of an underperforming economy.
"There was also some trepidation concerning the third-quarter earnings announcements that are going to be coming out in the next few weeks," said Edwin Walczak, chief investment officer of Vontobel U.S.A. "It's not exactly robust out there."
 
Market Indicators Advance
 Still, all three major market indicators advanced. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 8.67 points, to 3,593.41; the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was up 0.57 point, to 460.88, and the Nasdaq composite index was up 3.38 points, to a record high of 767.65.
These gains occurred, however, on extremely low volume. On the New York Stock Exchange, 183.2 million shares changed hands, compared with 243.6 million shares Friday. Advancing issues narrowly exceeded declines, 1,029 to 943.
The American Stock Exchange market value index set another record yesterday. It closed at 467.59, up 2.89 points.
Cyclical issues sensitive to the economy continued to erode. Among them were International Paper, which dropped 1/2, to 58 5/8; Bethlehem Steel, off 1/2, to 14 1/8, and Reynolds Metals, off 7/8, to 41 7/8.
Weakness also occurred among some retailers. Dayton Hudson fell 2 1/8, to 65, while Kmart declined 1/2, to 23 3/4.
 
Semiconductor Stocks Fall
 In addition, Intel slumped 4 3/4, to 65 1/2, despite reporting strong earnings, setting a negative tone for the semiconductor sector. National Semiconductor dropped 1 1/8, to 18, and Advanced Micro Devices fell 3/8, to 20 1/8.
On the other hand, some groups benefited from strength not only in the New York markets, but also overseas.
"There was some gravitation back to the safe areas of the market, those showing dependable earnings growth," Mr. Walczak said. "Some of these stocks have been oversold."
One such area was drugs and pharmaceuticals, which moved into higher ground despite the Clinton Administration's proposed health care plan. Pfizer increased 1 to 60 3/8; Warner-Lambert climbed 2 1/4, to 68 1/4, and Johnson & Johnson rose 1/2, to 39 7/8. Other gains were notched by Amgen, up 1 1/4, to 41, and Medtronic, up 1 7/8, to 70 3/4.
Another strong group was consumer nondurables. They included Philip Morris, the most active stock on the Big Board, which rose 7/8, to 49 1/8; Anheuser-Busch, up 3/8, to 46 5/8; Pepsico, up 5/8, to 39 5/8, and Coca-Cola, up 3/4, to 42.
 
Rebound by Nike
 Some issues that had been weak earlier rebounded yesterday into the plus side. Nike advanced 1 1/4, to 46 1/4, and Vons rose 1, to 18. Eastman Kodak also increased 1 1/2, to 59 1/4.
But Tyco Toys -- which said that third-quarter earnings would be sharply lower than the period a year earlier and projected a loss for the year -- declined 1 1/8, to 11 3/4. U.S. Healthcare tumbled 3 1/4, to 43 7/8, after Goldman, Sachs removed the company from its recommended list. And Score Board dropped 1, to 30, following an accusation by New York City that the trading-card company had violated its consumer protection laws.

HEADLINE: Greek Victor Now Facing Tough Task

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATHENS, Oct. 11

 BODY:
With Andreas Papandreou back in power in Greece, borne by a remarkable political resurrection, the question is whether the Socialist leader, onetime firebrand and perennial master of surprise will go back to his old quixotic ways.
Mr. Papandreou's Pan-Hellenic Socialist Movement has emerged with a solid majority of 170 seats in the 300-member Parliament after Sunday's national election. 
 His victory over Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis has thrust Mr. Papandreou, a Harvard-educated economist and onetime United States citizen, into a changed world where his cold war stock-in-trade no longer has currency. And despite result of the election, the campaign left more questions than answers.
First of all, there is the issue of his health, which has not been good since open-heart surgery in 1988.
 
European Community Post
 "If the question is whether he can run a hands-on, day-to-day Government, the answer is probably not," said a diplomat. The 74-year-old Greek leader's frailty is doubly important because in January, Greece assumes the rotating, six-month presidency of the European Community, which entails a potentially grueling travel schedule that Mr. Papandreou may be loath to undertake.
Similarly, his health may well constrain him from a more flamboyant foreign policy, as he concentrates on the more pressing problem of economic policy at home that forms the biggest question mark.
As he acknowledged victory last night, Mr. Papandreou spoke of "difficult problems" inherited from Mr. Mitsotakis and promised "economic policies that will bring stability, development and social security."
 
Inherited Austerity Plan
 What Mr. Papandreou has inherited from Mr. Mitsotakis, though, is not so much a problem as an unpalatable solution to Greece's chronic economic woes: an austerity program that was intended to curb inflation, cut huge state deficits and begin selling off chunks of Greece's vast state sector to private business -- in essence, a reversal of everything Mr. Papandreou stood for in the 1980's.
His last spell as Prime Minister, from 1981 to 1989, ended in scandal, corruption charges and accusations of mismanagement that left him isolated and discredited among the swing voters who decide Greek elections. His successful quest for vindication will have a price, however.
As his supporters careened through Athens into the small hours today with car horns blaring and banners flapping from motorcycles and car windows, the message they were sending Mr. Papandreou was one of anticipation: now that Mr. Mitsotakis is gone, they were saying, let's get back to the good old days when the money ran freely from the state coffers.
 
Pressure From Public Workers
 "He has an obligation to his voters who want him to reverse privatization and the hold-down on public spending," said Sotirios Papasotiriou, an economist. "He has to give something." Specifically, Mr. Papandreou is under pressure to increase wages for the 670,000 Government employees who, along with their families, make up a large chunk of his constituency.
At the same time, though, Mr. Papandreou needs economic growth and European support. Greece is the poorest nation in the community, and its signature on the Maastricht Treaty on European integration obliges it to keep pace with its partners.
"Greece is so dependent on the European Community, that I don't think Papandreou will be able to do anything like he did in the past," said Mr. Papasotiriou.
The conservative New Democracy party of Mr. Mitsotakis, with its 111 seats, was humbled by defections and the huge personal unpopularity that accrued to its leader after three years of biting economic austerity.
As he conceded defeat last night, Mr. Mitsotakis, also 74, said he would begin the process of holding elections for a new party leader, possibly a younger man like Miltiades Evert, former Mayor of Athens, to stanch the hemorrhage of voters towards Antonis Samaras, a 42-year-old maverick who broke with Mr. Mitsotakis and set up his own party, Political Spring.
With barely a majority at Mr. Mitsotakis's command, the revolt stripped New Democracy of its parliamentary edge, forced elections seven months ahead of schedule and split the one-time monolith of the Greek right.
By today, Mr. Samaras's party had won 4.6 per cent of the vote and 10 parliamentary seats, all of them taken from New Democracy.

HEADLINE: Hotel Sale May Signal End of Japan's Patience

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 11

 BODY:
At the peak of Japan's property-buying binge a few years ago, the little-known Azabu Building Company paid outrageous prices for real estate around the globe. Now, in a potent symbol of the severity of the financial hangover afflicting Japan's property and banking industries, Azabu's main lender has said it will auction one of the company's plum properties on Hawaii and accept what will likely be a huge loss.
The Mitsui Trust and Banking Company, which poured billions of dollars into ill-conceived property loans during the 1980's, said it had filed legal papers in preparation for the auction of the Waikiki Hyatt Regency. The bank seized the hotel after Azabu was unable to maintain its payments on a crushing debt burden said to total about $7.15 billion, a third of which is reportedly owed to Mitsui Trust. 
 Azabu had contended last year that the hotel was worth $660 million, but property experts here expect it to fetch a fraction of that.
Yoshiaki Koshimura, a spokesman for the ailing bank, said no date had been set for the auction, but he hinted that more might be coming by pointing out that the bank had seized control of several other hotels on Hawaii that Azabu Building purchased, including the Maui Marriott.
"This is not the end of Azabu's problems by any means," said Alicia Ogawa, an analyst here with Salomon Brothers. "Mitsui Trust also still has some pretty horrifying problems to deal with."
The auction is resulting from a surprisingly public feud between Mitsui Trust and Azabu's flamboyant chief, Kitaro Watanabe. Mr. Watanabe once tried to greenmail an auto parts concern, the Koito Manufacturing Company, by purchasing a large block of its stock and then demanding the company buy him out at an exorbitant sum.
When he was spurned, he recruited T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oil and gas man and self-proclaimed friendly investor, in an attempt to put additional pressure on Koito. That failed, but it did offer the spectacle of Mr. Pickens being shouted down by Japanese gangsters at Koito's annual meeting in 1990 as he sought to demand that his rights as a shareholder be respected.
The proposed sale of the Hawaiian hotel is also a belated acknowledgment that both the Japanese banks and the speculators who fed the real estate boom during the 1980's are going to have to face up to what will likely be billions of dollars in losses.
Japan's banks had steadfastly stood by the property investors, restructuring their loans and in many instances reducing the interest rates to zero in a desperate effort to wait out the plunge in land prices here and abroad.
The hope was that with patience, the banks would be able to avoid unpleasant write-offs. The significance of Mitsui Trust's announcement is that it shows the pain has simply grown too great. Japanese property prices show no sign of rebounding after losing more than 50 percent of their value over the last four years. There is little prospect of recovering much of the money spent overseas because in many instances the Japanese investors overpaid. The burden on banks from bad property loans has become a significant drag on the Japanese economy.
Azabu Building was the creation of the 59-year-old Mr. Watanabe, who rose from obscurity to run a profitable auto dealership. He parlayed that business into a thriving real estate empire during the 1980's, riding the crest of one of the most excessive speculative binges in history.
Fueled by a flood of bank loans, Mr. Watanabe and a number of other entrepreneurs put together multibillion-dollar portfolios of properties in Japan, Europe and the United States. The Japanese properties ranged from the Tiffany Building and the new Regent Hotel in Manhattan to the Pebble Beach Golf Club in California and more than half of the luxury hotel rooms on Hawaii.
Finally, soaring interest rates in Japan in 1990, a plunging stock market and a slide in real estate prices took their toll. Azabu halted interest payments on its debt in 1991, and early last year Mitsui Trust discreetly sent over seven executives to operate the company.
The cooperation ended with a startling board room ambush last March, when Mr. Watanabe used his control of the company's shares to oust the Mitsui Trust officials.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Little Changed In Subdued Holiday Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar showed little change against other most other leading currencies yesterday. Trading was subdued because Tokyo banks were closed for a Japanese holiday, while banks in New York and elsewhere in the United States were closed for the Columbus Day holiday. Volume was light in Europe as well.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 106.22 Japanese yen, up slightly from 106.10 yen on Friday. It also rose to 1.6042 German marks, from 1.6035 marks. 
 Gold prices edged higher. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery, the most actively traded futures contract, rose 20 cents, to $361.70 an ounce.
In European trading, currency traders focused on a long-awaited decision by the Germany Federal Constitutional Court on legal objections to the Maastricht Treaty, which details conditions for further European unification. Fears that the court may not accept the treaty unconditionally brought buying of mark assets.
Uncertainty regarding Europe's direction typically favors the mark, which is seen as the community's strongest currency.
"Even if they approve the treaty, there must be a risk that they add some sort of codicils," said Peter Lucton, economic adviser at Barclays Global Foreign Exchange in London. "That leaves Maastricht in a state of limbo."
 
 
European Volume Thin
 Volume thinned to a trickle after European foreign exchange desks closed shop for the day. With many American banks closed and others modestly staffed, interbank dealing was thin and most customers sidelined, dealers said.
News of an earthquake off the coast of Japan failed to shake the yen out of its narrow range, and dealers said they would await damage assessments before making a move.
"The assumption is that the yen would first drop if a disaster occurs, then it would surge on capital repatriation," said Lawrence Weinman, vice president at the Bank of America. The United States National Earthquake Information Center later said the tremor should pose no danger because its epicenter was far out at sea.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Mitchell Listens to Wife And Earns Starting Job

BYLINE: By FRANK LITSKY

 BODY:
Scott Mitchell spent Saturday night in Cleveland Clinic with viral conjunctivitis, an infection of his left eye. He telephoned his wife, Kim, and said he did not think he could play the next day.
"She told me I had to play," Mitchell said. "She said somehow I would get my first chance, and I had to be ready when it came." 
 How prophetic. Mitchell did play for the Miami Dolphins against the Browns, and not just to hold for field goals and conversions. When Dan Marino was knocked out of the game in the second quarter, Mitchell took over. Now he is the starting quarterback.
Coach Don Shula of the Dolphins said yesterday that magnetic-resonance-imaging tests showed that Marino's right Achilles' tendon was ruptured, meaning he would not play again this season. Marino underwent surgery yesterday and will need four to six months to rehabilitate. According to Shula, the doctors said Marino should recover completely.
Mitchell, 25 years old, is the only other quarterback on the Dolphins' 53-man roster. Had Mitchell been injured Sunday, the Dolphins' emergency quarterback would have been Tony Martin, a wide receiver who played quarterback at Mesa College, in Colorado.
The Dolphins have quarterback Doug Pederson on the practice squad, and Shula said he would be activated. He said the Dolphins would also look for a veteran backup. Although he did not name candidates, two possibilities are Mark Vlasic and Tom Tupa, both unemployed. The Dolphins might also look for a quarterback on another team's practice squad, such as Shane Matthews of the Chicago Bears.
No matter who they get, their hopes this season now rest with William Scott Mitchell. At Utah, he passed for 8,981 yards, placing him 12th in career yardage among major college passers. As a pro, he fell into obscurity.
 
Fourth-Round Pick
 Mitchell was drafted in the fourth round in 1990 and spent his rookie season on the inactive list. He threw no passes in 1991 and only eight in 1992, but before the 1992 season he was the starting quarterback for the Orlando Thunder of the springtime World League of American Football. He is 6 feet 6 inches, 230 pounds and left-handed.
"We've got great confidence in him," Shula said, "and we wouldn't really change things that much with him. We build a game plan and expect Scott or Dan to work within that plan the same way."
On his first play against the Browns, Mitchell's pass was intercepted and returned 97 yards for a touchdown. He later threw for two Dolphins' touchdowns for a 24-14 victory. He did not seem awed by his new responsibilities.
"I've been here four years and feel at home with our offense," he said. "I have the ability to do what's asked of me. Only time will tell how differently I play than Dan Marino."
The game cost the Dolphins more than Marino. Middle linebacker John Offerdahl, the key to their defense, suffered a dislocated right shoulder and will miss three or four weeks.
 
Wounded Quarterback No. 2
 Drew Bledsoe, the New England Patriots' rookie quarterback, has a sprained left knee, but how much time he will miss is uncertain. Bledsoe underwent tests yesterday to determine how much damage he suffered in a 23-21 victory over the Phoenix Cardinals, the Patriots' first triumph under Coach Bill Parcells.
"He probably won't play this week," Parcells said, "but I don't know. They didn't tell me not to play him yesterday. I'm the one who took him out. I watched him drop back, and it looked like he was going to struggle, and I didn't want to expose him any further."
Bledsoe's replacement would be Scott Secules. Like Mitchell with the Dolphins, Secules relieved Sunday and led his team to victory.
 
 
Wounded Offenses
 The Minnesota Vikings, somehow tied for their division lead with a 3-2 record, have scored five touchdowns in five games. In Sunday's 15-0 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, the Vikings totaled only 268 yards and gave up five sacks. "I am not a whiner or crybaby," Coach Dennis Green of the Vikings said, "so don't get into me with a lot of questions about what's wrong."
The San Diego Chargers, after Sunday's 16-3 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers, dropped to 2-3 and last place in their division. This was their third game this season without an offensive touchdown. Against a virtual eight-man front, they rushed 20 times for 19 yards. "They were waiting every play, every down," said Chargers' tailback Marion Butts. Coach Bobby Ross's assessment: "We were very, very poor."
 
Older Is Better or Wiser
 On relieving Jeff Hostetler and rallying the Raiders to a 24-20 victory Sunday over the Jets, 38-year-old Vince Evans said: "I believe my latter days have been greater than my former days. A degree of maturity sets in. I'm not rattled by things."
On deciding, after 31 years as a National Football League head coach, whether to retire when his contract expires after the 1994 season, 63-year-old Don Shula said: "When it's time to make the decision. I'll sit back and take my time and decide. But I will tell you, I still enjoy coaching very much."

HEADLINE: U.S. Prepares to Unveil Blueprint for Reducing Heat-Trapping Gases

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
THE Clinton Administration is about to announce its plan for reducing the United States' emissions of heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide, in accordance with the treaty it signed at last year's Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro. And though the plan is still being discussed and officials are closely guarding the details, it appears likely to rely more on carrots than on sticks in seeking to get industry to comply.
If Government officials, environmentalists and industry representatives who have been involved in creating the plan over the last six months are right, it will contain no new energy taxes, will hold regulation to a minimum and will emphasize and encourage voluntary efforts to use energy more efficiently. The goal is to reduce emissions of so-called greenhouse gases to 1990 levels by the year 2000 in an effort to avert a possible global warming. The announcement of the plan is expected within the next two weeks. 
 Energy efficiency is central to controlling emissions because carbon dioxide, the most important heat-trapping gas, is produced by the burning of coal, oil and natural gas, the energy foundations of the modern economy. Some scientists believe a continuing atmospheric buildup of the gases could cause a serious and even catastrophic warming of the earth's climate in the next century.
 
Timetable for Action
 In some ways the Administration's approach is similar to that of the Bush Administration, but with at least two big differences: President Clinton, unlike President George Bush, has committed the nation to a specific target and timetable for reducing emissions. And the Clinton Administration, unlike its predecessor, appears ready to enter the fray as an active participant with industry in trying to speed and expand the adoption of energy-efficient technologies.
"There are technologies on the shelf now that are sorely underdemployed," said Katie McGinty, the director of the White House Office of Environmental Policy, which is developing the plan. She said the Administration hoped to accelerate the use of those technologies. One likely provision calls for the Government to spend about $200 million a year to stimulate the adoption of such technologies. The Government would also act as a clearinghouse and expediter.
Among the measures that could be encouraged in this way, for example, is an expansion of the Environmental Protection Agency's "green lights" program, in which the Federal Government provides technical assistance to companies and local governments that agree to install more efficient lighting systems. Energy savings pay for the installation. The plan is said to contain a broad range of such energy-saving measures.
This general approach would be another example of a developing Administration strategy aimed at encouraging public-private collaboration on a variety of economic, technological and environmental issues. An earlier example was the announcement last month that the Government and the automobile companies were collaborating on the development of an auto three times as energy-efficient as today's cars.
 
Reversal of Bush Position
 Last April, President Clinton reversed the Bush Administration policy and committed the United States to a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2000. At that time, Mr. Clinton instructed his subordinates to come up with a plan that reduced emissions not through more regulation but rather by relying on "American ingenuity and creativity" in producing energy-efficient technology.
"I think this plan will achieve both of the President's objectives," Ms. McGinty said. She said that while the plan would include "every kind of approach going," the idea of voluntary partnerships would be "a significant part" of the package.
But can a voluntary plan work?
"They're going to give it the good college try," said William A. Nitze, president of the Alliance to Save Energy, a Washington-based nonprofit coalition of leaders in government, industry, environmentalism and the consumer movement dedicated to promoting investment in energy efficiency. Mr. Nitze said both he and the Administration were "pretty bullish about the outcome of such a strategy."
Industry, as might be expected, has supported the general principle. Environmentalists give it mixed reviews, with some faulting it as not having enough of a "hammer" and others approving the general idea. All sides are wary of details yet to come.
The plan will not rely solely on industry's good intentions, Ms. McGinty said, but will include features that give "backbone" to the partnership strategy. She did not specify the features.
Some Government officials have acknowledged that there is much uncertainty in the voluntary approach, since it relies on corporate and individual behavior, which is difficult to predict. Because of this uncertainty, the Administration intends to monitor the plan's performance carefully; if it appears not to be working, Ms. McGinty said, further measures will be considered.
 
Close Scrutiny Expected
 There is a substantial foreign-policy incentive for paying close attention and adjusting: the international community will soon be watching the United States, as it will all countries, to determine how well it is meeting its commitments to control heat-trapping gases under the Rio treaty. The Clinton plan stands to be scrutinized closely and critically by other signers of the treaty who are looking to Washington for leadership, not only on this issue but on environmental issues generally.
It is widely anticipated that the treaty will be ratified by the requisite 50 countries by the end of this year (when the Senate approved the treaty in August 1992, the United States became one of the earliest ratifiers). The treaty would go into force 90 days after the 50th ratification. If that happens next spring, the scrutiny would probably come a year later.
While the signers would eventually be required to stabilize greenhouse gas emissions at safe levels, the treaty calls only vaguely, as a first step, for countries to aim at returning greenhouse-gas emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2000.
The Bush Administration, which feared the economic price of meeting a firm target, refused to accept a specific target and timetable and successfully pressured other countries to go along. In adopting the timetable, the Clinton Administration has taken a first step that goes beyond what is required by the treaty.
In addition to encouraging the expansion of off-the-shelf energy-saving technologies that might show results by 2000, the Clinton plan is also expected to include provisions through which the Government would help industries speed the adoption, over the long term, of alternative energy technologies now on the cusp of economic practicality. These include, for example, photovoltaic electric cells and advanced wind turbines.
A disputed provision that is likely to be included in the plan would encourage owners of timberlands to leave trees in place rather than cut them down. Trees and other photosynthesizing plants are "sinks" that absorb carbon dioxide.
Environmentalists look askance at this measure because they believe it would send the wrong signal to other countries. "It tells the Europeans you don't have to deal with your emissions from energy production, that you can offset that by measures on the sink side," said Alden Meyer, director of the program on climate change and energy of the Union of Concerned Scientists, which focuses on energy and environmental issues. In addition, they say, there is no guarantee the trees will not eventually be cut or burned.
The Clinton plan is not expected to include any provisions for regulating energy use in transportation -- for example, stronger gas-mileage requirements for automobiles. Provisions like that presumably could be brought into play later if the initial proposals do not work.
The question of whether and how greenhouse emissions are to be reduced further after the year 2000, a concern of many environmentalists, is expected to be discussed but not resolved in the plan. A panel of scientists advising the United Nations and parties to the climate treaty has said that stabilizing the overall atmospheric concentration of carbon dioxide at today's levels would require a worldwide 60 percent cut in the 1990 level of emissions.
 
Numbers Are Questioned
 Some environmentalists, like Dan Becker, of the Sierra Club, question the emissions estimates on which the plan is to be based. "The numbers are very squishy," he said. But Ms. McGinty said the plan "has really been put through the wringer any number of ways; the numbers are really solid."
Dan Lashof, of the Natural Resources Defense Council, said he thought the general approach of "putting together a package of individual initiatives tied together by a commitment to keep track of how those are doing," plus the assurance that stronger measures could be applied if necessary, "is fine."
But he expressed concern about "what the specifics are, what's in and what's out in terms of actual measures to reduce fossil-fuel consumption, and to what extent the plan may anticipate using credits from the forestry sector to offset growth in the fossil-fuel sector."
Mr. Meyer's reaction was similarly equivocal. "I think the bottom line is mixed," he said. "There are going to be some individual measures we're going to applaud." But he said the plan, at least from what now appeared to be known, placed too much emphasis on voluntary measures, "with no prospect of hammers or sticks to bring us into compliance if those don't work."

HEADLINE: The Prodigal Returns in Greece

 BODY:
Few politicians have had more lives than Andreas Papandreou, the once and future Prime Minister of Greece. Europeans remember his previous term from 1981 to 1989, when his free spending dismayed central bankers and brought Greece close to insolvency. Americans remember him as a former U.S. citizen and an academic economist who later baited Washington. Yet confounding odds, age, ill health and charges of corruption, Mr. Papandreou trounced his conservative rival, Constantine Mitsotakis, in Sunday's election.
His comeback owed much to his opponent's austerity measures and to a split in the ruling New Democracy Party. Even so, Mr. Papandreou's victory is a remarkable personal feat -- especially since eight million voters were aware that their huge national debt was the legacy of his profligate brand of Socialism. 
 Whatever his return augurs for Greece, its wider repercussions are scarcely comforting. The dissolution of Yugoslavia has rekindled Greek fears that Macedonia, a former Yugoslav republic, has territorial designs on the Greek province of Macedonia. As leader of the opposition, Mr. Papandreou helped generate the nationalist passions that propelled Prime Minister Mitsotakis to press for the isolation of a weak and struggling neighbor.
Optimists can always hope that, once in office, Mr. Papandreou will prove less intransigent than his record suggests. As a member of NATO and the European Community, Greece has more to fear from Balkan turbulence than from Macedonia. And however tempted he may be to run up huge deficits again, Mr. Papandreou is constrained by an empty cupboard and the Community's monetary policies.
Still, for Mr. Papandreou to turn elder statesman would be yet another unexpected metamorphosis -- possible but not likely. For the Clinton Administration, the change in Greece more probably signifies a new source of friction in the Balkans.

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
An Independent Attack Against Florio

BYLINE: By Jon Nordheimer

 BODY:

Client: Hands Across New Jersey
 
Creator: Larry Weitzner, Jamestown Associates, South Orange
 
Visual: Jim Florio, smiling and looking confident, is seen in a television film clip waving to a friendly group of onlookers. The scene quickly shifts to a padlocked factory gate over the heading "325,000 Lost Jobs." The next graphic reads "71,000 Lost Homes" accompanied by a picture of what appears to be a homeless person sitting on the ground beneath a tree. A framed picture of the Governor remains on the screen as headlines from The Trentonian pop up alongside: "America's Worst Governor," "Think Tanks Give Florio an F," "2.8 Billion Tax Increase" and "Florio to Taxpayers: 'Drop Dead'." The television clip of Mr. Florio seen at the beginning is repeated followed by the anti-tax group's phone number "Call 1-800-VETO JIM." 

Text: Mr. Florio is heard in the television film clip saying "It's a good day to be Governor." (Narrator) Not for the 325,000 people who lost their jobs since you became Governor. Not for the families who have lost their homes. Not since you raised taxes $2.8 billion and won't rule out another massive tax increase. Hands Across New Jersey wants to stop Jim Florio before he destroys our economy for good. To support our effort call 1-800-VETO JIM. (Mr. Florio once again is shown waving and saying "It's a good day to be Governor." (Narrator) Not for long, Jim.
 
Analysis: Packaging the perfect screen image in a political attack ad is delicate work where the subliminal can work against, neutralize or even overwhelm the main business of whacking a target with heavy blunt instruments. The tricky element here is the decision to open and close the spot with a television clip of an attractive, almost warm Jim Florio surrounded by what appears to be a receptive crowd. You can search all day for a friendlier visual image of the Governor, who is to warmth what Madonna is to inhibition, and not find it, even in Democratic ads. Check last week's gubernatorial debate: Mr. Florio did not, could not, crack a smile in 60 minutes. Here the producers obviously thought promoting the benign image was worth the darker message: This guy is enjoying himself while the people of New Jersey suffer. The rest is boilerplate seen earlier in television spots of Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican candidate, with whom the tax protest group is closely aligned. A Whitman ad now on the air seeks to blame Mr. Florio's tax policy for the recession, saying the state lost 280,000 jobs since he became Governor in 1990. This Hands Across New Jersey ad bumps the figure to 325,000 and throws in 8,000 failed businesses -- heaping them all on Mr. Florio's shoulders.
 Jon Nordheimer

HEADLINE: Peggy Dennis Dies; Former Communist And Writer Was 84

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
Peggy Dennis, a Communist organizer and author, died on Sept. 25 at the Jewish Home for the Aged in San Francisco. She was 84.
The cause was complications from several strokes, said her son, Eugene Dennis Vrana. 
 Ms. Dennis was the wife of Eugene Dennis, general secretary of the American Communist Party from 1946 to 1959 and one of 12 American Communists jailed in the late 1940's for violating the Smith Act by conspiring to overthrow the Government. Ms. Dennis worked mostly in internal party organizing and for many years served as a courier of messages to Communist leaders in Germany, Poland, France and other countries.
After 1949, she worked primarily as a journalist at The Daily Worker and The People's World. She also wrote many freelance articles on politics and economics for socialist and liberal magazines including The Progressive and The Nation. She moved to San Francisco in 1961 after Mr. Dennis died.
In 1977, a year after she resigned from the Communist Party because of differences with its leadership, she wrote a book based on her experiences as an organizer, "The Autobiography of an American Communist: A Personal View of a Political Life."
A documentary about her life with Mr. Dennis, called "Love in the Cold War," was produced in 1991 by American Experience and Windfall Films and shown on public television in 1992.
Ms. Dennis is survived by two sons, Mr. Vrana of San Francisco and Timur Timofeev of Moscow, and a niece, Laura Bock of San Francisco.

HEADLINE: Bid to Restore Haiti's Leader Is Derailed

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
The two-year-old effort to restore the elected President of Haiti to power was close to collapse today as the United States pulled a troop ship away from Haitian shores and called on the United Nations to renew economic sanctions against the military Government.
Faced with the refusal by authorities in Port-au-Prince, the capital, to allow a ship carrying American and Canadian military engineers and instructors to dock, and with violent demonstrations by Haitians on shore, Administration officials ordered the ship back to sea and said a second troop ship scheduled to leave for Haiti Wednesday would not depart. 
 The steps effectively suspended American military involvement in the agreement reached in July to restore President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to the office from which he was ousted in a military coup in September 1991.
 
Clinton Demands Guarantees
 President Clinton, already under criticism over the deaths of 25 American troops in Somalia, said United States soldiers would not return to Haiti until the country's military leaders guaranteed the security of the advisers and the safe return of Father Aristide.
"I have no intention of sending our people there until the agreement is honored," President Clinton said. "What I intend to do now is press to reimpose the sanctions."
American officials also emphasized that they expected Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, leader of the military Government, to retire on Friday, as he had agreed under the accord to return Father Aristide to power by Oct. 30.
 
Ship Diverted to Guantanamo
 Pentagon officials said the ship, the Harlan County, a tank-landing ship with 175 American and 25 Canadian engineers and advisers aboard, would go to the United States Naval Base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba.
As the ship steamed out of Haitian waters, Haitians jubilantly danced, cheered and fired guns into the air on the shore. [Page A12.]
The decision to withdraw the ship came one day after it was blocked from landing at Port-au-Prince by armed demonstrators who were apparently directed by Haitian security forces opposed to the return of Father Aristide. The violence forced a hasty retreat from the harbor area by the United States charge d'affaires, Vicki Huddleston, and other diplomats.
 
Pressure at Home
 But Administration officials acknowledged that the decision to remove the ship was also influenced by the public and Congressional reaction to the death of American soldiers serving with United Nations peacekeepers in Somalia.
"It's obviously caused increased scrutiny by the Congress and the public of any projection of American military personnel," one senior Administration official said.
But President Clinton stressed that he did not believe the retreat of the troop ship meant the process to restore Father Aristide was at an end. "I do not think it is dead," he told reporters on the South Lawn as he departed for a speech in North Carolina. "I still think it will come back to life."
Father Aristide, speaking in Washington, supported the President's call for a renewal of sanctions.
"Those killers stopped the process yesterday and their removal is indispensable to the restoration of democracy," he said. "I already have the names to replace them."
The Administration's suspension of its role in carrying out the agreement, which had been painstakingly negotiated in July during talks on Governors Island in New York, throws the situation back to where it was in June, when the United Nations Security Council ordered an oil embargo and other economic sanctions against Haiti.
General Cedras and Col. Joseph Michel Francois, the police chief of Port au Prince, are not expected to leave office quietly, as both are supposed to do, and the Administration said it had no intention of using troops to force their removal.
"If one side is reneging, we're not going to shoot our way in there," a senior Administration official said. "They buckled before under the threat of sanctions."
 
Parallels to Somalia
 Even before the developments of the last two days, the Pentagon was a reluctant participant in the Haiti mission, and some members of Congress have recently drawn pointed parallels to United States losses in Somalia.
"We cannot support, indefinitely or in perpetuity, governments -- no matter how much we want to," said Senator Christopher Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat. "We can't sent 600 troops into Haiti and expect to become the police force and the army of Haiti."
Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat who chairs a House subcommittee that oversees policy in the Caribbean, said the Administration needed to rethink the purpose of its mission in Haiti.
"If, indeed, the mission is solely to train security forces, there should now be a change and have them trained in the United States," Mr. Torricelli said. "If the training was really a cover to interject the American military into Haitian affairs, then the Administration is being naive."
But Representative Charles B. Rangel, a New York Democrat whose district contains a large number of Haitian-Americans, expressed "disappointment" in the decision to withdraw the ship, and suggested it was the result of public disquiet over Somalia.
"I recognize a political decision was being made," Mr. Rangel said.
He added that the Administration needed to take urgent action to salvage the Governors Island agreement. "I think we've lost a lot of prestige in the international community," he said, "and it will take the strong response of the President to get us back on the track we were on."
The 600 United States troops are part of an international contingent of 1,300 who are to help Haitians rebuild roads, hospitals, schools and other structures. They are also to train a newly constituted Haitian army. Under the agreement, the international troops are to be lightly armed and would not intervene with force even if they saw Haitian soldiers committing violence.
President Clinton said today that after the threats expressed on Monday toward United States diplomats in Port-au-Prince and the unwillingness of Haitian authorities to control the small mob of demonstrators, he was unsure whether the light weaponry was sufficient.
"The Department of Defense and our military leaders are convinced that the relatively light arms that our people were supposed to carry as advisers are more than adequate to protect themselves as long as the Governors Island agreement is being honored," Mr. Clinton said. "But I am not about to let them land to test it."
Pentagon officials said that Secretary of Defense Les Aspin would again press for the adoption of some of the conditions he proposed last week prior to the sailing of the Harlan County: legislation separating Haiti's military and police forces, the removal of General Cedras and Colonel Francois and a statement from Father Aristide that he welcomes United States military personnel.
Because of the 19-year occupation of Haiti by United States marines beginning in 1915, Haitian politicians are reluctant to embrace the idea of American soliders on their soil.

HEADLINE: Policing a Global Village

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
A clearer demonstration of the global village that modern communications have created, and the land-mines that await American Presidents as a result, would be difficult to imagine.
After more than a dozen American soldiers were killed in street-fighting in Somalia 10 days ago, President Clinton argued that it would be dangerous for the United States to pull out its troops at once, because doing so would only encourage "aggressors, thugs and terrorists" all over the world. 
 Still, he yielded some ground, setting a deadline for full withdrawal by March 31. On American television last weekend, a number of leading Senators went further, suggesting that an earlier withdrawal would be better and warning against sending American units to Bosnia and Herzegovina or Haiti.
 
U.S. Landing in Haiti Fails
 As if on cue, a small gang of toughs, protected by the police, took to the streets of Port-au-Prince, threatening to create "another Somalia" to prevent American troops and other advisers from landing to help in a transition to democratic government that the demonstrators evidently do not want. Some of their leaders said they had been encouraged by what they saw on television.
Mr. Clinton promptly ordered a suspension of the American military effort in Haiti, a country whose entire armed forces consists of 7,000 members, of whom 1,500 are policemen. With the whole United Nations plan for stabilizing Haiti seemingly undermined, economic sanctions are to be tried again.
"So we have a group of 40 or 50 people -- O.K., maybe a hundred or two -- causing the United States and the United Nations to stop dead in their tracks," said a rueful American policy maker. "Somalia, Bosnia and Haiti don't have much in common, except their problems are complicated, what happens in one affects another and the country has no stomach for any of them."
 
'Virtual Collapse' of Leadership
 Senator Richard Lugar of Indiana, a Republican known both for his expertise in foreign affairs and for his judiciousness, spoke today of what he termed "the virtual collapse of Presidential leadership in these matters."
"The roof has fallen in," Senator Lugar said in a telephone interview. "There is no significant Congressional support for the President's policy in any of the three countries, and it's his own fault. A few people have stood beside him, but not because they agree with him. They are doing it solely out of loyalty to the Constitution and the role of the Commander-in-Chief."
That is so, he declared, because of failure by Mr. Clinton to discuss with Congress either the change of goals in Somalia from feeding the hungry to nation-building and pursuing Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, the elusive factional leader, or the plan for trying to restore democracy to Haiti.
 
Legislative 'Safety Net'
 "A President needs to coopt the leadership of Congress in any foreign-policy venture, however small, and the sooner the better," Mr. Lugar said. "That gives him a safety net if things go wrong, as they usually do, either temporarily or definitively."
Mr. Clinton's advisers depict themselves as pioneers, groping their way toward new principles in a post-Cold War world. It is uncharted ground, and they admit that they are having trouble. No one has had to do this, they say, since the 1950's, and containment was not a policy born overnight.
"Every one of these situations involves a lot of imponderables," a senior State Department official said. "It's not easy to define our national interests, to decide when to intervene, to see all the consequences of intervention, to know when to declare victory and end the intervention. And there's no upside. You win, and nobody in the general public cares much, you lose American lives and the country demands that you pull your horns in."
The President's top foreign-policy advisers, most of them formed in the Vietnam years, are unwilling to sharply limit the exertion of American power and influence, even in an era of scarce financial resources and even when they know their boss wants to spend most of his energy on domestic affairs.
 
Speech on Somalia
 But as Mr. Lugar remarked, Mr. Clinton has not done the spade-work on Capitol Hill; for that matter, he has not done it with the public at large. His speech last week about Somalia was well enough received, though some thought it lacked the zest and conviction of his address to a joint session of Congress on health care.
After it, however, polls showed that as many as 60 percent of American citizens still thought the United States should get out of Somalia, and in the Senate, there was still strong sentiment to do so before year's end.
There are obviously limitations on what sorts of foreign policies any President can sell, especially when American soldiers are dying and when the national interest is difficult to define. Lyndon B. Johnson discovered that in Vietnam, and his experience made his successors tread extremely carefully.
Mr. Clinton, on the other hand, has involved himself, or allowed himself to become involved, in a number of nettlesome problems at once. What is more, all of them have underlying political dimensions, too seldom fully explained, that make achieving what may seem like simple goals very difficult indeed.
 
Underlying Political Factors
 The problem in Somalia, for instance, was not really hunger; that was merely a symptom of the country's lack of anything approaching an effective government, and that, in turn, was merely a symptom of the hatred of one clan for another.
The real problem in Haiti is the reluctance of the military and the police to relinquish the power that they have enjoyed since the days of the Duvalier dictatorship, as they would have to do if the country is to gain a semblance of stability so its people will stop fleeing in small boats.
Helmut Sonnenfeldt, a foreign affairs scholar at the Brookings Institution who has served in several Administrations, said the danger in what has happened now in Haiti was two-fold.
First, and most obviously, Mr. Sonnenfeldt said, it may send a signal to others elsewhere that "you don't have to do much to take a bite out of the superpower" -- precisely the point that Mr. Clinton made about Somalia. Beyond that, he said, "there is the possibility of a grave miscalculation" -- the chance that someone, somewhere, may watch the United States struggling to define new policies and try something that Washington cannot tolerate.
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq seems to have made just such a miscalculation on the basis of ambiguous American diplomacy, and the result was the war in the Persian Gulf.

HEADLINE: A Talent for Rewriting History

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Two iconoclasts who practically reinvented the field of economic history, Robert W. Fogel of the University of Chicago and Douglass C. North of Washington University in St. Louis, won the 1993 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science yesterday, the first time the prize was awarded for work in economic history.
"Bob and Doug are clearly the leaders of the new economic history, the most visible, the ones with the most impact," said Peter Temin, an economic historian at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. 
 This is the fourth year in a row that the prize has gone to an economist at the University of Chicago, an institution that has fallen out of favor with some economists in the post-Reagan era.
 
Historical Puzzle Masters
 The professors were honored by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences for "applying economic theory and quantitative methods" to historical puzzles, ranging from the role of the Ten Commandments in an economy to slavery in the antebellum South to starvation in England and America in the Industrial Revolution.
Credited with founding "cliometrics," as their rigorous, number-crunching brand of history came to be known (in Greek mythology, Clio is the muse of history), Professors Fogel and North were also praised by the academy for digging up large amounts of fresh data and creating huge computer data bases.
Professor North, 72, helped bring cliometrics to the fore through his work on Colonial American economics and as an editor of the Journal of Economic History in the early 1960's, where he published the work of young Turks, including Professor Fogel.
But Professor Fogel, 67, pudgy, bespectacled and somewhat rumpled, is the better known of the two, in large part because since his student days in the 1940's and 1950's he has been regarded as both brilliant and something of a bomb thrower.
 
Challenged Established Views
 A charming man who has attracted a following of top-notch students, Professor Fogel, the son of Russian immigrants, got a relatively late start in economics. By the time he arrived at Columbia University in the 1950's to study statistics, he had spent several years as a Communist youth organizer, married and had two sons.
The first assault on conventional wisdom by Professor Fogel, in a 1964 book based on his master's thesis, was to contend that railroads were not nearly so critical to American economic development as Joseph Schumpeter, Walt W. Rostow and other prominent historians believed. By contrasting history with a hypothetical alternative, Professor Fogel boldly concluded that railroads had contributed less than three percentage points to the growth of the economy and that industrialization depended less on big technological breakthroughs than on smaller innovations.
"Bob wants to be known as the supreme empiricist, the great numbers person, the person who establishes what a fact is," said a former student, Claudia Goldin, now an economics professor at Harvard. "It just so happens that the facts he establishes are rather controversial."
A book on slavery that he wrote with Stanley L. Engerman, "Time on the Cross" (Little Brown, 1974), touched off an intellectual firestorm and made Professor Fogel an instant celebrity. The book challenged the accepted view that slavery was a moribund system destined to self-destruct and that slaves were treated like concentration camp inmates, beaten, starved and worked to death.
Using provocative language and aiming for a mass audience instead of the academic world, Professor Fogel argued that the owners of slaves looked upon slaves as economic assets and treated them as they would treat livestock, that slavery was an efficient system for growing cotton and that the system collapsed for political -- not economic -- reasons.
Relying on everything from accounts of slave auctions to plantation medical records to crop yields, Professor Fogel asserted: "The typical slave field hand was not lazy, inept and unproductive. On average he was harder working and more efficient than his white counterpart." The book's last sentence reads, "It's time to reveal, not only to blacks but to whites as well, that part of American history which has been kept from them -- the record of black achievement under adversity."
Professor Fogel's views were never fully accepted, but even critics acknowledged that the professor's research altered the prevailing consensus on the economics of slavery.
When "Time on the Cross" was published, it was even attacked as racist, and the ensuing controversy was so bitter -- shattering friendships and splitting the profession -- and the questions raised were so numerous, that Professor Fogel subsequently wrote "Without Consent or Contract" (W. W. Norton, 1989) to clarify his findings and include a moral condemnation of slavery. Professor Fogel's wife of 44 years, Enid, a former dean at Harvard, is black.
Today his research, which focuses on the decline of hunger and the lengthening of life spans in Europe and America, remains unconventional, showing that starvation was a major problem far more recently than most people realize. At the time of the French Revolution, he shows, France had lower food consumption than India a century and a half later and roughly one-fourth of the growth in per capita income in Europe and America since that time can be traced to improved nutrition.
 
A Historical Theoretician
 Professor North is a diminutive and white-haired man with an effervescent personality, a dog named Clio and a fondness for fast cars and fine wine. In contrast to Professor Fogel, who is famous for particular propositions, Professor North is a theoretician among historians, associated with a methodology and a framework that emphasizes institutions and how they evolve over time.
"Economists generally believe that markets, not institutions, are what matters," Professor Goldin said. "What Doug pointed to is economic historians' keenest insight, which is that markets are embedded in institutions. And that institutions change slowly over time, and therefore, that history matters."
One of the few controversies Professor North caused came in selling bottles of wine to his fellow cliometricians at the historians' annual conferences -- at a significant markup.
Professor North said yesterday that his work had gained greater currency since the collapse of Communism -- and the struggle to build market economies in countries where market-friendly institutions have not existed for half a century, if ever.
"Political institutions are as important as economic institutions," he said. "What happened in Central and Eastern Europe radically changed views about economic theory. Economists have no theory about that kind of change."
He added that accepted theory suggests that just putting a macroeconomic policy in place is not enough and that there also must be a body of law -- patent law, contract law, property rights -- "that gives people the right incentives to engage in economic activity."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Two economic historians were named as winners of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science yesterday. Robert W. Fogel, above, celebrated with his wife, Enid, at the University of Chicago. Douglass C. North, below, of Washington University, received flowers at home. (Photographs by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: ISRAEL SELLS ARMS TO CHINA, U.S. SAYS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Israel has sold advanced military technology to China for more than a decade and is moving to expand its cooperation with Beijing, says R. James Woolsey, the Director of Central Intelligence.
The C.I.A. assessment was provided in written responses to questions by the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee. The committee made the assessment public last week as part of a report on recent hearings it conducted on "proliferation threats of the 1990's," a committee aide said on Monday. 
 There have been many news reports about the sale of Israeli military technology to China, which did not establish diplomatic relations with Israel until 1992, and the Rand Corporation has made similar assessments. The C.I.A.'s response to the committee was reported on Monday by NBC News and confirmed by the aide.
 
Jets, Missiles and Tanks
 The C.I.A. says China has been acquiring advanced military technology from Israel for more than a decade on programs for jet fighters, air-to-air missiles and tanks. The agency said the sale of Israeli military technology to China "may be several billion dollars."
Despite the previous reports, the bluntness of the C.I.A. assessment surprised Congressional specialists and appears to reflect a growing concern among American intelligence experts that China is seeking to use Israel to obtain the sort of advanced military technology that the United States and other Western nations have refused to sell to Beijing.
China's acquisition of military technology -- and re-export to Pakistan, Iran and other countries -- is a major challenge to Western efforts to stem the spread of dangerous weapons.
Explaining its assessment, the agency noted that Beijing and Tel Aviv recently signed an agreement to cooperate in sharing technology in a number of areas, including electronics and space. Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel was visiting China today to discuss the broadening of ties.
 
Israelis Open Offices in China
 In addition, an increasing number of Israeli military companies have opened offices in China to sell their products.
The agency's assessment is likely to provoke calls by members of Congress for greater scrutiny of the sale of American military technology to Israel.
Ruth Yaron, a spokeswoman at the Israeli Embassy, said today that Israel had not transferred American military technology to China. "Israel adheres to all of its commitments to the United States with regard to its relationship with China," she said.
An Israeli diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity, noted that the four-paragraph C.I.A. statement to the committee did not say the Israelis had been re-exporting American technology.

HEADLINE: President Defends His Policies as Adding to Personal Security

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. Oct. 11

 BODY:
Offering a broad defense of his Administration's domestic and international priorities, President Clinton said tonight that the United States "cannot withdraw from the world we have done so much to make."
Speaking to more than 40,000 students, alumni and staff members celebrating the University of North Carolina's bicentennial, Mr. Clinton tried to link his initiatives on expanded trade, crime control and health care. 
 But in a nod to recent events abroad that have tended to overshadow the more politically valuable domestic issues, Mr. Clinton emphasized the importance of maintaining a viable foreign policy agenda.
Paying attention to all of these priorities, the President said, Americans will be provided with a blanket of security that will see the nation through periods of economic and global turbulence.
"The security we seek is like a rope for a rock climber, to lift those who will take responsibility for their own lives to even greater pinnacles," he said.
The need for personal security, he said, demands the passage of his health care proposals that would provide insurance coverage for all Americans as well as anti-crime measures that restrict the sale of guns and add more police officers.
"We must protect our people better against the ravages of violence," he said. "Our people have a right to feel safe where they live, where they go to school and where they work."
In his speech, Mr. Clinton also emphasized the connection between foreign policy and domestic policy.
As for his efforts on the domestic front like health care reform and passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that many of the items he is asking Congress to approve must first overcome opposition in many quarters, including members of organized labor.
 
'Imposes a Responsibility'
 "Our communities won't be secure until people who disagree on everything else stop shouting at each other long enough to realize that we have to save the kids who are in trouble the same way we lost them -- one child at a time," he said. "And it imposes a responsibility on each and every one of us."
Mr. Clinton's appeal to personal security has emerged in recent weeks as his advisers have sought for an overarching thesis that could put the President's opponents on the defensive while lifting Mr. Clinton onto the high ground as he fights for passage of his health care plan -- even though Congress has not yet received an actual bill.
But Mr. Clinton has had some trouble maintaining that momentum as one foreign policy crisis after another -- including the turbulence in Russia, the killing of American troops in Somalia, and the rejection of American troops in Haiti -- has distracted him from the domestic issues he would prefer to address.
Today, for instance, Mr. Clinton and his aides devoted more energy to hammering out a way to beat a path out of Haiti than in selling any single domestic issue.
And in his remarks tonight, the President also acknowledged six soldiers killed in Somalia who were stationed at Fort Bragg, N.C.

He spoke in Kenan Stadium during the university's bicentennial ceremonies. (Associated Press)
