HEADLINE: Is Women's Health Harmed By Medical Specialization?

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Medical care for most men is one-stop shopping: a trip to a general doctor for a physical examination that includes full preventive care. But that approach works poorly for a woman, new studies have shown, with tests like Pap smears often overlooked, particularly if the doctor is a man.
In practice, many women insure complete care by making the medical rounds: they visit a generalist, a gynecologist for Pap tests and maybe even a breast cancer specialist for breast examinations and mammograms. Now many public health experts are saying that there must be a better way. 
 "There is a growing and substantial body of evidence that for a long time women's health issues have not received enough attention," said Dr. Nicole Lurie, author of a recent study in The New England Journal of Medicine that highlighted some of the shortcomings in women's care.
 
Beginning in Adolescence
 "Previously we've talked about deficiencies on a national level -- in terms of not enough research on women's health. Now we are saying it's also a problem on a very basic clinical level -- that patients are not getting what they need."
Although many men as well as women find themselves visiting more than one doctor as they age, women's care is fragmented from adolescence on.
While most medical experts agree that a woman's basic medical care could be consolidated under one doctor, they debate whether that doctor should be an internist, a family practitioner, a gynecologist or a doctor who specializes in the new field of women's health.
Also, given that two recent studies have found male doctors to be lax in performing Pap tests and ordering mammograms, some women's health advocates are wondering whether women should be advised to seek out doctors who are women.
 
Shortcomings in Training
 "We favor provision of care by any type of primary care physician, but we feel that none of them right now are trained well in women's health," said Eileen McGrath, executive director of the American Medical Women's Association.
The association sponsored a conference yesterday in Washington to discuss ways to improve women's health care, and has designed a course to teach practicing general doctors "what they didn't learn in medical school."
President Clinton's proposal to overhaul the nation's health care system specifically guarantees coverage for Pap smears and mammograms, but on a slightly less frequent basis than the association and other women's health advocates would like to see. As a result, the details of such screening are under review.
Dr. Vicki Hufnagle, an obstetrician-gynecologist at Thompson Memorial Hospital in Burbank, Calif., says she believes that women need doctors devoted to their care. She recently opened a chain of women's health bookstores, called Her Body, and is organizing a women's hospital whose staff will include a urologist who focuses on treating women, a plastic surgeon who can remove defective breast implants and gynecologists who, where possible, will remove tumors without taking out the entire uterus or ovaries.
But she said that merely choosing a woman as a doctor might not guarantee good care. "All doctors are trained the same and learn the same myths about women's bodies, so you may feel more comfortable with a women, but you may not be better off," she said.
But Dr. Peter Franks, author of another recent study comparing the competence of male and female doctors in taking care of women, cautioned against jumping to the conclusion that the doctor's office was hazardous to women.
 
Superior Health of Women
 "It is politically correct to talk about how women don't get a fair shake from the health care system, and that's true to some extent, since most physicians are male," he said. "But if you look at medical outcomes, women do much better than men. They live longer, they have lower rates of mortality from the same diseases, they use the health care system more -- and more effectively."
There are no good statistics about where women currently get their medical care, although there is some evidence to suggest that women who are better educated and wealthier are more likely to have at least two doctors, a generalist and a gynecologist.
Although some health maintenance organizations require women who are enrolled in their plans to choose one primary doctor -- a family practitioner, internist or gynecologist -- others allow women to have a general doctor, as well as yearly visits to a gynecologist for Pap smears and pelvic examinations.
"Women get extremely mixed signals from the health care community about who should be their doctor," said Dr. Carolyn Clancy, director of primary care at the Federal Agency for Health Care Policy and Research in Rockville, Md. "The issue to me is how and why gynecologic issues got separated out into a special area instead of being part of general care." Pap smears and breast examinations should be easy for doctors to learn and perform, Dr. Clancy said.
Unfortunately, health policy experts say that given current practice, they see potential drawbacks with both approaches.
"There may be problems with having two doctors," said Dr. Franks, who is an associate professor of family medicine at the University of Rochester. "Problems can fall between the cracks. But there may also be problems in having one, if that doctor cannot provide the needed range of services."
Public health experts say that many internists and gynecologists have become so specialized that they are no longer capable of full-service care. Internists, for example, may have no practical training in performing Pap smears or pelvic examinations. And gynecologists have no formal training in managing asthma or bronchitis or back sprains in nonpregnant women.
 
Lack of Practical Experience
 Although internists and family practitioners must all memorize the screening guidelines for women -- and have book knowledge of issues surrounding menopause and contraceptive counseling -- many have little practical experience in such areas.
"Even though there are guidelines for Pap smears and mammograms, what doctors do is different in practice," said Dr. Margo Krasnoff, assistant professor of medicine at the Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center in Lebanon, N.H. "In terms of talking about menopause or nutrition, different doctors do drastically different things."
Dr. Clancy said she suspected that many women of childbearing age relied exclusively on an obstetrician-gynecologist for medical care. "A lot of family practitioners say ob-gyns don't have the training to do it," she said. "The gynecologists say, 'Of course, I provide it. I have to. I'm her only doctor.' "
And she added: "There is very little evidence about how good gynecologists are at general care. I think that there is evidence that women who go to one doctor right now -- whether a family practitioner, an internist or a gynecologist -- have great holes in their care."
In a recent study in The Annals of Internal Medicine, Dr. Alan Deitrich and his colleagues at Dartmouth sent actresses in their mid-50's posing as patients to hundreds of doctors' offices for checkups. Internists as well as family practitioners were included in the study.
Although Dr. Deitrich said that generally "the doctors did quite well in preventive care," he also pointed to a few disappointments, like the fact that only two-thirds performed breast examinations and few did any dietary counseling. The study could not establish whether the doctors properly performed Pap smears, since the actresses were instructed to say that they had had a Pap smear at a free clinic within the last six months. The doctors' visits lasted 5 to 60 minutes and the charge ranged from nothing to $108.
"I think women need to have some sense of what they want when they go for an annual checkup," Dr. Deitrich said.
Two recent studies comparing the effectiveness of male and female doctors in caring for women have also raised concerns. Dr. Lurie and her colleagues at Hennepin County Medical Center in Minneapolis surveyed the records of more than 100,000 women and found that female internists and family practitioners performed twice as many Pap tests as their male counterparts and ordered 40 percent more mammograms.
Most surprising, perhaps, is that the difference in care was greatest among younger doctors. Public health experts generally believe that younger doctors are best at preventive care, since such screening has only been added to medical education in recent years.
A similar study by Dr. Franks and Dr. Clancy, published this year in the journal Medical Care, found that women who used female doctors were more likely to have had a Pap test in the last three years and to have had a mammogram at some point in their lives. Male and female doctors did equally well in screening female patients for medical conditions that were not unique to women, like high blood pressure or cholesterol.
 
Possible Reason for Better Care
 The researchers in both studies cautioned that it was possible that women who sought out female doctors were more attuned to women's health issues and would have undergone more screening tests regardless of the advice of their doctors. But Dr. Lurie added that the very clear guidelines concerning mammograms and Pap smears should have reduced disparities and that even greater differences in care might exist in areas like menopause counseling, where the correct course was muddy.
"My sense is this is the tip of the iceberg with respect to issues of women's health," she said. "As women in the baby boom become perimenopausal, this will be a hot new issue that will probably be attended to differently by different doctors."
Dr. Franks said: "It did seem like women were more tuned into problems that women have. But that's not so surprising. If you look at race, you see that white physicians are less good at dealing with problems that affect minorities. In general, people are better at dealing with the problems of people like themselves."
While some health experts contend that the best way to improve women's health is to make women's care its own specialty, others favor improving the quality of medical education and general care.
"I personally would like to see general doctors have the skills and the psychosocial training to take care of both men and women," Dr. Krasnoff said. "I don't think creating a women's health specialty is going to help women's health-care needs in this country. Anyway, there are not enough female physicians to take care of all the women in this country."
To that end, Dartmouth Medical School now offers a women's health elective to internal medicine residents, where they get one-on-one training on health issues from pelvic examinations to contraception.
But Dr. Franks added that it was not the sex of a patient so much as race or economic status that disenfranchised patients from medical care.
"I do think we need to make a better effort -- I think it is being made -- to make sure that care is sensitive to gender," Dr. Franks said. "But I think issues are much less powerful than the issue of race or class when we're dealing with patients who are different than we are."

HEADLINE: Labor Secretary to Urge Clinton To Propose Minimum Wage Rise

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said today that he would urge the President to propose increasing the minimum wage, now $4.25 an hour, most likely by 25 cents.
But Mr. Reich said that the pay increase would be coupled with an increase in benefits, like insurance as provided under the President's health care plan, that could bring the value of the total increase to 50 cents an hour. 
 In an interview with reporters after speaking at the National Press Club, Mr. Reich said that how big the proposed increase in straight pay would be would depend on how much employers end up paying for other benefits, he said. He estimated that for many employers the cost of providing health insurance for minimum-wage workers, as President Clinton's health plan would require, would be from 15 cents to 35 cents an hour.
 
Backpedaling by Reich
 In an interview late today, after some White House officials had grown uneasy about Mr. Reich's suggestion of raising the minimum wage, the Labor Secretary backpedaled a bit, saying that he had not decided on any specific recommendation and that his proposal could end up amounting to less than 50 cents, including an increase in benefits.
Mr. Reich said he was convinced that a 50-cent-an-hour increase in the minimum wage would not lead to a net decrease in jobs -- an assertion disputed by many business lobbyists.
Mr. Reich has become the foremost champion of a higher minimum wage in an Administration in which some officials are leery of raising the minimum wage for fear of antagonizing the business community, already upset about the tax increases passed in Mr. Clinton's budget this summer.
Mr. Reich, saying he would make his proposal to the President within two weeks, defended the plan by explaining that the minimum wage, after accounting for inflation, was 30 percent below its 1968 level.
In addition, he pointed to studies by economists from Harvard University and Princeton University that show an increase in the minimum wage could actually increase employment by encouraging people who were not working to seek jobs.
"A 25-cent increase in the minimum wage to $4.50, combined with the health care plan, would be equivalent to quite a modest increase in employer costs for low-wage workers that would be within the range for which little or no adverse impact would be predicted," Mr. Reich said in a statement issued after his speech at the Press Club.
But Carlos Bonilla, chief economist at the Employment Policies Institute, a Washington research group financed by many companies with low-wage workers, asserted that the 50-cent increase would cause a loss of jobs and harm the economy.
"When you recognize that requiring all employers to pay health insurance can raise the cost for hiring some entry-level workers by $2,000 a year, it's incredibly insensitive to talk about raising these costs further with an increase in the minimum wage," Mr. Bonilla said. "You can probably do it without any catastrophic job loss, but you can't do it without any job loss."
Administration officials said the President's National Economic Council, which coordinates economic policy, had not yet received Mr. Reich's proposal. But some of the officials said that increasing the minimum wage was a politically sensitive issue and that Mr. Reich's recommendations might be scaled back.
In a memorandum he sent to President Clinton in July, Mr. Reich, without making a formal recommendation, indicated that he favored increasing the minimum wage to $4.50 an hour and then indexing it to keep up with inflation. "Indexing the minimum wage at $4.50 an hour is a minimum prerequisite to reaching the goal of lifting families of four with full-time workers out of poverty," he wrote.
His statement today was arguably more generous, because it envisioned an increase to $4.75, if increased health benefits are included. Mr. Reich said today that he had not decided whether to call for indexing the increase in the minimum wage.

HEADLINE: Clinton Will Recommend More Spending Cuts

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
President Clinton plans to propose an additional $10 billion to $15 billion in spending cuts later this month to make good on promises he made to win votes for his budget package in August, Administration and Congressional officials said today.
The new package of cuts, which will be spread over the next five years, is bound to create a storm on Capitol Hill, several lawmakers said. Some members of Congress think the anticipated package is too small, while others suggested that the proposed reductions would cause howls of protest from lawmakers whose favorite programs would come under attack. 
 Administration officials said the $10 billion to $15 billion in cuts would be proposed to Congress late this month, after passage of appropriations bills. Several officials said most reductions would ones recommended in Vice President Al Gore's report on trimming waste and streamlining the Federal bureaucracy.
Several influential lawmakers voiced disappointment with the size of the new package. "I wish I could persuade them to do more," said Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, who pressed President Clinton during the budget battle to be more aggressive about cutting the deficit. "For economic reasons and to give taxpayers confidence that we're paying attention, the cuts should be deeper. I'd like to see him start off with $7 to $8 billion in cuts the first year. Ten billion would be even better."
 
Other Plans for Savings
 Administration officials said one reason the proposed reductions would not be larger was that they plan to use some savings from Mr. Gore's efforts for programs against crime and to finance President Clinton's investment programs, including retraining efforts and high-speed trains. Congress sharply scaled back many of these programs in the budget battle.
One official said that with all the claims on the billions of dollars that the Vice President's waste-cutting program aims to achieve, the Administration might ultimately propose less than $10 billion in spending reductions.
Not all the additional savings would come from Mr. Gore's proposals, several officials said. The Administration might, for example, propose some reductions in money already appropriated for this year.
 
Hopes in Congress
 Like Senator Kerrey, Representative Timothy J. Penny, a Minnesota Democrat who negotiated with the Administration about spending reductions during the budget battle, said he hoped that the Administration would come up with more than $10 to $15 billion in cuts.
He said he was working with other Republicans and Democrats in Congress who hope to add to the President's package so it would make at least $50 billion more in spending cuts over the next five years.
"I was hoping the Administration would propose something in the $20 to $30 billion range for five years, and then we'd add to that," Mr. Penny said.
Several lawmakers said they feared that the Administration's spending reductions would be so small that they would be ridiculed, especially since Congress almost always cuts less than is proposed.
Representative Marjorie Margolies-Mezvinsky, a Pennsylvania Democrat who is a member of the bipartisan group looking for additional cuts, said the group was working with the Administration to find new cuts in required spending for programs like Medicare. She was one of the last Democrats to vote for the President's budget package, helping provide its one-vote margin in the House.
She said the President had agreed to participate in a Dec. 13 conference in her district that will examine such programs. She won the Administration's commitment to participate in the conference before the budget was passed.

HEADLINE: Opposites in California Join to Fight Trade Pact

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8

 BODY:
The opposition President Clinton faces in selling the North American Free Trade Agreement has a thousand voices, and many of them could be heard at a lunch-hour rally here a few days ago.
From the bandstand, Eddie Starr, a steelworker from Granite City, Ill., led the crowd of 300 in a ballad of the moment: 
 Say no, say no,
Don't let them send our jobs to Mexico.
Say no, say no,
'cause Nafta's such a sorry way to go.
In the crowd are three young women wearing tags saluting the grizzly bear, the California condor and the giant kangaroo rat, animals they say the agreement would hurt.
There are Chinese-Americans and Mexican-Americans here, Gray Panthers and college students, as well as followers of Ross Perot, Jerry Brown, Ralph Nader and Jesse Jackson. In other times, carpenters' union leaders and the Sierra Club's defenders of trees would not have been seen on the same side of the street. They carry signs. "Nafta Pollutes." "Shafta Nafta." "For Workers. For the Earth. Labor & Enviros Working Together."
This is the grass of many roots. Here, and in states as diverse as Minnesota, Illinois, Georgia, Massachusetts and Michigan, coalitions of otherwise improbable allies have mounted an unusually broad campaign to try to stop a President from doing something that he insists would be good for them and that they are convinced would be anything but.
 
California Problems
 California, with unemployment at 9 percent and legions of environmental advocacy groups, is an epicenter of a loosely coordinated, low-budget struggle to bring pressure on Congress. Here, and throughout the state, the groups are directing their campaign at 10 to 12 of California's 52 House members to reject the agreement, which would gradually eliminate tariffs, quotas and other barriers to trade among the United States, Mexico and Canada.
For the moment, there's little doubt about whom the groups in San Francisco are after. The biggest banner they carry reads, "Save Your Job. Stop Nafta. Call Congr. Nancy Pelosi. 415-556-4682." Ms. Pelosi, who represents the Bay Area's Eighth Congressional District, is resolutely ambivalent about her vote, or, as she put it, "definitely undecided."
As lobbying organizations go, this one seems small potatoes. A tiny lobby in Washington, the Citizens' Trade Campaign, keeps track of local efforts but contributes little else. Craig Merrilees, director of California Fair Trade, which is coordinating the groups in the state, has a staff of one. His says his budget for this year is about $100,000, raised mostly from environmental foundations and a few labor unions.
 
Lesson of Polls
 What drives him, he says, are polls showing that the more people learn about the trade agreement the less they like it. And then there's the vigor of volunteers like Gladys Mendelson. Ms. Mendelson is a husky, 39-year-old member of the communications workers union whose regular job is climbing poles for Pacific Bell and installing telephone lines.
A die-hard San Francisco Giants fan, she parked her 1988 Ford Ranger outside Candlestick Park before games and covered it with signs with messages like, "Stop Nafta. Call Nancy Pelosi."
"First it was just me and my pickup," Ms. Mendelson said. "People come up. They ask me, 'What is Nafta?' Those are the ones I wanted." Other volunteers climbed aboard the truck to help hand out flyers.
Her problem with Nafta? "I'm a dyed-in-the-wool Democrat," she said. "The Nafta was put together by Bush. Bush and Reagan did a good job of destroying America. Another big thing is the environment. Corporations going down there polluting the Rio Grande. People living in boxes. Drinking polluted water."
Picketing, demonstrating, sending out post cards, manning phone banks, stocking Ms. Mendelson with flyers -- the tactics of this campaigns -- are scheduled and organized at Wednesday night meetings, beginning promptly at 6, ending promptly at 7:30. Mr. Merrilees conducts them around a conference table at the offices of San Francisco Central Labor Council.
A disparate group of 35 men and 10 women gathers around the table and along the walls. Bundles of paper -- flyers and posters -- are passed around.
Mr. Merrilees took up what he perceived as an immediate threat to jobs in California: a gathering in San Jose sponsored by a business-relocation company. He passed around copies of a brochure from the concern, the PHH Fantus Company, that invites local business leaders to "meet personally with representatives from hundreds of business-friendly communities from across the nation and Mexico" and to learn about relocation issues like severance pay.
Mr. Merrilees told his group to go to the meeting and do some undercover work. "We need to send in some folks who say they're from XYZ Company," he said. "Ask about unions. Ask about the environment. Don't do anything illegal. But try to document what info they give the businessman."
Mr. Merrilees said the trade agreement would expand such business-relocation efforts.
Finally, he invited members of the group to report on meetings that they have had with Ms. Pelosi. What he heard was something about how politicians sit on the fence.
"I think Nancy Pelosi supports Nafta 100 percent," one man said. A woman from the Sierra Club reported, "She's leaning more or less our way." A Perot follower said she told him: "I've done the service of listening to you. Now I want to listen to my President."
Robert Lehman of the Coalition for Fair Trade said, "It was very hard to pin her down. She said: 'Maybe I'll make up my mind next week. Maybe I'll make it up five minutes before the vote.' "
 
Accurate Impressions
 Ms. Pelosi said they were reading her about right. The demonstrations and grass-roots alarm over Nafta "are a metaphor for the jobless of the last 12 years, the Reagan-Bush years," she said.
Is it possible that this exotic mix of compatriots will endure to tackle other big issues? "I don't care to be in bed with Ross Perot," said Jim Vaughan of a carpenters' local in San Francisco, "but this is an issue we agree on." Jaye Bell, a Perot worker, allowed only, "At this point, we're going issue by issue."
But Michael Knab of carpenters' local 217 in San Mateo County seemed to say conciliation was possible on any issue, including one that has divided environmentalists and people like him. "The spotted owl?" he said. "Yeah, that's a tough one. We need the jobs, but there's got to be a way so you don't have to cut every tree. We shouldn't be building on every available site. We want to be responsible, too."
Here, if not as yet with Ms. Pelosi, these alliances can bear fruit. Another politician, State Treasurer Kathleen Brown, a Democrat who is running for Governor, credits the movement in part for her opposition to the pact.
Certainly, the state's battered economy contributed to her position, she said. So did dissatisfaction with what she said were inadequate modifications that the Clinton Administration negotiated.
"But," she said at a reception with labor union leaders last week, "the other piece -- this wide range of people who just didn't get it -- made it hard for me to make a case" that the agreement is good for the average Californian. Borrowing a slogan of the campaign, she said, "It just added up to 'not this Nafta.' "

HEADLINE: Asian Republic Still Caught in Web of Communism

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUSHANBE, Tajikistan

 BODY:
When the Soviet Union was disintegrating, one of the first statues of Lenin to be pulled down in Central Asia was in this sleepy capital. It was replaced by a statue of Abul Qasim Firdawsi, a 10th-century poet.
Yet today, poets and writers are in jail or exile, and on tree-lined boulevards, neon hammer-and-sickle emblems hang from the lampposts. 
 Two years after Tajikistan declared its independence, there is still no private ownership of land and the collective and state farms in the south, where cotton is king, still bear names like Lenin, Communism and Fifty Years of the U.S.S.R.
At the University of Dushanbe, Communists challenge democratically minded professors. The hallway in a rural primary school is lined with photographs of Tajik heroes of the Bolshevik Revolution.
 
Semi-Hemi-Demi-Communists
 "We are still a Communist country," said Safarali Boymnrodov, the school's principal.
In spite of all this, Tajik and foreign observers insist, the Government is not really Communist. The Tajik leaders, these observers say, have no deep ideological commitment, but are devoted primarily to staying in power. A local university professor said it would be more accurate to describe the Government as totalitarian.
Whatever the labels, Government officials are not talking. Repeated requests for interviews drew no response.
For all the Government's shortcomings, however, it has the backing of Moscow and Washington because the alternative, as they see it, is a Government under the influence of radical Islamic elements from abroad.
 
The Russian Presence
 The main backer is Russia, which has more than 20,000 troops in Tajikistan whose primary mission is to keep fighters, weapons and drugs from entering from Afghanistan. There are almost daily skirmishes between Afghan and Russian troops.
The fighting is an outgrowth of violence last year that convulsed Tajikistan, a backwater nation of about 5.6 million people that is slightly larger than New York State. Though no one knows for sure, it has been generally reported that at least 20,000 were killed and that more than half a million were forced to flee their homes.
But the struggle is not a battle between Communism and Islamic fundamentalism. Though the Islamic Renaissance Party, which is supported by Iran, was a faction in the opposition, it did not call for an Islamic state, and now even Iran's influence has faded.
 
The Minority Peoples' Presence
 Nor is the fighting an ethnic conflict, like those in Georgia and Azerbaijan. There are ethnic divisions here; Uzbeks make up about 24 percent of the population. But the political strife arises mainly from clan and regional loyalties.
Under the Soviet Union, the government of Tajikistan was made up mostly of people from the northern province, which was known as Leninabad but was renamed Khojand. They ruled in an alliance with the southern province of Kulyab. The mountainous eastern regions, Garm and Pamir, the poorest areas of the poorest of the Soviet republics, were left out.
Once the firm Soviet hand was gone, the Garmis and Pamiris began demanding a larger share of government resources and formed a loose alliance with organizations espousing everything from Islam to Tajik nationalism to democracy.
For a while Moscow remained neutral. But worried about the increasing influence of the Muslims in the opposition, Russia sent up to 20,000 troops to support a Government headed by a hard-line Communist from Kulyab, Emomali Rakhmonov. Mr. Rakhmonov and his backers also had military help from neighboring Uzbekistan, whose President, Islam Karimov, is another hard-line Communist.
Russia is now providing Tajikistan with at least half its budget, as well as key military units. But the Tajik leaders cannot seem to decide whether they want Communism or capitalism, democracy or one-party rule.
 
The Presence of Corruption
 Some confusion is due to corruption, which according to several diplomats and United Nations officials reaches into the highest levels. For example the Government is reluctant to break up the state farms because they provide jobs for people willing to pay bribes.
Former Communist countries in Eastern Europe have discovered that the place to begin privatization is in the service sector -- hairdressers, laundries, television-repair shops. But even that has not happened here, because the head of the Government agency that oversees this sector does not want to lose his lucrative fief.
What Tajikistan needs, several diplomats suggested, are international organizations to engage in small-scale development. But the country is not likely to get much help because of the human rights situation.
 
The Presence of Terror
 Last winter, after gaining control of Dushanbe, the Government and the forces that backed it went about eliminating the opposition. "It was a real blood bath," a Western diplomat said.
People were stopped on the street or pulled out of bread lines and required to show their identification papers. If they were Garmis or Pamiris, they were taken away. Many were shot.
The abuses continue. In late July, for example, Saidshov Shoev, a member of Parliament, was abducted. Maj. Jorgen Muller, a military adviser to the United Nations, said Mr. Shoev was taken away in a Government car.
"I do not know where my sons are, nobody will help me," said Mr. Shoev's mother, Adolat Shoeva. She said she had made repeated inquiries to Government officials but had received no response.
 
'People Disappear'
 No one knows how many political prisoners there are or how they are being treated. The Red Cross has sought access to prisoners, but the Government has said the organization can only visit prisoners who have been tried. That ban excludes nearly all political prisoners. Under Tajik law, a person can be detained for 18 months before trial.
"People continue to disappear," Russia's Deputy Foreign Minister for Central Asia, Georgi Kunadze, said recently.
Fear is pervasive. Almost no one will criticize the Government, and those who do insist on anonymity. The newspapers that flourished immediately after independence have been closed, their editors and reporters now dead, jailed or exiled.
Western diplomats and United Nations officials say Russia has been pushing the Government to improve the human rights situation and become more democratic. But how hard Russia is pressing is uncertain.
 
A Poet Is Jailed
 When Gulchera Sobir, wife of Bozor Sobir, a Tajik poet who was jailed in March on charges of anti-Government activities, asked the Russians for help in getting her husband freed, the Russian diplomats told her there was nothing they could do because neither she nor her husband are Russian citizens.
Mrs. Sobir said Russian diplomats told her that her husband had written poems against Communism, but she said this was not true. "His poems were about our fatherland, about our desire to be independent," she said.
A university professor said of Mr. Sobir: "He was fighting for independence of Tajikistan. Now we celebrate independence and he sits in jail."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Two years after Tajikistan declared independence from the former Soviet Union, its new Government is corrupt and there is still no privately owned land. A farmer tended a cotton field near Dushanbe. (James Hill for The New York Times)
 
Chart/Map: "Tajikstan at a Glance"
 
HISTORY: In the 16th century, Tajikistan became a province in a group of Turkish republics. By the mid-19th century, Tajikstan was divided among competing regional factions. Russia took control in the 1880's and 1890's. After the 1917 Russian Revolution, regions of Tajikstan rebelled against Communist rule until 1921. In 1929, it became a republic of the Soviet Union. It declared its independence in 1992, as the Soviet Union was collapsing.
 
GOVERNMENT: The Government is dominated by former Communists, who came to power at the end of 1992 after many months of political violence, near anarchy and civil war. The Government is run by a Parliament that was elected when the country was still part of the Soviet Union, and remains the same structure. Political parties that formed after independence have been banned, but the Communist party, once banned, has been allowed to reorganize. Elections have been promised, but are not scheduled.
 
ECONOMY: The country is one of the poorest of the 15 former Soviet republics, and it relies on agriculture, primarily cotton, and a limited industrial sector. It possesses potential hydropower resources, oil and minerals (uranium, mercury, lead and others).
 
POPULATION: 5,680,000
 
ETHNIC GROUPS: Tajak 62%, Uzbek 24%, Russian 8%, Tatar 2% and others 4%
 
RELIGION: Sunni Muslim 80%, Shiite Muslim 5%, others 15%.
 
Maps show the size and relative location of Tajikstan.
 
(Sources: Central Intelligence Agency; The Columbia Encyclopedia; U.S. State Dept.)

HEADLINE: North Korea Assails Atomic Unit, Asks U.S. Talks

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 12

 BODY:
In its continuing campaign to avoid international inspections of suspected nuclear weapons, North Korea issued a blistering attack today against the International Atomic Energy Agency and said only direct talks with the United States could resolve the crisis.
The broadside, issued in the name of North Korea's Minister of Atomic Energy and carried by the official news agency, described a bizarre plot that it said was intended to discredit the country. The plot involved a letter North Koreans said was a forgery by the International Atomic Energy Agency that suggested North Korea was developing nuclear bombs. 
 Intelligence reports indicate the existence of a secret nuclear program, but North Koreans have long denied that intention and permitted some inspections earlier this year. North Korea has condemned demands for new inspections -- to which it agreed when it joined the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty -- as a violation of sovereignty.
There is evidence of a nuclear program and North Korea has test-fired a missile this year that could reach Japan, but some United Nations members do not want to isolate further what is already one of the most isolated nations on earth or impose an economic embargo on a country where malnutrition is believed to be rampant.
The Communist Government has steered an uneven course for months in efforts to keep inspectors away from two sites in the north of the country that are believed to contain evidence that North Korea is stockpiling nuclear materials for a bomb.
At North Korea's request there have been two meetings between senior American and North Korean officials, but Washington has said the discussions cannot continue until Pyongyang resumes discussions with the International Atomic Energy Agency inspectors and with South Korea.
The North Koreans refuse to recognize South Korea as legitimate.
But even while it was accusing the agency of being "closely linked with the base swindle of political charlatans," North Korea sought to project a conciliatory image at the same time by meeting with an American politician.
Representative Gary Ackerman, head of the House Asia-Pacific Affairs subcommittee, met with North Korea's President, Kim Il Sung, this week.
Mr. Ackerman, a Democrat who represents Queens, Nassau and Suffolk counties, was then allowed to walk across the heavily fortified demilitarized zone at Panmunjom. It was apparently the first such crossing in decades by an American official .
In a telephone interview, Mr. Ackerman indicated the talks were long on symbolism but short on substance. While there have been numerous reports that North Korea's economy is on the verge of collapse and that there are widespread food shortages, Mr. Ackerman said he was told the country had enjoyed bumper crops this year.
He said that he was also given "personal assurances" by Mr. Kim that Pyongyang was not and would not develop nuclear weapons, but that his calls for the Government to permit inspections to confirm this were rebuffed.
The North Korean broadside said that the International Atomic Energy Agency had forged the name of Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali on a statement read before the General Assembly last month. The message said that the agency would have to close ranks to halt nuclear proliferation in countries like North Korea.
Among other things, the North Koreans said they were angry at being referred to in the message as North Korea, rather than the official Democratic People's Republic of Korea.
David Kyd, the chief spokesman for the agency, said that the North Korean attack appeared to be focused on a standard message. He denied there had been any forgery.
The North Korean statement said Mr. Boutros-Ghali had disclaimed the message, but a United Nations spokesman called it "completely valid."
He said "it is a message from the Secretary General to the conference, and any allegation that it is a forgery is nonsense," the spokesman said. He acknowledged that the document did not use the country's formal name.

HEADLINE: S. I. Secession Could Avoid Big Tax Rise

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Staten Island could become independent from New York City without imposing huge tax increases on its residents, a state panel studying the issue said yesterday.
In its last report before Staten Island's 379,000 residents vote in November on a proposal to secede from New York, the State Charter Commission for Staten Island said yesterday that the island as its own city could provide comparable services to its residents without the sharp increases in taxes some experts have predicted would be necessary. 
 The commission has in the past said that the amount of revenue raised from Staten Island each year is about $170 million less than the amount the island receives in New York City services. But in its new report the commission said costs on services could vary widely depending on the scope and type of services that islanders were willing to accept. Some services, such as jails, it said, could even be provided more cheaply on a smaller scale.
The 13-member commission, formed in 1990 to study the impact of secession and provide options for voters, looked specifically at providing jails, police training and 911 emergency services as examples of the problems secession might bring.
 
Growing Support
 The report by the commission, which has made no recommendation for or against secession, came amid evidence of growing support for the proposal. Guy Molinari, the Borough President, will formally announce his support today, said an aide who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Although yesterday's report did not analyze the costs of creating some larger government programs -- including schools and social services -- it said that jails, police training and 911 emergency services were selected because they are not provided on Staten Island now, and therefore might be expected to require large outlays for new construction and other start-up costs.
But compared to what Staten Island residents now pay in New York City taxes for comparable services, secession would not cause serious strains, the commission said.
"It is doable," said Joseph P. Viteritti, a professor of management at New York University and executive director of the commission. Although he declined to say whether secession could be accomplished without any tax increases, residents of Staten Island "can provide a comparable level of service without greatly increasing revenues," he said.
The commission did outline some problems. In some cases, they said current services might be impossible to duplicate.
 
911 Service Is a Concern
 For instance, the commission said, setting up a new 911 emergency phone number for Staten Island might not be possible because such services require the allocation of a special radio frequency from the Federal Communications Commission, and none are now available. The likely solution would be for Federal officials to require New York City to share its 911 system with the island. But the commission said it didn't know what the price tag would be.
In creating other new services, the commission said, residents of a City of Staten Island would face tough choices over the type and scope of municipal programs.
The island, which now has no jail, might pay New York City to incarcerate its prisoners at a projected cost of $14.6 million a year or build its own jail, which would cost an estimated $15.1 million annually, including $3.9 million a year to pay off its debt for construction. Other options include splitting up its jail population by sending its maximum security prisoners back to New York City, and building its own jail for lesser offenders. The estimated yearly cost: $15.8 million in combined payments to New York City, operating costs and construction debt.
In a report in July 1992, the commission had said the island generated $955 million a year in property, sales and income taxes, Federal and state aid and debt service, compared to the $1.13 billion it received annually in city services.
That led some officials, particularly opponents of secession in the Dinkins administration, to a conclusion that the commission said yesterday had been far off base -- that the government of a newly created City of Staten Island would immediately face a $170 million budget shortfall.
The commission is chaired by John Marchi, a Republican state senator from Staten Island. All of its members are Staten Island residents and most, according to Mr. Viteritti, have expressed personal support for the proposal. But he said that support has not influenced the research because that has been done largely by outside consultants from New York University and elsewhere who do not live on Staten Island.
Although he has until now been neutral on secession, Mr. Molinari has said that tax increases would be all but inevitable. In his announcement today, according to his staff, he is to provide new analysis of the economic impact of secession.
The proposal is widely expected to win a majority in the election next month. But Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the state Legislature would have to approve it before the island could secede, and all sides agree that the bigger a margin of support from residents, the more pressure Albany would feel to go along.
The state commission said yesterday that Staten Island residents would face a myriad of decisions, and in some cases might elect to pay for programs that cost more than it now costs for services from New York City. But they might also save money by offering comparable services on a smaller scale, the commission said.
In one example, it said the cost of constructing a new jail, although high, might lead to savings because it could be expected to be built within walking distance of the existing Staten Island courthouse. Because prisoners could then simply walk to their court proceedings under police escorts, the high costs paid by New York City to transport thousands of prisoners from more than a dozen jails to the court appearances would be averted.
 
What About Police?
 One difficult decision that would have be made by a newly created Staten Island government would be whether to train its police at the New York City Police Academy, which is widely regarded as the nation's best.
Richard J. Koehler, a professor of criminal justice at John Jay College and former Commissioner of Corrections in New York City, who was hired as an analyst by the commission, said yesterday that Staten Island would pay far more to continue using the New York City academy that it would to create its own school.
But Mr. Koehler said the high cost of New York City police training might be worth it, particularly for specialized classes. He recommended that some, if not all, Staten Island recruits be sent through the New York City academy.
Although the report did not provide an estimate of the overall costs of creating a new police department, it said one problem not likely to be faced was recruiting experienced police away from New York City.
"Based on the number that we already know would prefer to transfer to Staten Island, it should not be a problem at all," Mr. Koehler said.

HEADLINE: A Surge in Advocacy Within Parent Groups;
P.T.A.'s Shift From Bastions of the Status Quo to Challengers of Authority

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

 BODY:
Until recently the parents at Public School 154 in Flushing, Queens, played little role in school life, split as they were into immigrant groups from 20 countries and harried by the demands of their jobs.
But last month, after school officials ordered P.S. 154 closed and the children bused elsewhere until the building was certified to be free of asbestos, parent leaders blanketed the neighborhood with pamphlets printed in Chinese, Spanish, Arabic and Farsi, rallying scores of parents to a school boycott. 
 Overnight, school officials cut through the red tape, producing reports that showed the school to be safe, and ordered it opened.
"The authorities took us seriously because we knew how to scream," said Valerie Cohen, who became president of the school's parent association last year.
 
'Renaissance Occurring'

The tactics parents used at P.S. 154 show just how much times have changed from the days when the P.T.A. organizations were essentially fund-raising.
A host of societal shifts, from the movement of women into the work force to new arrivals of foreign immigrants, have radically transformed the P.T.A.'s of New York and the nation.
If parent organizations in their heyday were mainly middle-class bastions of the status quo that collaborated closely with school officials, today they are smaller, scrappier groups with rainbow memberships that often challenge authorities over everything from teacher hiring to classroom violence. After a 25-year decline in membership, there is now a resurgence.
"There is a renaissance occurring," said Jeanne Frankl, who recently retired as executive director of the Public Education Association, an advocacy group. "The movement that is emerging has the style of the 90's. It reflects the parents who are in the school system now."
The surge in activism has manifested itself in a variety of ways in recent years. After a knifing last year at Eastern District High School, Brooklyn parents refused to allow their children to attend classes until school officials increased security. In the Bronx, parents persuaded politicians through years of protests and lobbying to give them a new school. At the High School of Graphic Communication Arts, Manhattan parents forced teachers to back away from an early dismissal plan that they said cheated students of classroom time.
The activism accelerated during the asbestos crisis. The police were called to at least 13 separate parent protests on Sept. 20, the first day of school this fall, and there was at least one school protest somewhere in the city virtually every day during September.
"There's a lot of pent-up anger," said Ayo Harrington, president of the United Parents Associations, New York's oldest citywide parents group.
 
Decline and Rebound
 Nationwide, the most prominent group is the National P.T.A., with its headquarters in Chicago, comprising of 27,000 school-based parent-teacher associations. Although the National P.T.A. has registered the name "P.T.A.," many groups in New York City include teachers and call themselves P.T.A.'s even though they are not affiliated with the national organization. Others that do not include teachers call themselves Parent Associations.
Nationally and in New York City, membership in parent organizations peaked in the 1960's before beginning a steady decline. The National P.T.A. had 12 million dues-paying members in 1961. Twenty years later, membership had fallen to five million; it has rebounded to seven million. While the baby boomlet of the 80's means more children are in school, the P.T.A. attributes the new membership chiefly to a rise in volunteerism.
Educators and academics said that powerful social and economic forces caused the overall decline in membership. Driving the P.T.A. from its inception were the energies of thousands of mothers donating their free time to their schools. From 1960 to 1990, that volunteer force shrank sharply as the percentage of American women with jobs rose from 35 percent in 1960 to 54 percent in 1990, according to census figures.
In New York City, the shifting fortunes of the United Parents Associations, a citywide federation of school-based parent groups, reflected the changes. Founded in 1921, the U.P.A. was a major force in improving the city's school system in the 1930's and 1940's, and by the 1960's, it was a prosperous organization with a largely white membership of some 400,000 members in 450 schools. Local chapters sustained neighborhood schools with cake sales and raffles.
But the struggles over desegregation and decentralization of the late 1960's weakened the U.P.A., often pitting parent organizations in largely black and white neighborhoods against one another. Many white parents who had been U.P.A. stalwarts left the city for the suburbs, and others devoted their energies increasingly to their local school boards after the system was decentralized in 1970.
Twenty years later, the U.P.A. had disappeared completely from 250 schools and only a handful of loyalists were active in many of the schools still affiliated. The organization that once occupied a posh Madison Avenue headquarters with 16 paid workers was sharing a downtown office with several other nonprofit groups and had no staff at all.
"The U.P.A. was in very hard times, almost a nonentity," said Jan Atwell, who became a vice president in 1985 and who later, as its president, helped rebuild the organization.
 
Growth in Voluntarism
 The parent movement's recovery is taking many forms; vigorous new leadership is one sign. Ms. Atwell's successor at the head of the organization is Ms. Harrington, who was educated at Malcolm X Liberation College in North Carolina, Ms. Harrington has sought to make up for the U.P.A.'s diminished numbers by forcefully articulating parent concerns through the media.
The movement is recovering nationally, as well. "We're seeing new growth in voluntarism, but of a different type," said Kathryn Whitfill, president of the National P.T.A. More fathers are participating, and instead of bake sales, many P.T.A. chapters are fighting for school financing by lobbying local governments, Mrs. Whitfill said.
In New York City, new groups have emerged. One is the Parents Coalition, the only citywide parents group with a full-time staff. Jon Moscow, its executive director, said he helped found the group in 1984 because he saw that even as parental activism declined over two decades, the power of the Board of Education bureaucracy, the teachers' union and other special interests were growing.
"This is a struggle and the issue is parent power," Mr. Moscow said. "Unions struggled to be taken seriously for workers, and parents have the same fight."
One instance in which the Board of Education failed to consider parents' needs, Mr. Moscow said, came when the board persuaded the teachers' union to defer wages during the 1991 budget crisis by establishing an annual, weeklong midwinter break that gives teachers time off but is a nightmare for working parents, who must arrange child care. The issue remains a source of bitter contention with the school system.
But in June, parents' groups claimed a victory when the seven-member Board approved extensive revisions to a 20-year-old document, known as the Blue Book, which outlines the rights and responsibilities of the groups.
Perhaps the parent leader who worked most tirelessly for the revisions was Lillian Lopez, a mother of two public school students and a member of the school board in District 15 in Brooklyn. In many ways, Ms. Lopez's own story reflects the evolution of the parents' movement.
Eight years ago, Ms. Lopez was just getting on her feet after two years of homelessness, riding the subways with her infant son. When she joined the P.T.A. at P.S. 15 in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn she found the group's focus on candy sale fund-raisers to be irrelevant to the school's needs. Over years of P.T.A. work, she changed the emphasis, starting an antidrug campaign in the Red Hook projects and training parents to be classroom tutors and conflict mediators.
Another mother who proved her leadership powers in school organizing is Juanita Rodriguez, who came to prominence a year ago after a schoolhouse stabbing ignited parent anger at Eastern District High School in Brooklyn. Ms. Rodriguez, president of the parents association, led parents into a two-day boycott that she called off only after wringing pledges from Board of Education officials not only to tighten security but also to relieve crowding and to initiate other programs, like a baby-sitting system for student mothers.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Give Up Early Gains

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Treasury market gave up early gains yesterday and prices ended slightly lower amid nervousness about the September inflation figures, which are scheduled to be issued later this week.
Contributing to the market's concerns was a sharp jump in gold prices. 
 The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond, up more than half a point in early trading, closed unchanged. Its yield held steady from Friday's close of 5.92 percent.
Prices of short-term Treasury securities, meanwhile, were 1/32 point lower and intermediate maturities fell by as much as 4/32 point.
The Treasury market was closed in the United States on Monday, Columbus Day.
 
Prices Reverse Direction
 Treasury prices initially rose yesterday as bond traders returning from a long weekend continued to focus on what many considered a weak September jobs report on Friday.
The Labor Department said that while the unemployment rate held at 6.7 percent, the 156,000 jobs added in the month were concentrated in low-paying, part-time positions.
That and other indications of weakness in the report suggested that the economy was not growing fast enough to push up inflation, which can hurt the value of securities that pay a fixed rate of return.
But bond sellers emerged later in the day as the price of gold and other precious metals surged. Such movements are considered an indication of underlying inflationary pressures. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery jumped $7.50, to $369.20 an ounce.
Analysts said the rising precious metals prices apparently made some fixed-income investors nervous about the Producer Price Index, scheduled for tomorrow and the Consumer Price Index, on Friday.
Those worries spurred some holders of fixed-income securities to cash in on the recent run-up in bond prices, said Kevin Flanagan, money market economist at Dean Witter, Discover & Company.
 
Some Unpredictable Factors
 Economists generally expect the Producer Price and Consumer Price Indexes for September to show a continuation of the slow inflation trend this year. However, several unpredictable factors are creating concerns.
Matthew Alexy, market strategist at the First Boston Corporation, said that some manufacturers and distributors of gasoline might have raised their prices in anticipation of a Federal gas tax increase that took effect early this month.
In addition, he said auto makers had been inconsistent in discounting year-end prices, but that new model prices are not expected to rise as much as in previous years.
"They will be tricky numbers," Mr. Alexy said.
In its weekly bill auction, the Treasury sold $12.9 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 3.04 percent and a yield of 3.10 percent. An additional $12.8 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 3.12 percent and a yield of 3.21 percent.
In secondary trading, the discount rate on three-month Treasury bills rose two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 2.99 percent. The discount rate on six-month bills rose four basis points, to 3.10 percent. And the discount rate on one-year bills rose three basis points, to 3.20 percent.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, fell 0.53, to 1,336.35.
 
Funds Rate at 3%
 The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, rose to 3 percent, from 2.88 percent late Friday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10528/32 , up 8/32 point from late Monday. The average yield to maturity was 5.39 percent, down from 5.43 percent.
Following are the results of the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Relenting, Whitman Will Release Her Family's Income Tax Return for 1990

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Christine Todd Whitman is going to give Gov. Jim Florio what he wants: her family's 1990 income tax return.
Mrs. Whitman will release the return by the end of the week, her spokesman said today, because, she says, she wants to get back to the important issues in the campaign.
The announcement was meant to upstage a news conference several hours later at which Governor Florio again criticized his Republican opponent for not releasing the information. 
 In August, Mrs. Whitman made public tax returns for 1989, 1991 and 1992, raising immediate questions as to why she withheld the 1990 returns after previously promising to "set the standard for disclosure."
 
Seizing the Issue
 Governor Florio, who has voluntarily released his returns every year since becoming Governor in 1990, immediately seized the issue in an effort to erode Mrs. Whitman's credibility on ethics.
James Carville, Mr. Florio's chief campaign consultant, brought up the issue again this morning in a call to the Trenton radio station New Jersey 101.5.
Later today, Carl Golden, the Whitman campaign spokesman, said: "The Whitmans' 1990 tax returns will be released before the week is out. If the Governor is that obsessed at peeking at them, they will be released."
Mr. Golden said the decision was not a response to Mr. Carville's comments, but rather an effort to return the focus of the campaign to topics like the economy, jobs and taxes.
"Let's get it out of the way and talk about things that are important," he said.
Governors, and candidates for the office, are not required to disclose personal income tax information.
Mrs. Whitman has said she was a private citizen in 1991, when the 1990 return was being prepared, so she saw no need to turn over the information.
She was a public figure and official in 1990, however. She stepped down as president of the State Board of Public Utilities in February 1990 to enter the Senate race against Bill Bradley.
The announcement today did not stop Mr. Florio from going ahead with his news conference, during which he called on Mrs. Whitman to release the tax documents immediately.
"In January, you may recall that Mrs. Whitman promised to set a new standard for disclosure of assets and income," he said in Edison. "Instead, she set a new standard for offering excuses."
Alan Rosenthal, a political science professor at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University, said he doubted whether the voters cared as much about the missing tax return as did Governor Florio.
But he said Mrs. Whitman allowed Mr. Florio to box her into a corner by releasing tax information for three of the last four years without a good explanation.
"I don't know that people running for governor ethically are bound to release all of their income figures, but when one does it it challenges the other," Professor Rosenthal said. "It's an ethics race."

HEADLINE: Stock Are Mixed, With the Dow Off 0.28

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday, with strength in brokerage issues, high-techs and some health care and pharmaceutical issues, but weakness in cyclical companies sensitive to the economy's direction.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which in early trading had raced above the 3,600 level, closed down 0.28 point, to 3,593.13. But, while the Nasdaq composite, heavily influenced by high-technology issues, and American Stock Exchange both closed at record highs. 
 Stronger than expected earnings reports from Motorola and Merrill Lynch helped other stocks in their industry groups move higher.
Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist for the Kemper Securities Group in Chicago, saw a market that could not make up its mind.
"There was no follow-through from last week, or even yesterday," he said. "What we saw were beaten-down sectors like health care, biotechs, and some selected technologies coming back to life, with gold stocks, responding to gold prices, going up as well."
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy at 264 million shares traded, up from 183.2 million on Monday. The number of stocks posting gains outnumbered those posting losses by 1,081 to 937.
The Nasdaq composite rose 4.81 points, to a record closing high of 772.46, while the American Stock Exchange composite gained 2.91 points, to 470.50, also a record closing high.
Given the lack of economic data, earnings were the big factor in yesterday's session. The seimconductor sector responded to Motorola's better-than-expected third-quarter results. The company reported after Monday's market close that it earned 92 cents a share, versus 47 cents a share. Financial stocks benefited from strong third-quarter results issued by Merrill Lynch, which earned $3.14 a share, compared with $2.04 and Bear Stearns, 81 cents a share, versus 55 cents.
Centocor rose 3, to 14 1/4, as Prudential Securities upgraded the drug company to buy from hold. According to traders, Prudential sees a price target of $18 for the stock over the next 12 months. The company tied the rise to its Panorex drug data presented yesterday at a medical conference in Germany. The drug, designed to treat colonrectal cancer, extended the lives of patients in a five-year study.
US Healthcare rose 1 1/8, to 45, as it filed a petition with the Supreme Court of New York to annul rate cuts ordered by state regulators on Sept. 30.
 
Consolidated Paper Down
 Among the weak cyclicals, Consolidated Paper fell 2 7/8, to 40 1/8, after posting third-quarter earnings of 17 cents a share, down sharply from Street expectations of 38 cents a share. Also hurting the Dow was drops in Caterpillar, off 5/8, to 80 3/8, and Ford Motor, down 1/8, to 54 7/8.
CUC International, which is teaming up with A.T.& T. and Viacom to test an interactive home shopping network, rose 4 1/8, to 38 1/8, in active trading.
Investors unhappy with Hilton Hotels' lower third-quarter earnings, despite higher revenues, sold, causing the stock to decline 1 5/8, to 48 1/2.
Meca Software rose 1 1/8, to 6 1/2, after H& R Block and Meca announced that they had entered into a definitive merger agreement whereby a Block unit would make a cash tender offer for all outstanding shares of Meca at a price of $6.625 a share.
Cardinal Distributors, a wholesale distributor of pharmaceuticals, surgical and hospital supplies, gained 3 1/2 to close at 40 after agreeing to acquire Whitmire Distribution for 8.3 million of its common shares valued at more than $400 million.
Solectron, which announced a 2-for-1 stock split yesterday, rose 2 3/8, to 54.

HEADLINE: F. B. Withington, School Headmaster And Principal, 71

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Frederic B. Withington, who retired in 1988 after 22 years as headmaster of the Quaker-affiliated Friends Academy in Locust Valley, L.I., died on Sept. 29 at his home in Brunswick, Me. He was 71.
The cause of death was a malignant melanoma, the school said. 
 During Mr. Withington's years at the academy, he saw the campus and enrollment nearly double, and the school, founded in 1876, now has 85 teachers and 685 pupils. The academy also became religiously, racially and economically more diversified under his stewardship.
Mr. Withington, a native of Winchester, Mass., spent a year after high school graduation at Phillips Exeter Academy in New Hampshire, during which he set a New England preparatory-school record in the 440-yard dash in 1941. He attended Harvard College, then entered the Army Air Corps in 1943. Based in Italy as a B-24 bomber pilot, he flew 24 missions, was shot down twice and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with three clusters.
 
Teacher and Coach
 Returning to Harvard, he again excelled in track. After graduating in 1947, he became a mathematics teacher and coach at Governor Drummer Academy in Massachusetts and earned a master's in English at Middlebury College in Vermont.
He then served as principal of the Upper School at Sidwell Friends School in Washington and later as headmaster of Morgan Park Academy in Chicago before moving to Friends Academy.
Mr. Withington, known as Ted, retired to Maine in 1988. His book, "Flight to Black Hammer" (Biddle Publishing, 1993), tells of his war experiences through his letters and diaries.
He is survived by his wife, JoAnn Souter Witherington; three daughters, Susan Withington Meyn of Topsham, Me., Ann Withington of Gorham, Me., and Sarah Withington of Concord, Mass; two brothers, Dr. William A. of Lexington, Ky., and Arthur of Clinton, N.Y., and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mark Is Strong After Treaty Is Backed by German Court

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against other leading currencies yesterday, while the German mark remained strong.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.5940 marks, down from 1.6041 marks on Monday.
Currency traders focused their attention on the mark after Germany's constitutional court gave its approval to the Maastricht Treaty, the framework for Europe's political and economic union. 
 With the court ruling, Germany becomes the final European country to approve the treaty, which calls for creating a single currency by 1999.
"In recent days there was concern that it would be a negative vote, and people started buying marks," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the advisory firm IDEA.
But when the vote was announced, traders took profits in the mark, briefly driving the currency lower. Shortly thereafter, the German currency resumed its upward path.
 
Dollar Off vs. Yen
 The dollar dropped to 106.02 Japanese yen in late New York trading, from 106.22 yen on Monday. The British pound rose to $1.5330, from $1.5319 on Monday. The currency markets were more active yesterday than on Monday, when trading was limited because banks in New York and Tokyo had closed for national holidays.
Analysts said traders remained disappointed with the American nonfarm payroll numbers in the September employment report, which the Labor Department released on Friday.
Kevin Lawrie, a vice president with the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said traders were awaiting fresh economic data, particularly the merchandise trade report to be released on Friday.
The market is also bracing for tomorrow's report on producer prices in September and Friday's report on consumer prices.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.3985 Swiss francs, down from 1.4080; 5.6005 French francs, down from 5.6330; 1,572.30 Italian lire, down from 1,585.00, and 1.3295 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3300.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP. (N)

 BODY:
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that weakness in its operating businesses led to a decline in revenues in the third quarter, but it said it was making progress in selling the assets of its failed finance subsidiary and paying off debt.
Debt was cut $500 million in the period and was at $5.9 billion at the end of the quarter, compared with $8.4 billion at the beginning of the year. The company said asset sales had allowed it to pay back $765 million of revolving credit borrowings. 
 Westinghouse said the economic slowdown in California had affected its broadcasting and home building segments and reduced demand for hazardous waste disposal, which depressed the environmental unit.
The company said its operating profit margin in the quarter was 6.9 percent, down from 9.4 percent a year earlier.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Prices Surge on Hopes Of Better Economic Growth

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Gold prices surged yesterday as big commodity funds showed renewed interest in the metal.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery, the most actively traded futures contract, jumped $7.50, to $369.20 an ounce, after trading as high as $370. Silver rose, with the December contract gaining 11 cents, to $4.44 an ounce. 
 Traders said expectations of improved economic growth also contributed to the market's perception that gold might be due for a rebound.
"People saw prices as cheap," said Jon Nadler, the head of precious metals trading with Bank of America in New York. "That was the catalyst, and the anticipation that this time, the inflation report might help, instead of hurting prices."
Since early August, gold prices have plunged from their three-year highs of more than $410 an ounce amid expectations that economic weakness would keep inflation low.
Tomorrow the Labor Department is scheduled to report on producer prices in September. But some traders are expecting a rise of only one-tenth of a percent.
 
Commodity Funds Big Buyers
 Price movements and other technical factors also contributed to the run-up in gold yesterday. Traders said commodity funds bought large amounts of gold after prices rose above $363 an ounce.
Exaggerating the move was the relatively small size of the gold market. The value of all the outstanding contracts for gold is only about $4.8 billion. By contrast, the value of the shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange is nearly a thousand times that, or roughly $4.4 trillion.
"The gold market is fairly small," said Michael Martin, an analyst and trader with the Sinclair Group in New York. "It's not that fluid a market, and it is subject a lot to these trading patterns."
On other commodity markets, wheat futures rallied to an 11-week high. On the Chicago Board of Trade, December wheat rose 4.75 cents, to $3.2675 a bushel. But December corn slipped a quarter-cent, to $2.4425 a bushel. And November soybeans were unchanged at $6.1475 a bushel.
 
Crop Estimates Smaller
 After the close of the market, the Agriculture Department estimated this year's crop at 2.422 billion bushels, which was smaller than expected. The department also estimated the corn and soybean crops below previous projections, with corn totaling 6.962 billion bushels and soybeans totaling 1.891 billion bushels.
Elsewhere on the Chicago Board of Trade, rice surged to a two-year high, gaining its maximum daily limit. November rice closed at $8.49 a hundredweight, up 45 cents. Rice has soared $2.29, or 37 percent, since Sept. 24.
After the close, the Agriculture Department projected a 5.77-million-ton decline in world rice production.

BYLINE: By Peter Watrous

DATELINE: The Pop Life

 BODY:

New Material Girl
Remember Madonna? The entrepreneur, book subject, actress and singer recently seemed to be slipping out of her dominant position in the pop world; not too many public spats, financial or physical disclosures or new records, books or movies.
But if anybody was wondering if the Material Girl still had any drawing power, her three shows this week at Madison Square Garden, boasting a top ticket price of $75, sold out in less than an hour, and that's with only some radio promotion and a Madison Square Garden advertisement in The New York Times. Given that her last record, "Erotica," was a commercial disappointment, that's not bad. Even if her celebrity is based more on the creation of a self-image than on musical virtuosity, her reputation as a ferocious live performer clearly precedes her. 
 At least 60,000 people will see her shows on Thursday, Friday and Sunday, which means lots of security. Midtown South, the police precinct that covers Madison Square Garden, is sending about 150 police officers, including a dozen mounted police and 15 more on motorcycles, to make sure things don't get out of hand. Madonna has two personal bodyguards, plus a handful more for general tour security.
Here's what the audience will see, and hear. Madonna will appear in many changes of clothes, made by the Italian designers Dolce and Gabbana. There will be nine musicians, including two back-up singers, and eight dancers, half of them men and half women. During the two-hour show Madonna will perform everything from "Like a Virgin" to "Erotica." She (or Memorex) will sing 16 songs and dance a lot. Her audience, which comes for the sheer spectacle of it all and never seems to care much whether she's really singing or not, will adore every move.
 
A Perspective on Jazz
 The drummer Arthur Taylor's "Notes and Tones" has just been released again, this time by Da Capo Press, and it's just as revelatory as it was when it first came out in 1977. Mr. Taylor, who has been and continues to be, one of jazz's top drummers, spent some 10 years interviewing musicians with whom he'd worked, or knew. This version of the book includes a previously unpublished interview with Dexter Gordon, along with interviews with Miles Davis, Thelonious Monk, Art Blakey, Ornette Coleman, Dizzy Gillespie and others. It's unlike anything that has been published in jazz, with as many different opinions as interviews.
As a musician himself, Mr. Taylor had special access to his subjects. They were his friends, and like them, he is black. The pieces are by and large more candid about the state of race and jazz esthetics than most jazz books.
"The musicians were probably a little freer with me than with other people," Mr. Taylor said recently. "They had no fears or qualms talking to me, they'd speak to me like an equal because I had made music with them, and hung out with them socially. So it was easy to get them to speak their minds."
When it first appeared, the book was enormously controversial. The interviews were done after the civil-rights movement had all but collapsed, and there's a sense of bitterness and frustration that prevails in some of the interviews.
Here, for instance, is the saxophonist Johnny Griffin talking in 1969 about the life of an expatriate jazz player in Europe: "Black musicians all over Europe running away from America. But that's part of the white power structure that's killing us and our music."
Mr. Taylor said the initial response to the book was "tremendously negative."
"White people complained because I didn't include any white musicians. Jews were upset about what some musicians said about them. And black people said I was giving up too much information about how we think. Everybody was down on me."
But Mr. Taylor has persevered. Not only has he collected enough interviews for another book -- taken in part from his interview show on WKCR, Columbia University's radio station -- but he's also leading one of jazz's best groups, Taylor's Wailers.
"I'm getting a fantastic response to the book this time out," Mr. Taylor said. "I think people have kind of moderated their views, but like I say in the new introduction, some things haven't changed. Thelonious Monk said he couldn't get a cab up to Harlem, and you still can't get cabs to drive up there."
 
Big Apple Grammys
 The Grammys are coming back to New York on March 1, and New York is looking for the payoff. The New York City Host Committee for the 1994 Grammy Awards, which more or less manages the proceedings, is trying to stretch the festivities connected with the show out over a week, and make it a tourist event. Anybody wondering why should look at the money involved: the committee says the Grammys will generate approximately $40 million for the city.
"A tremendous amount of revenue is generated by all the visitors, who'll be going to restaurants, night clubs, Broadway theaters, and using taxis," said Jonathan Tisch, the chairman of the committee. "And a tremendous amount of revenue is spent by record companies looking to entertain. It's a real boost to the economy."
Every year, Los Angeles and New York compete for the awards, upping the ante to play host. Next year the committee will have photo exhibits open to the public, and plans to broadcast the show in Times Square on the Sony Jumbotron, among other things. Most importantly, several record companies will pay for some programs dear to the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, or Naras, the organization that puts on the Grammys.
"I know Los Angeles was upset to lose the Grammys for next year," Mr. Tisch said. "We spent a lot of time working on this, and I'm glad it's going to happen. We guaranteed a couple of programs important to Naras, like the Grammy in the School program. Things like that helped us get the Grammys. People are really excited about it."
