HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Sarah Lyall

 BODY:

A New Thatcher Watch
Special to The New York Times
 LONDON, Oct. 12 -- The memoirs of Margaret Thatcher, the former British Prime Minister, aren't scheduled to reach bookstores here until Monday. But they have already caused a considerable fuss, because of a combination of clever marketing, London's vicious newspaper wars and Britain's continued obsession with a political leader who, even out of office, has managed to keep herself solidly in the public eye. 
 The book, "The Downing Street Years," is being published by HarperCollins U.K., which reportedly paid the enormous sum of 3.5 million (about $5.4 million) for it and a yet-to-come companion volume that is to detail Mrs. Thatcher's early career and rise to power. The publisher has printed 250,000 copies of "The Downing Street Years," and has timed its release to take place in the midst of a five-part serialization here in The Sunday Times (both HarperCollins and The Sunday Times are owned by Rupert Murdoch).
 
Beaten to the Punch
 A rival newspaper, The Daily Mirror, stole some of the thunder last week by printing the most scandalous excerpts it could find, which showed Mrs. Thatcher criticizing members of her own party in intensely unflattering terms. But The Sunday Times went ahead this week with its first installment, and booksellers say the competition of excerpts may actually have helped the publishing hype.
"I think the unauthorized quotes in The Daily Mirror would have created enormous interest and that many people feel these quotations might have been taken out of context, and will be interested in reading the book," said Alan Giles, the managing director of Waterstones Booksellers, Britain's largest specialty bookstore chain, which has ordered 21,000 copies for its 90 stores.
Mr. Giles predicted "The Downing Street Years" would be a big best seller in Britain. He explained that political memoirs from the Thatcher era have been doing particularly well, even if the people who buy the books don't necessarily read them. "They're like exercise cycles: people buy them with enormously good intentions and put them away and never use them," he said.
How the book fares here probably won't have much bearing on how it does in the United States, where its publisher is HarperCollins and where it is to appear in stores on Monday. The memoirs of past American presidents haven't always been so successful, in some cases bombing outright.
 
A Shorter Attention Span?
 Britain and the United States have always enjoyed a warm publishing relationship and, indeed, many editors in the two countries are friendly and tend to publish one another's books. But it seems that trade between the two countries is now more one way than the other, with the British buying more American books than Americans buying British ones.
But if the disparity between what is imported from across the Atlantic and what is exported is noticeable here, it is even sharper in other countries, where publishers lap up American books but seem to have an excruciatingly hard time selling their own authors to United States houses. The reasons for this include American readers' apparent preference for home-grown authors, a decreasing number of American editors who know how to read languages other than English, and American publishers' reluctance, in a lingering recession, to gamble on fiction that is likely to bring in little in return.
Foreign publishers' frustration was all too apparent at the Frankfurt Book Fair, which ended on Monday.
"I don't think there are so many books coming from Germany that many Americans want to read," said Hans Ewald Dede, a prominent German publisher. "For one thing, there are only a very few German writers who can write highly entertaining novels; they are perhaps too didactic, too interested in teaching."
 
And Then There's Bulgaria
 German publishers like Mr. Ewald are at least well known to their American counterparts. Many foreigners from countries where publishing is less international have an even harder time. "Offering Bulgarian books to be published abroad is a very, very difficult phenomenon," said Katalina Sabeva, who runs the Anthea literary agency in Bulgaria. "We're interesting as an exotic country to the Americans, but our modern culture is difficult for modern Americans to understand."
Sander Knol, an editor at Der Boekerij, a Dutch publisher, said rather sadly that "Holland authors cannot travel." But American authors obviously can: Der Boekerij has a list 90 percent of which is foreign translations, most of them American, and is publishing Amy Fisher's memoir, for instance. "I think the story has elements that will appeal to many people," Mr. Knol said.
 
The Lannan Prizes
 The Lannan Foundation, a private arts organization in Los Angeles, has announced its annual literary prizes, given to "accomplished writers who have made significant contributions to English-language literature" and to "writers of distinctive merit who demonstrate potential for outstanding future work." This year, the prizes, worth $50,000 each, were awarded to 10 authors:
Lifetime Achievement Award: William Gaddis
Fiction Award: Paul West
Poetry Award: Denise Levertov
Nonfiction Award: Edward Hoagland
Fiction Fellowships: Rikki Ducornet, Denis Johnson and Carole Maso
Poetry Fellowships: Cyrus Cassells and Benjamin Allen Saenz
Nonfiction Fellowship: Terry Tempest Williams.

HEADLINE: How to Get Tough With Haiti

 BODY:
The thugs who prevented U.S. and Canadian troops from landing in Haiti on Monday do not represent the majority of the Haitian people. The country's voters made their choice three years ago when they elected President Jean-Bertrand Aristide with a 65 percent majority. The military elite, accustomed to unquestioned power, drove him into exile. Now that elite, aided by its paramilitary "attaches," is invoking nationalist pride and characterizing the U.N. mission to restore President Aristide as a foreign invasion.
The attaches, who prevented a U.S. troopship from landing and threatened the U.S. charge d'affaires on Monday, kept at it yesterday by menacing a television crew with machine guns and preventing children from attending school. 
 The junta clearly has no intention of following the agreement reached in July on Governors Island in New York City, which created a timetable for returning President Aristide to power. The thwarted mission was supposed to be a part of that process, helping to "professionalize" the military and separate it from the police force.
In accordance with the Governors Island agreement, economic sanctions against Haiti were lifted in August. It was those sanctions -- fully supported by Haiti's poor majority, despite the pain it caused them -- that finally forced the recalcitrant military, led by Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, to the bargaining table. But General Cedras and his cronies have demonstrated in the past few days that they have no intention of giving up power.
While nominally accepting the U.N.'s conditions to get the sanctions lifted, General Cedras has obviously been sending quite another message to the troops at home, encouraging them to believe they can stop democracy through intimidation.
Now it's time to get serious with the Haitian junta. Since the Governors Island agreement has clearly been broken, the economic sanctions should be reimposed -- and strengthened. General Cedras should be given a very short deadline -- 24 to 48 hours -- to get his followers under control.
President Clinton has belatedly but correctly recognized that the U.N. mission, in its recent form and under the present hostile circumstances, would not work. He has ordered a temporary halt to the mission. Now Mr. Clinton can tell General Cedras that he must give up power to the democratically elected Government, as agreed, or face a naval blockade and cessation of all commercial air traffic and financial transactions -- in other words, complete isolation from the international community.
Only when the United Nations joined in the Western Hemisphere's embargo, cutting off its oil supply from Europe, did Haiti's ruling elite feel enough pain to start talking about handing over power. It's clear they now need another sharp reminder that complete disregard for the will of their own people will carry a heavy price.

HEADLINE: Ex-Detroit Officers Ordered To Prison for Beating Death

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Two white former police officers convicted of beating a black motorist to death outside a crack house were sentenced to prison today by a judge who told the courtroom, "I know nobody in the community will be completely satisfied with what has transpired here today."
Judge George W. Crockett 3d sentenced one former officer, Larry Nevers, 53, to 12 to 25 years in prison. The other, Walter Budzyn, 47, received a sentence of 8 to 18 years for the beating death of Malice Green last Nov. 5. 
 Under Michigan law, Mr. Budzyn will have to serve at least six and a half years in prison; Mr. Nevers will serve a minimum of nine years and eight months, a prison spokesman said.
Judge Crockett said he had asked the Federal prison system to allow the former officers to serve their sentences there, presumably in another state. Lawyers for the former officers had asked that they serve their time out of state because, as longtime street patrolmen, they would be among many convicts they had helped to send to prison.
 
'Excessive in the Extreme'
 While Judge Crockett told Mr. Budzyn, who served 19 years on the Detroit police force, that he did not believe the former officer's assertion that he did not strike the victim, he added, "I don't think you should be treated as a person who wanted to kill someone."
But he said he could not quarrel with the jury's verdict of second-degree murder. By failing to stop the beating, the judge said, Mr. Budzyn subjected the victim to "the risk of great bodily harm."
The judge had harsher words for Mr. Nevers, who was a Detroit police officer for 24 years. "Yours were the blows that resulted in the death of Malice Green, in all probability, from the evidence I have heard," he said. There was a murmur in the courtroom as the judge went on: "I don't believe you intended to kill Malice Green. I believe you intended to do harm, and serious harm. What you did was excessive in the extreme."
The two former officers were convicted of second-degree murder by separate juries on Aug. 23 after a trial that was closely followed through the summer here. They were dismissed from the police force after the incident.
 
Starts With Drug Arrest
 Testimony at the trial indicated that the officers suspected that Mr. Green, a 35-year-old unemployed steel worker with a history of drug problems, possessed crack when they confronted him while he was sitting in his car outside a known crack house. Witnesses said the officers beat him with heavy metal flashlights when he failed to follow orders to open his hand. A medical examiner testified that Mr. Green had died from more than a dozen blows to the head.
While there was never any testimony that race was a factor in the beating, there were concerns that a not-guilty verdict or lenient sentences might have touched off the kind of civil disturbance that rocked Los Angeles after four police officers there were acquitted on state charges in the beating death of Rodney G. King after a car chase.
Today, the sentences were calmly accepted in this city. "Justice has been served," said Wendell Anthony, president of the Detroit chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Several white Detroit police officers, all of whom declined to identify themselves, said they were not surprised by the sentences, which they said were too harsh.
Outside the court, there were some signs of dissatisfaction as about 50 Green family supporters and a similar-sized group of supporters of the former police officers shouted taunts and slogans at each other.
 
Appeals Are Planned
 The request that the officers serve their sentences in a Federal prison is "not all that unusual," said Warren Williams, a spokesman for the Michigan Department of Corrections. He noted that 28 Michigan prisoners are currently serving state sentences in Federal prisons, in most cases because of concern for their safety.
So far, Judge Crockett said during sentencing, the Federal Bureau of Prisons has not responded to his request. In the meantime, Mr. Nevers and Mr. Budzyn will be housed in a special protective custody unit at an undisclosed Michigan prison.
"I'm sure there is every likelihood that they will agree," Mr. Williams said. "It could take two to four weeks to get a response."
The former officers' lawyers immediately said they would appeal the convictions. Earlier, Mr. Budzyn's lawyer, John Goldpaugh, had sought a mistrial on the ground that the jurors were shown the movie "Malcolm X" during the trial, a film that begins with the videotape of Mr. King's beating. And a juror in the trial of Mr. Budzyn, identified only as Karl, wrote to Judge Crockett and told news organizations that he had been pressured into the verdict and wished he could change his mind.

HEADLINE: BELL ATLANTIC DEAL FOR 2 CABLE GIANTS PUT AT $33 BILLION

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
In what is shaping up as the largest corporate merger in history, the Bell Atlantic Corporation has agreed to buy both Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, and its cable programming company, the Liberty Media Corporation, in an all-stock deal valued at more than $23 billion, three executives close to the negotiations said last night.
With the assumption of $10 billion in debt, the total value of the deal would be $33 billion. 
 The corporate marriage, which is expected to be announced this morning, would be one of the first to take advantage of a regulatory environment that has become more hospitable to telephone companies' branching into new businesses as a way to bring about a nationwide "superhighway" communications network that would carry voice, video and computer data.
 
 
Well-Positioned Company
 Assuming regulators do not frown on the deal, the merged company would be well positioned to explore and develop new technology for delivering an arsenal of innovative programming into American homes. But its sheer size is bound to attract intense scrutiny from the Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission.
The new company would have access to 42 percent of American homes, a figure that reflects the extraordinary reach of both Tele-Communications, which controls 25 percent of the United States cable television market, and Bell Atlantic, which is based in Philadelphia and provides telephone service for the Middle Atlantic states.
The merger would also create a colossal company with $60 billion in assets and more than $16 billion in revenues. Ranked by assets alone, it would deserve to be showcased as the sixth largest company in Fortune 500's annual list of largest American companies, ahead of Philip Morris and Chrysler, and overshadowed only by General Electric, General Motors, Ford Motor, International Business Machines and Exxon in that order.
The size and scope of the deal stunned the industry last night, and even people involved in the deal were at a loss for words. While telephone companies have begun buying smaller cable companies, it had hardly seemed possible that a telephone company would try to swallow a major cable operator whole.
Nor had there been any clue -- despite enormous scrutiny in the last few weeks because of Tele-Communications' role in the takeover battle for Paramount Communications -- that Tele-Communications' president, John C. Malone, intended to sell his company.
Just last week, he seemed far more intent to play the buyer, arranging to buy back the 90 percent of Liberty Media that Tele-Communications did not already own. Now, it seems that the Liberty buyback may have been motivated by the Bell Atlantic deal, since consolidating the ownership of Tele-Communications and Liberty should vastly simplify the telephone company's task.
Mr. Malone has flirted with various phone companies before, but never on this magnitude. He did a number of small deals with telephone companies including U S West and has apparently been in talks over the past several months to sell at least an interest in Tele-Communications to one of the phone companies.
Far from killing a bid for Paramount that Bell Atlantic was considering joining, experts said that the latest purchase might actually strengthen that bid, which also involves QVC Network Inc. The reason is that Liberty would be that much stronger with Bell Atlantic's financial power behind it. And one expert said he believed that Bell Atlantic could buy another movie company if it chose to do so if Paramount merged instead with Viacom Inc., its handpicked merger partner, or if the deal simply fell through.
Bell Atlantic's entry into Mr. Malone's orbit and therefore into the Paramount deal, however, may put on ice plans that QVC's chairman, Barry Diller, had been making. He had been seriously exploring an investment by BellSouth that would have helped him increase his $9.5 billion bid for Paramount if necessary. But now it is far from clear whether BellSouth would care to invest in QVC, if that company is owned in part by Bell Atlantic, one of its biggest rivals. Liberty Media is the largest shareholder in QVC.
For Bell Atlantic's part, it has been among the most aggressive of the phone companies in diversifying into new areas. Clearly, it is gambling that it will not have to deal for long with current American law that bars telephone companies from owning cable systems in their own territory. Bell Atlantic has already won a district court ruling in Virginia declaring the law that prohibits such cross-ownership as unconstitutional, but the case is being appealed.
 
 
Political Sentiment
 Even so, time is on Bell Atlantic's side. The political sentiment in Washington and the Clinton Administration is shifting rapidly to eliminate legal barriers for consumers' sake because telephone companies are seen as a good way to force competition into the cable market.
Several people close to the talks said last night that Bell Atlantic would pay about $35 a share of its own stock for each share in Tele-Communications, after it absorbs the shares of Liberty it does not already own. Those shares will pay no dividends for five years to conserve cash. Bell Atlantic also intends to assume the roughly $10 billion in debt that Tele-Communications already carries, they added.
Counting the absorption of $10 billion in debt, the deal weighs in at about $33 billion and therefore should easily rank ahead of RJR Nabisco's 1989 leveraged buyout, which at the time involved $25 billion in equity and $4.5 billion in debt.
Though the deal's total value is enormous, the price is in line with other media deals, bankers say. Bell Atlantic appears to be paying close to 12 times recent cash flow, what comparable deals usually fetch. The deal should be tax-free to Tele-Communications and Liberty shareholders who hold on to their newly issued Bell Atlantic stock.
Bell Atlantic refused to comment yesterday. It released a statement that said it would make a major announcement in New York at 7:30 this morning, followed by a news conference at 10.
Bell Atlantic is investing heavily in fiber optic and advanced digital switching technology, which will allow it to deliver a sophisticated network that has the theoretical capability to let people order whatever video entertainment they might want.
The company is already installing that technology throughout New Jersey and in a showcase system in Virginia. What Tele-Communications brings is a rich source of programming through Liberty and its cable networks, which already deliver dozens of programming channels.
The nation's telephone systems have the ability to provide two-way communications, but telephone wires running into individual homes do not have the capacity for more than a single channel of video at one time. By contrast, a cable operator such as Tele-Communications offers networks that bring lots of channels into the home. Its big drawback is that it offers little ability to send information back to the supplier, which is the base of any two-way programming service such as movies-on-demand.
 
 
'Have to Be a Fool'
 "You would have to be a fool not to figure that the telephone companies have figured out that the broadband networks owned by cable companies are going to be tremendous strategic assets in the next decade," said Gordon Crawford, a senior vice president of Capital Research, the largest shareholder of Liberty Media and Tele-Communications.
Mr. Malone and his mentor, Bob Magness, Tele-Communications' chairman, stand to do extremely well under the deal. They will each get a premium for their class B voting stock in each company. And they will get to name five directors out of the 15 who will serve on the combined company's board. One person close to the deal said that he believed that Mr. Malone will assume the vice chairman's title behind Bell Atlantic Chairman Raymond W. Smith.
Mr. Malone's 1991 reorganization of his cable empire already made him one of the richest men in America. Now, with the buyout by Bell Atlantic, his fortune would continue to soar.

HEADLINE: Haiti Army Celebrates U.S. Withdrawal

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 12

 BODY:
To the accompaniment of 15 minutes of jubilant dancing, cheering and gunfire, a United States troop ship pulled out of Haitian waters this afternoon after two days anchored under the baking sun a mile from port.
A demonstration organized by security forces opposed to the return of Haiti's deposed President prevented the 560-foot Harlan County, carrying more than 200 soldiers, from docking on Monday. Today it headed to the United States naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. 
 The troops are part of a 1,300-member United Nations contingent set up under the settlement in July that calls for restoring the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide to the presidency.
 
Dockside Under Siege
 Demonstrators surrounded the port with roadblocks today, and cars venturing near the area were stopped and searched, or scared off with gunfire. Members of an American television crew who drove into the area were briefly arrested and threatened with execution, but were later released.
Diplomats said the forces manning the roadblocks and building barricades were police auxiliaries, who have been blamed for much of the recent violence here, and regular soldiers. The Army, led by Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, accounts for about 7,000 troops, including 1,500 police officers led by Col. Joseph Michel Francois.
Colonel Francois is widely suspected of having organized a similar number of auxiliaries, known as attaches, who rove the streets heavily armed.
Diplomats said the armed forces threatened the efforts to restore democracy. Father Aristide was ousted by security forces two years ago.
 
General Under Duress
 Diplomats are divided on whether to expect General Cedras to retire, as he is supposed to do Friday. Even if he retires, many warn, other members of the high command, working in league with Colonel Francois, are likely to balk at carrying out the settlement.
In a three-hour meeting here with two United States Congressmen, General Cedras refused to guarantee protection for United States forces sent to Haiti under United Nations mandate.
The mandate calls for the 1,300 soldiers and police officers to separate Haiti's police force from the army, and to retrain both forces.
A Canadian diplomat here said his nation's small police contingent already in Haiti was "staying put and staying calm." The diplomat, who insisted on anonymity, was surprised that the Harlan County, which is carrying 175 United States troops and 25 Canadians, had turned back. "Can anyone explain to me why Washington has just done this?" he asked. "We learned of it on CNN, and just about everyone is shocked."
 
Few U.N. Troops Under Arms
 The United Nations force is to be lightly armed, with only a few members carrying pistols. Diplomats and military officials say there is no way to bring in the troops without a secure environment and a clear commitment from the Haitian Army.
The two Congressmen, Senator Bob Graham and Representative Alcee L. Hastings, both Democrats of Florida, said such a commitment was rejected by General Cedras, who argued that protecting the forces was the job of the transitional civilian Government, which was appointed six weeks ago.
"Quite frankly, his answers amounted to obfuscation," Mr. Hastings said. "It seems that they are looking for any excuse to make the accords collapse."
The civilian Government, led by Prime Minister Robert Malval, also faces a refusal by the military to cooperate and threats of violence by the attaches.
 
People Under Threat
 In recent weeks, crowded neighborhoods have become the scene of nightly raids by roving bands of men spraying automatic-weapons fire.
In another incident today, international human rights observers in a provincial town, Hinche, were threatened by a mob of 300 protesters. Although no one was hurt, the mob smashed a United Nations vehicle.
"We are extremely concerned at the moment for the safety of our observers," said Colin Granderson, the head of a joint mission by the United Nations and the Organization of American States that has been monitoring human rights since February.
The lack of a prompt response to the defiance by Haiti's military has brought a mood of despondency to many of the diplomats here. Dante Caputo, the special United Nations envoy, speaking at a reception Monday, said of possible new trade sanctions: "I don't think they are the best way to restore democracy, but they may be the last tool we have."
Another senior diplomat said: "The international community has run out of initiatives. The Haitians have run circles around us, and people are only just now realizing how truly evil the people we are dealing with are."
 
Goverment Under a Cloud
 Members of Mr. Malval's Government say that given the international community's recoil from crises in Somalia and Bosnia, they see little chance of armed intervention here to unseat the military.
"They are talking about sanctions, but that is an abstract measure for people like this," said one senior adviser to Mr. Malval. "We are looking at just three days of life left in the agreement here. After that, all bets are off."
The upswing in violence also prevented a vote today by members of Parliament on a law separating the police and the army. The elected members walked out when politicians opposed to President Aristide who were elected fraudulently last January and later purged under international pressure returned to their seats, accompanied by uniformed police with rifles.
"We are going back into the Parliament," said Dejean Belizaire, one of the purged senators. "The accord has been violated by the Government."

 CORRECTION:
A brief background summary on Wednesday, headed "Haiti at a Glance," included incorrect dates in some editions for the country's independence and for the election of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide as President. Independence was in 1804, not 1934. Father Aristide was elected in December 1990; February 1991 was the date of his inauguration.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Haiti at a Glance"
 
HISTORY: Haiti was a French colony from 1659 until 1804, when black slaves declared independence. Instability throughout the 19th century finally led the U.S. to take military control from 1915 to 1934. Francois (Papa Doc) Duvalier became President in 1957. Jean-Claude, his 19-year-old son, took over in 1971 and opened the country to developement until he fled in 1986. President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, elected in February 1991, was ousted in a military coup in Spetember 1991. After an oil and arms embargo, an agreement was reached in July to reinstate Father Aristide at the end of this month. But the plan is in doubt because American and Canadian peacekeepers were not allowed to land.
 
GOVERNMENT: The Government is based on a popularly elected President and a Parliament with two houses. But it has been a military dictatorship since Father Aristide's outster.
 
ECONOMY: The country is one of the poorest and most populous of the West Indies. Haiti relies on agriculture, primarily coffee, sugar, and cotton. Coffee is also its largest export.
 
POPULATION: 6,431,000
 
RACE: Black 95% and mixed race 5%
 
LANGUAGE: French and Haitian Creole, though Creole is predominant.
 
RELIGION: Roman Catholic. Voodoo is the folk religion.

HEADLINE: Choke Haiti's Thugs

BYLINE: By Amy Wilentz; Amy Wilentz is author of "The Rainy Season: Haiti Since Duvalier."

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
The television footage out of Haiti is like a scene from a recurring nightmare: the brandished weapons, the ugly insults, the violent attacks on bystanders. The Haitian military and its "attaches," descendants of the Duvalier regime's infamous Tontons Macoutes, love to beat up the weak, the downtrodden, the unarmed -- anyone who threatens to come between them and their booty.
The latest object of their ire is the amphibious ship Harlan County, which was supposed to unload an "observer" contingent of some 200 American and Canadian troops. Yesterday, the Pentagon ordered the ship to leave Haitian waters. 
 U.S. policy in Haiti has been so indecisive since the 1991 coup overthrowing President Jean-Bertrand Aristide that it seems almost reasonable that a few dozen thugs can force the army of the world's sole remaining superpower into retreat.
Under George Bush, the U.S. said it supported democracy in Haiti but did not give 100 percent backing to President Aristide, who was overwhelmingly elected in Haiti's first free and fair balloting. The U.S. then supported a halfhearted embargo against the de facto military regime, one that was so porous that oil and other necessities flowed freely into the island.
When the United Nations, with full support of the new Clinton Administration, finally levied serious sanctions against the regime, the U.S. helped broker an agreement on Governors Island this summer that lifted the new embargo far too soon, against the better judgment of the Aristide administration.
If Haiti's brief democratic experiment is to continue, the U.S. must once and for all have a consistent policy there.
The U.S. has to push hard for the immediate reimposition of U.N. sanctions. We should insure that the Government of the neighboring Dominican Republic understands that harsh penalties will be imposed on its vital sugar trade if it allows goods to leak across the border it shares with Haiti, as has happened in the past. (Of course, since sanctions were lifted, the Haitian military has reportedly stockpiled enough oil to last six months to a year.)
The U.S. and its allies should enclose the island with a naval blockade. This way, small ships carrying contraband, from which the generals and their men have made hundreds of thousands of dollars during the various embargoes since the coup, will not be able to get in. Also, a naval blockade will show that we are dead serious.
The U.S. and its allies should also revoke the visas and freeze all assets of those individuals -- perhaps 200 officers and the industrialists who bankrolled them -- who were involved in the coup and its bloody aftermath. We know who they are.
It's just possible that Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, who has presided over the whole brutal mess, will actually step down, as mandated in the accord. If he does abide by the agreement, President Aristide would then name a new head for the Haitian army, whose first great test would be to get rid of the rogue police chief Michel Joseph Francois, an instigator of the riots on Monday as well as the terror campaign of the last year. He has vowed to remain at his post.
In any event, the U.S. should insure that reimposed sanctions are not lifted until all the officers involved in the bloody assaults and assassinations have given up power and are in exile. The democratic government also needs to be back in place with new officers and new chiefs of staff, appointed by President Aristide.
If these prescriptions sound like a scratched record, it is only because the Governors Island accord planned its own failure by lifting sanctions before they had achieved these goals. One can only wonder why.

HEADLINE: A MERGER OF GIANTS: The Vision;
A Phone-Cable Vehicle for the Data Superhighway

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
The Bell Atlantic Corporation and Tele-Communications Inc. announced the biggest media merger in history yesterday, a deal offering perhaps the clearest evidence yet that American industry is serious about building the vaunted "information superhighway" of the future.
In announcing the $33 billion deal, the cable industry entrepreneur John C. Malone held out the vision of a single powerful box on top of each home television set that would combine the diverse streams of information that now flow separately into the home: telephone calls, television shows, video rentals, newspapers and even books. 
 If the vaunted information superhighway is coming, this set-top device will be the steering wheel, combining the video controls of a cable converter box, the two-way capabilities of a telephone and the information-processing power of a personal computer. In short, "it will allow us to control all the communications needs of a household with one device," Mr. Malone said.
Although there is no guarantee that consumers will buy the services that Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications envision, the companies are among many big media players that see advantages in combining the capabilities of cable and telephone networks.
Currently, cable networks have the capacity to carry hundreds of channels of television programs or other information, but most cable systems are not very good at letting consumers send information back over the network, whether to order a movie or play video games with other cable customers.
 
Predicting a Transformation
 Telephone "channels," by contrast, can handle only limited amounts of information, but they have an almost magical ability through switching systems to let anyone on the network communicate with anyone else.
Therein lies the promise of this mega-merger, which will blend the information cargo-carrying capacity of the nation's largest cable company and the traffic-control talents of one of America's most technically sophisticated telephone companies.
"This is going to forever change our lives and rearrange the whole computer and the communications industries," said Lawrence J. Ellison, chairman of Oracle, a Redwood City, Calif., software company. Oracle is designing software systems for storing and retrieving video and data from vast information libraries that will be available to American consumers.
More than any of the hundreds of information-age alliances that have been proposed to date, a merger of Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications clearly outlines the potential of a national data highway.
"When video and voice and everything else is all digital, there are economies that can be achieved by offering all of the information over a unified medium," said John Moussouris, a Silicon Valley computer designer.
By blending telephone and television networks, Mr. Malone and Raymond Smith, the chairman of Bell Atlantic, may help ignite an explosion of new information services that will go far beyond the conventional ideas of ordering videos on demand and shopping at home, the types of services that have been presumed to be the first commercially viable businesses on the digital information highway.
The truly successful new information services, some experts say, may go beyond traditional television programming and consumerism.
"It's very easy to envisage a time when video communication will be the most natural way to communicate," said Nathan Myhrvold, a senior vice president at the Microsoft Corporation, who is in charge of developing the software company's interactive television business.
What will be possible when "video dial tone" is widely available in every American home? For one thing, some industry executives predict, there will be a proliferation of video cameras throughout society, permitting people to dial into the network and peek virtually everywhere.
For example, before leaving for work in the morning, commuters might be able to dial up the camera that is pointing at the freeway on-ramp or at that frequently troublesome overpass to see instantly if there is a traffic jam. Indeed, such cameras scattered along the entire route would make it possible to virtually "drive" to work before leaving home -- or stay there, if things look truly grim.
"Dialing" itself, in fact, is likely to be a vastly different experience when such services arrive in the next century. Rather than pecking at numbers on a telephone keypad, it is likely that a telephone caller will simply use a remote control to point at an icon on the television screen. The call might be audio only, or it could include full-motion video, if the two -- or more -- parties agree.
Whatever new services ultimately arrive on the information superhighway, yesterday's merger announcement was seen by many computer and communications industry executives as the clearest evidence yet that the convergence of digital information media is really occurring.
"This is not a conventional merger in any sense," said James Moore, president of Geopartners, a Cambridge, Mass. consulting firm. "It's all about coming together to build the next generation of technology and services."
If the synergy between cable and telephone is real, some believe it will shift the center of technology innovation away from the personal computer business. Mr. Ellison, Oracle's chairman, in particular argues that growth in the future will not be in stand-alone personal computers, but instead in the television set-top boxes and in hand-held information and communications devices that will connect wirelessly to the information highway.
Mr. Ellison is also betting that there will be a boom in demand for supercomputers, which will act as the information servers for the powerful new networks. These machines will provide the raw computing horsepower to deliver simultaneously thousands of movies or other items from electronic data bases.
Despite the promise of the nation's most ambitious technology merger yet, there are also obvious caveats. To date, most of the high-technology experiments in interactive television have been disappointments, beginning with Warner Amex Cable's interactive QUBE system in Columbus, Ohio, which began in 1977 and ended a few years later without living up to expectations. And an interactive cable system that the GTE telephone company has been operating for several years in Cerritos, Calif., has yet to show it can effectively compete with video rental stores.
 
Doubts Expressed
 Histories like these cause some analysts to be pessimistic about the ambitious plans of Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications.
"John Malone is smart; he's getting out at the top," said Mark Stahlman, president of New Media Associates, a New York City consulting firm. "Cable television won't continue to grow."
As for Bell Atlantic, he said, the phone company is groping for a way to find new revenue beyond the local-telephone business, a mature industry. In cable, Mr. Stahlman said, "Bell Atlantic is turning to the obvious business and trying to use the obvious technology to squeeze the last drop of blood out of the stone."

HEADLINE: Where Hispanic Voters Sided With Dinkins, Now Defection

SERIES: Campaign Stop: A periodic report on neighborhood reaction to the mayoral race. 1. Soundview

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
With its tree-shaded streets lined with tidy brick and stucco homes, parts of Soundview look downright suburban, and for many of its residents it is. This corner of the southeast Bronx was the working-class promised land -- a house, garage and yard -- a hard-earned reward for sweating it out at work and toughing it out in the tenements of the South Bronx or Spanish Harlem.
Now, as residents prepare to vote for mayor, they grumble that the out-of-the way feeling that attracted them to the neighborhood in the first place may be its curse as New York City officials show little interest in their concerns, which range from uneven sidewalks and overgrown trees to the recent incursion of drugs and crime. All they have to do, they say, is glance at the street through barred windows and fenced-in porches and wonder if the phrase "quality of life" will ever be more than a campaign catch phrase. 
 This is the kind of community where Mr. Dinkins must run up a big vote to assure his re-election. But a visit to one neighborhood in Soundview suggests the nature of Mayor David N. Dinkins's difficulties among Hispanic voters, who supported him by a 2-to-1 ratio over Rudolph W. Giuliani in 1989 and are an important swing vote this time around. Within this neighborhood -- a 15-block census tract that is nearly half Hispanic -- there are signs that Mr. Dinkins will not garner as much support as he did four years ago when he outpolled Mr. Giuliani 982 votes to 135 votes. Whether he has lost enough support to foil his re-election bid remains to be seen.
Many say he has not lived up to their hopes. The Mayor's term has left one-time supporters like Antonio Burgos Jr. disillusioned. "I really wanted him to make it," Mr. Burgos said. "It would have been so cool. He would have opened the door for Hispanics. But the way he talked about Crown Heights and the problems with the Korean store, he messed it all up."
Many Hispanic residents said the Mayor took Hispanic votes for granted, and they expressed a keen realization that they were in a position to thwart his re-election.
Mr. Burgos, 26, a porter who said Mr. Dinkins captured his hopes and vote four years ago, plans to vote for Mr. Giuliani, not so much out of support, but rather disenchantment with Mr. Dinkins, whom he said did little but waffle on the issues and pepper his speeches with empty phrases. He suggested Mr. Giuliani would be a more effective crime fighter.
"There's a lot of little neighborhoods like this suffering from the same problems," said Mr. Burgos, who grew up in Soundview. "These are the people who work and pay taxes and they're upset because they can't have anything. What's the point of buying a house and fixing it up if you can't keep it clean and safe?"
Melissa Vega, 21, a dental assistant who lives on St. Lawrence Avenue, has heard those criticisms, but they have not deterrred her from her intention of voting for Mr. Dinkins.
"I think he's done O.K.," she said. "A lot of people criticize him, but I don't know why."
Longtime residents remember when their neighborhood was a respite from the overcrowding and crime they had tolerated in their search for a better life. Their homes, fixed up with gardens and statues, were a proud signal that they had made it, even if they had to work two jobs to finance a mortgage.
 
Crime and Drug Dealers
 Now, the talk is of crime, especially that fueled by drug dealers who ply their trade near the Soundview Houses housing project, where grafitti scrawls challenge the police and gunshots ring out at night. Last year, parishioners from Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church held prayer vigils outside of one suspected crack house on Randall Avenue. Several weeks later, intruders broke into the church, smashing statues and setting fires.
The incident brought official attention and the crack house was closed, but residents said the dealers only moved down the block, leaving them with the impression that their concerns have been forgotten.
"The city should have ways of hitting and hitting it until it's clean and they don't come back," said Catherine Oliveri, a retired city worker who has lived on Beach Avenue for 14 years. "Now, they give up. It's like a revolving door. It's a joke."
Mrs. Oliveri, a Democrat who voted for Mr. Giuliani in 1989, said she planned to do the same this year, hoping that his years as a Federal prosecutor would help bring stability to the neighborhood.
"Dinkins really never did anything with crime," she said. "Giuliani dealt with crime before. I imagine he's got better ideas. I hope he does. I feel we should give him a chance to try and do better than Dinkins."
Crimes of a lesser sort irked Mr. Burgos, who tinkered with his car one recent afternoon outside of the two-story house he shares with his wife and parents. He complained that vehicles left overnight on the street were often targeted twice, first by vandals who smash windows and steal parts and then by traffic enforcement agents who in the last year have stepped up their ticketing of illegally parked cars.
"We never had traffic patrol before," he said. "But since the city is so hard up for money, you got them giving tickets."
For others, the economy dominates their thinking. Nelson Sicardo, a 38-year-old construction laborer who is on workers' compensation after a back injury, said that despite the Mayor's policy of favoring minority companies for city contracts, workers like himself are often laid off.
"I wish he could do something about that," said Mr. Sicardo, who did not vote in 1989 but said he intended to this time. "Why should I worry about being laid off when Irish and Italians don't have to bust their butts for a paycheck because they're related to somebody. I get laid off when the work is slow. How can it be slow when a job is 80 floors and we're only on the 30th?"
He said he had not decided who would get his vote.
In a way, residents said, the election of the city's first minority mayor left them with expectations that conditions would improve for other minorities, but their experiences suggest Mr. Dinkins's talk of inclusiveness and tolerance has not filtered down through the ranks of city government. For example, Mr. Sicardo, like others his age, said he felt unfairly singled out by the police even when he passed the time with friends outside of his house, which is a block away from a thriving crack trade.
"I'll be hanging outside here and the cops tell me to get away from my corner," he said. "How can they do that? They treat me like a hoodlum because I'm Puerto Rican."
In a larger sense, there is a feeling among many Hispanic residents that Mr. Dinkins's administration has taken their loyalty for granted. They still remember slights like his denunciation of the Puerto Rican nationalists as "assassins" who shot up the Congress in the 1950's, and the disparaging comments about Hispanic immigrants made in 1990 by a supporter, Hazel Dukes, when she said, among other things, they were taking jobs away from blacks.
 
Only 'Helping His Own'
 "I don't think he's done anything for us," said Robert Felix, a 46-year-old motor mechanic. "Maybe in midtown. But when we need him on this side he did nothing. I think he only likes his own race. He's only trying to help his own."
While Mr. Felix did not vote in the last election, he said he planned to vote for Mr. Giuliani next month. "Something's got to change," he said.
His friend, Louie Alvarez, 47, a general contractor, said he thought Mr. Dinkins's favoritism was geared to the green of campaign contributions, the kind that working people like him cannot afford to dole out.
"He doesn't care about Latinos or blacks," said Mr. Alvarez, who favored Mr. Dinkins in 1989. "He only cares about white society, you know, take care of my pocket and I'll take care of you. But you know something, I don't blame him. Everybody promises so much, once you put him there, nobody can do anything."
A block away, inside an elaborately gated and decorated house, Mr. Felix's mother, Francisca, said she would simply like the city to cut the branches of an overgrown tree whose limbs dangle onto her roof. She said that since the tree is on the sidewalk outside her home, it was the city's responsibility to take care of it, but her efforts to get something done have been unsuccessful.
"They tell me the city is short of people," she said.
But Mrs. Felix, a retired hospital worker, said she voted for Mr. Dinkins before and planned to do so again, following the lead of Dennis Rivera, the hospital workers' union leader who is a key ally of Mr. Dinkins's.
For Antonio Burgos Sr., how the Mayor says something is just as important as what he says. The 55-year-old plumber had voted previously for Mr. Dinkins, but is considering supporting Mr. Giuliani. He faulted Mr. Dinkins for being too deliberate.
"For Dinkins to say anything, he needs to read," Mr. Burgos said. "It doesn't matter to me where the man is from. If he knows what he's saying, it's good."
Like other Hispanic voters of his generation, Mr. Burgos contrasted Mr. Dinkins's public style with that of his predecessor, Edward I. Koch.
"People talk a lot about Koch, but for me he was the best," Mr. Burgos said. "He spoke his mind. If you got hurt you got hurt, but he told you the truth. He didn't care where it fell."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Accuses Dinkins Of Being a Weak Leader

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
Rudolph W. Giulinai made a blistering advertising attack on Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday, criticizing his record and accusing him of weak leadership that has caused the city to lose 350,000 jobs, allowed government scandals and public disorder to flourish and encouraged racial divisiveness.
Though Mr. Giuliani has attacked the condition of the city on the stump and in commercials before, the two new commercials mark the first time he has taken on Mr. Dinkins's record -- and what Mr. Giuliani calls his lack of accountability -- in paid advertising with such blunt, confrontational language that clearly seeks to put Mr. Dinkins on the defensive. 
 One of the 30-second spots attributes a list of government failures to Mr. Dinkins, including the 1990 boycott of a Korean grocery store in Brooklyn, the 1991 racial disturbances in Crown Heights, ethical questions about a contract for collecting parking violation fines, and botched asbestos inspections in public schools.
The commercial fails to note that the asbestos inspections occurred before Mr. Dinkins's election and that the Mayor responded as soon as he learned of the problem.
"And all David Dinkins says is, it's not my fault," the narrator says. "Maybe he's right. Maybe it was our fault four years ago."
 
'Not Innuendo'
 David Garth, who is Mr. Giuliani's chief campaign strategist, said of the new campaign, "It's not innuendo -- it lays it right out there based on facts."
Mr. Dinkins's chief media adviser, Robert Shrum, called the new commercials a "reckless" effort by a candidate who is "sinking."
"Gone is the nice little kid who grew up in Brooklyn liking the Yankees and getting knocked in the mud," said Mr. Shrum, referring to an earlier commercial for Mr. Giuliani. "He forgot to tell us he collected bags of mud for future use."
Mr. Dinkins has also aired harsh ads, linking Mr. Giuliani to policies of the Reagan Administration and accusing him of waffling on the abortion issue.
The new commercials follow closely sets of commercials by Mr. Giuliani intended to reach Hispanic voters and to pressure Mr. Dinkins into debating him.
Though the candidates have been at an impasse over the debate issue for months, Mr. Giuliani gave it a higher profile this week with commercials that call on Mr. Dinkins to meet in a "one-on-one, face-to-face" confrontation.
Those commercials began running on Tuesday.
 
Sharply Worded Response
 Mr. Dinkins replied by releasing a sharply worded letter on Tuesday, accusing Mr. Giuliani of "being afraid of" a debate that involves George J. Marlin, the Conservative Party candidate.
With less than three weeks left in the campaign, neither candidate seems willing to blink first.
Mr. Dinkins says he will not appear in any debates without Mr. Marlin, whom he calls a "major-party candidate."
Mr. Giuliani has refused to appear in any forum or debate with Mr. Marlin because, he says, Mr. Marlin's main goal is to attack him.
Their disagreement has left several television stations and civic organizations in the lurch, uncertain of whether debates that have been under discussion since the summer will go forward. One station, WABC-TV, canceled a debate scheduled for yesterday because Mr. Giuliani refused to attend.
In at least one other case, a debate sponsored by the League of Women Voters and St. Francis College is expected to proceed tonight with Mr. Marlin and Mr. Dinkins but not Mr. Giuliani.
Others, including the National Abortion Rights Action League and WCBS-TV, have said they may proceed with mayoral debates even if one candidate is not present.
The battle over the debates says as much about the closeness of the race as about the two candidates' strategies. Several recent polls have shown the two men running neck and neck, and political strategists said neither candidate wants to appear to have capitulated to the other or be subjected to the unpredictable arena of a televised debate at this time.
"A debate is a big risk from both vantage points," said Lee M. Miringoff director of the Marist College Institute of Public Opinion. "Things can happen in a debate. If you stick to controlled campaign stops and paid advertising, less happens."
There has not been unanimity on the debate issue among Mr. Giuliani's running mates. Herman Badillo, the Republican-Liberal candidate for city comptroller, has said he will only debate his Democratic rival, Alan G. Hevesi. Mr. Hevesi will debate two other candidates tonight. But Susan Alter, the Republican-Liberal candidate for public advocate, said yesterday that she would debate other candidates, provided she had at least one head-to-head debate with Mark Green, the Democrat.
But yesterday, hours before a scheduled debate between public-advocate candidates that did not include Ms. Alter, aides to Mr. Garth threatened to withdraw all of Ms. Alter's campaign commercials from New York 1 News if the station broadcast the debate, said Richard Aurelio, president of the cable network. Ms. Alter has spent $22,000 in advertising with the station.
When asked if anyone on his staff had threatened to pull Ms. Alter's ads, Mr. Garth said, "Somebody here might have called, but I can't control that."

HEADLINE: Rabin Says Sales to China Didn't Break U.S. Law

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzak Rabin, acknowledged on a state visit today that his country had sold arms to Beijing, but he disputed a United States intelligence estimate of the size of the sales and insisted that they do not violate any restrictions on transferring American weapons technology.
At a news conference, Mr. Rabin responded to a United States Central Intelligence Agency report in Washington suggesting that over the last decade, Israel had sold several billion dollars worth of arms and military technology to China. 
 "All these stories of billions of dollars of arms business in the past 10 years are total nonsense," Mr. Rabin told reporters. But he declined to discuss the specifics of Israeli military assistance.
He said that Israel's reported annual trade with China undermines the C.I.A. estimate. The figure for 1992 was about $60 million, he said.
 
Rabin Says Law Was Upheld
 "We have made it clear time and again," Mr. Rabin said, "that we have never done anything against American law." He said that with the exception of a sale of American jet fighters to Ecuador, Israel has "never transmitted items of technology that we got from the United States" under restrictions that prevented re-export.
Mr. Rabin said, "We are not stupid enough to endanger" Israel's annual $3 billion aid package from the United States, and its longstanding military and intelligence sharing ties with Washington, by violating licensing agreements.
Israel is believed to have assisted China in improving its missile arsenal, including surface-to-surface missiles used as offensive weapons, surface-to-air missiles used in air defense and air-to-air missiles used in air combat. Improving China's tank armor and providing airborne early warning technology are also believed to be part of the Israeli assistance.
 
Modernization Proceeding
 China's military modernization program, according to Western analysts, is proceeding at a modest pace, but does not have as high a national priority as economic reform and civilian development programs.
"I'm really sorry that from time to time there are leaks that cannot be proved about Israel doing something which is in contradiction to our commitments to the United States in the field of defense," Mr. Rabin said before leaving Beijing for Shanghai.
These sales boost Israel's trade and defer weapons development costs for Israeli defense industries. They may also increase the Israelis' influence with Beijing as they try to halt ballistic missile sales in the Middle East.
 
Concerns of Israel
 At the same time, Israel must beware of providing technologies and weapons that someday could be turned against Israeli targets. And if American technology is the foundation of an Israeli weapon system, the Israeli Government, in selling such weapons, would run the risk of embarrassing clashes with Washington.
One of the best examples of how Chinese technology can return to the Middle East to bedevil Israeli security planners was the 1988 sale by China of CSS-2 medium-range ballistic missiles to Saudi Arabia. These missiles gave the Saudis the ability to strike any Middle Eastern capital with large high-explosive warheads.
Mr. Rabin's visit, the first by a Israeli Prime Minister since formal diplomatic ties were established in early 1992, follows a recent visit by the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat.
Later this month, Beijing will be the host of Arab-Israeli talks on sharing water resources in the Middle East.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

A Merger of Giants
Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications announced details of their proposed $33 billion merger, offering a majestic vision of how telecommunications might transform the home. [Page D11.] The merger suggests a method of navigating the "information superhighway," with a box on top of each television combining diverse streams of data. [A1.]
John Malone and Raymond Smith come from opposite directions, but they have much in common, including a vision. [D11.] 
 Could a merger between feuding monopolies usher in more competition? Quite possibly, against a backdrop of enormous changes in technology and the marketplace. News Analysis. [D10.]
It may be the biggest corporate takeover, but Wall Street's bill, compared with those in other deals, seems like small change. [D11.] Companies that may build the data superhighway are benefiting. Market Place. [D1.]
The Bell Atlantic deal provided a new twist in the unpredictable Paramount drama, leaving some key actors startled. [D10.]
 
Companies
Woolworth plans to eliminate 13,000 jobs and close 970 stores, including half of its remaining five-and-dime variety stores. [D1.]
First Interstate's turnaround has been engineered by Edward M. Carson, who has completely reversed its strategy. [D1.]
The auto workers' union at Ford refused to sign a contract because of a feared defect in a provision for a new, four-day holiday weekend. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Turkish Leader to Press U.S. on Iraq Embargo

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Turkey's Prime Minister, Tansu Ciller, left here tonight for Washington, where she is expected to ask President Clinton a question that has come to preoccupy many political and economic leaders here and elsewhere: how long can the Western embargo of Iraq continue without visible political result?
The question is particularly pertinent to Turkey, which says it is losing about $3 billion a year in trade and income from Iraq's pipeline across Turkey, an artery that has been closed since the beginning of the Persian Gulf crisis in August 1990. 
 Diplomats and officials here say Mrs. Ciller's primary aim when she meets Mr. Clinton on Friday will be to press for relief from the cost of Turkey's pivotal role in applying the sanctions against Iraq. Accordingly, she is expected to seek Mr. Clinton's assessment of Iraqi progress in meeting the terms of United Nations resolutions on the sanctions.
Officials said Prime Minister Ciller was likely to press President Clinton to support the draining and refilling of the pipeline. Mrs. Ciller, a Western diplomat said, will probably launch "an appeal to the U.S. to take a leadership role in helping Turkey solve its problems." But the United States, he said, will "find itself short on resources to respond to an appeal."
The questions go to the heart of Turkey's problem as a remote Western ally lodged among unruly and hostile neighbors in the east: While it pursues a Western identity, it is also a player and a trader in rough region.
After Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990, Turkey, a member of NATO, was among the first to support the coalition assembled by the Bush Administration. Ankara severed trade ties with Baghdad worth an estimated $1 billion dollars a year and, most important to the West, closed down the pipeline that carried oil from northern Iraq to world markets. The shutdown is denying Baghdad the chance of selling oil to rebuild further, but it also is denying Turkey income and oil supplies.
 
'Who Is Suffering?'
 "Without any hesitation, Turkey supported the coalition," Foreign Minister Hikmet Cetin said in an interview tonight, but added: "Who is suffering from the embargo? Turkey and the Iraqi people, not the leaders, not those who created this problem."
Mr. Cetin also said that since the gulf war, Baghdad's authority no longer extended to Kurdish-controlled northern Iraq, giving a base to Kurdish guerrillas seeking a separate state in southeastern Turkey.
"The north of Iraq is like a no-man's-land," he said, hinting that Turkey viewed the return of some normalcy in Iraq as a priority. "The territorial integrity and unity of Iraq is very important for the whole region and for us."
The Foreign Minister continued: "The problem is how long will this continue? Saddam is there, sanctions are there and no one knows how this will continue to the end. We want to find a solution, and we are not as pleased as the others. They have all left the area and we are here with all the questions because Iraq is our neighbor."
Along with other officials, Mr. Cetin said Turkey had no plans to break with the coalition. But while saying that "what we do, we have to do with the United Nations and our allies," he indicated that his Government wanted progress on a tentative Turkish-Iraqi agreement to drain and refill the oil pipeline so that its jointly owned contents could be sold.
For some Turks, an issue of equal importance is their Government's worry that the Russian military, strengthened by its alliance with President Boris N. Yeltsin in crushing the revolt by Parliament last week, will feel emboldened to exercise its power in such former Soviet republics as Georgia and Azerbaijan -- both of which are just to the east of Turkey.
Prime Minister Ciller, officials said, is also likely to register sharp differences with the Clinton Administration over developments in Russia, which are seen in Ankara not so much as a free-market democracy striving for life as a potential regional threat pursuing what one official termed "a grand Russian design, a hidden hand in the Caucasus" on Turkey's borders.

HEADLINE: ROMANIA GRANTED FULL TRADE STATUS

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
The House of Representatives has given its seal of approval to Romania by voting to restore normal trade relations.
With Senate approval assured, the unanimous vote on Tuesday permits the United States to resume normal trade with Romania for the first time since 1988, when the former Romanian dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu, scuttled a trade deal because of his objections to American demands that Romania improve its behavior on human rights. 
 At the time of the break, the benefits of so-called most-favored-nation trading status were estimated by the Commerce Department to be worth $300 million to Romania, affecting exports totaling $800 million.
The value now will be much smaller because Romania has been staggered by a slow transition from a Communist command economy to a market economy. But the granting anew of trade preferences is likely to encourage sorely needed foreign investments in Romania and to signal greater credit worthiness to lenders.
 
Status Rejected a Year Ago
 A year ago, the House voted by an overwhelming majority to reject a Bush Administration proposal to restore trade benefits, mainly on the ground that efforts by Bucharest to institute democratic practices in Romania were insufficient.
Romania under Ceausescu, despite his highly repressive regime, was one of the few Communist countries to be accorded most-favored-nation status, principally in recognition of its permissive policy toward emigration of Jews. But after the fall of Europe's Communist regimes four years ago, Washington deemed the successor Government ineligible for the preferences.
Members of Congress concerned with Romania maintained a skeptical attitude toward the Government of President Ion Iliescu even after the Administration began, in 1992, to give it good marks for taking steps to increase press freedom, privatize business, hold democratic elections and bring the Romanian intelligence services under legislative control.
These concerns were reflected today in remarks by several Congressmen who said they still had reservations about the Government's behavior.
"They still need to clean up their act on the Hungarian minority," said Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico. Tom Lantos, a California Democrat of Hungarian origin, said there had been "some improvement" in Romania's conduct following "outrageous human rights violations" against ethnic Hungarians and Gypsies.

HEADLINE: First Interstate Ascends As a Banking Phoenix

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
In the summer of 1990, Edward M. Carson, the newly appointed chairman of the First Interstate Bancorporation, promised angry shareholders that he would cut the bank's bad loans to 1 percent of assets by the end of 1993, from a level of 5 percent.
Recession interceded, real estate values here collapsed, and the only other major bank based in Los Angeles, the Security Pacific Corporation, was virtually destroyed. But Mr. Carson will deliver on his pledge: When First Interstate announces its earnings on Oct. 18, problem loans are expected to be below 1 percent, three months ahead of schedule. 
 Mr. Carson, in fact, has presided over one of the most remarkable transformations in banking. He not only rescued First Interstate from financial oblivion, but he completely reversed its strategy.
"Ed Carson should be banker of the year," said George Salem, a bank analyst at Prudential Securities. "Two years ago everyone said they were about to be acquired, but he has brought the organization to a much healthier state."
Joseph J. Pinola, the chairman of First Interstate for most of the 1980's, had fancied the bank as a dynamic global financial services company competing with Citicorp and Merrill Lynch. He ventured into many acquisitions and new activities, like international merchant banking.
The excitement almost killed the bank. Mr. Pinola was inattentive to the problems that were building in the company's existing banks, and some of his new acquisitions, especially a bank in Texas, turned out to be awash in bad loans.
When he took over, Mr. Carson said in effect, "There is no place like home." He declared that First Interstate would be local, not global; consistent, not dynamic. And he shed nearly all the company's activities not related to basic banking services for consumers and small companies in its 13 Western states.
"Our business is a man, a wife, two kids and a station wagon," Mr. Carson said in his office atop the 72-story headquarters tower commissioned by Mr. Pinola. "When we stepped out of that realm and started making big loans, it all went bad."
Although he now lives in Beverly Hills, Mr. Carson -- a 42-year employee of the bank -- gives the impression that he has just parked that station wagon. With an avuncular manner and piercing sky-blue eyes, Mr. Carson communicates his strategy by disseminating aphorisms like "Keep things as simple as possible" on company bulletin boards.
 
Much Like Jimmy Stewart
 "Carson reminds me very much of Jimmy Stewart in personality and the roles he plays," says Raphael Soifer, an analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman. "He has restored a sense of calm and order to management even as he presided over substantial cost cutting and restructuring."
Mr. Carson eliminated more than a quarter of the company's 35,000 jobs. And he forced bank officers to take an intensive training program on how to avoid making bad loans with a test so tough that more than a third failed and had to find new jobs at First Interstate or leave the company.
Most important, Mr. Carson decided to bail out of $3 billion in California real estate loans at the beginning of 1991, a year before the other banks in the state realized the extent of the problems here.
As a result, after heavy losses in 1991, the bank's earnings and capital have risen steadily while bad loans have fallen. In the second quarter, the company's profits were at an annual rate of just over 1 percent of assets, a benchmark level for a healthy bank.
[First Interstate's stock gained 37.5 cents, to $67.625, on the New York Stock Exchange Wednesday. The current stock price represents roughly a 72 percent increase from its 52-week low of $39.]
This success shows the profound change in the aspirations of the banking industry. The role model for many banks is no longer the far-flung Citibank, but the neighborhood branches of Banc One. "The wimps of the 1980's have become the heroes of the 1990's," said Robert F. Smith, a former chairman of Security Pacific.
Mr. Carson took drastic action to turn First Interstate into a "nouvelle" wimp. He sold or closed most of its units outside the Western United States and got out of lucrative but volatile activities like foreign exchange trading.
"If they are not being chewed up with bad credit, our banks are very predictable," Mr. Carson said. "We couldn't afford to have a 'for-ex' trader come in to us on the day before the end of the quarter and say they just lost $30 million or even made $30 million. Our shareholders did not enjoy being surprised."
 
An Enjoyable Surprise
 A surprise the shareholders of First Interstate have found enjoyable has been how little trouble the California recession has caused to the bank's loan portfolio. After living through unpleasant surprises in Texas, Arizona and Colorado, the bank's executives were especially sensitive to the first signs that the California real estate market was softening.
"We saw the same trends we saw in Texas, vacancy rates going up and the power turning to the tenant away from the landlords, so we said, 'Here it comes,' " said William E. B. Siart, the intense, intellectual president of First Interstate.
So, in 1991 First Interstate placed $6.8 billion of its $30 billion in loans, half from California, in a special pool for aggressive workouts, where borrowers are given the opportunity to work out of their financial problems and repay their outstanding loans. Less than a third of those loans were behind on their payments, but in Texas the bank had developed a philosophy of dealing with potential problems quickly before they get worse.
"We're good at getting rid of not only known problems but anything that smells like a problem," said Allen D. Brown, who ran workouts in Texas and later for the holding company. He tried to get these loans out of the bank by any possible means, often selling properties at deep discounts or accepting reduced payouts.
 
Limits Set on Exposure
 In 1991 many other California banks scoffed at First Interstate, and some even lent money to customers booted out by the bank. "I'm not sitting here saying I'm a genius, but there were a lot of people in this town with blind faith," Mr. Carson said. "It was very difficult to turn away customers. Yet it was clear we had to do something."
At the same time, Mr. Siart was assigned to oversee an overhaul of the bank's lending procedures to insure that it would never again get into this sort of trouble. The bank set limits on its exposure to various categories of loans, some far lower than in the past. And it created procedures to identify potential problems in the future.
"You don't get in trouble for having a good loan go bad; you get in trouble for being surprised that it went bad," said Bruce Willison, the head of First Interstate Bank of California.
The lending officers were put through a training program followed by a rigorous, six-hour test. "Of 2,300 lending people, 1,500 passed and 800 people found anther career," said Mr. Siart, who passed only 8 of the 15 sections when he took the test. Lending officers had to retake the test until they passed it all or find new jobs.
 
Fewer Loans Made
 Predictably, the bankers at First Interstate are making fewer loans. It has $43 billion in low-cost deposits from its 1,000 branches. Since it has only $24 billion in loans, it has been forced to invest $15 billion of spare cash in low-yielding bonds.
Mr. Siart calculated that if the bank's loans rose to $30 billion, which is only 60 percent of its $49 billion in assets, not a very high percentage for a bank, First Interstate's profitability, as measured by return on equity, would increase to an outstanding 18.5 percent from an unremarkable 16 percent.
Making $6 billion in new loans is no small task, especially if the bank sticks to its strict new credit policies. While the buoyant economy in the Mountain states is increasing loan demand there, California is a disaster.
"The California recession has stayed down longer than any of us had expected," Mr. Willison said. "At the beginning of 1992, we felt there would be an upturn by the end of that year. Now we don't expect much good news until mid-1994."
 
Looking at Acquisitions
 The recession has created some opportunity for First Interstate because it is in better shape than many of its competitors. Many smaller banks are saddled by loan losses, and Bank of America has been preoccupied with integrating Security Pacific, which it bought in 1991.
First Interstate is looking to acquisitions as a source of growth. In August, the company agreed to buy the San Diego Trust and Savings Bank, which has $2 billion in assets, for $340 million, a hefty 2.6 times its book value.
But that bank had a good franchise and low loan losses, and as the only independent bank in a growing market it was "the last opportunity to get into San Diego in a significant way," Mr. Willison said.
And Mr. Carson said he hoped more acquisitions would help him build market share in California, Texas and Washington, although he said he did not want to go beyond this home region.
With most of the medium-sized banks in California owned by Japanese banks, which despite their problems show no sign of being willing to sell them, First Interstate is eager to acquire one of the large California savings and loan institution like Great Western Bank, Mr. Willison said.
 
Merger Questions Linger
 Ironically, the success of Mr. Carson has raised the same question he faced in the dark period when he started: Will First Interstate be sold or merged into another large regional banking company? The low-risk, back-to-basics branch banking strategy of First Interstate makes it an attractive addition to any number of other institutions. But with its stock at a relatively high multiple, the bank could also remain independent, if it wanted.
An important clue to the bank's thinking in this regard will be how it approaches naming a successor to Mr. Carson, who is 64. Banking analysts said banks with older chairmen were far more likely to be acquired than those with younger chief executives.
While Mr. Siart, 46, is considered the leading candidate, Mr. Carson refuses to call him an heir apparent. For now, Mr. Carson simply says he is keeping his options open.
"I don't want to be a lame duck," he said.
