HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
At the Wire, U.A.W. Balks On Ford Pact

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Two hours before they were to formally sign a three-year contract negotiated last month with the Ford Motor Company, top officials of the United Automobile Workers union notified Ford that they were unhappy with the company's view of one provision and would not sign.
Ford officials said they were caught off guard Tuesday night by the union's objection, which deals with a section giving workers a four-day weekend around Independence Day. Ford and the union had scheduled a signing ceremony at 10 A.M. today, which they called off at 8 A.M. No new date for signing the agreement was scheduled.
 
No Longer Settled
 It was a highly unusual, perhaps unprecedented, move by the U.A.W., since the Ford agreement had already been ratified by the union's members at the No. 2 auto maker by a 2-to-1 margin, and the union had publicly treated it as a done deal. Furthermore, the U.A.W. is now locked in negotiations with the General Motors Corporation. 
 While Ford said it expected to reach agreement on the provision without a strike and without rewriting the rest of the contract, union officials were far less optimistic today.
At issue are paid holidays intended to provide a four-day weekend over the Independence Day holiday in 1995 and 1996. The union won the new days off as part of the agreement. But U.A.W. officials said today that they were concerned that those new days might overlap with traditional two-week production shutdowns at Ford plants.
Most workers already use their vacation time during that two-week period. While workers may still realize a net gain in time off under the new contract, they could lose the special four-day weekend the U.A.W. intended to create if it falls during the production shutdown.
"We're having a discussion about the holiday provision," said David Caplan, a Ford spokesman. "What the union has asked us to consider is moving that vacation shutdown out of that Fourth of July week so that the holiday and the shutdown do not overlap." Mr. Caplan said, however, that moving that shutdown period could prove difficult because it would upset company production schedules.
 
Wider Problems With Pattern?
 Since negotiating with Ford, the U.A.W. has used the agreement as a pattern in establishing a tentative contract with the Chrysler Corporation. The Chrysler contract incorporates the July 4 holiday provision, but it was unclear today whether union officials were also concerned about an overlap with production shutdowns there.
The U.A.W. has not set a strike deadline in negotiations with G.M., a sign that it believes the talks are making progress. Although G.M. has repeatedly raised concerns that the pattern agreement will raise its labor costs and slow its efforts to reduce plant capacity and payrolls, the company appears likely to accept the basic package of wages and benefits, perhaps before the weekend.
Among other things, the contract provides for increases in pension benefits for retirees that could raise G.M.'s unfunded pension liability to $25 billion by the end of the year, from a previously expected $19 billion. Besides that, the new contract builds up job-security funds for laid-off workers, funds that cost G.M. more than $3 billion under the current contract negotiated in 1990.
Company officials have pushed for greater freedom to move laid-off workers to other plants. Now, G.M. cannot require workers to relocate to another plant more than 50 miles from their old one. If the new plant is within 50 miles, it can reduce workers' layoff benefits if they refuse to move.
General Motors is also trying to change its hourly workers' vacation benefits. Like Ford, it shuts down for two weeks during the summer. But unlike at Ford, hourly workers at G.M. are considered temporarily laid off during that two-week period, meaning that they can collect unemployment benefits paid by the company.
G.M. would like its hourly workers to use some of their vacation time during the two-week shutdown.
Such a change -- which many G.M. workers vehemently oppose -- would save the company millions of dollars in unemployment costs.

Accord Set in Canada
 TORONTO, Oct. 13 (Reuters) -- The president of the automobile workers union in Canada said the union and the Ford Motor Company of Canada had reached a tentative three-year labor deal ahead of a midnight strike deadline. The union has now reached accord with all of the Big Three American auto makers.
The union's president, Buzz Hargrove, said Ford Canada accepted all components of the pattern agreement the union reached with the Chrysler Corporation's Canadian unit.
The union also won a demand not in the pattern agreement: mandatory vacation time. Workers could previously accept money in lieu of time off. "The major issue of mandatory vacation was the key issue here," Mr. Hargrove said.
The accord marked the first time in more than three decades that the Canadian union had reached settlement with the three companies without resorting to a strike, he said.

HEADLINE: Lehman Bros. to Move 900 Back-Office Jobs to Jersey City

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
After months of speculation, Lehman Brothers Inc. has decided to move more than 900 back-office employees to Jersey City, to the same 42-floor tower to which Merrill Lynch moved 2,500 back-office jobs a year ago.
Richard S. Fuld Jr., Lehman Brothers' president, said the decision to move was the result of a six-month study of future space needs, and reaffirmed plans to keep 5,000 employees in New York, the bulk at company headquarters at 3 World Financial Center. 
 "We believe our decision to relocate certain employees to our headquarters building in New York City and to a new space in Jersey City best serves the interests of the firm," he said in a formal statement issued yesterday evening.
Word of Lehman's decision played differently on the two sides of the Hudson River.
The company's impending arrival at 101 Hudson Street, where it will occupy 340,000 square feet on 11 floors, is a cause for joy in Jersey City, which has an unemployment rate of almost 12 percent, compared with less than 8 percent for the rest of the state.
"Anytime a new employer comes to the city it means more people who will spend money and enrich the economy, and that is what we have been trying so hard to promote," said Thomas M. Gallagher, press secretary to Jersey City's Mayor, Bret Schundler.
 
In an Urban Enterprise Zone
 Moreover, 101 Hudson Street is in a state-designated Urban Enterprise Zone. Office supplies and equipment sold by vendors in such zones are exempt from sales tax. That might encourage Lehman Brothers to make many such purchases from nearby vendors, further helping the local economy.
Lehman's move is a blow to New York, which will lose more than 900 jobs and the taxes associated with them. It is also a blow to the downtown Manhattan real-estate market, which is plagued with a persistent 22 percent vacancy rate. Many industry professionals had expected Lehman Brothers to move into 344,000 square feet at One Financial Square, a 36-story, million-square-foot building on the block bounded by Old Slip, Gouverneur Lane, Front Street and South Street. One Financial Square is half empty.
"We had an agreement in principle and a 100-page document ready to be signed," said a disappointed Arthur J. Mirante, chief executive officer of Cushman & Wakefield, leasing and managing agents for One Financial Square. "Then they decide to go to New Jersey."
New York City officials refused to discuss the incentives they had offered, although real-estate brokers say that New York was sweetening its offer as recently as late last week. However, few say the offer was particularly lucrative. In a statement issued after Lehman's announcement, Mayor David N. Dinkins expressed his disappointment that 900 jobs were moving to New Jersey, but added that "the city cannot justify the high cost per job it would have taken to match Lehman's projected savings."
"I am pleased to learn that more than 5,000 jobs will stay headquartered in New York," Mr. Dinkins said.
Mr. Gallagher said that Jersey City did not offer financial incentives, that its tax structure was enough incentive.
"We have no city payroll tax, no city income tax, no corporate tax, we don't even have an unincorporated business tax or a tax on commercial leases," he said.
 
Cheaper Power, Lower Rent
 Real-estate brokers watching the deal said that Lehman also was lured by the extensive emergency backup systems offered at 101 Hudson Street, and that power costs 15 percent less in New Jersey than in New York. They said that Lehman struck a deal in the vicinity of $15 a square foot a year, and that One Financial Square was insisting on more than $20.
One source said that Lehman concluded that it would be just as easy for many of its employees to commute to Jersey City by PATH trains as to get to One Financial Square, which is much farther east than the company's current offices.
"This simply did not boil down to a battle over incentives," said one real-estate broker who insisted on anonymity.
There was never a question that Lehman Brothers would have to move its back offices. It used to be part of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., a subsidiary of American Express. Its back office and trading operations were at 388 and 390 Greenwich Street, which American Express owned.
But in March the Primerica Corporation bought the Shearson part of the subsidiary, including those two buildings. Lehman Brothers, which remains part of American Express, must vacate the premises by July. Most of Lehman's operations are situated elsewhere in lower Manhattan.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Mixed in Quiet Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Treasury market ended narrowly mixed yesterday as most investors refrained from major transactions ahead of wholesale inflation figures to be released today.
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond rose 3/32 point, or 94 cents for every $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.91 percent, from 5.92 percent late Tuesday. 
 Prices of short-term Treasury securities fell 1/32 point, and intermediate maturities dropped by as much as 3/32 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
Bond prices fluctuated in a narrow range of buying and selling as traders shrugged off several developments, including Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve.
 
No Sign From Greenspan
 Mr. Greenspan strongly rejected a move in the House to make the nation's central bank more politically accountable, but he made no comments to suggest any change in monetary policy direction.
The bond market also largely ignored an auto industry report that cars sold at a higher-than-expected annual rate of 6.8 million units over the last 30 days. Economists generally expected a rate of 6.5 million.
But the report did add to speculation that the Government report on September retail sales, also due today, would exceed growth expectations. Forecasts call for an increase of three-tenths of a percent.
Investors in fixed-income securities typically sell bonds in reaction to news of economic growth, which can aggravate inflation. Higher inflation tends to hurt the value of investments that pay a fixed rate of return.
But investors saved most of their attention for today's release of the Producer Price Index for September, which will be followed by the Consumer Price Index tomorrow.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Corporate Issues
 By Bloomberg Business News
 The most notable corporate issue yesterday was $150 million of bonds maturing in 100 years sold by the New York branch of Amsterdam's ABN Amro Bank.
The bank was the third company to sell 100-year bonds in recent months. In July, the Walt Disney Company and the Coca-Cola Company surprised investors by offering 100-year issues, the first debt with such a long maturity since the late 1800's, when railroads sold bonds due in as much as 1,000 years to finance leases on land.
On Tuesday, the Boeing Company offered $125 million of 50-year bonds. The 6.875 percent debentures due in 2043 were priced at 99.788 to yield 6.89 percent. The noncallable debentures were rated A1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by Standard & Poor's.
Investors snapped up the ABN Ambro bonds because interest rates are at historic lows.
The 7.125 percent percent subordinated deposit notes due in 2093 were priced at $991.78 for a $1,000 bond to yield 7.184 percent percent, or 110 basis points more than the 7.125 percent Treasury maturing on Feb. 15, 2023. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent. The notes, which are not redeemable, are rated Aa2 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P.
Bonds of cable operators increased in price amid expectations that more companies would form combinations and joint ventures similar to the one announced yesterday by the Bell Atlantic Corporation and Tele-Communications Inc. The Comcast Corporation's 10.625 percent bonds due in 2012 gained $20 a bond to $1,130. Cablevision Systems Inc. 9.875 percent bonds due in 2013 gained $20, to $1,035, and Continental Cable's 9 percent bonds due in 2008 were quoted at $1,050, up $30.
Tele-Communications 9.25 percent bonds due 2023 soared to $1,291.97 per $1,000 face amount, up from $1,150, with its yield declining to 6.91 percent, or 100 basis points more than comparable Treasury bonds.
Bonds of subsidiaries of Bell Atlantic were little changed. Moody's said it might lower the ratings on Bell Atlantic and its operating subsidiaries, which have a total $9.8 billion of debt outstanding.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Drugstores to Sue Pharmaceutical Makers

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The nation's largest retail drugstore chains are preparing a broad antitrust lawsuit that accuses leading pharmaceutical companies of price fixing.
Executives from the Rite-Aid Corporation and Revco D.S. Inc., two of the largest drugstore chains, are scheduled to appear today at a news conference in New York to announce the Federal price-discrimination complaint. The plaintiffs operate more than 5,000 pharmacies across the country. 
 Drugstore chains and independent pharmacies have become increasingly incensed over pharmaceutical makers' common practice of discounting bundles of their products to huge purchasers like hospitals, health maintenance organizations and mail-order drug companies.
"The issue is regarding giving discounts simply because of the class of trade," said D. Dwayne Hoven, president and chief executive of Revco, which is based in Twinsburg, Ohio.
 
 
Discounts for Some
 Though he declined to comment on the lawsuit, Mr. Hoven said that certain high-volume purchasers "do get discounts that are not available to community pharmacies" or even big chains like his. Revco employs 3,000 pharmacists in nine states.
Drug companies contend that big purchasers should be rewarded with lower prices. A single health maintenance organization like Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest, can purchase billions of dollars worth of prescription drugs in a year.
The $52 billion chain drugstore industry is struggling to maintain the core prescription department. In the shift toward managed care, more companies are contracting with mail-order pharmacies, which dispense medications across the country from a few central locations. More employees are being told they cannot go to their corner drugstore if they want to be reimbursed for their prescription drugs.
Meanwhile, the nation's drug makers have come under fire from the Clinton Administration for the high price increases they levy on prescription drugs. To stave off possible price controls, the leading pharmaceutical companies have pledged to hold price increases to the inflation rate.

HEADLINE: Japan Is Urged to Insure Foreigners' Trade Share

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 13

 BODY:
As a keystone of its new approach to trade with Japan, the United States will demand that foreign companies gain the same share of the market for various goods and services in Japan as in other industrial nations, an American trade official said today.
The official, who is here for talks aimed at reaching detailed agreements under a broad trade framework signed by the United States and Japan in July, spoke at a news briefing as the talks began in earnest today. The negotiator said that if the United States and Japan could not agree on "objective criteria" to measure the opening of Japanese markets, as was called for in July, Washington would establish such indexes itself. 
 "If we can't do it together then we will do it," said the official, who spoke on condition that he not be identified by name because only the highest-ranking people in his agency are allowed to speak for attribution. "We have to measure results. We have to be able to assess the results at the end of the day."
Today, American representatives presented a proposal for opening Japan's insurance market, pointing out that foreign companies had only 2 percent of that market. For the Group of Seven industrial nations, the market share held by foreign insurers ranges from 7 to 10 percent in the United States to 33 percent in Italy.
 
More if This Succeeds
 "The gap between Japan and the rest of the G-7 is enormous," the official said, adding that one way the Clinton Administration wants to judge the success of the trade agreement is that in three to four years, "the Japanese market would become more in line with the industrialized world." Washington wants to apply the same approach to other businesses and services, he said.
In keeping with July's accord, the two nations are to negotiate detailed agreements aimed at increasing Japan's imports in various business, industries and service areas, and to determine quantitative and qualitative indicators to measure progress.
Japan has said that it will not agree to setting targets.
The two nations had preliminary talks under this arrangement in September. This week and next, the Americans are presenting concrete proposals in three high-priority areas -- insurance, autos and auto parts, and official procurement of telecommunications and medical equipment. The aim is to reach agreements in these areas by January or February, when President Clinton and Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa are expected to meet.
The United States argues that Japan's insurance market is effectively closed because strict or unclear regulations prevent the entry of new companies or the introduction of innovative products. It also says that Japanese corporations tend to buy insurance from insurers in their own keiretsu, or industrial groupings.
 
50 States Puzzle Outsiders
 Japan denies that its market is closed. It argues that the American market is hard for foreigners to penetrate because separate licenses must be procured from each state, and in some states, all insurance company directors must submit fingerprints.
The American negotiator said that Washington would step up efforts to enforce the July framework. It has been somewhat lax in this, he said, contending that as a result, world opinion, rallied by Japan, had built up against the framework.
Some American economists have said that the agreement is contrary to free trade and will lead to government-managed trade. Some Asian and European countries have expressed fear that the agreement will give American companies an unfair advantage in selling to Japan.
But the United States trade official said "it's totally bizarre" that the Japanese "can go around the world claiming that they are the protectors of free trade." He asserted that the July framework would help all nations sell more to Japan and that the American demands were in line with calls from Japanese for deregulation.
Regarding the matter of foreign access to the Japanese construction industry, which is not part of these talks, the official said the Japanese had not been negotiating seriously. The United States has threatened to impose sanctions against Tokyo if progress was not made by Nov. 1.
"The sanctions will be in place if something doesn't happen," the official said. "The initiative will have to come from the Japanese. We haven't heard 'boo.' "

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Against Mark While Gold Prices Retreat

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar firmed against most European currencies yesterday in thin trading, but eased slightly against the Japanese yen.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6020 marks, up from 1.5940 marks on Tuesday. But it slipped to 105.92 yen from 106.02 yen.
Meanwhile, gold prices retreated after Tuesday's run-up of $7.50 an ounce. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery, the most actively traded futures contract, fell $1.60 an ounce, to $367.10.
 
 
Technical Support
 Dealers said the dollar firmed against the mark after defending key technical support levels Tuesday. The dollar drifted from its highs, however, after the Bundesbank allowed German money market rates to hold steady during its weekly tender, rather than allow rates to ease as many had expected. 
 Many dealers bought dollars earlier this year on the expectation that Germany would cut interest rates to spur growth while United States rates would rise as its economy recovered. As long as nothing happened to disturb Germany's slow easing pace or to jolt the American economy, analysts said, there was little reason to alter long-term dollar positions.
"If one is to look just at interest rate differentials, that scenario hasn't changed and there is little reason to buy dollars," Alison Gibbs, a currency analyst for MMS International, said. A narrowing of the spread between German and United States interest rates makes dollars less expensive to own.
 
 
Belgian Franc Falls
 There was more activity in the European market, where the Belgian franc fell to three-year lows against the German mark. The franc has suffered as the Belgian Government tries to deal with its huge budget deficit.
The Bank of Belgium bought Belgian francs for German marks several times to support its currency. The New York Federal Reserve sold marks for Belgian francs, in one of its rare operations that did not involve dollars.
The French franc also fell to its lowest level against the mark in two months, as well as losing ground against the dollar. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 5.6560 francs, up from 5.6015 francs on Tuesday.
Meanwhile, the British pound fell in New York to $1.5209 from $1.5325.

HEADLINE: Greenspan and Panel Clash Over Fed's Status

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve came under fierce attack at a Congressional hearing today, as House members called it undemocratic, unaccountable and an exclusive club made up mostly of white males.
But Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman, stoutly rejected numerous proposals that would give elected officials more power in choosing Federal Reserve policy makers, saying such steps would be a "major mistake" that could fuel inflation and hurt the economy. 
 At a hearing of the House Banking Committee, the crux of Mr. Greenspan's argument was that the Federal Reserve was operating well, so there was no need for Congress to tinker with it and perhaps create a flood of undesired consequences.
 
Political Factor Is Cited

 
 "If accountability is achieved by putting the conduct of monetary policy under the close influence of politicians subject to short-term election cycle pressures, the resulting policy would likely prove disappointing," Mr. Greenspan said.
The hearing was called by Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the banking committee, who is mounting Congress's biggest effort in three decades to revamp the laws governing the Federal Reserve. He is sponsoring a bill that would have the President appoint the presidents of the Federal Reserve's 12 regional banks, 5 of whom sit on the Fed's main policy-making committee.
In Mr. Gonzalez's view, the current system is undemocratic because the regional presidents are chosen by local boards dominated by commercial bankers.
Several lawmakers said the proposals to change the Fed had a modest chance of passing. The biggest obstacle is a letter that President Clinton sent Mr. Gonzalez, saying he was disinclined to support the Gonzalez bill because he saw no need to overhaul the Fed.
 
Audits and Taping Proposed
 To increase the Fed's accountability, Mr. Gonzalez's bill calls for conducting full audits of the Fed's operations and videotaping the meetings of its main policy-making committee. Mr. Greenspan said such steps would interfere with the central bank's independence.
In three hours of sparring, Mr. Gonzalez and Mr. Greenspan often used pointed language, but their tone was unfailingly polite. Nonetheless, Mr. Gonzalez made clear that he resented the way Fed officials have suggested that his proposal is a mortal danger for the economy.
"This is not radical reform, and there is no cause for the Federal Reserve to proceed as if barbarians are at the gate and it is the end of Western civilization," Mr. Gonzalez said. "We should not pretend the Federal Reserve, of all institutions in Government, is infallible."
Mr. Gonzalez lambasted the Federal Reserve for not hiring more women or members of minorities, noting that only one of the 12 regional bank presidents is a woman and not one is a member of a minority. "I want to take the 'bankers and their friends' sign off the door to this exclusive club and open it up to all competent Americans," he said.
While rejecting virtually all the criticisms leveled at the Fed, Mr. Greenspan granted that the central bank could do more to increase diversity. He said the Fed had made progress, noting that 22 percent of top-echelon Fed officials are women, up from 5 percent in 1977, while 9 percent of the bank's officials belong to minorities, up from 2 percent in 1977.
 
A Republican View
 Mr. Gonzalez's campaign won some support from James A. Leach of Iowa, the committee's ranking Republican, who said it was unseemly for private bankers to choose Fed officials who not only make important policy decisions but also regulate private banks. While opposed to the idea of having the President appoint the regional bank heads, Mr. Leach did propose that the 12 regional presidents be named by the Federal Reserve Board, whose seven members are appointed by the President.
Throughout his testimony, Mr. Greenspan kept returning to his central point, that tinkering with the Fed's independence would upset a finely tuned system that he said had worked well for decades.
"The temptation is to step on the monetary accelerator or at least avoid the monetary brake until after the next election," Mr. Greenspan said, noting that in such cases the Fed would ultimately have to slam on the brakes. "Giving in to such temptations is likely to impart an inflationary bias to the economy and could lead to instability, recession and economic stagnation."
Mr. Gonzalez sought to reassure Mr. Greenspan that he was not trying to influence monetary policy, saying: "I am not seeking to politicize the central bank nor take away its independence. I am not calling for policies that would cause inflation or deflation."

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Orange Juice Prices Tumble After Florida Crop Forecast

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Orange juice prices plunged 10 percent yesterday, the largest single drop in three years, after the Agriculture Department's 1993-94 Florida crop report projected larger-than-expected supplies.
On the New York Cotton Exchange, orange juice for November delivery fell 13.20 cents, to $1.1605 a pound. 
 The department said late on Tuesday that it expected the crop to total 172 million 90-pound boxes, 12 million boxes more than some analysts had expected.
"There had been speculation of a bullish report," said Judy Ganes, a commodity analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company. "When that didn't happen, there was no reason left to be in the market."
Still, traders said there were some concerns that storms in March might have reduced this year's crop.
Indeed, some traders were betting on a repeat of the 1991-92 growing season, when the crop was initially estimated at about 170 million boxes but totaled only 140 million boxes, said Steve Platt, commodity analyst with Dean Witter in Chicago.
"The storms in March seemed to have affected the bloom," said Robert Barber, an economist with Florida Citrus Mutual, an association of Florida's orange growers. "When the groves were examined, they were getting a low fruit count. I had seen estimates on the Florida crop as low as 158 million boxes."
 
Hogs Are Lower
 On other commodities markets, hog futures fell sharply amid expectations that farmers would begin to unload more hogs onto the market, traders and analysts said.
Live hogs for December delivery dropped 1.1 cents, to 50.37 cents a pound, on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork bellies for February delivery lost 1.27 cents, to 57.87 cents a pound.
The pace of hog slaughter has increased and is expected to rise through the week, analysts said. So far this week, 1.037 million hogs were slaughtered, down only about five-tenths of a percent from a year ago. According the Government's latest inventory estimates on hog herds, slaughter should be falling.
Crude oil prices finished lower after an industry report showed an increase in American crude oil and petroleum product supplies. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for November delivery fell 7 cents, to $18.64 a barrel.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The health care plan could worsen injury-claim abuses.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
BILL CLINTON'S health care plan makes a cautious stab at curbing malpractice suits, reducing the incentives to go to court and forcing those injured to try mediation first. So there is at least a hope that the total cost of the accident liability system, which runs $130 billion a year in insurance premiums, will fall. Right?
Don't spend the savings just yet. Peter Huber, a legal scholar, points out that the medical malpractice slice represents no more than one-eighth of the total tort liability pie. And there are good reasons to believe that the President's plan would inadvertently fatten the other seven-eighths. 
 In fact, suggests Michael Horowitz of the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research, passage of a health care package guaranteeing access to treatment -- especially psychiatric treatment -- could force the White House to come to terms with an injury liability system that serves trial lawyers better than it serves the public. "The Administration's bill will, as a certainty, accelerate fraud and abuse in both the liability and health care systems," Mr. Horowitz contends.
If you are injured in an accident it obviously pays to go to a doctor. Even if you are not injured, though, it often pays to go (and go and go).
For starters, many liability claims are covered by the "collateral source rule," which permits aggrieved parties to collect twice for medical bills -- once from their own health insurers and again from those at fault.
More important, notes Jeffrey O'Connell, a professor of law at the University of Virginia, the cost of medical treatment is generally used as a benchmark of injury severity in calculating out-of-court settlements for "pain and suffering." Hence a $4,000 medical bill can be used to leverage a $4,000 profit under the collateral source rule -- and then another two or three times the $4,000 payment for pain and suffering.
Not surprisingly, say those with a jaundiced view of human nature, the system is often abused for all it's worth. Oakley Van Slyke, a consultant in Mission Viejo, Calif., points out that in parts of the country where pain and suffering awards are uncommon, just one auto accident in six generates a claim of bodily injury. In California, by contrast, there are four bodily injury claims for every six accidents.
While it is widely acknowledged that accidents in rural areas generally cause more damage because collision speeds are higher, the reported frequency of whiplash injuries is several times greater in cities, where the probability of claimants being represented by lawyers is much higher. Dan Seagraves, the executive director of the industry-financed Insurance Research Council, estimates that in Philadelphia the "whiplash-to-fender bender" ratio has reached 75 percent.
What does this have to do with the President's health care plan? Little, directly. Indeed, the plan might actually help to contain tort settlements by eliminating the collateral source rule for medical malpractice claims. But it would greatly add to the risk of fraud by underwriting the cost of medical treatment for those who must now finance the enterprise from their own pockets.
This is potentially a bigger-ticket item than one might imagine. In Hawaii, a state with generous universal health coverage, the median number of visits to chiropractors by tort claimants was an astonishing 53 in 1990. And Mr. Horowitz points to an as-yet-unexploited form of coverage that he thinks is ripe for abuse: outpatient psychiatric care.
Today, only a tiny fraction of tort claims are buttressed by expert evidence of emotional trauma. Can you imagine what will happen, Mr. Horowitz asks, if up to 30 visits a year to a psychiatrist or psychologist were automatically covered by insurance?
It is unclear whether this potential impact on tort liability carries much weight with Congress or the White House. After all, suing is the American Way -- and at least thus far, trial lawyers have proved to be a far more effective lobby than businesses or insurance companies worried about rising liability premiums.
But Washington is sensitive to the cost of health insurance. Indeed, health care reform is being sold as both a means of containing health care costs and a way of extending coverage. And it is precisely the people who are now underinsured who would be given the added incentive to build accident liability claims by running up medical bills.
One counterargument is that health care reform will sensitize medical payers to potential abuses. For example, it is at least possible that the "gate-keepers" in the proposed system, regional health alliances that must live under Federal expenditure caps, would not allow all those whiplashed Hawaiians to make second homes of their chiropractors' offices. Possible, but hardly inevitable.
The surer route to cost control, Mr. O'Connell suggests, would be a serious effort to reform the tort liability system as well. "With luck," he said, "Congress won't allow one interest group -- the plaintiffs' bar -- to sabotage the health care reform."

HEADLINE: THE PLAYOFFS;
But the Blue Jays Have Some Storybook Characters, Too

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Now that the Toronto Blue Jays have proved they can repeat as American League pennant winners despite a wholesale change in their appearance, they go to the World Series to see if they can repeat there, too, with their adaptable dozen.
The Blue Jays, who wrapped up the pennant Tuesday night in Chicago, have 12 players among the 25 who were not on their World Series roster a year ago; the most important cast changes were Paul Molitor playing the role of Dave Winfield and Dave Stewart as Jack Morris. 
 In becoming only the second team in the last 15 years to have a chance to win two successive World Series, the Blue Jays have answered the widespread questions raised by their decision to make those changes last winter. They lost most of their departed players as free agents, some of whom they tried to re-sign, some of whom they let go by economic design.
Molitor, who played his first 15 major league seasons in Milwaukee, was one of those signed as free agents to balance the large losses. About two weeks before the start of the season, he discussed the effect the changes could have on the team.
 
Difficult to Measure
 "It's a difficult thing to measure," he said then. "The irony is this is a championship ball club, and it has such a different look from last year. There have been dramatic changes. There will be inevitable comparisons. When you're successful and you make changes and then if you don't do well, people will say if it ain't broke, why fix it."
It wasn't broke, and General Manager Pat Gillick was only trying to fix the payroll, a major league high $49.5 million. But by the time he was finished maneuvering, particularly with the late-season addition of Rickey Henderson, the Blue Jays wound up with a payroll only slightly lower than last year, just shy of $48 million, with some post-season bonuses to be added.
"It feels good," Gillick said yesterday by telephone from Toronto, discussing the team's success. "We moved a lot of people around out of necessity, more financial necessity than anything else. It wasn't that we wanted to get rid of the players. They certainly would've been welcomed back. But we couldn't handle it financially."
Gillick, however, was delighted to pay out the latest $50,000. That sum goes to Stewart as a bonus for being named the most valuable player of the league championship series.
"That's good," Gillick acknowledged. "I'm happy about that."
Stewart wasn't spreading the bonus among his teammates, but he was passing out accolades.
"To me, this is the best ball club I've played with, offensively," Stewart said. "We've got a lineup with so much talent. We've got guys who care about what they're doing. They take their jobs seriously. They know what they have to do to win. Starting with Paul Molitor. He's my favorite player. He has an idea of what he has to do. If there's a play he can make a bigger play, he goes for it."
When the Blue Jays let Winfield go as a free agent and decided to sign Molitor, five years younger, the popular view was that Molitor couldn't possibly contribute more offensively than Winfield did. But Molitor topped Winfield in batting average, .332 to .290; runs batted in, 111 to 108; slugging percentage, .509 to .491, and on-base percentage, .402 to .377. He fell only four home runs short of matching Winfield's total of 26.
 
Stewart Comes Through
 The Stewart move was questioned, too. The Blue Jays signed him for significantly less money than Jimmy Key and David Cone would have cost them, and the skeptics were correct. A combination of injuries and ineffectiveness limited him to a 12-8 record during the season. But with two victories against Chicago, he responded to the high standards he had established in four previous pennant playoffs.
"When the season started with injuries, Paul Beeston and Pat Gillick said what's important is that I be able to pitch at this point of the year," Stewart related. "Regardless of what happened during the year, they expected me to come through at this time of year."
And Stewart did, raising his playoff record to eight victories (no other pitcher has more than four playoff victories) and no losses in 10 starts, a 2.03 earned run average and a ratio of nine baserunners per nine innings. With his victories against the White Sox, Stewart outdid the 1992 peformance of Morris, who won 21 times during the season but lost three post-season games while winning none.
Morris was back this season but suffered a season-ending elbow injury last month.
As they head into the World Series, the Blue Jays have to watch for a change in Stewart's effectiveness. In six previous Series starts, he has a creditable 2.49 e.r.a. but a 2-3 record.
Manager Cito Gaston indicated in the flush of playoff success that he would use his pitchers in the same order as he did against the White Sox, meaning that Juan Guzman and Stewart would start the first two games Saturday and Sunday.
Gaston wasn't prepared to say, but Molitor most likely will start at third base instead of Ed Sprague in the three games in the National League city, when the designated hitter will not be used.
Sprague was a member of the World Series roster last year, but he batted only three times, all as a pinch-hitter. Gaston doesn't use pinch-hitters much any more. The Blue Jays were the last major league team to use a pinch-hitter during the season -- Darnell Coles on May 13, in the team's 34th game -- and Gaston didn't call for one in six games against the White Sox. In fact, the same nine players played every inning of every game against the White Sox.
 
All Sorts of Changes
 Sprague has become the everyday third baseman, replacing Kelly Gruber. Tony Fernandez has returned to play shortstop, a job vacated by Manuel Lee. Duane Ward, who had been the setup reliever for the closer, has replaced the departed Tom Henke as the closer. Pat Hentgen has moved into the starting rotation.
Danny Cox, Al Leiter and Tony Castillo are new to the World Series bullpen, and veterans Coles and Dick Schofield and rookies Willie Canate and Rob Butler are new to the reserve unit, the guys who don't play. Gone are pitcher David Wells, reserves Pat Tabler, Rance Mulliniks and Derek Bell and left fielder Candy Maldonado.
In Maldonado's place, of course, is the enigmatic Henderson. When the Blue Jays acquired him from Oakland July 31, they expected him to lead the charge to the post-season. But Henderson has hit a stunningly low .202 for the Blue Jays, including .120 (3 for 25) in the playoff.
That kind of performance won't help the Blue Jays become the first team since the 1977-78 Yankees to win two successive World Series championships. Since then, only the Athletics, with Henderson on hand, have had a chance to repeat. They won the Earthquake Series in 1989 and returned the next season but lost to Cincinnati in four games.

HEADLINE: Conners to Return to Yanks

 BODY:
The looting of the Yankee coaching staff is expected to begin today or tomorrow when the club announces that Billy Conners, the Chicago Cubs' pitching coach who held the same job with the Yankees, has been hired to replace Tony Cloninger, who was the pitching coach last season.
While General Manager Gene Michael refused to confirm what has been speculation for weeks, a Yankee official said the announcement could occur within 48 hours. Another American League general manager said the Yankees had dismissed four coaches, likely meaning that first-base coach Frank Howard, bullpen coach Mark Connor and bench coach Ed Napoleon will join Cloninger in the unemployment line. Since Manager Buck Showalter had already conceded that the Yankees would trim their staff from seven coaches to six, Jake Gibbs was already believed to be relieved of his coaching duties. 
 The 51-year-old Connors has coached for the Cubs since June 29, 1991, in his second stint with the team. He would assume his second stint with the Yankees, where he was the pitching coach in 1989 and 1990. A close friend of Showalter and an ally of owner George Steinbrenner, he has been rumored as a Yankee coaching candidate for two years.

HEADLINE: Clinton Offers Job Training For Trade Pact Casualties

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration proposed a $100 million program today to help retrain Americans who lose their jobs because of the North American Free Trade Agreement. But critics of the pact were unimpressed by the proposal.
The Administration, which has long insisted that few Americans would be put out of work by the trade agreement, put the plan forward as a way of blunting opposition by unions and some Congressional Democrats. 
 The chief deputy United States trade representative, Rufus Yerxa, told the House Ways and Means Committee this morning that the Administration was drafting the retraining plan as a temporary measure that would last no more than 18 months. After that, Mr. Yerxa said, workers put out of work by the trade pact would be helped by a comprehensive job training program that is being prepared by Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich.
Mr. Reich said at a Senate Labor Committee hearing this morning that the cost of the program "would probably be in the neighborhood of $100 million a year."
 
Fears of Added Costs
 For months the Clinton Administration has resisted promising any such temporary job retraining program, fearing that it would increase the total cost of the free-trade agreement.
Moreover, some Administration officials were concerned that what would begin as a temporary measure might become a permanent exception to President Clinton's goal of a single Federal program to help all Americans who lose their jobs to foreign competition, technological advances or other changes in the economy.
But in recent weeks Democratic supporters of the agreement have pressed the Administration to include a jobs program. The program may offer political cover against assertions by labor unions and Ross Perot that the pact would encourage American companies to relocate in Mexico, taking advantage of that country's low wages.
Mary Meagher, the press secretary for Mr. Reich, said that establishing an interim jobs program was necessary because of the busy Congressional calendar, which has forced the Administration to postpone until January its plan to seek legislation revamping current Federal jobs programs.
In last year's campaign President George Bush proposed spending up to $670 million a year to help workers who lost jobs because of the agreement but never said how he would pay for it. Ms. Meagher acknowledged that the Clinton Administration figure for the first year was smaller but pointed out that Mr. Bush did not call for a comprehensive job retraining program in the following years.
Nonetheless, labor unions were not impressed by today's $100 million proposal. "It strikes me as a Nafta Band-Aid," said Mark A. Anderson, the director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Task Force on Trade.
Representative Sander M. Levin, a Michigan Democrat who opposes the agreement, said the program was too small to affect the agreement's fate in Congress but acknowledged that the Administration faced a difficult choice. "If they come in with a large figure, they'll be acknowledging a lot of dislocation," he said. "If they come in with a low figure, then they're not doing much."
 
Plans to Raise Fees
 If approved by simple majorities of the House and Senate, the free-trade pact would gradually eliminate tariffs and other trade barriers between Canada, Mexico and the United States.
The free-trade pact's elimination of tariffs would cost the Federal Government $2.36 billion in lost revenues over the next five years, Mr. Yerxa said today. He said the Administration wanted to raise Federal fees on travelers entering the United States by plane and ship but had not yet decided by how much.
 
Anger in Travel Industry
 Mr. Yerxa said "a very slight increase" in the fees would be needed. But he also said the free-trade agreement would cost $210 million in lost tariff revenues in 1994 rising to $612 million in 1998. By contrast, customs fees on arriving international passengers raised $180 million last year, he said.
The nation's travel industry has begun lobbying vigorously against the scheme in the last several days. "It's an outrage," said James E. Landry, the president of the Air Transport Association, an industry trade group here. "It would be a severe distortion of the user-fee concept."
Mr. Landry said dozens of bilateral air agreements with other countries barred the use of customs fees for any noncustoms purposes, but White House officials denied this, citing legal opinions by the State and Transportation Departments.
Today's hearings on Capitol Hill were the first of a complex series of actions by more than a dozen Congressional committees. The goal of the sessions is to produce a draft law by Oct. 31 to amend American law in hundreds of ways to make it consistent with the trade agreement.
Committee chairmen are scheduled to meet near the end of the month to settle differences between House and Senate drafts and then send a single document to the President, said Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the Ways and Means Committee. The full House and Senate would not, however, vote on the draft bill.
The President would then resubmit it along with any changes as a so-called President's bill.

HEADLINE: 'Art' Is No Luxury

 BODY:
New York City is a difficult place to find an apartment, a cheap hotel room, a seat on the subway or, all too often, a moment's peace. But finding a theater, a museum, an art gallery, a dance group or a concert is a cinch. The city is up to its ears in the arts.
Last week the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey released a report that tells just what that extraordinary cultural concentration means to the metropolitan economy. It means jobs, lots of them, for New Yorkers -- and tax revenues for the city and state. 
 In 1992 the arts and other cultural activities in the metropolitan region generated almost $3.5 billion in wages, salaries and royalties, a 10 percent increase over the last decade. They were responsible for 107,000 jobs, ranging from starring on stage to making ballet slippers to catering for movie crews. And their total economic impact, counting expenditures by arts institutions, their suppliers, wage earners and visitors, generated 9.8 billion sorely needed bucks in the metropolitan area. Nearly 25 percent of that money came from tourists who said they had come to New York, or lengthened their stays there, to go to museums, galleries, theaters and concerts.
Some of what the arts bring to New York is impossible to quantify. The film makers who shot, in whole or part, more than 100 features there last year spent $168 million. But the public relations value of, say, the opening of Woody Allen's "Manhattan Murder Mystery" -- a magical nighttime city seen from above while Bobby Short sings "I Happen to Like New York" on the soundtrack -- are incalculable.
The Port Authority report makes no recommendations for subsidizing the arts at any particular level. But it contains more than enough hard figures to convince readers that the arts in New York feed a whole lot more than the soul. The arts are clearly a major economic sector, more so in New York than anywhere else in the country; their health should be treated with care.
But while Mayor David Dinkins has seen the wisdom of keeping the city's Cultural Affairs budget, which mostly supports nonprofit organizations, close to its 1990 high, Gov. Mario Cuomo has seen only the short-term gain of Draconian cuts. Three years ago, the New York State Arts Council's budget -- much of which comes to the metropolitan area -- was $54 million. Today it's $25 million -- and would be even less had the Legislature not restored $3 million that the Governor wanted out.
The state needs to take a second look at the adequacy of its arts funding. Would that the baseball fan who governs and who suggested spending $500 million on a new stadium in Manhattan were half as interested in keeping the arts in town.

HEADLINE: Stocks End Day Higher; Dow Up 10.06

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Cable and entertainment issues led the stock market higher yesterday in reaction to the proposed acquisition of Tele-Communications Inc. by Bell Atlantic, which would be the nation's largest corporate merger ever.
Tele-Communications rose 3, to 31 3/8, while Liberty Media, which it hopes to reacquire, was up 2 5/8, to 29 1/4. Disney advanced 4 3/4, to 44 1/2, and Time Warner increased 1 7/8, to 41 7/8. Bell Atlantic itself rose 5 7/8, to 65 7/8. 
 Propelled by the big gain for Disney and a jump of 2 3/4 by Philip Morris, to 51 1/2, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 3,603.19, up 10.06 points. Both the Nasdaq composite index, which was up 6.51 points, to 778.97, and the American Stock Exchange market value index, which was up 5.35 points, to 475.85, set new highs.
"By closing above 3,600, the Dow may be ready to test the next resistance level between 3,610 and 3,620," said Harry W. Laubscher, senior vice president of the Tucker Anthony brokerage firm. "It may even test the record closing high of 3,652.09."
Mr. Laubscher noted, however, that "the Nasdaq volume was more than 60 million shares higher than the Big Board volume." He added, "This is significant historically because it means that speculation is starting to run rampant and the market may be topping out."
 
Volume Climbs Sharply
 On the New York exchange, 291 million shares changed hands, substantially more than Tuesday's volume of 264 million shares. Declining issues narrowly outnumbered those that rose, 1,004 to 953.
Big broadcasters showed large gains, with traders focusing not only on the Bell Atlantic deal but on Monday's announcement that Westwood One was acquiring Unistar Radio Network from the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation. CBS was up 8 3/4, to 285 1/8, and Capital Cities/ABC was up 13 1/4, to 593.
With some analysts talking about the possibility of cigarette price increases, tobacco stocks were firm. In addition to Philip Morris, Loews -- which owns Lorillard -- advanced 1 1/4, to 92 1/2; American Brands rose 5/8, to 34 1/4, and RJR Nabisco increased 1/2, to 5 1/4.
Regional banks also showed gains after the Germantown Savings Bank of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., announced that it had hired Alex. Brown & Sons to help it find a buyer. Germantown jumped 8 1/4, to 51 3/4, and some other smaller banks reached record highs.
Utility stocks declined and analysts cited the huge amounts that these companies would have to spend to meet clean-air requirements. Public Service Enterprises fell 1/4, to 33 7/8, and Con Edison dropped 1/4, to 35.
Also down for the day were the big international oil stocks. Texaco dipped 5/8, to 68 1/2; Mobil was off 7/8, to 83 3/8, and Chevron fell 3/4, to 95 1/8.
Semiconductor issues dropped on a trade association report that the industry's book-to-bill ratio -- the industry's main economic indicator -- declined in September, the lowest level since November 1991. Intel was off 1 1/2, to 63 1/2; National Semiconductor was off 1 5/8, to 16 7/8 ,and Motorola was off 3/4, to 102 3/4.
Pioneer Hi-Bred, the seed company, had an impressive gain of 4, to 37 1/4. Yesterday was its first day as a stock in the Standard & Poor's 500 index, replacing JWP Inc. The S.&P. index advanced 0.37 point, to 461.49.

HEADLINE: Whitman Goes on Attack, Accusing Florio on Funds

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
After a bruising week on defense, Christine Todd Whitman's gubernatorial campaign went on the attack today, charging Gov. Jim Florio with violating state election laws by spending money designated for the general election before the primary was held in June.
Speaking at a news conference at the State House, the Whitman campaign lawyer, Peter Verniero, contended that the Florio campaign spent or transferred $225,000 in general-election funds between April 9 and the June 8 primary. Ed Rollins, the campaign manager for Mrs. Whitman, said the suspected violation was significant because it allowed Mr. Florio to get a headstart on campaigning for the governor's race. 
 "I've heard of a lot of people trying to steal campaigns Election Day," Mr. Rollins said. "I've never seen anybody try to steal a campaign two months before it gets started."
Mrs. Whitman did not attend the news conference.
 
Hearing Requested
 The Whitman campaign said it filed a complaint with the New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission and asked for an emergency hearing on the allegations.
Frederick M. Herrmann, executive director of the election commission, said commission guidelines prevented him from commenting on whether a complaint had been filed.
But he said state law was clear on the matter. "A gubernatorial candidate may raise money during the primary for the general election, but the money cannot be spent during the primary election," he said.
Mr. Herrmann said the next monthly meeting of the commission is next Tuesday, but if necessary, the panel is prepared to meet in emergency session before then.
"Historically, the commission has dealt with gubernatorial election complaints expeditiously," he said.
A spokeswoman for the Florio campaign, Jo Astrid Glading, termed the allegations "nonsense" and called on the commission to resolve the issue as soon as possible.
"We don't think the commission will find a violation," she said.
Ms. Glading said that although the money was spent before the primary, it was not a violation because all of the expenses were general-election expenses. Mr. Florio was unopposed in the primary.
 
Spent on Raising Funds
 Ms. Glading said some of the money was spent for fund-raising activities. It is not illegal to raise money for the general election during the primary. The rest was used for items like rent, consultant fees, equipment rental and insurance, she said.
"The alternative would have been to write checks dated midnight June 8 and rush them over the next morning," Ms. Glading said, adding that "we don't think" the election commission "wants people to pay their bills late."
The standard remedy for an election-law violation is a fine -- $3,000 for the first offense and $6,000 for each subsequent offense of the same sort. "Beyond that," Mr. Herrmann said, "we would have to look carefully at the election statute to go beyond our customary fines."
The allegations came during a week in which Mrs. Whitman found herself repeatedly defending against attacks by the Florio campaign. First, Mr. Florio ridiculed Mrs. Whitman for saying during a debate last Thursday that tens of thousands of dollars were wasted buying Adidas sneakers for state prisoners.
Officials with the State Department of Corrections said the state does not buy Adidas sneakers for any inmate. Most prisoners get a pair of generic sneakers that cost $7 to $8, said Jim Stabile, a department spokesman. Inmates with medical problems diagnosed by a physician get special, high-arch sneakers that cost $34, he said.
Carl Golden, the Whitman campaign spokesman, said the candidate had been given faulty information by a state legislator.
 
Tax Returns at Issue
 On Tuesday, after blistering attacks by Mr. Florio and his chief political consultant, James Carville, Mrs. Whitman announced that she would release her family's 1990 income tax returns by the end of the week. Mrs. Whitman had already made public tax returns for 1989, 1991 and 1992. But she said at first that she saw no reason to release the 1990 tax return because she was a private citizen in 1991, when the 1990 return was being prepared.
Mr. Rollins, the Whitman campaign manager, said today's charges were not in response to the Florio campaign tactics. He said Mrs. Whitman decided to release the returns because she wants to get back to discussing important issues like jobs and the economy. And he said the charges against Mr. Florio were important because they point to the issue of integrity.
"This is a governor who will lie, cheat, do whatever it takes to win this election," Mr. Rollins asserted. "It goes to the arrogance of this administration."
The Whitman campaign also contended that Mr. Florio's campaign inappropriately transferred $308,700 to an account run by Democratic Finance '93, a joint campaign account of the Florio campaign and the Democratic State Committee's campaign.
Although the entity also filed a campaign finance report, Mr. Verniero, the Whitman lawyer, said mixing Florio campaign funds with money from the Democratic State Committee made it impossible to determine exactly how the Florio campaign funds were spent.
 
Cost of Clinton Visits
 Mr. Rollins also demanded the Florio campaign help pay for recent visits to the state by President Clinton and several top-level cabinet officials. White House officials maintain that a visit by Mr. Clinton on Oct. 8, as well as visits in September by Attorney General Janet Reno and Interior Secretary Bruce Babbit, were official in nature and not politically related.
In 1990, Mrs. Whitman was fined $1,700 by the Federal Election Commission for a violation of Federal election laws. The commission said she failed to make a timely report of a $50,000 loan she made to her own campaign in the Senate race against Bill Bradley.
Mr. Verniero said Mrs. Whitman's 1990 violation was minor, compared with the allegations against Mr. Florio. "It's like comparing an elephant to a flea," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 15, 1993, Friday

He said a state legislator had given Mrs. Whitman information that the state was spending tens of thousands of dollars on Adidas sneakers for prisoners. He did not say the information was faulty.

HEADLINE: Clinton and Aristide Move To Affirm Policy on Haiti

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
A day after an American troopship was forced to retreat in the face of a small mob on a Port-au-Prince dock, the Clinton Administration and the exiled Haitian President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, sought to demonstrate the United States commitment to the return of democratic rule in the Caribbean country.
"Our commitment to this process is unshakable," William Swing, the recently appointed Ambassador to Haiti, said today, referring to the negotiated settlement between Father Aristide and Haiti's military rulers that was supposed to lead to the Roman Catholic priest's restoration as President on Oct. 31.
 
Countering the Images
 Mr. Swing made his comments as he presented his credentials to Father Aristide at the Haitian Embassy in Washington. Advisers to Father Aristide invited the United States Information Service to record the event in hopes it would be broadcast to Haiti, where it might counter images of gun-toting police auxiliaries cheering on Tuesday as the American troopship retreated over the horizon. 
 Later in the day, President Clinton, meeting with a delegation from the Congressional Black Caucus, said he would soon make what one participant termed a "strong statement" in support of the return of the ousted Haitian President.
"He wants to bring this thing back on track," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of the Bronx, who attended the meeting at the White House.
As the Administration sought to maintain Congressional support for its policy toward Haiti, a policy that envisions the placing of lightly armed American soldiers and sailors in the country, one Administration official suggested that the raucous dockside demonstration that forced the retreat of a troopship carrying American and Canadian military personnel did not really constitute a threat.
 
'A Bit of Theater'
 "What happened at the docks I would continue to say was a bit of theater, a very effective bit of theater," said one official, who asked not to be identified. "It came at a point where it took on importance well beyond what it should have. And if you didn't have an international community focusing on Somalia and things of that nature, it probably never would have taken on the importance that it did."
Nevertheless, he said, "we had no choice" but to pull the ship out of Haitian waters.
"We were not going to force our way ashore," he said.
The ship, the Harlan County, was supposed to deposit 200 American and Canadian combat engineers and military trainers in Haiti. The military personnel are part of an international contingent of 1,300 who will help build roads, schools, hospitals and other projects and provide training for a reconstituted Haitian military and police force.
 
Trainers Could Stay for Years
 The Administration official said today that while the contingent of engineers would probably stay in Haiti for about six months, the military and police trainers could remain in the country for several years.
Mr. Swing is scheduled to take up his post in Haiti's capital on Friday, the same day that Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, leader of the Haitian military, and Col. Joseph Michel Francois, his chief of police, are supposed to step aside to make room for Father Aristide's return 15 days later.
At the ceremony, Father Aristide said, "With the deadline for the departure of Cedras, Francois and the high command only two days away, we hope that the international community will continue to stand with us to make that happen, so that true democracy will be restored to Haiti."
Administration officials say they hope that economic sanctions voted today by the United Nations Security Council would persuade Haiti's military and police commanders to step down as scheduled and place the process for Father Aristide's return back on track. In addition, the Administration is considering seizing the assets of individual supporters of the military junta.
In June the Administration froze the assets of 83 members of Haiti's economic elite in an attempt to bring pressure on the country's recalcitrant military leaders. Those sanctions were suspended along with United Nations sanctions in August after a new Prime Minister selected by Father Aristide took office.


CORRECTION-DATE: October 16, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about United States policy toward Haiti misidentified the home district of Representative Charles B. Rangel. It is in Manhattan, not the Bronx.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Woolworth To Shutter 970 Stores

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

 BODY:
The Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that it planned to eliminate 13,000 jobs and close 970 stores, including half of its remaining five-and-dime variety stores, in what would be the largest, most costly reorganization in the retailer's 114-year-history.
The retrenchment will take place over several months and will include 400 of the discount stores and 330 Kinney shoe stores. The moves will further transform Woolworth from its Main Street dime store origins into a specialty retailing conglomerate. 
 The company said about 250 of the stores were expected to be converted to other formats like Foot Locker, Woolworth's highly successful athletic shoe and apparel chain, or the Bargain Shop, its chain of low-price apparel and household merchandise stores in Canada. Woolworth will cut 10,000 jobs in the United States and 3,000 in Canada, or 9 percent of its work force of 143,000.
 
 
Giving Up the Core Business
 "They've taken the hard decision to give up the core business that gave Woolworth its name," said Alan G. Millstein, editor of the Fashion Network Report. "The old-fashioned five-and-dime will be a memory."
 In a statement, Woolworth said it expected to take a $480 million after-tax charge against third-quarter earnings.
William K. Lavin, who became Woolworth's chairman in July, said third-quarter earnings were expected to fall sharply from a year earlier. In a five-week period that ended on Oct. 2, Woolworth's overall sales were off four-tenths of a percent, making it one of the weakest performers among the big retailers.
 
 
Unfavorable Conditions
 "The continuation of unfavorable economic conditions in the United States and Canada, along with increased competitive pressures affecting customers' shopping habits and the generally depressed environment, have led us to accelerate our store closings," Mr. Lavin said.
Woolworth said the stores to be shuttered had contributed 9 percent of the company's total revenue of $4.42 billion for the first half of the year. The stores lost $36 million in that period, the same amount the stores lost for all of 1992.
Shares of Woolworth rose 25 cents yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, to $26.125.
The company did not say where the affected stores are situated. While about 450 five-and-dime stores will stay in business, most analysts expect they too will be tallying final receipts soon.
"I'd not be surprised if within three years, Woolworth will not have a Woolworth," said Isaac Lagnado, principal of Tactical Retail Solutions, a retail consulting firm.
Woolworth has been plowing its resources into specialty concepts, which generate twice the operating profits of dime stores, even as sales and profits at its central city locations have slowed. Woolworth's traditional customers have been lured away by discount mass merchants like Wal-Mart and Kmart, which typically have vast inventories and suburban locations that are viewed as safer and more accessible.
 Analysts said that long-term low-cost leases played a key role in supporting profit margins at Woolworth's five-and-dime stores and that they possibly masked the format's declining customer base. Woolworth closed 100 variety stores in 1992.
 
 
Shift to Specialty Chains
 In its efforts to transform itself, Woolworth has spawned a number of specialty chains, including Champs Sports, a sporting goods store; Northern Reflections, a women's outdoor apparel chain, and Foot Locker, which has been highly profitable.
But even specialty retailers like the Limited and the Gap have felt the pinch of a sluggish economy. And the grunge look has made heavy-sole leather shoes popular, dampening interest in athletic shoes.
Woolworth's largest previous housecleaning was the discontinuance of the 336-store Woolco discount department store chain, which led to a $428 million charge in 1983.

HEADLINE: HAITI JUSTICE MINISTER SLAIN IN DEFIANCE OF U.S. WARNING TO MILITARY TO KEEP PEACE

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Further defying international efforts to restore democracy in Haiti, gunmen shot and killed the Justice Minister and two aides this afternoon as they were leaving the minister's office.
The killing of the minister, Guy Malary, came less than two hours after radio stations here broadcast a warning by President Clinton that the United States would hold Haiti's military responsible for the safety of members of the transitional Government. The Cabinet was appointed six weeks ago by the ousted President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. 
 On a day of rising tensions, with Haitian soldiers and police officers staging an offensive of killings and threats, 51 Canadian police officers sent here by the United Nations left the country.
United States officials have said the 46 American military and police personnel in Haiti will be withdrawn Monday if the military does not insure their safety.
 
Violence Intensifies
 The Canadian withdrawal followed by two days the departure of a ship carrying 218 American and Canadian troops. Several hundred heavily armed demonstrators opposed to the return of Father Aristide had prevented the ship, the Harlan County, from docking, and the berth the military authorities had promised was occupied by another ship.
In response to the intensifying violence, the United Nations reimposed oil and trade sanctions on Haiti on Wednesday.
Since the troop ship sailed away, many diplomats here have warned that a newly emboldened Haitian military may step up its campaign of violence to avoid surrendering power.
 
Assigned to Retrain Police
 Despite repeated threats on his life by police auxiliaries, Mr. Malary, 50, had been one of the new Government's first senior officials to occupy his office shortly after their appointment by Father Aristide, who is in exile in Washington.
The minister, a respected and wealthy lawyer who was to have overseen the retraining of the police under a political accord reached last July, had quickly taken on dangerous work, insisting on the retirement of a Supreme Court justice favored by the Army.
In an interview Tuesday night, Mr. Malary said of threats against him after his removal of the judge: "I have come not to work with the justice establishment I've found on the ground. I've come with the intention of building something new that this country can be proud of."
According to people who arrived on the scene moments after the killings, the three bodies were lined head to toe in the road. Mr. Malary's wife arrived minutes later and removed his wallet and watch. As an ambulance arrived quickly to take the bodies away, armed civilians and police began chasing away by-standers and threatened to shoot news photographers at the scene.
The three killings set off a panic downtown, with shops quickly shuttered as the news spread and everyone from business executives to street merchants rushing to leave town.
The assassination occurred within a few feet of the spot where one of Father Aristide's most prominent supporters, Antoine Izmery, was dragged from a church service last month and shot in the head.
In addition to killing Mr. Malary, his chauffeur and his bodyguard, gunmen also occupied the National Assembly, briefly holding a small number of legislators and employees hostage.
 
Demand for New Talks
 According to local radio reports, the gunmen demanded that Father Aristide reach some sort of reconciliation with the Army commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras. Under the terms of the political accord, which General Cedras signed, he is to retire from his command by Friday.
Another anti-Aristide group with strong ties to the military announced a national strike on Friday to show opposition to the international community's efforts to restore democracy. A similar strike last week was enforced at gunpoint as the police shut down the capital for the day.
The gunmen's attacks followed warnings earlier today by Army officers that imposition of the embargo by the United Nations, which is to take effect Monday, would bring the arrest of Prime Minister Robert Malval.
And late Wednesday, the Port-au-Prince police chief, Lieut. Col. Joseph Michel Francois, announced in a defiant message that he had decided "to stay and die in my country." Under the accord to restore Father Aristide, Colonel Francois is to resign and clear the way for a newly trained police force.
 
Accusing Americans
 Colonel Francois, who is widely believed to be the leader of a network of 1,500 brutal police auxiliaries known as attaches, charged that his life had been threatened earlier this month by United States diplomats, who warned him to leave the country.
Colonel Francois said he was preparing to release "material proof" of his assertions. Diplomats who met with him earlier this month denied ever issuing a death threat.
In an unusually blunt news conference today, the United Nations special envoy to Haiti, Dante Caputo of Argentina, denounced General Cedras and Colonel Francois, saying they were personally responsible for the violence afflicting Haiti and calling them "false nationalists and mafiosi."
Mr. Caputo said new sanctions on Haiti would be lifted only if the removal of the two men from power were accompanied by an end to political violence by the army.
On Wednesday the Security Council reimposed an oil and arms embargo that had been in effect earlier in the year. When first imposed, the sanctions dealt a blow to Haiti's economy. But many experts say such sanctions may be less effective this time, since Haiti is believed to have replenished its oil supplies and its leaders have moved and hidden their assets abroad.
 
The Reluctant General
 As the deadline for his resignation has approached, General Cedras has given some indications that he might not step down. In a news conference on Wednesday, he said he would resign only if a number of intermediate steps were undertaken first, steps he said were included in the political agreement.
Chief among these, he said, was a blanket amnesty for Army leaders for any crimes committed since the Sept. 30, 1991, military coup against Father Aristide. General Cedras also requested a forum to address the United Nations, and said Father Aristide had violated the settlement by failing to name a consensus government.
United States and United Nations diplomats both rejected General Cedras's demands, saying that a limited amnesty decreed by Father Aristide earlier this month was all that the negotiated agreements required.
A senior Western diplomat said today that the Army had "nothing to say about the composition of the Government, neither under the constitution nor under the agreement."
 
Diplomats Consult
 Mr. Caputo, the United Nations envoy, was seen shortly after Mr. Malary's killing speeding in his heavily guarded car toward the home of the United States charge d'affaires, Vicki Huddleston. No statement was immediately available from either diplomat.
A statement issued in Washington expressed grief at Mr. Malary's killing, calling him "a true champion of democracy."
The position of the Government of Prime Minister Malval has grown more tenuous as the United Nations has scaled back its presence here.
A dinner for Mr. Malval on Tuesday given by Senator Bob Graham of Florida broke up early when Mr. Malval's wife called to warn him that there had been shooting near their house.
Mr. Malval's home, which is guarded by a handful of soldiers who spend most of their time playing dominoes and by a small number of private security guards, has also been repeatedly threatened by the police auxiliaries.
"What we are engaged in is a psychological warfare," said a member of Mr. Malval's Government. "Cedras might want to try to get out by salvaging a little of his reputation somehow. Michel Francois has no reputation to worry about."

Chart: "Who's Who in Haitian Drama"
 
Jean-Bertrand Aristide: Haiti's first democratically elected President
 
Son of provincial landowner, studied with Roman Catholic priests in Port-au-Prince, became priest, gained prominence as outspoken critic of Duvalier dictatorship and subsequent military-backed governments. Escaped assassination attempts in 1987 and 1988, gained overwhelming victory in election for President in 1990, accused by opponents of violating constitutional rights while in office, governed for seven months before being overthrown by the military in September 1991.
 
Robert Malval: Prime Minister
 
Graduated from University of Miami and Institute of of Political Science in Paris, opposed most Aristide policies during his presidency, but began advising him this year in effort to stanch the country's economic devastation, chosen by Aristide to lead Haiti's transition to democracy, won international respect and that of much of Haiti's small middle-class population, but he has been unable to stop the political violence and kiilling or to disarm military-backed civilian gangs that are responsible for much of unrest.
 
Raoul Cedras: Army commander
 
Youngest of four sons in a middle-class Protestant merchant family in southwestern port of Jeremie, assured voters' security in Haiti's first democratic election, in December 1990, promoted from colonel to lieutenant general in February 1991 by Aritisde, who selected him as army chief over entire army general command, says he was a reluctant participant in ouster of President Aristide, but has quietly resisted his return while publicly proclaiming support for United Nations accord providig for it and which Cedras signed in July.
 
Joseph Michel Francois: National police chief
 
Son of member of the presidential guard for Francios Duvalier, President from 1957 until his death in 1971, was saved by Cedras when Aristide's police chief tried to dismiss him for insubordination, weeks later, joined coup that ousted Aristide, promoted himself from commander of Port-au-Prince police precinct to national chief, leads shadowy group of thousands of armed civilians blamed by United Nations for series of political killings since Sept. 8 and for protest that forced retreat of United States ship carrying American and Canadian military advisers. (pg. A8)
