HEADLINE: U.S. Presses for New Haitian Plan In Effort to Restore Ousted Leader

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Jolted by the assassination of Haiti's Justice Minister, Administration officials scrambled today to develop plans to salvage the stalemated effort to return to power the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
Even before the killing in Haiti, the Administration was considering tighter sanctions against Haiti by the United Nations, freezing Haitian assets in the United States and perhaps sending American ships to enforce the cutoff of oil and arms, the officials said. 
 President Clinton indicated this morning that he would heed the advice of his Pentagon advisers and stop short of direct military intervention, but that option was nonetheless discussed by senior Presidential advisers who convened late this afternoon, after word of the killing reached Washington. Mr. Clinton joined the meeting toward its end.
No decision was made, and the President said nothing in public. A statement by the White House said he "strongly condemns" the killing of the Justice Minister, Guy Malary.
A senior Administration official said that there was a growing belief among the top ranks of the Administration that the agreement for restoring Father Aristide was dead, and that it would not be practical to send trainers and engineers to Haiti, as the White House had hoped. But the official said that no final decision on abandoning the plan was made at a late afternoon meeting of top Administration officials, and that they planned to reconvene on Friday.
 
New Problem, New Debate
 On a day that started with Mr. Clinton's declaration that he would stand by Father Aristide in spite of the intensifying violence in Haiti, Mr. Clinton found himself faced by mid-afternoon with a new debate about whether the United States should intervene in foreign conflicts.
Mr. Clinton said at a news conference this morning that sending troops to Haiti would violate the tenets of the Governors Island agreement, which provided for Father Aristide's return to power in exchange for a limited amnesty for the military leaders who ousted him.
"I would remind you that the Governors Island agreement basically was an agreement among all the major parties in Haiti which clearly set forth the fact that they did not want other countries' forces or a U.N. force coming in there to provide law and order," the President said.
That agreement was seen by the Administration as a way of ending the political crisis and thereby settling the issue of refugees who had fled Haiti to seek asylum in the United States, an issue that Mr. Clinton had vowed to resolve.
The slaying of the Justice Minister came just hours later, lending additional gravity to comments made by Mr. Clinton when he worried aloud about the safety of Haiti's new Prime Minister, Robert Malval.
 
Praise for Prime Minister
 "Malval is key to making this whole thing work," Mr. Clinton said. "He is recognized as a stabilizing figure, as a person who will work with all sides, as a person who will be fair to everybody. And it would be, again, a grave error to underestimate the extent to which this country regards him as an important part of the ultimate solution.
"I want to send a clear signal today, too, that the United States is very concerned about his ability to function and his personal safety and the safety of his Government."
Mr. Clinton said he would consider taking action if there was no progress made in carrying out the agreement, under which President Aristide is to return to Haiti by Oct. 30. He did not rule out sending ships to enforce the renewed sanctions against Haiti, saying only that he did not want to use the word blockade because it would connote an act of war.
The assassination raises the stakes for the United States, which earlier this week postponed plans to send 600 American and Canadian engineers and advisers to Haiti after an angry mob turned away the first troop ship.
"The people of Haiti would be sadly misguided if they think the United States has weakened its resolve," Mr. Clinton said.
 
Meeting at White House
 Secretary of State Warren Christopher met at the White House this afternoon with Defense Secretary Les Aspin and Anthony Lake, the national security adviser. Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, said the President's advisers would eventually present him with options for action.
Kathleen deLaski, a Pentagon spokeswoman, said sending United States naval forces to cut off access to Haitian harbors remained a possibility.
"We're not sending ships anywhere to be part of what you describe as a blockade," she said. "We certainly reserve the right to take steps to insure that sanctions are carried out, but no operations are happening at this time or about to happen."
At his news conference, President Clinton offered a blanket defense of his Administration's foreign policy, arguing that recent events in Haiti and Somalia had vindicated his faith in the wisdom of involvement in trouble spots.
 
'Living in a New World'
 Asserting that his critics have found it "easy to second-guess" his foreign policy advisers, Mr. Clinton said his Administration should be given credit for its efforts to aid democracies in Haiti and elsewhere.
"We are living in a new world," he said. "It's easy for people who don't have these responsibilities to use words like naive, or this, that or the other thing. The truth is, we're living in a new and different world, and we've got to try to chart a course that is the right course for the United States to lead, while avoiding things that we cannot do or things that impose costs in human and financial terms that are unacceptable for us."
But two members of Congress who support Father Aristide called for tougher action against the opposition forces in Haiti.
Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, called on the United Nations to send troops from several nations to disarm the forces in Haiti. In killing Mr. Malary, Mr. Rangel said, "The thugs in Haiti have shown that they are not about to cooperate with the diplomatic measures being undertaken by the United Nations."
Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts, said that there should be an international ban on commercial flights to Haiti and that the United Nations should protect for the members of Haiti's transition government.
Michael Barnes, a Washington lawyer who is an adviser to Father Aristide, called the assassination "an absolute tragedy."
"I hope that Guy Malary didn't die in vain, and that his murder will be the galvanizing force to get the world community to demand that the Governors Island agreement be enforced," he said.
Officials of the Organization of American States said that a number of their human rights monitors in the country have been harassed by armed men in recent days.
 
Demonstration at O.A.S.
 On Wednesday morning, the officials said, a crowd of about 200 demonstrators, wielding machetes, gathered outside the headquarters of the O.A.S.-United Nations monitors' mission in Port-au-Prince and chanted, "Go Home!" An O.A.S. official said today that it would not send in any more monitors until the situation calmed down. There are about 100 rights monitors in Haiti now.
Forty-six members of a United States military team remain at a hotel in Port-au-Prince awaiting word -- expected by this weekend -- about whether they should return home.
Mr. Clinton warned about equating policies in Haiti, Somalia and Bosnia. Any peacekeeping force sent to the Balkans would work because the troops would be controlled by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, he said.

HEADLINE: House Rejects Democratic Leaders' Plan to Extend Jobless Benefits

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
In an embarrassing defeat for the Democratic leadership, the House of Representatives today rejected a plan to extend emergency benefits for workers who had been unemployed more than six months and had exhausted their state benefits.
Congressional budget rules require that the $1 billion cost of extending the benefits be offset by spending cuts or tax increases, but Democrats were deeply divided over where to come up with the money. 
 Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the Ways and Means Committee, had wanted to save $331 million to help pay for the extension by requiring immigrants to wait five years after their arrival, instead of three, to become eligible for Supplemental Security Income, a program for the disabled, elderly and blind.
But after strong opposition from the 15-member Hispanic caucus, the leadership instead proposed to save a similar amount of money by reducing the extended benefits from four months to three, a strategy that splintered the party's rank-and-file.
The leadership plan was defeated by a procedural vote of 274 to 149.
The fate of the unemployment bill now appears uncertain, and 60,000 unemployed workers who would become eligible for Federal extended benefits each week face a delay in their benefits. Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan and a senior member of the Ways and Means Committee, said after the vote that the House would approve an extension of unemployment benefits "if the leadership can think of a political solution."
This would be the fifth extension of Federal unemployment benefits since Nov. 1991, when Democrats attempted to embarrass President George Bush by highlighting the troubled economy and making it appear that he had failed to recognize the problem. The last extension of unemployment benefits expired Oct. 2.
The vote followed a debate in which members pitted the needs of the jobless against the needs of immigrants. Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the ranking Republican on the Ways and Means committee, told the House, "This may well be your only chance to reduce the burden on taxpayers by reducing benefits for aliens."
But Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, Republican of upstate New York, told his colleagues that if they supported the leadership plan, "You'll be voting to take away employment benefits for workers to give welfare benefits to aliens."
 
Rostenkowski Forges Alliance
 Representative David Bonior of Michigan, the Democratic Whip, exhorted the House: "Let us not pit the disabled, blind and elderly against unemployed people."
And Representative Jose E. Serrano, the Bronx Democrat who heads the Hispanic caucus, warned, "Any time you single out immigrants, you're going to have a problem with the Hispanic caucus."
But Mr. Rostenkowski, who persuaded 103 Democrats to join 171 Republicans in opposing the leadership bill, told the House that his original bill "does not single out any group of immigrants; it applies to all."
"A growing number of aliens are becoming public charges after three years, even though their sponsors are not poor," Mr. Rostenkowski said.
There are now 2.5 million people receiving state unemployment benefits, and an additional 1.4 million were receiving Federal emergency unemployment benefits, which expired Oct. 2d. Congressional experts said those whose Federal benefits expired before approval of the extension would not be eligible for the emergency benefits, which will expire Jan. 1st.
The bill would have extended unemployment benefits for seven weeks, except in four states and Puerto Rico, where unemployment is above 9 percent. In those states -- Alaska, California, Rhode Island and West Virginia -- benefits would be extended 13 weeks. The average benefit is $179 a week.

HEADLINE: U.S. Study Says Job Retraining Is Not Effective

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
An internal Labor Department report says the Government job training program for workers hurt by foreign trade is largely ineffective and used primarily as an income crutch for the unemployed.
The $200 million program, one of the biggest and most generous for unemployed Americans, was enacted 19 years ago in an effort to help laid-off manufacturing workers who could show that imports cost them their jobs. They were to be retrained in computer operation, nursing, accounting and trades like welding and air conditioning repair. 
 The Labor Department audit, based on an examination of 1,198 workers in nine states in 1991, found that only one in five of the retrained workers were steered into jobs paying at least 80 percent as much as their old jobs.
The findings were quickly cited by opponents of President Clinton's proposed North American Free Trade Agreement as evidence that the Government cannot easily make up for job losses by retraining workers.
 
Timing Is Coincidental
 The report, completed two weeks ago and now being distributed in Washington, followed the inspector general's normal schedule for audits and the timing was unrelated to current concerns about the economy, including the announcement by the White House yesterday of plans to provide special retraining for people who lose jobs because of the trade agreement. But it has landed in the middle of the debate over the trade agreement, on which Congress must vote before Jan. 1, when it is intended to take effect.
The audit says that half the eligible workers did not even enroll in training courses but that they still collected the unemployment benefits meant to support them while they were in school. The audit, which conducted its own survey, says it is hard for the Labor Department to monitor the program because no one -- in Washington or in the states, which administer it -- keeps track of the workers once they leave it.
In 1991, the largest number of participants were laid-off apparel workers. Most of the others worked in the auto, electronics and other manufacturing industries.
The program, established under the Trade Adjustment Assistance Act, costs about $200 million a year and covers about 30,000 workers. It provides up to 18 months of unemployment benefits, three times longer than the unemployed normally receive, so the workers will not have to drop out in the middle of their training because their benefits run dry.
"Briefly," the Labor Department's inspector general's office wrote, "we believe that the T.A.A. program fell short of meeting the re-employment or training goals implied by the act. The evidence collected shows that the program was managed as an entitlement-compensation program rather than a training program."
The audit dwells mostly on the management of the program and a failure to steer more workers toward training in new skills.
In a thorny aspect of the debate, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich frequently says that with training, workers will again find good jobs, but critics say the only jobs the economy is generating in any volume are relatively low-wage service jobs that require little training.
 
Problems Acknowledged
 The Clinton Administration, which has been critical of the training programs it inherited, did not try to defend this one. "The inspector general raises a number of problems with the Trade Adjustment Assistance Act, which are essentially valid," said Douglas Ross, assistant secretary of labor for employment and training.
He said the Administration was overhauling the Government's unemployment-assistance and retraining programs and that the flaws found in the trade adjustment program would be removed in the new plan, to be introduced next year.
But he differed with the audit's suggestion that training did not lead to good jobs.
"Is the American economy or any Western economy creating as many good paying jobs as they would like?" he asked. "The answer is they are not. But can I find a decent job?" With appropriate training -- better than that many workers receive through the workers trade adjustment program -- "the answer is yes," he said.
Some Democrats in Congress, however, found ammunition for their opposition to the trade agreement in the audit.
 
'Programs Just Don't Work'
 "These training programs just don't work," said Representative Collin C. Peterson, the Minnesota Democrat who heads an anti-agreement caucus in the House. "They keep saying Nafta will create 200,000 jobs or something like that, but they can't tell us what those jobs are. How are they going to put together training for jobs when they don't know what they are?"
Mr. Peterson has scheduled hearings for Tuesday with Labor Department officials to question them about the audit. Representative Lynn Woosley, Democrat of California, has introduced legislation to provide up to three years of unemployment assistance to maintain workers' incomes while they train and look for other jobs.
Mr. Peterson's team found that the average participant in the program was male, 43 years old, finished the 11th grade, had worked for his previous employer for 10.6 years, earned $440 a week and was a member of a union. The 1,198 workers the auditors surveyed had been employed in Alabama, Colorado, Georgia, Illinois, Missouri, New Jersey, New York, Ohio and Pennsylvania.
The audit determined that 80 percent of the workers had found jobs within a year after completing the trade adjustment program. While 80 percent of the job losers had worked for manufacturers, 57 percent found new jobs in manufacturing. Those who enrolled in training programs received an average of $13,134 in unemployment aid assistance, and those who did not obtain training received $10,775.
 
Results a Year Later
 It found that within a year of completing the program 62 percent of the workers, retrained or not, found new jobs, that 18 percent were recalled by their previous employers and that 20 percent were unemployed. Of those who found jobs a third settled for wages of less than 80 percent of their prior wages. They kept the jobs for an average of just eight months.
The audit said that 51 percent of the workers had enrolled in training programs and that these workers had done slightly better in finding jobs than those who did not. But it said only 19 percent of the retrained workers found jobs that required their training and paid at least 80 percent of their previous wages.

HEADLINE: New York City Sells Notes

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
New York City sold $650 million in tax-anticipation notes yesterday, featuring the first swap of competitively bid municipal notes to a variable rate.
The city saved about $175,000 by selling variable-rate notes with six-month rates near all-time lows, Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman said in a statement. 
 The CS First Boston Group won the bidding on the $400 million fixed-rate portion of the notes. That portion, due on April 1, was priced to yield 2.45 percent, the underwriter said. The notes have a taxable equivalent yield of 3.83 percent.
Goldman, Sachs & Company won the bidding on the $250 million variable-rate portion of the sale. The notes will float against the Public Securities Association index, less 10 basis points. The rate will be reset every seven days.
After the sale, the city swapped the variable-rate portion of the notes with Goldman, Sachs for a fixed-income rate. The city got a rate of 2.37 percent, city officials said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Wholesale price inflation was unexpectedly low in September and consumers continued to spend at a brisk clip, the Government reported. Analysts said the data confirmed the moderate-growth, low-inflation direction of the economy. The news drove the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond down to a 25-year low. [Page D1.]
A Government job training program for workers hurt by foreign trade is largely ineffective, according to a report by the Labor Department. [A1.] The House rejected an extension of emergency unemployment benefits. [A16.] 
 The Administration lowered its estimate of how much its health care plan would cut the budget deficit, acknowledging that the plan would be more expensive than anticipated. [A22.]
 
Companies
Chrysler earnings more than doubled in the third quarter, helped by a rebounding car and truck market. The results, which were a third-quarter record for the company, exceeded Wall Street's expectations and sent Chrysler's stock surging. [D1.]
Military contractors may have found a new growth industry in working for the Government to dismantle and recycle the weapons they were paid billions of dollars to produce. [D1.]
Many regulatory hurdles facing Bell Atlantic's acquisition of Tele-Communications have escaped public attention, analysts say, and the $33 billion merger may take years to complete. [D1.]
U.S. Surgical announced hundreds of layoffs and cutbacks in pay and workers' hours. It also reported a second consecutive quarterly loss and a dividend reduction. [D1.]
Apple Computer eked out a small quarterly profit on a big sales gain, defying the most pessimistic expectations. Also, the president of Apple U.S.A., Robert L. Puette, resigned. [D3.]
Microsoft will soon raise the ante in the "suite wars," a battle in the fast-growing business software market. [D3.]
Drugstore companies sued seven large drug makers and a mail-order drug pharmacy, accusing them of price fixing. [D3.]
Kmart provided more details about its plans to sell the pieces of some of its specialty store businesses to the public. [D3.]
Prudential Securities agreed to pay $120 million to about 130,000 investors in 35 oil and gas partnerships that went sour. [D4.]
QVC Network is preparing to begin discussions with Paramount on its $9.6 billion merger proposal. [D4.]
Whittle Communications' Edison Project for profit-making schools hired Detroit's school superintendent. [A19.]
 
International
Ferruzzi's $17 billion financial rescue plan was rejected by 104 non-Italian banks, dealing a blow to efforts to save Italy's second-largest private enterprise from bankruptcy. [D2.]
 
Markets
Stocks moved higher again, with the acquisition of Tele-Communications by Bell Atlantic providing the impetus. The Dow industrials gained 18.44 points, and other indexes set records. [D6.]
The yield on the 30-year bond dropped to a 25-year low of 5.85 percent on reports of low wholesale inflation. But traders also began looking to today's report on consumer inflation. [D14.]
Silver and gold prices fell on news of low inflation and slow economic growth, which could depress demand for metals. [D13.]
The dollar was higher against most foreign currencies after the Bank of Japan was said to have bought dollars. [D13.]

Insurers are flocking to open in Bermuda, where private and corporate investors are pouring billions of dollars into new and expanding offshore insurance companies. Market Place. [D6.]
In its first trade campaign for Discover, Walt Disney is seeking to make the science magazine it acquired two years ago a consistently successful title. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D16.]

HEADLINE: Health Plan Is Now Seen as Less of a Deficit Fighter

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Acknowledging that its plan to overhaul the health care system will be more expensive than anticipated, the Clinton Administration has lowered its estimate of how much the plan would cut the budget deficit.
Several Administration officials said today that the plan would reduce the growth of the deficit by $70 billion to $80 billion between 1994 and 2000, down from the original estimate of $91 billion. 
 The new estimate comes at a time of intense political jockeying, when the White House is under pressure to demonstrate that its plan is credible. Indeed, Administration officials admit that it is hard to give precise predictions about how much money will be saved or spent in an overhauling the health sector, which represents one-seventh of the economy.
One reason for the lower estimate is that the Administration, recognizing that full savings will not occur until every state takes part, has concluded that some states will not be ready to join the program by Jan. 1, 1997, as it first anticipated.
These details emerged as the Administration rushed to put the finishing touches on the plan in the hope of giving Congress a formal legislative proposal late next week.
 
Battling Charge of Optimism
 The new estimates come after an intense round of number crunching, using what officials called conservative projections. They are intended to combat accusations by members of Congress and outside health care experts that the Administration's financial estimates are too optimistic.
Leon E. Panetta, the White House budget director, said today that the health plan would pare the deficit by $10 billion to $20 billion less than the $91 billion estimate. Another official, insisting on anonymity, said the deficit reduction would total "around 70 billion."
Under the revised plan, the Administration has decided to take back some of the gains that companies would realize from the proposal to have the Federal Government pay most health costs for early retirees. For the first three years, companies would have to repay to the Government half the money they save when the Government takes over most of their insurance costs for early retirees. From the fourth year on, companies would keep the full benefits.
 
Claiming Part of 'Windfall'
 "This is not a change in policy," said Christine Heenan, an Administration health-policy adviser. "These companies are experiencing a windfall, and we have always said there would be an assessment."
Administration officials have usually talked about a one-time assessment, not a three-year assessment. The new assessment was reported today in The Wall Street Journal.
Administration officials said the money would be used to offset losses in the Medicare and Social Security trust funds that are expected to result when the plan causes an increase in the number of early retirees.
The President proposed to lighten the corporate burden of paying for health insurance for retired people under age 65 because he was concerned that this burden was hurting the competitiveness of large manufacturers. At present, many large manufacturers pay the full cost of health insurance for early retirees, but the President has proposed that the companies pay 20 percent and the Federal Government pay 80 percent. This provision will cost between $4.5 billion $6 billion a year, Administration officials say.
 
Subsidies Balloon
 In preparing its new estimates, the Administration relied on its own forecast that inflation would be 3.5 percent a year through the year 2000. That is significantly higher than the Congressional Budget Office's 2.7 percent-a-year forecast that the Administration used in its original estimates.
By using the higher inflation figures, the Administration has concluded that the cost of subsidies would be considerably larger that anticipated. The Clinton plan calls for subsidies to low-income Americans and to low-wage companies with 50 or fewer workers.
One health care adviser estimated that the annual cost of subsidies would be about $90 billion a year, up from the previous estimate of $80 billion.
Administration officials also said they would probably alter their subsidy scheme for small companies. The President's plan would require these companies to provide health insurance, and the subsidies are intended to make it affordable to do so.
Some officials worry that the plan to subsidize low-wage companies with 50 or fewer workers would create some perverse incentives, like discouraging companies with 50 workers from expanding because they would lose their subsidies once they hired their 51st employee.
To alleviate this problem, the Administration is studying a phase-out of the subsidies. One idea is to reduce the subsidies gradually, starting with companies that have 30 workers, and phasing them out completely for companies with 50 workers. This phase-out would not increase the cost of the subsidy program, officials insist.
Worried that it might have underestimated the number of individuals and companies that receive subsidies, the Administration has increased the size of the financial cushion it has set up in case its estimates are too low. Officials said it had expanded its cushion so it represents 15 percent of estimated subsidies, up from 10 percent.
The Administration is having a hellish time estimating how many large companies would, to take advantage of the subsidies, contract out low-wage work, like janitorial work, to firms with 50 or fewer employees. If such contracting becomes widespread, the cost of subsidies could balloon.

HEADLINE: Breaking Down an Arms Buildup

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MAGNA, Utah

 BODY:
Having earned billions of dollars building weapons for the military, many contractors think they have found a new growth area -- dismantling and recycling the weapons they were paid to make.
"If you are looking for someone to take things apart, the first guy you are going to look for is the guy who made them," said Steven Malevich, a marketing director for Alliant Techsystems Inc. of Edina, Minn., which makes bullets, cluster bombs and torpedoes. 
 For decades, the military discarded conventional weapons like bombs by blowing them up, burning them or dumping them in the ocean. But as environmental regulations slowly bring such practices to a halt, the Defense Department has turned to military contractors like Hercules Inc., which once turned out hundreds of missile motors here annually, to find sounder ways to dispose of explosives and other weapons, as well as to recycle their ingredients.
 
 
345,000 Deadly Tons
 The Defense Department is currently sitting on about 345,000 tons of bombs, bullets and other ordnance, enough to fill a convoy of tractor-trailers stretching from New York to St. Louis. The Government also has chemical and nuclear weapons and unfired missile motors that it wants to get rid of, and this arsenal of obsolescence is expected to grow substantially in coming years as the size of the military shrinks.
Experts can only guess at the ultimate cost of destroying old arms, but there is little question it will amount to hundreds of millions of dollars. Nor is the United States Government alone in such initiatives. In July, Alliant Techsystems entered into a joint venture with the Ukrainian Government to dispose of 200,000 tons of ammunition, artillery shells and mortar rounds.
For weapons producers, the chance to recycle old arms will not greatly soften the blow of a sharp decline in military orders. But many company executives, seeking to convert their companies to a peacetime economy, are desperate for any opportunity to generate revenue.
Both Government and contracting officials said it was difficult to estimate the cost of recycling a specific weapon. Mr. Malevich of Alliant Techsystems said that tank artillery shells, for which the Government paid about $1,500 each, cost about $25 each to burn and would probably cost about $75 each to recycle.
 For their part, Government officials want to avoid some of the controversies associated with less sophisticated disposal techniques. Between 1988 and 1991, for example, the Defense Department destroyed more than 840 Pershing and ground-launched cruise missiles to comply with the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty. The motors that powered the rockets were simply bolted down by military contractors in vacant fields and ignited, which spewed clouds of noxious fumes containing ozone-depleting chemicals.
"We all know that the use of open burning is suspect," said John Byrd, the chairman of the Joint Ordnance Commanders Group, which is coordinating Defense Department efforts to demilitarize obsolete ordinance.
Congress allocated $62 million in 1991 to finance research into better disposal methods, turning to companies that build rocket motors like Hercules Inc., the Thiokol Corporation and Gencorp. Other companies, including Alliant Techsystems and the Olin Corporation, began to look at sounder ways to get rid of bombs and artillery shells.
Here at the ghost-like Hercules plant near Salt Lake City, which now produces a fraction of the missile motors it once turned out, company researchers are looking at methods to take apart and recycle the solid-fuel motors. Essentially, the motors are made by pouring a mixture of chemicals that includes explosives into a case where it solidifies to the consistency of a pencil eraser.
The fuel, once cured, is virtually bolted to the casing. "This stuff beats the heck out of superglue," said Jerald Peterson, vice president for business development at Global Environmental Solutions Inc., a Hercules subsidiary formed in 1991 to specialize in demilitarization.
 
 
Ammonia and Liquid Nitrogen
 In one process being tested here, pressurized liquid nitrogen is used like a cutting torch to break the solid fuel into pieces. Hercules has also begun experimenting with using ammonia to dissolve the solid fuel into a liquid. The ammonia is then vaporized, leaving behind the fuel's initial ingredients -- including explosives.
"What you can do is sell some of the materials to offset the cost of recovering them," Mr. Peterson said, mentioning the mining, quarrying and construction industries.
Some companies have taken different approaches. The Aerojet division of Gencorp, facing strict environmental rules in California, started looking several years ago to find alternatives to open burning, said Joseph Biagioni, the company's director of resource recovery.
"We knew that sooner or later we would get tagged because this open-burn cloud could just drift off your property," he said.
So Aerojet developed a technique to use jets of water, exerting pressures of up to 10,000 pounds a square inch, to remove the fuel. Depending on the degree of the fuel's explosiveness, it can then be burned in an incinerator to produce energy or be processed back into ammonium perchlorate, a component of solid rocket fuel that can also be used in the production of paint or new fuel, Mr. Biagioni said.
In July, Aerojet made the first successful test firing of a Minuteman 3 rocket motor that used fuel containing recycled ammonium perchlorate. Aerojet executives and Nevada state officials have also discussed the possibility of building a plant to process 10 million pounds of obsolete explosives a year, Mr. Biagioni said. "At those processing rates, we can make it cheaper than burning," he said.
 
 
A Glut May Develop
 But the economics of recycling old weapons is far from proven. Like newspaper or plastics, there is likely to be a glut of commercial explosives as military contractors convert millions of tons of military ordnance to commercial applications. And because many contractors already produce explosives for commercial uses, they may wind up competing against themselves.
Some weapons may also prove impossible to recycle. Pyrotechnic devices intended to fool missiles by mimicking the exhaust of an F-16 jet, for example, emit a 3,000-degree burst when detonated. "There were a lot of items that were never designed to be taken apart," said Mr. Malevich of Alliant Techsystems.
 For more conventional weapons, like bombs and artillery shells, alternative disposal methods are being developed. Mr. Malevich said his company had developed a process that uses high-pressure jets of water to cut shells and casings into pieces. The metals can be recycled and the explosives, which are washed out of the shells, can be used commercially or to produce fertilizers or synthetic fuels.
"The Government believes it will cost about $500 a ton to demilitarize these shells and make them into bathroom fixtures," Mr. Malevich said.
Just when the Federal Government will begin such work is not clear. In the case of solid-fuel missile motors, Defense Department officials said they hoped to decide by 1995 on the best ways to dispose of and recycle them.
"The continental United States is now becoming a warehouse for weapons, and it is not something that you can abandon or walk away from," said Mr. Byrd of the Joint Ordnance Commanders Group.

HEADLINE: U.S. Warns North Koreans of U.N. Action on Nuclear Inspections

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 14

 BODY:
The United States and the International Atomic Energy Agency have warned North Korea that they will seek action by the United Nations Security Council unless Pyongyang admits inspectors to its nuclear sites within two weeks, according to officials in several countries.
For months the Clinton Administration has been trying to keep the issue of North Korea's suspected nuclear weapons out of the Security Council, in hopes that its direct talks with Pyongyang -- the first since the Korean War -- would derail its effort to build a nuclear bomb. But officials from South Korea and Japan, who have also been involved, now characterize the talks as an empty exercise that has allowed North Korea to buy time.
 
Equipment Not Serviced
 Officials of the International Atomic Energy Agency, based in Vienna, which conducts the inspections, said that North Korea had repeatedly prevented inspectors from servicing equipment monitoring key nuclear sites. The equipment is expected to run out of film and batteries in November. 
 "We are coming up on something of a technical deadline, and North Korea has not been responsive at all," David Kyd, the spokesman for the atomic agency, said today. "At this point, we have no access to the sites at all."
South Korean and Japanese officials said they do not know if the Clinton Administration is ready to confront North Korea over its months of foot-dragging on the inspections.
 
'Sanctions Are the Last Card'
 "Economic sanctions are the last card, and no one wants to use it too early," a senior Japanese official who has been involved in the effort to persuade Pyongyang to end its project.
American officials said today that even if the issue is referred to the Security Council, there are a range of possible actions short of economic sanctions.
On Wednesday in Vienna, North Korean officials said they had broken off all dealings with the atomic agency, charging that it is biased and manipulated by the United States and its intelligence agencies. They said that they would deal directly with the United States in the future. The third round of American-North Korean talks, headed by Under Secretary of State Robert Gallucci, was postponed indefinitely in September after Mr. Gallucci said that North Korea had failed to live up to several of the commitments it made earlier.
 
Inspectors Harrassed
 Even after North Korea announced in March that it would pull out of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, it allowed inspectors from the atomic agency into the country. But in recent trips they have been harrassed and obstructed, at one point even forced to visit a key nuclear installation at night, by flashlight. They have never been permitted to conduct two special inspections of suspected waste dumps that could yield evidence of how much plutonium North Korea has produced from its nuclear waste.
The warning to North Korea was sent at a fairly low level, through a diplomatic channel recently established with North Korea's delegation at the United Nations. The United States still has no diplomatic ties with North Korea.
Until now, North Korea's willingness to let inspectors maintain the equipment was the one piece of evidence of minimal compliance with the international inspection system. That has faded quickly in recent months, as Pyongyang and the agency have repeatedly tangled over restrictions placed on inspectors.
Other negotiations have come to a dead stop. North Korea has not held bilateral talks with Japan since last November, and its talks with the United States have come to a halt since the summer. On Friday North and South Korea are expected to meet again to talk about "mutual inspections" in which both sides would send inspectors into the other's country.
If the issue went to the Security Council, the key player would be China. So far it has abstained from major resolutions criticizing North Korea, although it says it has joined in the effort at quiet persuasion. But the talks with the United States were partly an effort to demonstrate to China, North Korea's greatest remaining ally, that every effort was being made to negotiate a settlement.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Up Only 0.2%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Wholesale price inflation was unexpectedly low in September, and consumers continued spending at a brisk clip, Government reports showed today.
The news drove interest rates lower; the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond slipped to 5.85 percent, the lowest in 25 years. [Page D14.] 
 Prices received by producers of finished goods climbed a modest two-tenths of 1 percent last month. But wholesale inflation would have been nonexistent had it not been for a jump in food prices, which move erratically and were affected by the summer's floods and drought.
Retail sales were also better than they appeared at first glance. Over all, sales rose a slender one-tenth of 1 percent, but excluding the automotive sector, which experienced some unusual factors in September, retail sales rose six-tenths of 1 percent in the month. Receipts from car sales were depressed by larger-than-usual price discounting to liquidate stock at the end of the model year, economists said, a development that also restrained the rise in producer prices.
 
More of the Same
 Taken together, said William V. Sullivan Jr. of Dean Witter Reynolds, the results "confirm the moderate-growth, low-inflation environment" that has prevailed all year.
Still another report today showed that first-time claims for unemployment benefits rose 8,000, to 329,000, last week, with nearly a third of the increase in Pennsylvania. Some analysts had expected the latest Labor Department tally to show a larger increase to reflect workers whose extended emergency benefits had run out and who might instead have filed under the regular program.
But the four-week moving average of claims, which economists consider to more accurately reflect the true trend, edged up only slightly, to 330,000, from a four-year low average reported last week.
So far this year producer prices have risen at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of eight-tenths of 1 percent, compared with a 1.6 percent gain in 1992. The modest rise in overall producer prices in September followed three months of declines.
 But analysts expressed confidence that the slight September rise did not represent a revival of inflationary pressure. Among other things, they pointed to the fact that the finished-goods index had risen only five-tenths of 1 percent the last 12 months and that prices also remained in check at earlier levels of production.
Intermediate goods, like a bolt of cloth, rose just one-tenth of 1 percent last month, while crude goods, like a bale of raw cotton, fell four-tenths of 1 percent. This meant there was nothing worrisome that might show up in coming months in finished goods -- the level at which products are ready for sale to the final business or individual user.
The producer price gauges, however, exclude most services and imported goods. These are included in the Consumer Price Index, which the Labor Department will release on Friday and which is expected to show another modest increase.
Wholesale food prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in September, with higher prices for fresh fruits and vegetables, pork, beef and veal, cheese, poultry and processed fruits and vegetables, the department said.
Tobacco products rose 2 percent after a plunge of 25.6 percent in August, while books and women's apparel turned up. Prices of passenger cars tumbled six-tenths of 1 percent -- 3.4 percent before adjustment for recurring seasonal patterns -- after a 1 percent August increase.
The Labor Department attributed the decline in car prices to liquidation allowances granted to dealers by auto makers.
Finished energy goods were unchanged last month after hefty drops in July and August. And prices of capital equipment, which rose in most earlier months this year, were also unchanged.
The Commerce Department's report on retail sales, showing a one-tenth of 1 percent overall advance for September, required a bit more interpretation than usual, but analysts generally concluded that spending remained on a solid, though restrained, upward trend.
Not only did liquidation allowances lead to lower showroom prices for cars, they noted, but car sales -- only mediocre for the month -- were thought to have been hurt at least as much by a shortage of desirable models as by slack demand. Moreover, car sales perked up in the first 10 days of October.
Today's report also doubled the previously reported average sales gains for July and August, with each month now showing an advance of five-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Cool-Weather Bump
 On the other hand, sales of apparel and possibly other goods seemed to benefit last month from cooler-than-usual weather, with the result that some business might have been "stolen" from October.
Reversing the August pattern, nondurable goods like clothing advanced eight-tenths of 1 percent in September while durables like cars fell 1 percent.
Sales climbed 2.1 percent at merchants that sell apparel and accessories, 1 percent at stores that sell general merchandise, eight-tenths of 1 percent at drug and proprietary stores, seven-tenths of 1 percent at restaurants and bars and three-tenths of 1 percent at gasoline stations. Sales at food stores, however, eased two-tenths of 1 percent.
Among durables, the drop for automotive dealers was 1.8 percent, while those selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes posted a 1.2 percent sales decline. Bucking this trend, however, was a 1.9 percent jump in sales of furniture, home furnishings and equipment.
At $174.45 billion, retail sales last month were 6.1 percent ahead of the September 1992 level without adjustment for inflation.

HEADLINE: Teachers Union's Crucial Alliance With Dinkins Is Shattered

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
When Mayor David N. Dinkins was running for office four years ago, the powerful teachers union and its president, Sandra Feldman, broke a 12-year tradition of silence and endorsed him early, then worked hard for him as he eked out a narrow victory.
When he gave the teachers a large pay increase that first year in office, despite a worsening fiscal picture, many saw it as a reward. 
 That pay increase ushered in a period of both political and fiscal problems for Mr. Dinkins, and when he demanded that the unions give back part of the raise, one of the most important political alliances in town began to unravel.
Now the relationship -- once a symbol of the powerful partnership between the Mayor and the labor movement -- is in tatters, the victim of personal animosity between Ms. Feldman and the Mayor's staff, teachers' anger over chaos in the schools, and a feeling among the union's leaders and members that despite all the heat he had taken, Mr. Dinkins had not come through for them in contract talks.
 
Dinkins's Appeal Snubbed
 On Wednesday, turning aside a personal appeal to Ms. Feldman from the Mayor's campaign manager, Bill Lynch, the union's 3,000-member delegate assembly decided not to endorse anyone this year, directly repudiating Mr. Dinkins.
Union officials say the decision reflected a divided union membership and widespread frustration over what they see as punitive spending cuts of more than $700 million from the school system's budget.
Teachers are an important swing voter group in the mayoral election. The union's members are about a third minority, a third Jewish and a third white Roman Catholic, according to a union survey a few years back, and they have traditionally been considered been more liberal than other voters.
"There were people working for the Mayor who cut the school system more than they did other areas," said Ms. Feldman. "The Mayor trusted their judgments, but from our perspective they were out to hurt the schools. I wonder if they had the Mayor's interests at heart."
Or, as Mary Esterlyn White, a math teacher at Martin Luther King Jr. High School on the Upper West Side, put it: "He owed us. The last time he ran we made a difference in a way. He made us sweat. Make him sweat. I think Giuliani is a worse choice, but I think Dinkins shouldn't get off easy."
Behind the shift is Mr. Dinkins's transformation from a fresh challenger to a veteran incumbent, with the extra political baggage of a prolonged recession in the city, which has made it difficult for the union to act.
And mayoral aides and officials in the union movement say that the union's decison not to endorse the Mayor reflects a feeling of misunderstanding and betrayal over a two-year dispute over a new teachers contract.
 
'Perception' Criticized
 Leland T. Jones, a spokesman for the Mayor, said that schools had been cut less than parks and sanitation and other agencies -- when measured against spending plans. He said actual spending increased by $700 million in the last four years.
"There is perception out there, in large part fed by any number of political opponents of the Mayor who have been ignorant of what the real facts are," he said. "The Mayor supports the schools, but he also supports other services, including public safety."
To be sure, Mayor Dinkins will likely have the support of the largest municipal and private unions -- almost all unions outside the Police and Fire Departments -- with hundreds of thousands of members and well-organized phone banks to get out the vote.
But even as they roll out the campaign machinery, some of his supporters in the labor movement say their enthusiasm has waned over four years. This time, they say, the unions can deliver their members to the polls, but cannot necessarily tell them whom to vote for.
"He has made mistakes," a prominent union leader supporting the Mayor said. "Obviously there are things that I would have liked him to do differently, that he would have liked to have done differently. But Ed Koch took a long time to learn the business, and I look forward to a stronger Dinkins in the second term."
Ted H. Jacobsen, the secretary of the New York City Central Labor Council, said, "We are hot and heavy in this campaign and so are most of our affiliates." He said that the economic distress cited by Mr. Giuliani in his attacks on the Mayor is "nationwide and international. It is not just unique to David Dinkins."
Four years ago, the United Federation of Teachers, with 120,000 teachers, teachers' aides and other school workers, endorsed Mr. Dinkins in the midst of a hotly contested Democratic primary, helping him to be recognized as a serious contender.
At the time, Ms. Feldman said, many teachers were fed up with the Koch administration, which they "perceived as being hostile to teachers."
The honeymoon with the Dinkins administration ended after it reached a one-year contract with the teachers in September, 1990, in a deal that was roundly attacked by the editorial boards and the city's outside fiscal monitors. It also contributed to a sell-off of the city's bonds.
Teachers were soon threatened with up to 8,000 layoffs and forced to postpone $40 million worth of wage increases into the 1990's. Ms. Feldman said that the Mayor's staff and his budget director punished the school system for the settlement through damaging cuts that hurt teachers and students in the classroom.
Then the union went for two years without a contract, and reached a settlement that did not give teachers much more than other unions had received.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Investor's Dreams Rise From Decay

BYLINE: By Charles Strum

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
MILES P. BERGER has just bought one of the biggest empty buildings in Newark. Soon he will take possession of the one next door. Then Mr. Berger will have two large empty buildings, only a fraction of the city's ample inventory.
But skeptics who think he has stumbled into the urban equivalent of investing in swampland should think again. Mr. Berger and his partners may be conspicuous in their daring, but they are not greenhorns. They know Newark wants to promote, at almost any cost, the physical transformation of a distressed city that produces too little tax revenue. 
 They also know what's taking shape just across Broad Street: the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, the state's $200 million response to Lincoln Center.
"Location, location, location," said Mr. Berger, reciting the real-estate developer's mantra and emphasizing three points.
One: All highways, railroads and flight paths in New Jersey lead to Newark, the state's largest city.
Two: The larger of his two empty buildings, the former Hahne's department store on Broad Street, had the best location in Newark when it was built in 1901, and it will again.
Three: The arts center, with a 2,700-seat concert hall and a 500-seat theater, is scheduled to open in 1995, and so is No. 609 Broad Street, the former Hahne's.
"It's no accident that Hahne's decided to build there," Mr. Berger said. "This is truly the center of Newark."
The Berger Organization -- Miles, his brother, Bruce, and his cousin Sol -- paid $2.5 million for the Hahne's building, a four-story pile of brick and limestone with an architectural style that can only be called fin de siecle mercantile. Each floor, a forest of support columns, is nearly two football fields in size. A skylight obscured by tar paper and the four-floor atrium it illuminated will be uncovered to brighten customized office space. Retail shops are planned for the first floor. The basement will accommodate 150 cars. Cost of the renovations: $25 million.
Next door, the 15-story Griffith Piano Company building, acquired at a tax auction, will provide more office space, and its recital hall will be reborn as a nightclub or theater. "A place to go after the concert," Mr. Berger said. "This is a project that will invite people outside and over here."
But "over here," a short stroll across Military Park, is the city center that did not hold, as the middle-class exodus and poor economy vacuumed commerce from its once-thriving core. Macy's finally abandoned its 16-story building on Market Street last year, joining a long and dispirited caravan of merchants who led the way out of town in the 1960's and 70's. Hahne & Company, founded here in 1858, closed its doors in 1986.
Mr. Berger is betting this will change, the way that Lincoln Center and other urban renewal projects on the Upper West Side of Manhattan helped reclaim neighborhoods and promote commerce, a process that began in the 1960's just as Newark's retreat became a rout.
That's a long time to wait, even for a methodical investor like Mr. Berger, whose company successfully restored the landmark Robert Treat Hotel and the handsome 1920's Firemen's Insurance Company building, just a brief stroll from his Broad Street buildings.
In the short run, Mr. Berger said he would do what seemed to work best in a city where private investment still relies on public money: he will seek tenants from county, state and Federal agencies, which have helped stabilize the rental market here. He will also take advantage of a tax-abatement program that has so far proved a double-edged sword for Newark and the restoration program it calls its renaissance.
Abatements have helped cultivate a swath of glass-walled office towers on the eastern edge of the original business corridor. The result is a trade-off: a patina of urban prosperity, but a citizenry still yearning for education, jobs and amenities that wealthier places take for granted.
Among these are retail stores, an endangered species here, despite the thousands of potential shoppers who fill the new office towers.
"Many of the buildings have retail shops built up inside them, connected to over-the-sidewalk bridges," Mr. Berger said. "Those bridges are to keep people off the sidewalks. When they're keeping you in, you're not going to be on the street."
The intent of the arts center -- and by extension, his own projects -- is "getting people walking on the sidewalk,"
"People with dollars in their pockets, ready to spend," he said.
But ruminating on the future, the man with two big empty buildings must pause occasionally for a reality check.
"I start to feel crazy when I see that there's no competition out there," Mr. Berger said. "Sometimes I think no others are seeing what I see happening."

He and his partners have recently bought two large, empty buildings in Newark with the anticipation of the construction of a cultural center in the neighborhood. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Enclave Outgrows Its Racial Tensions

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Nina Gennaro Suarez remembers when the glow of Ebbets Field's lights danced on her bedroom wall and the roar of Brooklyn Dodger crowds rolled over her neighborhood. She wistfully recalls the Saturday morning "kiddie shows" at the old Patio Theater on Flatbush Avenue.
And she will never forget the brick that came through a window of her house on Rutland Road after her father refused to join with neighbors demanding that he help buy out the first black family on the block. That was in 1949. 
 Much has changed since then in Lefferts Manor, an eight-block tree-lined enclave south of Crown Heights and east of Prospect Park that is celebrating its centennial on Sunday. Threaded like a cable through its history is a covenant that has held the economic structure of Lefferts Manor in place. Written into the original deeds, the covenant forbids the construction of "any building other than a private dwelling for one family."
To be sure, Lefferts Manor is not the place it was when the heirs of Pieterse Lefferts -- who was granted the land by Peter Stuyvesant in 1661 -- carved up a piece of their vast farmland to build stately Victorian homes for Brooklyn's well-to-do.
Today the neighborhood of 600 homes is a middle-class stronghold. Three-fourths of the families are black, and the racial tensions that resulted in the construction of "hate fences" and in white flight in the 1950's and 60's in Lefferts Manor have long since been overtaken by a spirit of community.
Paul Skrobela, a real-estate agent for the William B. May Company, has sold 30 of the approximately 50 houses that have been bought in the community in the last decade. He estimated that 11 of those homes were bought by black families, 11 by whites and 8 by interracial couples.
When residents gather on Sunday for a street fair and house tours, they will have much to look back upon, though, like intense growing pains, not all of it easy to bear.
"Few neighborhoods have covenants like ours," said Stephen McGill, 41, president of the Lefferts Manor Association. "It helped us maintain a middle-class community" since the turn of the century, when the going price for a home was $5,000. The current average market value is $250,000, Mr. Skrobela said.
 
A Landmark District
 In 1960, the covenant was given legal teeth when the city zoned this niche of Brooklyn for single-family homes. Lefferts Manor's standing was further enhanced in 1979 when the mixture of neo-Georgian, late Romanesque, Federal and Tudor homes was declared a landmark district.
Mr. McGill, who is black, said that "for the most part, the black people in the neighborhood would agree that the covenant has been a positive factor." But, he added, "There are older people on my block who remember how isolated they felt back then."
Back then was the 1950's, when George and Almeida Holmes, seen by some as intruders in an all-white preserve, challenged the covenant. After they advertised for boarders, the Holmeses were taken to court by the neighborhood association.
John Petito, a lawyer and historian who wrote his master's thesis on the litigation surrounding the covenant, placed particular blame on real-estate agents. "You had your blockbusters telling them, 'You can divide your house up,' " he said. "They said a covenant is no longer effective if the neighborhood changes."
From the surrounding area, clergy and citizens nursing the seeds of conscience that would become the civil-rights movement formed the Holmes Defense Committee. One of their pamphlets declared of the case: "It is a bare-faced attempt to drive them out of the neighborhood. The same weapon may be used against any others whom these bigots may choose to drive away."
The validity of the covenant was upheld in State Supreme Court in 1950. But the racial animosity shown toward black families during the 1950's endured. Many longstanding families chose to isolate themselves.
 
Hate Fences
 "We used to call them hate fences -- those high, corrugated plastic things," said Donald Wynne, 57, whose family arrived in 1958. "Rather than give you any verbal abuse, the fence would say, 'You're here, but I don't have to look at you.' "
Other white families moved away, but some embraced the change.
"There was a strong handful that stayed, that said, 'These are family people moving in and they want for their families what we want for ours,' " said Mrs. Suarez, who has lived here all her 55 years. "My father was Sicilian. He bought this house in 1919. And even though he was a surgeon, as far as a lot of people around here were concerned back then, he was still from Pigtown -- that's what they called the Italian section beyond Nostrand Avenue. So he wasn't about to turn up his nose at anyone else."
When the petition to buy out the Holmeses came around, she recalled: "My parents refused to sign, and my neighbors refused to sign, a whole string of houses. Then, over a period of five, six months, there were bricks coming through your windows, people on the roof at night. Then it stopped."
 
Learning to Get Along
 Even though the antipathy toward newcomers did not vanish -- the Holmeses moved out in 1955 -- a sense of calm returned to the streets.
"People learned to get along," Mr. Wynne said. "Bear in mind, back in the 60's, we had a whole revolution; a more enlightened person moved in."
Lefferts Manor, which shares the 71st Precinct with Crown Heights and is buffeted on its borders by the urban ills of poverty and crime, remains a pocket of peace.
"It's a vibrant, mixed neighborhood," said Inspector Anthony Marra, commander of the 71st Precinct. Crime statistics, he said, are not kept separately for Lefferts Manor, "but the incidence of serious violent crime is relatively lower in this area where the people have a vested interest, pride in their community."
As part of the celebration, the association has set up an exhibit at the old Lefferts Homestead, a white clapboard farmhouse in nearby Prospect Park. It includes photographs and statements of residents taken by Andrew Strawcutter, who lives on Midwood Street.
The quotation under the photo of Betty Frumkin, who lives on Maple Street, says: "I love raising my kids in the neighborhood. They are tolerant of all kinds of people."
The hate fences are lore and have long since been dismantled. Renovations are now more inviting.
"We have a flower-barrel planting project with over 350 flower barrels on the streets," said Mary Miller, who publishes The Manor Echo periodically to promote community unity.
Mrs. Suarez -- who confesses to sneaking into the old Patio Theater with the Skelton girls, who were black, and the Strauss kids, who were Jewish -- said: "Our little enclave is great. If you don't like your neighbor, it's because he's a lousy neighbor."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The scene along Midwood Street in Lefferts Manor in Brooklyn, an eight-block enclave south of Crown Heights and east of Prospect Park. The neigborhood, a middle-class stronghold, is celebrating its centennial. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 500 words

HEADLINE: Giant Deal Continues to Drive Up Stocks

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Stocks moved strongly upward for the second consecutive day yesterday, with much of the impetus again from the huge proposed acquisition of Tele-Communications by Bell Atlantic.
"The strength of the market was primarily in the Baby Bells," said Edward Nicoski, managing director of Piper Jaffray in Minneapolis. "That's because of prospects that we are going to see more combinations of cable companies and telephone companies." 
 For example, Southwestern Bell was up 3, to 43; Ameritech 3 3/8, to 87 1/8, and U S West 2 1/8, to 49 5/8.
Even smaller media-related companies participated in the euphoria. Electronic Arts rose 2 1/4, to 41 1/2, and Acclaim Entertainment increased 7/8, to 29 1/2.
As for the two companies in the merger, Bell Atlantic, the sixth-most-active stock on the New York Stock Exchange, climbed 1 3/4, to 67 5/8, while Tele-Communications advanced 1 1/2, to 32 7/8.
Traders were also influenced by evidence that inflation remained under control. A Government report that September wholesale prices edged up only two-tenths of a percent prodded a rally in the bond market, where the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.85 percent, a 25-year low.
The lower interest rates led all the big stock market averages higher. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 18.44 points, to 3,621.63, and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, the Nasdaq composite and the Amex index all closed at highs.
Volume soared still higher on the Big Board, reaching 352.5 million shares, compared with 291 million shares on Wednesday. Advancers topped decliners, 1,162 to 913.
 
Strong Consumer Issues
 Another sector that demonstrated strength yesterday, as it has for the last couple of weeks, was consumer nondurables. Thomas McManus, a strategist for Morgan Stanley, said that his firm's consumer stock index had increased 4.4 percent since Sept. 30.
"Consumer-oriented growth stocks are strong," he added. "This market is being driven by the 1993 laggards."
Among those he cited were Coca-Cola, up 2, to 44 1/8; Procter & Gamble, up 2 1/4, to 52 1/4, and General Mills, up 4 1/8, to 64 7/8.
Automobile issues were another market standout, after a report on Wednesday that sales of cars and light trucks climbed in early October to the highest point since the summer. Chrysler, which reported unexpectedly robust third-quarter earnings yesterday, jumped 3 1/4, to 51 3/4, while Ford Motor gained 2 1/4, to 57 1/2, and General Motors rose 1 1/8, to 44 3/4.
One of the weakest parts of the equity market, however, was the financial sector, with banks hit hard over earnings concerns. Citicorp fell 1 1/4, to 38 3/8, on heavy volume of three million shares. Wells Fargo fell 5 3/4, to 125 7/8; Chemical Banking declined 1, to 45 1/8; J. P. Morgan dropped 3/4, to 77 3/4, and Banc One lost 7/8, to 42 5/8.
And a couple of stocks that had disappointing earnings also notched declines. Cooper Tire dropped 4 1/8, to 20 3/4, and Walbro fell 2 7/8, to 26 3/8.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
30-Year Bond's Yield Hits New Low

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The yield on the 30-year bond dropped to a new 25-year low yesterday.
But that new low -- 5.85 percent -- was just below the old one of 5.86 percent. As such, yields will need to drop even lower to confirm that the rally at the long end of the bond market has resumed. 
 Confirmation could come today when the Labor Department releases the Consumer Price Index for September.
The consensus forecast for the Consumer Price Index, according to Bloomberg Business News, is a moderate increase of two-tenths of 1 percent. If that is the increase, the index will have risen at an annual rate of 2.8 percent in the first nine months of the year, just below the 2.9 percent pace for 1992.
 
 
New Lows Seen
 Nancy Kimelman, chief economist for Technical Data in Boston, said if the Consumer Price Index number came in as expected, the market should "blow through" to new lows.
She said this did not happen after the release of the Producer Price Index yesterday, which rose two-tenths of 1 percent in September, because the September Consumer Price Index number was still unknown and because the August Consumer Price Index surprised the market with a three-tenths of 1 percent increase after it was reported that the Producer Price Index fell six-tenths of 1 percent.
Reflecting this caution, the market made just one big trading move yesterday, with prices rallying quickly and yields, which move in the opposite direction, falling immediately after the release of the Producer Price Index. At the same time, the Commerce Department said that retail sales gained one-tenth of 1 percent in September.
While the jump in the Producer Price Index was the first in five months, it was in line with market expectations. And combined with the retail sales data and the September employment report of last Friday, it seemed to indicate that the environment of low inflation and sluggish economic growth, which the bond market has thrived on, would remain unchanged for some time.
In late trading at 5 P.M., the price of the 30-year bond was up 30/32 point, with the yield down from 5.91 percent Wednesday. The yield hit 5.86 percent on Sept. 8; since then it has jumped as high as 6.12 percent.
 
 
10-Year Note
 The yield on the 10-year note, which is an alternative measure of long-term interest rates, also inched down to a new 25-year low. The price of the 10-year note was up 14/32 with the yield falling to 5.21 percent, from 5.26 percent the day before and from the previous 5.22 percent low.
But yields of issues with shorter maturities were still above their recent lows. They have been locked in a tight trading range because market analysts expect that the Federal Reserve will not change its short-term interest rate target, which has been 3 percent for more than a year. Without the expectation that the Fed will cut its interest rate target, it is unlikely that short-term rates will hit new lows.
In trading yesterday, the yield on the two-year note fell to 3.79 percent from 3.81 percent. Its 1993 low was 3.69 percent on Sept. 3.
Dennis Bushe, a managing director and strategist at Prudential Investment Advisors, said that if the moderate level of prices increases reflected in the Producer Price Index were confirmed in the Consumer Price Index, the yield on the 30-year bond should be pushed into a new trading range, with a low of 5.5 percent and a high of 6 percent.
He said long-term yields should also be pulled lower by the lack of supply of new 30-year Treasury bonds. Because the Treasury has decided to cut the annual issuance of 30-year bonds by about 40 percent, no new bonds will be sold until February.
"These are the issues that make the fall look strong in the bond market," he said.
Ms. Kimelman of Technical Data said that the inflation report "does not suggest that there is any reason to worry about price pressures down the road."
 
 
'Too Soon to Get Excited'
 On the pace of economic growth, she said that the retails sales data, while weak, reflected a little more spending by consumers. There were upward revisions in July and August, while September came in at a weaker-than-expected one-tenth of 1 percent increase. "We are seeing consumers open up their pocketbooks a bit, but it is too soon to get excited about any consumer-led burst in the fourth quarter of this year or even the first quarter of next year," she said.
Some corporate treasurers have seemed to be betting this week that long-term interest rates are near their lows by selling several issues of 50-year and 100-year bonds.
This is the second time this year that there has been a flurry of 50-year and 100-year debt sold in one week. The last one came in mid-July. If the selling of such debt is a signal that companies are betting that interest rates have hit bottom, then the last sales were not well timed. In the interval since Walt Disney and Coca-Cola sold 100-year bonds, the yield on the 30-year bond has dropped from 6.66 percent to yesterday's 5.85 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Purchases by Bank of Japan Said to Help the Dollar Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most major currencies yesterday in technically driven trading after the Japanese central bank reportedly bought dollars to support the United States currency.
In late New York trading, the dollar jumped to 107.32 Japanese yen, from 105.92 yen Wednesday. It also rose to 1.6125 German marks from 1.6015 marks. 
 The dollar started to rise against the yen during Tokyo trading. Traders said the Bank of Japan bought dollars after the currency came under pressure because of published comments by Treasury Under Secretary Lawrence H. Summers that were interpreted as favoring a higher yen.
The rise of the dollar continued in London trading, as it breached several technical levels against the yen, touching off further dollar buying.
Traders were mixed on whether data released yesterday on United States retail sales and inflation in September helped the dollar's rise. Retail sales edged up one-tenth of 1 percent, while the Producer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 percent.
Ken Gettinger, head of foreign exchange at the Union Bank of Switzerland's New York office, said the data were better than expected.
"The anticipation had been on the down side, and people were short," he said, referring to investors who had sold dollars they did not own, expecting the currency to fall before they had to pay for it. When the dollar rose, they had to buy it to cut their losses.
 
Rises Against Other Currencies
 The dollar gained against other currencies on the back of its climb against the yen, traders said.
European currencies continued to slide against the German mark. Frank Pusateri, a vice president at the Bank of Boston, said investors were expecting several European countries to lower interest rates. While that would stimulate their economies, it would mean less return on investments in those currencies. That, in turn, would lower the value of the currencies.
"The market is voting with its cash flow," he said, adding that investors thought the rate cuts were overdue in recession-bound countries.
The British pound also lost ground, falling in New York to $1.5157, from $1.5225 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Silver Tumbles on Reports Of Slow Economic Growth

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver prices fell sharply yesterday as low inflation and slow economic growth killed the appetite of investors for precious metals.
Gold prices also retreated. 
 On the Commodity Exchange in New York, silver for December delivery fell 8.5 cents, to $4.348 an ounce; December gold sank $1, to $366.60 an ounce.
Silver had risen by 38 cents, or about 9 percent, since Oct. 1 on speculative buying. But yesterday's economic data gave investors little incentive to hold precious metals.
Producer prices edged up just two-tenths of 1 percent in September, while retail sales and new unemployment claims rose. The numbers suggested that the United States economy was continuing to grow slowly, with almost no inflation.
Investment demand for precious metals typically rises with inflation. Silver is sensitive to economic growth because it is used mainly as an industrial metal.
 
Further Drop Seen
 "Ninety percent of silver is consumed in the industrial nations of North America, Europe and Japan, and if you look around, none of those is doing especially well," said George Milling-Stanley of Lehman Brothers Inc. in New York. "None is showing the kind of robust economic growth you need to support silver."
He predicted silver would drop, possibly to $4 an ounce, a price at which the metal last traded on Sept. 14.
But Ted Ryan, the director of futures research for the Chicago Corporation, a trading company, said he expected silver and gold to rally late in the fourth quarter and into 1994 as demand picked up overseas.
On other commodity markets, live cattle futures rose sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on higher cash prices and perceptions that the market had established a seasonal bottom and would move higher.
Live cattle for October delivery rose almost a cent, to 72.07 cents a pound; October feeder cattle rose a quarter of a cent, to 84.50 cents a pound; October live hogs fell more than a half-cent, to 48.97 cents a pound; February frozen pork bellies fell more than a tenth of a cent, to 57.72 cents a pound.
Light sweet crude oil for November delivery fell 14 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange, to $18.50 a barrel; November heating oil fell more than a tenth of a cent, to 55.52 cents a gallon; November unleaded gasoline rose a third of a cent, to 52.92 cents a gallon; November natural gas fell 3.8 cents, to $2.167 for 1,000 cubic feet.
