HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Same Winter Racing, but Three More Days at Saratoga

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
New York's race tracks defused their dispute with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday when they agreed to continue racing all winter at Aqueduct despite severe losses last winter. But they pleaded for the Governor to soften the financial crunch by deferring the payment of some taxes and by allowing New York to expand simulcast betting on races televised from Florida.
The tracks also voted to add three days to the booming summer season at Saratoga. The five-week season will not be expanded to six full weeks. But three days will be added as a "preview weekend" starting on Friday, July 22, for a total of 33 days at the homey 126-year-old track in the foothills of the Adirondacks. 
 The actions were approved by the trustees of the New York Racing Association at their monthly meeting at Belmont Park almost on the eve of Belmont's busiest and grandest day of autumn racing. It will be staged tomorrow as the Breeders' Cup Preview with seven stakes races with $2.4 million in purses.
The trustees didn't settle the ultimate issue of winter racing, but they did remove it for now as a point of conflict with the Governor, who has been insisting on winter racing for the taxes and jobs it provides. Officials of the New York Racing Association have said they lost $9 million racing in bad weather last winter, and they repeated their arguments yesterday.
 
Relief Is Sought
 "N.Y.R.A.'s desire to continue winter racing," said Gerard J. McKeon, president of the association, "is tempered by an equally strong commitment to avoid the unfortunate and detrimental situation that occurred last winter when N.Y.R.A. had to choose between continuing operations or deferring the payment of taxes. Winter racing runs at a significant loss."
But, he said, "from trainers to hot-walkers, white caps to maintenance employees, thousands of people rely on year-round racing in New York." And he asked the state to supply financial relief, presumably by deferring the regular collections of parimutuel taxes and by inducing the Legislature to expand simulcast betting beyond the 50 races a year now authorized.
Allen Gutterman, vice president for marketing, said the ideal combination might be seven live races a day at Aqueduct plus five televised from Gulfstream Park near Miami, which will run from Jan. 4 to March 16. The Meadowlands track began carrying full racing programs from Gulfstream and other tracks last winter, and business soared.
"We're going to race all winter long," Gutterman said. "The state wants us to race. The trainers want us to race. The horsemen want us to race. Our employees want us to race. This is our mandate. But every year, more trainers are racing in Florida, and more jockeys. Last year, Julie Krone spent the winter there. This year, Mike Smith."
 
Two New Wrinkles
 Under the calendar reported yesterday, Belmont will close next Monday, then Aqueduct will open next Wednesday and run through May 2. Racing will switch to Belmont on May 4 and continue through Wednesday, July 20. Then comes the new wrinkle in Saratoga dates.
Racing, which normally opens at Saratoga on a Wednesday late in July, will open instead on Friday, July 22, for the three-day preview weekend and will continue through Monday, Aug. 29. After a three-day pause, which is also new, it will switch back to Belmont on Friday, Sept. 2.
 
FINISH LINES
 The issues of geography, pace, distance and money were decided in different ways for two star horses, Diazo and Valley Crossing, for the weekend's big races. They were entered in both the $500,000 Meadowlands Cup tonight and the $850,000 Jockey Club Gold Cup tomorrow. But BILL SHOEMAKER, who trains Diazo, said from California that his horse would run at Belmont. And RICHARD SMALL, who trains Valley Crossing, said that he would run in the Meadowlands. ALLEN JERKENS, who trains Devil His Due, the favorite in the Gold Cup, said that the race would be "like a war," especially with the title of Horse of the Year still wide open. Dehere, the favorite for the Breeders' Cup Juvenile and even for next year's Kentucky Derby, remained the shortest-priced favorite in the Belmont jamboree at 2-5 in the $500,000 Champagne Stakes. His trainer, REYNALDO NOBLES, said the colt had learned a lesson after losing the Futurity by half a length last month in the mud. "He's more aggressive, mentally and physically," Nobles said. "He's a dream horse." Dehere's main threat may be NICK ZITO 's Crary, who has raced twice and won twice. How does Zito feel? "Very optimistic," he said. "I think he's a special horse."
